Title:
Another post from me sorry! 

Currently in Disney area. We were struggling to find a decent meal, but we went to Yakiniku Toraji in the Ikspiari complex which is at the Maihama station where Disney line starts.  3rd floor of the complex. 

Kids loved cooking their own meal. They had a good understanding of GF, and a full allergen menu. They had GF soy sauce on the table. 

Allow yourself time to get your head around it, but once ordered it was fast, great service, fun experience for us all! 

We ordered mushrooms, plenty of steak, spring onions, roasted garlic, rice and a salad which I ate without the dressing. 

https://maps.app.goo.gl/EGjT71aqnjWLgRhm6?g_st=com.google.maps.preview.copy

Between diners they put a sparkling clean grill plate in so no CC.

Title: Can anyone recommend hotels in Tokyo, Hakone, Takayama, Izu Peninsula, Kyoto and Osaka that have been suitable for gluten free please?we are a family of four and I‚Äôm the one whose gluten free we are looking for family friendly mid range accommodations

ResponsesV2.Message:
I don't tend to eat at hotels so unfortunately only have a couple to share.

First is my personal experience in Hakone - we stayed at Hakone Yutowa (https://maps.app.goo.gl/ZcSYiNQouMb1q9wV8) last March and liked it so much that we're going back next month for our second trip.  When we booked, my husband included a message saying that I have Celiac and need to eat gluten-free.  We'd seen a few comments about it online and thought it would be fine.  They responded back saying they won't make special food for me, but the breakfast and dinner buffets have allergens marked.  When we arrived, on our first night, they checked with us when we got to dinner and confirmed my gluten-free needs, then later a server came to our table to ask what "main dish" we wanted for our dinners and let me know that one of them could be made with no sauce and would be gluten-free.  They also brought me a special plate of roast beef, that I assume was different from the roast beef at the buffet somehow but they didn't explain it, haha.  At breakfast, they again confirmed my GF-ness as we checked in and I received a bowl of soup with tofu and veggies that my husband didn't get when he joined me a bit later, so I think that may have been special for me as well.  Overall, I had a lovely time at the hotel and am excited to go back.  The buffets were both really nice, with a good amount of options, and honestly the gelato at dinner was exquisite.

For Tokyo, I've heard that Gluten-Free T's (a very popular 100% gluten-free restaurant) opened a second location that is also 100% GF and does different food from the original location that is located in the APA Hotel Ueno Hirokoji (https://maps.app.goo.gl/TsYTzn8ATybqQut46).  So if you want very convenient access to that restaurant, that hotel is an option though I haven't stayed there myself yet.

We stayed at Citadines in Namba area Osaka. They have a simple kitchen and eating area so you can prepare some food yourself. My daughter had breakfast at the  restaurant buffet and was just selective what she chose, we took bread and her toaster bag too.  I asked if they would do her a fried egg and they said yes as long as they weren‚Äôt too busy. (As scrambled there aren‚Äôt gf) 
It‚Äôs close to electric street too.

Title: Ok so I need honest opinions. I know Japan is obviously difficult, but on a scale of 1-10 just how difficult is it? My 10 year old coeliac is desperate to go to Japan but after reading how hard it can be we settled on Italy. But now for many reasons I am doubting my decision and thinking about cancelling the flight and heading to Japan instead. My son eats pretty much anything (oysters and Brussel sprouts are regulars in our house!) so that isn‚Äôt an issue, but we want to be able to eat authentic Japanese food. He has told me he will happily eat boiled rice and sashimi for 2 weeks but obviously that isn‚Äôt feasible! I looked Into Gluten free tours Japan but sadly they weren‚Äôt available when we are looking at travelling. We would probably stick to Tokyo and Osaka. Any tips, recommendations and opinions are much appreciated!

ResponsesV2.Message: I‚Äôm celiac and here now. It‚Äôs been fine. I have a set list of things I can eat from 7-11, includes few different kid friendly sushi. I have a diet allergen card I have showed at restaurants and they are all super helpful. I‚Äôve also taken my own cereal/snacks from home. So takes some pre planning but it‚Äôs doable.

It‚Äôs harder for a kid as they can be fussier and many gf menus don‚Äôt cater for children‚Äôs tastes. However, with proper planning and also taking some things with you it‚Äôs totally doable. We also like to stay in apartments so we can cook. You mentioned your child is good with various foods which helps.

Title:
Summary from our 8 day trip to Tokyo with my 9 year old coeliac son 

We extensively used 711 for breakfasts and lunches were possible as it was cost effective and had some go to GF options for him. The kids loved the 711 smoothie cups you put in the machine and must have had a dozen or more each on the trip. 

Some places we really struggled to find proper lunches for him and he had to resort to just the snacks we packed for the day. Even had to resort to McDonalds French fries a couple of times. 

We initially started off trying to use local lunch options but just became too hard as almost all would read the travel card and then politely state they couldn't help. 

Where we had success was 
- GF T's Kitchen: had lunch twice at Ueno and dinner once at Roppongi
- Gonpachi in Asakusa for a wonderful dinner overlooking the river and Sky Tree
- Rice Hack: for a late lunch pizza that he loved
- Kuroboshi Sweets: churros shop in Asakusa
- Yakiniku Toraji: Korean BBQ at Disneyland Gateway Mall
- Over Macrons: a tiny street vendor in Shibuya that just does amazing GF Macrons that I stumbled across 
- Black Eggs at the Hakone ropeway 

We also found that going to large food courts (Sky Tree mall, opposite Tokyo Station etc) provided some dinner options like Mexican which could be made GF

Disneyland and Disney Sea was saved by the spreadsheet table some on this group had made as it greatly helped knowing where to go. To be fair the food options are average and limited for a Coeliac and so he survived on fries, popcorn and ice cream and made sure he had big breakfasts beforehand. The hotels also weren't that good (seemed mostly very expensive buffets) and so ate at the Gateway Mall or 711. 

What surprised me by Disney is once you can get hold of a supervisor at each of the eating places they have a great app on an iPad where you select your allergies and it then shows what is left that you can have. Just not sure why they don't make this same app available to the public. And I would avoid the turkey legs, not because they are not safe. Just because they are tough and very bland. 

Hope this helps overs with younger children when travelling to Tokyo.

ResponsesV2.Message: What did he mostly have at Disney? The curry/vegetables? We'll be at Disney for 3 days!

Title: Travelling through Kyoto, I went to Oku-No-Niwa, where I encountered a disappointing experience. Despite their advertisement of gluten-free options, the staff was uninformed and mistakenly believed their vegan options were gluten-free. When I informed them of my celiac disease, they were unable to accommodate celiac requirements. This serves as a warning to others to avoid wasting their time. Reservations are available which provide a ‚Äúgluten free‚Äù option, but I did not make one as we were just walking past.

ResponsesV2.Message: So disappointing!  When I went March '23 I had a great experience.  We had a party of three and I'm the only one gluten-free.  As the other two looked at the menu I called a waitress over and said "Gluten-free?" and she immediately knew what I was talking about.  Turned out they only have one set menu for gluten-free, so she turned to the others and asked what they wanted to order so I accidentally rushed them a bit haha.  But the food came out fine and I had no issues.  I think that was my first time actually getting to try tempura and I was thrilled.  I didn't try showing them a Celiac card or going further in depth with them.
This is a major problem in Japan where they think gluten free is the same as vegan and don‚Äôt get it.

Title:

ResponsesV2.Message: It says it‚Äôs prepared in accordance with celiac guidelines. Why wouldn‚Äôt you eat it? Most airlines don‚Äôt even say that so I would have full confidence in this meal.

I‚Äôve eaten gluten free meals on Asiana. All was fine. 

Most airline meals only say gluten intolerant, and I think that is due to risk of cross contamination, but they‚Äôre made in an industrial kitchen, so my view is the risk is low. 

I fly international in and between Asia a lot and have had only one issue. There‚Äôs a beef in brown sauce meal that I‚Äôve had twice.  Mild stomach issue, but it could be a different ingredient I‚Äôm reacting to. 

Just watch out for any bread that is not packaged and labeled. I‚Äôve had times where they inadvertently served me the wrong bread.

Title:
We just came back from our trip to Japan. Sticking to a gluten free diet in Japan was a challenge for me, but here are some tips I would like to share hoping Iit helps you on planning your trip.
Breakfast: Unless you have it booked with your hotel, it was a bit hard to find GF food early in the morning; we wanted a more authentic experience so we decided not to have breakfast at the hotels which was quite of a challenge since must restaurants either open after 11:00 am or don‚Äôt sell gluten free food, what we ended up doing was going to 7/11 or any convenience store and have yogurt, cheese sticks and sometimes onigri. Having raw fish for breakfast wears thin after a few days 
For lunches and dinner, we showed the waiters an allergy card, most of the time it worked, they would either suggest having our meals with salt or have some white vinegar but some others were not accommodating so don‚Äôt feel afraid of walking out of a restaurant if they can‚Äôt accommodate you (although very polite, we were kicked out of a restaurant cause they couldn‚Äôt provide me with GF food) 
Google translate was a good tool but sometimes due to the way the packages were done, I couldn‚Äôt get google to work. Lawson natural was a great find (almost at the end of our trip) and found the amazing but expensive bread that I have in the picture.
I think if I would do this trip again, I probably try to find the natural store early and or bring snacks from home.

ResponsesV2.Message: Can I ask where you get an allergy card?

I find using ¬´ find me gluten free ¬ª app very convenient to find gf restaurants and having to ask if they can do something. I planned it in advance depending on each areas we were willing to visit. Hope it will help for another time

Title:
WAITING IN VAIN at #tokyostation and craving for #dessert ‚ùìMany have repeatedly mentioned #soranoiro but it's not really a place where you can stay a little longer if you have a bus or bullet train (#skinkansen) to wait for. 

Easiest option is to find a #Starbucks because I've been noticing that they have been keeping at least one wheat-free (possible cross-contamination due to same cake display) option each season. Many talked about the chocolate and matcha rice flour roll cake and cupcake, which they changed to peach, which they now changed to banana. I've enjoyed all of them üòã 

But if you have Google Maps, within 3-8 MINUTES, mostly via Marunouchi Exit, so many GF options abound. They're not GF advertised, but I usually have meetings at Tokyo Station, so I've learned to seek and find. 

‚óè I loooove the cream-filled rusks made of almond flour at #PecheMignon Artisan de Saveur and chef says it is wheat-free (with a GF card, they can easily identify other allergens). 

‚óè The meringue macaron from #PierreHerme satisfies post-meal cravings. 

‚óè The geisha caramel pudding and the top tier coffee from #gesharycoffee comes with a good view at the top floor. 

‚óè #Rosebakery at the Comme de Garcons boutique (has salad and desserts!) comes with Tokyo-only fashion options. 

I'm mobile now so can't locate and pin individually but basically all are within 3-8 minutes walk from Tokyo Station. Pin below if you can. ü•∞ 

Happy (Not) Waiting in Vain! ü§≠ 

If you care for more pics, details and summary, find them in stories and location-grouped (per train station coming up) highlights here 
https://www.instagram.com/glutenfreejapandelivery?igsh=MTI3M2o3Z29za3M2dw==

ResponsesV2.Message:
Lee Marshall Many people have written about this in the past. üòä Unfortunately, coeliac and gluten intolerance are mostly unknown to Japan. My two doctors, 7 years ago (high-demand onesüòè), can't endorse me to any coeliac or gluten intolerance test because there's none. According to them, it's not an inherent Japanese disease. This is not of "national concern," so there's no regulating body and people are undereducated about it. Some Japanese have wheat allergy though, hence health dept education available and a market for wheat free. üòä Hence, many Japan residents have come up with gluten-free cards itemizing each coeliac allergen (and potential hidden gluten) because "gluten-free," even those who market as such, may not even be GF-certified. üòä That's why the group exists, I think. It's undeniably a challenge, so everyone exchanges info, and reads allergens on packages for others, because Japanese GF-certified is technically non-existent in Japan. üòè Being part of this community is possibly the best way to get around, working around available options. We all have different sensitivities and tolerance (and desperation üòÇ) levels, I believe üòä 

If anything, Rose Bakery markets some products as gluten-free. üòè
If you need GF cards and info about basic info/reality of "GF state" in Japan, you can find them here:  https://www.instagram.com/glutenfreejapandelivery?igsh=MTI3M2o3Z29za3M2dw==

Title:
SURVIVAL HACK: Find a local #supermarket usually a few meters away from the train station. As much as I love Seijo Isshi, it's way pricier than regular supermarkets. The ones directly connected to the train stations are usually pricer because they have to pay the rent, except for #TokyuSupermarket found in Tokyu Train Stations. THERE ARE TREASURES UNTOLD at night, nearing the closing time. If you're tired from the day and failed to get a good meal, you can actually easily whip up a JAPANESE SPECIALTY in your AirBnB. This #DIYrecipe is about 500 yen, but so packed with healthy, filling protein. 

This one is a karashi #mentaiko or spicy pollack cod roe on sale for about 399 YEN for three slabs. Get those packs of rice (on the shelves for about 450 yen for 5 trays). Buy a tray of eggs and boil them. If there's a dollar store (Daiso, Can Do, Seria), there are soft boiled egg containers to make one in the microwave in 1.40 seconds (precise because this is what it says in the label, and what I do on lazy days). Try natto with these. Stinky but very good for the gut, which we intolerants want. No other flavoring needed, but I personally like sesame seeds and sesame oil drizzled on top. MENTAIKO is rich in B12 good for the nerves and energy replenishment for long days. Also rich in Omega 3 which has a long list of benefits. "Eases inflammation" may be the most useful for us. If mentaiko is not your thing, sashimi slices on sale abound at night, which I could have for dinner and brunch (with a fridge). 

And the other pic, well, FOR A BALANCED DIET üòÇ I know sugar ain't on the healthy list but sweet tooth calling. These ones are grocery/supermarket brands below. I looooove the mochi in caramel ice cream (the one in a maroon cup; the matcha version is also good). I hardly see them in convenience stores (or maybe sporadically stocked) and if they have one, it's usually x 2.5 the price of those in supermarkets. These range from 99 yen to 150 yen for the cream-based stuff, and 250 for the kurumi (walnut mochi). Not all mochis are created equal, and this one's my favorite (almost like the specialty of Okayama Prefecture).‚ù§Ô∏è The law now mandates clear markings for ALLERGENS so the cream-based stuff clearly shows these. The handmade mochi packaging still needs to catch up with the labelling. I mainly scanned the ingredients (CLEAR!) and only skimmed through cross-contamination, since I hardly react to it and was soooo famished, so double check. 

If you want to see the back labels, it's in Insta Stories, which will be later clearly grouped with GF Grocery Highlights. If the last thing you want though, is think of your food during a packed itinerary, there's always an option for gluten-free delivery. üòâ 

https://www.instagram.com/glutenfreejapandelivery?igsh=MTI3M2o3Z29za3M2dw==

ResponsesV2.Message: Seijo Ishii is slightly more expensive but you‚Äôre paying for more options - especially if you‚Äôre gluten free or have other dietary requirements so it‚Äôs totally worth it to me

Title:
Hi! I'm traveling in November and I was wondering if there is any sake that we can drink without any problems. I've been reading that many have some ingredient with gluten. If someone could send me some photos If you have any sake that is suitable for celiacs, that would do me a huge favor!! 
Thank you so much! üòä

ResponsesV2.Message: I believe pretty much all rice based sake are fine, at least the premium stuff. I went to sake tasting at a factory show room, checked the ingredients, discussed it with the folks who work there, had a lovely time, did not get sick.

There are over 1,000 sake breweries in Japan all making various types of sake. It is very hard to find the same brand over and over- things are very regional. Always order "junmai". Junmai means it is only rice and rice koji. No alcohol added if that worries you. Following the words Junmai you might see "ginjo or daiginjo." That has do do with the rice polishing ratio. Don't worry about it (but daiginjo is more expensive.).

Title:
PSA: Those planning their weekend grocery.üòÇCASE IN POINT: Seijo Ishii vs. Gyomu Supermarket #grocery #shopping 

I loooove #seijoishii  and I have it at my home station, so one long day at work always brings me there. I can read the allergens so the cheese and everything for charcuterie always get me. And I have a sweet tooth, so double whammy. üòÖ But when I want to have more bang for my buck, I walk a little farther from the station and go to a #GyomuSupermarket 

These churros from Seijo are my kryptonite. The thing is, I can finish it in 2-3 days with restraint üòÖ. It costs 699 YEN. At Gyomu, the choco covered dates and nuts cost 298 YEN and the coconut crispy roll (like wafer/langue de chat creamy feels) costs 278 YEN. Those from Gyomu can possibly (with restraint üòÇ) last me 7 DAYS. And this is just one of the 30 something things I bought from Gyomu (frozen brussel sprouts and meats included üòÇ)

I feel sad for those who have a hard time finding food in Japan, mainly because of the general lack of knowledge of Japan of gluten, and the intimidating kanji. But for those of us who've lived our pre-glutenfree and gluten free life in Japan for years, Japan can honestly be affordable and enjoyable. 

I have tooo many photos of my grocery hunts from Gyomu in my stories if you care to see it  Happy Weekend shopping! ü•∞
https://www.instagram.com/glutenfreejapandelivery?igsh=MTI3M2o3Z29za3M2dw==

ResponsesV2.Message: These are my favorite GF snack from #gyomu. Good stuff.
i just discovered those churros, i'll never be the same. my wallet will never be the same.

Title:
Hello, 
I would like to ho pick up some snacks from seijo ishii but the closest to my place is 40min away. Are they all carring gf items or is it just selected locations ? 
#seijoishii

Thank you

ResponsesV2.Message: Not all GF. And also you have to go through the aisles. Japanese ones are usually lumped with Seijo Iishi brand cookies. They are mostly called Macrobiotic cookies. Then there are Protein bars in some other aisle. And they always carry the GF breads, and for some reason even the very small branch at the station in my area, has extensive GF stuff with the prep meals. Gf curry, pancake mix, flours. There are GF pastas but usually not with grouped with the "stick pasta" but with the pasta sauces because usually they come in different form. My favorite is the Salted Caramel churros, though. üòã Of course a lot of cheese, meats, dairy, drinks that are naturally GF, but wih no labels. I've never gone empty-handed after a trip at any seijo ishii. üòÖ But I personally find more stuff from Aeon (also Peacock and Max Value run by Aeon) and Bio-ral definitely. May I ask which seijo ishii branch you're planning to go? üòÖ Once upon a time, when GF was scarce, it was my version for a Friday night bar-hopping. üòÇ

Title:
If you like Japanese sweets, I highly recommend checking out famous confectioner Ryouheido.
They‚Äôre known for their delicious sweets that use persimmons and chestnuts.

The items I got this time were their chestnut cake roll made with rice flour + their chestnut filled dried persimmons.
The best part about their items is they only use sugar to sweeten them, so no mizuame/unspecified starches, etc.

The items are made in the same factory as items with wheat, so do be aware if you‚Äôre concerned with cross contamination.

Ryouheido has an online shop as well as stores in #gifu and #ginza (at Ginza Six).

Title:
Narita is notoriously bad for options, but I had about 8-9 hours there recently before a long haul flight and found some things, just thought I'd share to add some info (it's possible these places are newish, I'm not too sure, but didn't see them in any previous posts)

1. Jai Thai Narita - in the food court Terminal 1, absolutely incredible curry!! The best Thai curry I've had in Japan. Tastes just like in Thailand. They have allergy information but they only had wheat listed on items with flour (not on dishes that likely contain soy sauce) so I opted for curry just to be safe. You order through a machine. 

(They also have a salad place there that has options too and looked good)

2. Snacks from The American Pharmacy - not amazing but at least there were a few things to choose from. 

3. They do have the Doraemon Tokyo banana but I could only find them in one shop, near the check in counters on the side with the currency exchange. I didn't get a photo.

Title:
Update: The Ryokan I mentioned below is Kadensho Arashiyama Ryokan. Please see the pictures of the original breakfast set and after removing the allergens. The highlighted items in the dinner menu were not gluten free. Honestly the private onsens and the experience staying at the Ryokan were absolutely delightful, including the very convenient location, I wouldn't mind going back.

#arashiyama #onsenryokan 
....,..........,...........................
I booked a ryokan, and they came back with this:  Does it mean they can't accommodate wheat allergies?  
"FOOD ALLERGIES:
If you have any food allergies, please inform us of the specific item(s) and number of people.
*Available up to 4 days before arrival. Only removal of the actual foodstuff. We cannot accommodate "removal of ingredients", "wheat/soy/nut/fish allergies", "likes/dislikes", "vegetarian/vegan diets" or "religious diets".

ResponsesV2.Message: I think I means if you can't, say, have wheat, they have to remove that entire item like, say, noodles with wheat. Or something marinaded in soy sauce. They can't just remove the soy sauce but that entire food item. So it sounds like they can not serve you something with those ingredients but they can't substitute for them.

They won't cook another meal for you. They will only take out the item from your dinner experience. 

If it's a 15 plates dinning experience, you may have half removed.

Before agreeing and paying 100$, try to ask what your meal will look like with a wheat allergy.

Title:
üçõ GLUTEN-FREE Japanese Chicken Katsu Curry Sauce

Major üîë - Learn to fry gluten-free chicken! (I'll post this separately. It's also already posted to my Reddit: Rach_CrackYourBible.)

üíó My version of Japanese Curry Sauce

Roux

50g (1.7 oz) unsalted butter
¬º cup Gluten-free flour (I used Bob's Red Mill)
4 tablespoons Japanese curry powder (not the blocks, those have wheat.) I use S & B brand oriental curry powder but you can also make your own mix.
2 teaspoons garam masala
1 tablespoon tumeric
1 tablespoon chili powder 

*****

1 small onion, finely diced, sauteed
4 tablespoons bacon grease

*****

1 green apple, finely grated
¬º cup gluten-free soy sauce
1 tablespoon honey
2 teaspoons apple cider vinegar
¬æ cup juice (I used kombucha)
3 cups chicken stock
3 waxy potatoes, cut into bite-sized pieces (I used Idaho Gold)
1 carrot, cut into bite-sized pieces
sea salt to taste.

*****

Instructions:

1. Make dark blonde roux, add spices. 
2. In a separate skillet, sautee diced onion in bacon grease or butter until translucent.
3. Add sauteed onion to spiced roux.
5. Add all other ingredients to sauce mixture. 
6. Cook over medium-low heat until potatoes and carrots are al dente and the sauce has thickened.
7. Serve alongside rice and protein.

#celiac #glutenfreejapanese #glutenfreefriedchicken #glutenfreekatsu #glutenfreejapanesecurry #coeliac

ResponsesV2.Message: YUM!!

Title:
I don't think I've seen Rizriant in #kichijoji mentioned here much?

It's a beautiful little cafe and bakery which specialises in French-style desserts. You won't find any bread or anything savoury there, but the cakes are sublime.

The owner is a French-trained pastry chef with a wheat allergy and everything is made from rice flour. It advertises as 100% gluten free - I don't know whether the ice cream they use in some of the parfaits etc would have mizuame, but certainly everything home-made in store is rice-based. I've eaten there twice as a sensitive coeliac and had no reactions.

It's about a 15-min walk from Kichijoji station. I think they also take orders for birthday and Christmas cakes etc.

Title:
Hi there 

I've had a bit of a search through the page and not having 100% luck. 

I'll be in Japan pregnant and with celiac disease and need to stick to low carb food and high protein (like 120g a day of protein!). Just found out that I can't pack biltong from home to have some emergency snacks just in case I get caught on fresh options while out. I'll pack some nuts and protein bars, but still feeling a bit anxious about it.

I have brain fog to the max, does anyone have photos of readily available gluten free low carb products that I could likely get at a konbini? The less ingredient scanning I have to do the better. ü´†

Thanks very much

ResponsesV2.Message: Do you have to be low carb for medical reasons? If not I‚Äôd highly suggest going off. Food is hard enough in Japan without being able to have the staples. Protein is not usually a thing in large portions and carbs are much heavier.

The convenience stores sell things like GF hard boiled eggs, dried meats (jerky), salami, cheeses etc...You will be fine. If you want to reduce the GI of rice remember that if you reheat cooked rice it becomes low GI and all the convenience stores have a microwave if you do not have access to one where you are staying (although most places do). Also you may not be aware that if you have diary with any meal it reduces the GI of the entire meal. I am a type 1 diabetic and coeliac. I also take a prebiotic called Kfibre twice everyday that has been clinically trialled and shown to reduce the GI of everything you consume for 12 hours and regulate blood sugars. I am not sure what country you are based in.

Title:
Hey GF locals and visitors! I have lived gluten-free in Japan for over a decade now and have seen this community grow so much. I recently opened up a small yoga studio in Minami-Asagaya (Tokyo), and I not only teach yoga there, but also occasionally (when my schedule allows!) host small community events. Recently I've been thinking about hosting a monthly or bi-monthly GF meetup there, but I wonder if folks would be interested in something like that? Title:
Thanks to this group I was able to eat in japan so I thought I would share my experience. Just got back from three weeks. I will say I ate way better than I thought I would. It did help that my mother in law is Japanese and we spent some time with her family who was super helpful when buying/cooking me food ü•πü•π 
However it still was a tad difficult having to go out of the way to eat rather than just walking into the first place you see. 
Places visited were Hiroshima, Osaka, Miyajima island, Kyoto and Tokyo. We visited family out near Mt Fuji, only reason I found it easy there was because we had family to cook for us and communicate easier with restaurants. 
Easiest places by far was Tokyo and I found Osaka the hardest. 

The gf food map and Google translate were my best friends when my MIL wasn‚Äôt around. Super convenient able to use to translate ingredients lists. I also learnt the Japanese word for wheat
 Â∞èÈ∫¶  when looking at the ingredients list. 
However it‚Äôs nearly impossible to look out for barley and rye so I didn‚Äôt even bother. I went with my gut instinct on some things eg didn‚Äôt eat sauces. 
I took my own soy sauce which came in handy and I bought little sachets of kewpie in Japan to carry to put on salads! 

This was my first time back in Japan since being diagnosed and I was very scared I would be eating rice everyday ( not a bad thing but I love Japanese food haha ). Since I‚Äôll be going back often as my husband has family in Japan it‚Äôs nice knowing I can comfortably eat there üòã 

All photos have the locations of the places I knew üòÅ

#japan #glutenfree #tokyo #osaka #hiroshima #kyoto #ramen #mtfuji #tips #miyajima #restaurants

Hi Sarah, I just joined this group and your post is the first one I see...THANK YOU! I could cry right now ü•∞ We are heading to Tokyo and Hakuba in January and this is making me so much less anxious about eating there ‚ù§Ô∏è Travelling with a group when ur the odd one out is always tricky but Im hoping to be prepared by doing all the research now.

Title:
Hi everybody,
Now it‚Äôs my turn to give a contribution to this group that has been very useful to plan my trip to Japan. I booked all dinners in advance and also some lunches. 
Here are the restaurant we personally tried:

#TOKYO
- Gluten Free T‚Äôs Kitchen Ueno-hirokoji: very very friendly staff but service a bit slow and not well organized. Almoust everything is fried (also things that shouldn‚Äôt) so the dinner was a bit heavy, but overall I would suggest it at least for the possibility to eat in a completely safe place.

- Gonpachi Asakusa: very friendly service and good choice of dishes thanks to the gluten-free separate menu. Not so ‚Äútypical‚Äù, many tourists, but overall it‚Äôs ok to try some japanese specialties. 

- Heij≈çen (Asakusa): restaurant yakiniku style. We showed the gluten-free card and they seemed to understand, at least they understood that the meat should be served without sauces. We had our rice and meat to cook by ourselves, since the meat was plain we didn‚Äôt have any problem. 

- Sushi Morinari: an excellent service in this (quite pricey) sushi omakase. The staff knew about gluten and didn‚Äôt use any sauce in the preparation of the nigiri. They also had gluten free sauce. It‚Äôs better to book in advance indicating in the reservation that the lunch/dinner should be gluten free so that they are prepared. 

- Teppan Baby (Shinjuku): good okonomyaki, very friendly staff and nice place. They are prepared about gluten, the only things to consider is that all stuffs are cooked on the same place to it‚Äôs not suggested for people with a strong allergy. 

#KANAZAWA
- Love for all: staff very friendly and good choice on the menu. Not so memorable but I would suggest it as a very safe place. 

- Kourin Sushi: since on monday almost everything was closed, we chose this place with very good reviews. Sushi is very good, fresh and also cheap but they needed to be told in advance that one person was gluten intolerant. So they kindly said that sushi could‚Äôt be served since it contained gluten, but the menu offers some nice alternatives such as a tuna fillet that was very good and it was served with plain white rice. 

#TAKAYAMA 
- Aji-no-Yohei: good Hida beef, not specifically gluten-free. It offers different menus with meat, rice, vegetables, miso soup. If you just eat the meat and the rice it‚Äôis safe for sure, maybe it‚Äôs better to avoid the vegetables (that are topped with a sauce) and the miso soup. 

#KYOTO
- Gion Soy milk ramen: we came here twice. 4/5 ramen choices and some appetizers. Ramen was good, someone may not appreciate the soy milk taste but I liked it. 

- Choice: good choice of dishes, even a (small) pizza. Nice and quiet atmosphere.

- Masaemon (link Maps: https://maps.google.com/?q=Giappone,%20%E3%80%92605-0826%20Kyoto,%20Higashiyama%20Ward,%20Masuyacho,%20349-21%20%E3%82%B8%E3%83%93%E3%82%A8%E3%83%BB%E6%B4%BB%E5%B7%9D%E9%AD%9A%E6%96%99%E7%90%86%E3%83%BB%E5%8D%81%E5%89%B2%E6%89%8B%E6%89%93%E3%81%A1%E8%95%8E%E9%BA%A6%E5%87%A6%20%E3%80%8C%E6%94%BF%E5%8F%B3%E8%A1%9B%E9%96%80%E3%80%8D(MASAEMON)&ftid=0x600109a72b6b2469:0xa0a247525adfb00f&entry=gps&lucs=,94224825,94227247,94227248,47071704,47069508,94218641,94203019,47084304,94208458,94208447&g_st=com.google.maps.preview.copy): our best culinary experience in Japan. The chef speaks only Japanese but the communication is made possible thanks to a translator that he uses with voice transcription. He prepares gluten free 100% buckwheat  soba noodles that can be served with different kinds of meat/ fish plates. Booked in advance online. 

- Steak Misono: very expensive and booked in advance to treat ourselves with a culinary experience to taste Kobe beef. Very recommended, they understand about gluten.

- Sugarhill: good choice of western and asian dishes, their best is chicken teryiaki.

#NARA
- Big mountain cafe & farm: nice place, good choice of dishes, we tried a good hamburger. 

#HIROSHIMA
- More Than: western style place with a dedicated gluten free menu (mainly contaning meat/fish/salads).

#MIYAJIMA
- Miyajima Base: chicken curry was not avaiable so we took chicken bites with rice. A bit heavy but it remains a good alternative on the island to eat something safe. 

Regarding the accomodations: 

TOKYO
- Asakusa Tobu Hotel: at the breakfast all the allergens are clearly indicated. No specific gluten free dishes, the choice is among eggs, salad, fruit, rice. 

KANAZAWA
- Tokyu Stay Kanazawa: same as the previous hotel, but with a smaller choice of dishes at breakfast. I wouldn‚Äôt recommend it.

TAKAYAMA
- Oyado Koto No Yume (Ryokan): they know about gluten and they even serve a gluten free version of their breakfast with gluten free bread (made with rice flour)

KYOTO
- Hotel Alza: breakfast is served in the room, they know about gluten so they can serve a gluten free breakfast. They don‚Äôt add things like gluten free bread, they simply remove the food with gluten from the traditional breakfast. 

MIYAJIMA
- Miyajima Seaside hotel: same as above, they know the problem and the breakfast is served removing the ingredients with gluten. 

Hope this can be useful :)

ResponsesV2.Message: Thanks for the suggestions! We are planning a trip for next may and trying to find places to eat has been my biggest challenge so far
Thank you so much

Title:
Hello! I‚Äôm looking for a hotel catering to coeliacs in Kanazawa. I‚Äôve searched the group and saw a recommendation for Hotel Intergate, but I got the following response from them: ‚ÄúWe have a buffet at our hotel.
We are unable to offer special menus.
We do have a list of allergies.
Thank you for your understanding.‚Äù Has anyone been there, or are there any hotels or at least restaurants that you could recommend?

ResponsesV2.Message:
We stayed there in Nov 2023. I am asymptomatic celiac. I did my best to avoid obvious gluten, but since I don't react, I definitely took chances during this trip. If I'm remembering correctly, their breakfast buffet was very expensive (the most expensive of all our hotels during our 24 day stay in Japan), and I did not see any allergen markings. It was not that good-tasting, either.  Really nice hotel, though!  Riiiiight down the street from their bus, which you can buy the tourist pass for in the hotel hobby. Saved us a ton of money. So easy to hop on and off the special bus line for tourist spots once you get the hang of it...üòÖ

Here's the map from another user that helped me the most on my trip: https://www.google.com/maps/d/u/0/viewer?ll=35.00351730692734%2C135.7755862755366&z=17&fbclid=IwAR2WsWDoWKhm_uHwyxOwMjRqxw2XSS_8ljkqMIWk4AwgDgunNsmhorXQNbM&mid=1iwutbbadlGniNmCDVuBz_2E5BVlyb5s

KEY: Red are dedicated gluten-free or extremely accommodating. Blue means I've verified through either comments in this page or the restaurant websites/reviews that the restaurants have GF options or can accommodate when asked/phone ahead/allergy card. Grey are the ones that are borderline and questionable as a lot of time has passed or things have changed.

It's been so long since I opened that link, in case Kanazawa isn't listed, here are the restaurants where I ate: 

Within walking distance of hotel. Wish I would have eaten here all the days! Didn't until our last day: Cafe Merzbau, ÈùíÂ±±„Éì„É´ 1F 1-25 Oyamamachi, Kanazawa, Ishikawa 920-0918, Japan

Lunch, within walking distance of hotel, but difficult to find (both the building entrance as well as the location of the restaurant within the department store basement): Daizen Steak House, ÈáëÊ≤¢„Ç®„É†„Ç∂Âú∞‰∏ã 1Èöé 15-1 Musashimachi, Kanazawa, Ishikawa 920-0855, Japan

Within walking distance of hotel, offers breakfast, but odd hours of operation (so I did not eat here because I missed it): Shirom Creperie, 4-8 Oyamamachi, Kanazawa, Ishikawa 920-0918, Japan

NOT within walking distance of hotel, ate here for lunch. Aashirwad, 1 Chome-4-59 Nagamachi, Kanazawa, Ishikawa 920-0865, Japan
We used the Kanazawa Intergate in 2019. There was definitely a risk of cross contamination on the breakfast buffet but allergens were marked, as they say.

Title:
Last night I went to Moon and Back in Kyoto 
585 Takamiyacho, Nakagyo Ward, Kyoto, 604-8056

I found it recommended on the Find GF page.
After walking a long way we found it and it looked great. 
It‚Äôs a very limited menu unless you eat beef or pork. 
There were just 2 vegan options.
I chose the Spicy Tandan and asked for the option of gluten free noodles. 
The chef then came over and asked if I had an allergy, I told him Gluten free. 
He explained that the ramen base was made with normal soy sauce and therefore not gluten free. He gave me the option of the beef or pork or creamy ramen. 
All of which would be no good for my stomach. 
I ended up with just my drink. 
My poor husband wasn‚Äôt feeling great (turns out it was the start of food poisoning from yesterday!)but we knew he had to eat so he quickly ordered what we thought was sushi. 
3 pieces of raw fish came out- known as Sashimi. 
He ate it (reluctantly) and we paid.
I‚Äôve just realised we were charged for the meal I didn‚Äôt have. 
So when you see the big signs advertising Vegan and gluten free. 
Be aware it‚Äôs limited to say the least.
Very disappointed. 
Now the worry of food poisoning and the necessary travelling tomorrow with cases and no lifts!

ResponsesV2.Message:
If you carry big suitcases, I recommend sending them directly to your next hotel. You can simply go to your hotel counter to ask for this service. We do not regret doing that as we had many changes!
I hope your husband is feeling better.
Thankyou for sharing. Hope you remained well.

Title:
It‚Äôs not until you visit Japan with a food intolerance that you realise just how difficult it is to eat anything! 
Japan has been amazing but I‚Äôve lived on boiled rice and my own Soy sauce for 2 weeks.
I brought 1 noodle pot with me, it was a ‚Äújust in case‚Äù for the long flight. 
I needed it tonight, I can‚Äôt eat any more rice. 
It was so delicious! Simply a @Tesco Freefrom chicken and mushroom noodle pot, I added grated cabbage and carrot (bought from a supermarket and possibly the only thing that didn‚Äôt contain wheat!)
I added @kikkomanuk soy sauce and seaweed flakes.

ResponsesV2.Message: For other readers to gauge how hard it is, just offering a different experience. I feel like i never had a bad meal for the two months I was there, and I also never actually needed my gf soy sauce either! I was lucky enough to have the time to do quite a lot of research beforehand though.

Title:

Title:
If you‚Äôre looking for some cheap/easy snacks in the Ginza area, I recommend going by the shops in Tokyo Kotsu Kaikan.

They have a lot of speciality shops, including ones for Akita and Okinawa prefectures, which naturally use a lot of rice/less wheat and gluten in their sweets.

Building: Tokyo Kotsu Kaikan
Closest stations: Yurakucho and Ginza (it‚Äôs right outside the JR Kyobashi exit at Yurakucho station)
Best shops (1st floor): Okinawa and Akita speciality shops (marked on the map photo)

‚û°Ô∏èOkinawa Specialty Shop
Okinawa naturally has a lot of purple sweet potato and rice-based desserts + sugar cane-based chocolates that are both gluten and even dairy free.
My favorite snack from here is their chocolate rice-flour cake. (They were sold out today so will add a photo next time I go.)
They also have Blue Seal ice cream and soft serve!
I‚Äôve also been addicted to their sweet pork miso for 10+ years‚ò∫Ô∏è

‚û°Ô∏èAkita Specialty Shop
Akita has a lot of rice-based cakes. My favorite here is their black sesame rice cakes. They also have matcha and green tea flavored @snacks.

‚ö†Ô∏èNote
I am gluten intolerant so some of these items also contain mizuame (unidentified sweetners).
Check the ingredient labels to find what works best for you!

#ginza #yurakucho #dessert #vegan #dairyfree #icecream #japanesesweets #mochi

Title:
Look what I found at San-A supermarket in Ishikawa Okinawa! 

Gluten-free udon and somen noodles, perfect for those with wheat allergies or following a gluten-free diet.

Udon

Made with 100% domestic rice flour (look for the words ÂõΩÁî£Á±≥Á≤â)
Smooth, chewy texture
7 minutes cooking time

Package says Â∞èÈ∫¶Á≤â‰∏ç‰ΩøÁî® (no wheat flour) and „Ç∞„É´„ÉÜ„É≥„Éï„É™„Éº (gluten-free)

Soumen

Made with 100% domestic rice flour
Refreshing, smooth texture
3 minutes cooking time

Package says Â∞èÈ∫¶Á≤â‰∏ç‰ΩøÁî® (no wheat flour) and „Ç∞„É´„ÉÜ„É≥„Éï„É™„Éº (gluten-free)
Both packages are in Japanese, but look for the key phrases:

Â∞èÈ∫¶Á≤â‰∏ç‰ΩøÁî®: This means "no wheat flour," so it's safe for those with wheat allergies.
„Ç∞„É´„ÉÜ„É≥„Éï„É™„Éº: This is the Japanese word for "gluten-free."

I found these in Ishikawa, but they might be available in other parts of Japan too.  Let me know if you spot them!

EDIT:  I don't mean to mollycoddle, or deprive you of your chance to improve your Japanese, but the english directions leave a little to be desired so Just a little tweaking to make the instructions even easier to follow! I kept it short and sweet, polishing up some phrases for smoother reading. And hey, all about that tsuyu, right?

 I added some info about the delicious dipping sauce. Shoga, anyone? I've added ginger as a suggestion.

DELICIOUS WAY TO ENJOY SOMEN 

ONE BAG (APPROX. 2 SERVINGS)

Cooking Instructions
1. Before cooking the noodles, prepare your dipping sauce (tsuyu), toppings (yakumi), and bowls. Bring 2 liters of water to a rolling boil in a large pot. Gradually add the somen noodles, stirring gently to prevent them from sticking together. Cook for 3 minutes.
1. Quickly transfer the noodles to a colander and rinse thoroughly under cold running water. Gently rub the noodles together to remove excess starch. Drain well.
1. Serve the noodles in your prepared dipping sauce (tsuyu). Add your favorite toppings, such as grated ginger (shoga), wasabi, green onions, or other ingredients of your choice.
1. Besides cold somen, you can also enjoy them in hot soup, stir-fried, or as a salad.

Title:
Hello! I‚Äôve just finished 5 days in Hokkaido and wanted to share my tips as I couldnt find much before I went. I visited Sapporo, stayed in Asahedake Onsen to do hiking and visited Furano.

Sapporo:
Fuku Noki: rice noodles, tomato based ramen which was different but nice and a really lovey owner.
Ring Ring: gluten free baked goods, really yummy
Cauldra: definitely visit this place, everything was gluten free on the menu, I had my first pain au chocolate in many years, and chicken and waffles and a croque monsieur!
Cologne Annex: teppanyaki, chef was so lovely and very accommodating of coeliac. I watched him cook everything and he checked with me multiple times about different ingredients. I did not have any symptoms and the food was SO good- we had steak and seafood
Ikanari Steak: a little izakaya, understanding of gluten free using allergy card, yummy steak

Asahedake:
We stayed at Bear Monte hotel for 3 days as a base to do walking. They knew I was gluten free and as breakfast and dinner were included they made sure I had something safe to eat. There was additional buffet style items and everything labelled with allergens. I have not had any symptoms so labels hopefully accurate. Would recommend for anyone looking to stay in Daizetsuzan National Park for hiking 

Furano:
Sora no kujira: we happened upon this place while stopping through Furano briefly. Everything gluten free and made of rice flour. I bought a muffin, brownies and a slice of pizza and all was very good. No English menu though (apart from the signs saying everything is rice flour) so use your google translate lens!

Names of services are what they come up as on google maps. 

Hopefully this helps someone heading to Sapporo! For reference I am a fairly sensitive coeliac. I used the allergy cards from this group!

#sapporo #furano #asahedake #hokkaido

ResponsesV2.Message: I'm going to be in Sapporo for a conference in October and have a place with kitchenette, near Sapporo Station. Are these in that area?
Thank you so much üôè Heading to Sapporo next year

Title:
Location: Sugamo, Tokyo. About a 2 minute walk from the JR/Mita station.  2-9-26-102 Sugamo, Toshima-ku, Tokyo 170-0002

Restaurant/Shop: Takagiya. Eat in or take out

Food: gluten free & vegan Japanese curry, taco salad, crepes, muffins, cookies, parfaits, mont blanc, and gateau

Price: 1,300¬• for gf/v curry, 420¬• for a gf/v muffin, 610¬• for a 6 pack of gf/v cookies, 1,500¬• for a gf/v parfait. 

Safety: I explained I have an allergy to wheat, not gluten, and I heard her explaining to the kitchen that it was a wheat allergy and that was why all the gluten free. That being said I struggled with our discussion on whether or not the oatmeal was certified gf. Since I have gotten hives from eating non-gf oatmeal in the past, I steered clear of the bottom half of my gf/v fruits parfait and didn't get any oatmeal cookies. The rest of the gf goods appears to use rice/almond flour.

Taste: curry and top half of parfait were excellent, excited bear cookies are "meh" but beggars can't be choosers. Haven't tried my muffin or gateau yet.

Verdict: Recommended!
#sugamo #tokyo #takagiya

Title: Hello - can anyone tell me the easiest way to make restaurant reservations? I‚Äôm in Tokyo now and then going to Kyoto. I found the website Tablelog and couldn‚Äôt figure out how to search for a specific restaurant. Is it better to book directly on the restaurant website?

ResponsesV2.Message:
I went to each restaurant's own website to discover if reservations were necessary, days and times they were open, etc. But, I never made reservations the entire 24 days we were in Japan Nov 2023. Relevant to your question, we stayed 5 nights in Kyoto, and 9 nights in Tokyo.

The only exception of not making reservations was for a place in Takayama because that's the only way to eat there, and that's what their website said.  Everywhere else, I allotted enough time if we had to wait, had a backup plan in the area, etc.  

Now, if someone from this group recommended we make reservations, I definitely took that into consideration. I did call one place to make reservations (also in Takayama), but turns out that restaurant changed to not serving foreigners during lunch, so I didn't eat there. (Already had reservations for dinner with the first place I mentioned.)

Did that make sense...? ü§îüòÖ
Tablecheck are also good and I have other tips here https://www.thetokyochapter.com/how-to-make-a-restaurant-reservation-in-japan/

Hello everyone, I have a question to people who live in Japan. I've stopped eating gluten about a year ago but I also don't take any supplements. Are there any supplements in Japan that are gluten free and would help me to stay healthy? I tried to research this topic but got no answer so far, thank you

ResponsesV2.Message:
Generally speaking, unless a doctor identified you are deficient in something you don't need to take supplements to stay healthy. If you don't need them they can actually do more harm than good, especially since they are often poorly regulated  (could even have hidden gluten).

The best thing to do (generally speaking, see below) is eat a wide variety of food, with lots of vegetables.

however, if you have celiac or other digestive or dietetry issue it can definitely be a big issue, but you can't really tell where the issues are without tests, so so it would be good to see a doctor and get checked for deficiencies and then follow their advice.
I also use iHerb but for my iron supplement recommended by my gastroenterologist and vitamin D recommended by my PCP, both because of abnormal lab values. Are you concerned you have deficiencies?

Title:
‚ö†Ô∏èFriendly Reminders‚ö†Ô∏è

1. Please read the group rules before posting.

2. Posts that do not follow the group guidelines will be removed.

Thank you again to all of the amazing members who share helpful information and make this a wonderful resource for everyone visiting and living in Japan.ü©∑

Hi, I'm gluten free but not celiac and from Australia. Many people have told me about eating wheat/gluten while overseas especially Europe and not having symptoms. I recently went to Vietnam and thought "f#@k, it, I'm going to eat what I want" and I was fine. If I eat gluten in Australia (a friend accidentally glutened me last week ‚òπÔ∏è )and it took hours to recover. Has anyone eaten gluten (soy sauce etc)  in Japan and been ok?

ResponsesV2.Message:
There's nothing significantly different about wheat in different countries. It is a myth.

You said you are not celiac, if you ate something with wheat in Australia and got sick, but are fine in another country it can be several things.

1. Something else you are intolerant to makes you sick 
2. You get sick because of something else not related to what you ate (like nervousness)
3. You got food poisoning from a germ or poison in Australia 
4. Your reactions are inconsistent (this can happen with celiacs too, some like me are completely asymptomatic)
5. The quantities of what you ate are different and there may be a threshold. E.g pasta has more wheat than soba.
6. Something else I forgot to mention
Is there a reason you wouldn‚Äôt use gluteguard in your position? I‚Äôm a coeliac so it‚Äôs not an option, but it should work for someone intolerant?

Title:
DisneyLand + Harry Potter + Universal

DisneyLand was able to cater allergen safe meals in the East Cafe (steak) + Blue Bayou Restaurant (3 course meal). I was also able to eat a spicy chicken leg, as it stated no wheat within the ingredient list. I did take Glute Guard as a precaution. 

The Making of Harry Potter was able to provide a small set lunch consisting of a patty, rice bread and sides. Butterbeer is NOT safe, however the bottles in the shops ARE! 

Note CARAMEL POPCORN at all resorts are not safe. But there is a caramel popcorn available at 7/11 which is delicious! 

Universal, I took my lunch box and showed my dietary card at the gate. They were really strict with other people. So make sure YOU are the only one carrying food, enough for YOU. There wasn't much available, I didn't go to any restaurants however. Smoothies were safe. 

#disneyland #disneysea #harrypotter #universal #tokyo #osaka

ResponsesV2.Message: This is awesome thank you! Was the food rather expensive? I know most park foods are pricey but wondering if it was heaps extra being gf üò¨ was your dietary card enough to prove you needed to take food in? I read previously people had got notes from doctors üò≥

Gluten-free sweets made with natural ingredients that are not harmful to the body

Title:
Just finished a two week trip in Japan in Tokyo, Kyoto and Osaka as a celiac and thought I would share my experience as this group was extremely helpful for me! 

Eats in Japan:
Shinjuku - Sakura sushi (a yummy sushi train but they don‚Äôt have gf soy sauce so bring your own)

Shinjuku - Moyan curry (recommended by this group with GF Japanese curry options. No bookings required when we went) 

Shinjuku - Ginger grass (this was in our hotel and they had some GF options on their menu. They had Vietnamese cuisine available) 

Shinjuku - Mikis Cafe (cute cafe we found down the road from our hotel, they had GF muffins and biscuits and did a really yummy smoothie!) 

Shibuya - Shimbu Sakiya Ramen (recommended by this group. Great GF ramen options, also dumplings and fried chicken. It was delish but quite a small place!) 

Shibuya - Riz Labo (GF fluffy pancakes, so delicious!) 

Harajuku - Ricehack GF baby (I didn‚Äôt eat anything from here cause it was too hot and just checked it out. It‚Äôs just a hole in the wall place with pizza, bread and a hot dog option which looked nice. No seating) 

Osaka - Gengi Soba (GF noodle option with tempura, it was a bit more pricey than other places but so worth it and so good!) 

Kyoto - Engine Ramen (my favourite meal of the trip hands down! The best ramen with tonnes of GF options. We didn‚Äôt have a booking so should be able to walk in) 

Apart from the above recommendations I wanted to also share some tips from what I found: 

1. GF soy sauce is hard to find so I would bring your own from your country if possible to save the hassle
2. A lot of restaurants didn‚Äôt understand when I would ask if there were gluten free options in Japanese, so I always ask in different ways such as ‚Äúdoes anything contain soy sauce or have wheat?‚Äù 
3. Even though I had lots of options from the group and doing prior research, I still did struggle and GF options were hard to come by. Some of the GF options people recommend are quite far out so you might need to make a trip of it. 
4. A lot of nights we got bits from the supermarket such as crackers, dip, meats, sushi and did that for dinner at our hotel, we loved it and you can‚Äôt go wrong! 
5. I lived off Salmon onigiri from the 7/11s and Family Marts. I found they were the only real safe option. 

Hope this helps and thank you to everyone that also helped me!

#celiac #shinjuku #osaka #kyoto #shibuya #curry #ramen #tips #recommendations #onigiri

ResponsesV2.Message: Can you bring those little soy sauce fish bottles you get from the sushi shops in Australia? Thanks

Title:

ResponsesV2.Message:
If you‚Äôre ok to hire a car, we went to Shikoku last year and found this little cafe to be great, had soba noodles we could eat, and also a bunch of pastries and desserts that had been homemade. The owner bought out the sauce (flavouring for the dipping sauce) bottle to show it was gluten free (I actually think it was Australian, as are we, so we recognised the brand), and while he spoke limited English, there was a waitress who spoke a bit more English. Fabrizio Cioni and Phil Pillera both have ones that they update whenever people post in the group about them. If you look at those you'll be able to find locations to go that have a decent amount available.

Title:
Gluten Free Obanzai LL Restaurant
at   3‚àí4‚àí5 Yamada Building 4F, Nishihara, Shibuya, Tokyo
https://www.instagram.com/freebanzai_ll?igsh=ZWp2eXQyb3hra3pv&utm_source=qr
Found this through Japanese language search.  Very good traditional Japanese obanzai food.  The restaurant is in the Yamada building (easy to find via google map directions) and 2 minutes from Yoyogi-Uehara Station.  It is in the same building as Ishii Coffee and you take the stairs on the side of that building.  Went here after touring Meiji Jingue.
RESERVATIONS:  DM them via their Instagram site.  They would like you to specify Date, Time and Number of people.  The place probably seats a total of 10 - 12 people (they have one table for 4 and 3-4 big couches that surround a big square low wood table).  The place is small so please only reserve if you are certain you can make it and please try not to cancel last minute - def. let them know asap if you can't make it via Insta DM.  The owner/chef preps all food prior to your arrival and does all communication via Insta DM.   The food was so good here, that I really want them to make it!
****By the way, I had them make my food both gluten free and dairy free.

Title:
A huge thank you for everyone‚Äôs contribution to this group. It made planning our trip so much easier! I hope you find my reviews useful!

‚ö†Ô∏èVERY LONG POST AHEAD‚Ä¶
We are now on our way home after two weeks in Japan for our honeymoon. Please note that as we were celebrating and we are massive foodies, we did splash out. Some places are quite expensive. 

I am coeliac as well as having a nut allergy. Most restaurants, I (or our hotel) contacted in advance to make sure they could cater for me and were well prepped before our arrival. 

#TOKYO

Gonpachi, Asakusa
There is a gluten free menu (I believe at this location only), just ask your waiter. Food is delicious (especially the tuna belly), tasted very fresh. 
‚è∞ Arrived at 11:30 when it opened and were seated immediately.
üí∞ Very reasonable for quantity and quality 

Kuroboshi Churros, Asakusa
Churros made with rice flour, fried infront of you. There are separate boxes for toppings, the cinnamon sugar is safe and was INCREDIBLE!
üí∞ I believe 1x was 500¬•

Lobelisk
100% gluten free yakitori restaurant.
A nice experience, but not our favourite meal. I think we had 6 courses of chicken‚Ä¶and as mentioned in this group by a few others, it‚Äôs quite expensive for what you get, but it was great knowing there is no risk. They also had very good wine!
‚è∞ Reservation required
üí∞üí∞Set course only 

Tsukiji Fish Market
OIDEYA - wagyu & seafood BBQ. All grilled, and torched in front of you. No meat or fish is marinaded, sauces are added onto your plate once cooked, so I just asked for no sauce with my Wagyu and it was delish!

Sweet Potato stand - very simple, but surprisingly delicious.

Rizlabo
The fluffiest, lightest pancakes! I went very classic with just maple syrup. Located down a gorgeous little street, but it‚Äôs quite easy to miss (see photo of entrance). It‚Äôs definitely worth the trip!
‚è∞ We arrived at 3pm and walked straight in, no queue at all. Note: It does take about 20/25mins for them to make.
üí∞ Good price for the size!

Nobu
If you‚Äôre celebrating, for us you can‚Äôt go wrong at Nobu. We have visited many Nobu‚Äôs across the world, and every time the quality, service and experience is fantastic. They are also well trained on allergies and understand cross-contamination risks. Gluten free safe options we ordered: salmon crispy rice, tuna tartare with caviar, miso black cod, roasted leek, a selection of maki rolls and sashimi. 
‚è∞ Reservation recommended 
üí∞üí∞üí∞

Shake Shack
Cheese burger wrapped in lettuce - order at the counter, not through the screens!

Shimbu Sakiya Ramen
We loved being able to order from the machine outside! Clearly marked up what is gluten free, and I double checked with the staff inside before ordering. I couldn‚Äôt believe they served fried chicken, and it was really good. I found the Ramen absolutely delicious.
‚è∞ Arrived at 9pm on a Friday, and walked straight in
üí∞2x pieces of GF fried chicken 300¬•

#KYOTO

YASAKA, Park Hyatt
This was by far our favourite meal. Everything was just perfect! Teppanyaki with a sensational view. We had a set menu, with dishes including: sea urchin, cheese, scallops, Wagyu, crab, local tilefish. It was the cleanest teppanyaki I have ever seen, and the chefs took extra care to cook my food separately from others. 
‚è∞ Reservation required (enquire far in advance)
üí∞üí∞üí∞ Pricey, but worth it for a celebratory meal

Kura Sushi Plus
This is a chain sushi conveyor belt restaurant. I‚Äôve seen people mention gluten free soy sauce here, but I couldn‚Äôt get any. The staff didn‚Äôt speak any English, and when trying to translate they just got confused. There is an allergen sheet though, which makes it easy for ordering. The conveyor belt experience is fun, but I found the sushi to be very average.
‚è∞ Expect to queue!
üí∞

Ikkakuju Karasuma
100% gluten free okonomiyaki.
A nice experience again seeing the chefs cook infront of you. However I didn‚Äôt find this restaurant to be very clean, and it put me off a little. The okonomiyaki did taste good, but it‚Äôs very heavy!
‚è∞ Reservation required
üí∞

Sushi Naritaya, Arashiyama
Hidden behind the main street of food places, an absolute gem of a place! The staff were so kind, and very knowledgeable of gluten allergies (plus they had GF soy sauce!). You can see the chef work, and the wait staff were continually communicating with him to make sure our food was safe. 10/10 sushi, incredible quality! 
‚è∞ Walked in at 12:30, seated immediately 
üí∞üí∞

Mr Maurice‚Äôs Italian, Ace Hotel
My husband was desperate for a pizza after this first week. Luckily, Mr Maurice had gluten free spaghetti. I asked them to cook the pasta in fresh boiling water which they did, and I could choose almost any sauce from their standard menu. Vodka pasta was nice! 
‚è∞ Reservation recommended
üí∞üí∞

#OKINAWA

We stayed at Halekulani for a few days, and chose to mostly eat at the resorts restaurants which all had notes of my allergies. Chefs had prepared special plates in advance.
AOMI - fantastic Shabu Shabu
Kingdom - great steak & chicken
Shiroux - a unique take on the set western breakfast
House without a key - the most restrictive menu, and not that exciting
üí∞üí∞üí∞

We also visited the Ritz-Carlton for lunch after my husband played golf. Food was beautiful and the chef was able to tweak anything from the savoury menu to make it a gluten free version. 
üí∞üí∞üí∞

#OSAKA

Matsusakagyu Yakiniku M Hanare 
Fabulous cooking experience, one of our top meals! All the meat is great quality Wagyu, they have GF soy sauce, and each table has its own clean grill. Highly, highly recommend!
‚è∞ Reservation required
üí∞üí∞

La Baie, Ritz-Carlton
This holds 1 Michelin Star ‚≠êÔ∏è 
A beautiful, intimate dinner for our last night. The food was divine! The chef tweaked the classic course menu to fit my requirements, so I didn‚Äôt feel left out. It is expensive, but reasonable for a Michelin star restaurant in our opinion. 
‚è∞ Reservation required 
üí∞üí∞üí∞

W Hotel
Breakfast is outstanding here! Buffet style across two large rooms, all food has allergens listed, and the chefs are around for any questions. A huge selection!
üí∞üí∞

ResponsesV2.Message: Hi, just wondering was the Churro made in a separate fryer? I‚Äôm super sensitive and have coeliac disease xxx
Thank you for the detailed post - super helpful!

Title:
A dangerous discovery - if you like unagi/eel, you can make your own unadon by buying plain eel and making your own sauceüòäü©∑

Eel is in season for the next month, so check your local supermarket (I got mine at Life)!

The meat is precooked, so just heat it up in the toaster oven and add your sauce + sansho (Chinese pepper) and enjoy!

‚û°Ô∏èUnagi sauce recipe (for 2 meals)

- 2-3 tablespoons of sugar
- 3-4 tablespoons of soy sauce
- 2 tablespoons each of mirin and cooking wine/sake

Simmer the ingredients on medium in a pan to evaporate the alcohol and then turn down to low until the sauce becomes your desired consistency.
This sauce works on just about any meat or veggie dish so you can always double/triple the recipe and store it in the fridge!

I used my extra sauce and simmered it with some tofu for an easy side dish.

#unagi #unadon #recipe #sauce

ResponsesV2.Message: Will have to try this, thank you! I saw online that they have a GF unagi sauce (labeled "sushi sauce" in the UK). If anyone has friends coming from the UK, they might be able to bring/post you some?

Title:
Hi everyone!
I did some group research and couldn't find an answer to this question unfortunately, please correct me if I missed something üôèüèª
I am gluten intolerant and also really dislike seafood (anything that came from the sea except for seaweed).
I am wondering what kind of foods are something I can order in most places (not specifically gluten free restaurants), other than vegetable sushi?
Like, a common Japanese meal that is naturally gluten free (except for soy sauce) and doesn't have seafood in it.
I don't have an issue with cross contamination but I don't know Japanese and I don't want to spend too much time looking for food.
I have to say that going through the group posts I saw some great gluten free restaurant recommendations that I am hoping to try!
However, I am traveling with friends and we would rather find food where we travel and not travel depending on where the food is, if you know what I mean üòÖ
Thank you to the amazing community in this group!
It really gives me hope I won't be eating just sushi for 2 weeks üòÅ

ResponsesV2.Message:
Inbar Zoref I totally get what you mean about wanting to eat where you travel, instead of travelling to places you can eat. This is possible in Japan, in my experience, but only if you accept that there may be many many times when you are not eating with your group of friends. (Depending on where in Japan you are going of course). 
After I changed my ‚Äúfoodie mindset‚Äù of travel and instead focused on the people I might meet, the culture, the language, the history, the EVERYTHING that is so amazing in Japan, then it suddenly becomes quite acceptable to make do with daily 7-11 trips for food, added to with snacks I bring from home, and occasionally you get a wonderful experience of finding somewhere you can eat with your group and it becomes a wonderful highlight of your trip! Many restaurants in Japan are very small and I felt it unreasonable to take an extra seat to sit with my family while they ate, so often I would go for a walk and explore by myself, just taking in the sights, instead of the miserable alternative of watching my family consume bowls of udon. I hope you love the country and are prepared to ‚Äúfuel‚Äù your body with food that suits you, rather than experience the cuisine fully.

Yakiniku and yakitori with salt no sauce, salad without dressing (some mayonnaise brands have gluten here, and they also have a grain vinegar with gluten), rice, edamame beans! As said before sushi rice more often than not is prepared with a vinegar that has gluten!

Title:
#Himeji

Kushiyaki Kobe Beef is really close to the Himeji Castle entrance and he knew what I could have as soon as I mentioned gluten free. You can have either the skewers or the meat/rice bowls without sauce. I had the Kobe Beef Rice bowl and added my own soy sauce. I forget to take a photo but it was a decent size and really delicious.

Rice Flour Taiyaki Stand a block over from the road between the station and castle is a covered walking street with some cool murals on the ground. I stumbled across this Taiyaki store and they told me they were made with rice flour and all fillings were gluten free. I had the custard one but forgot to take a picture. I can‚Äôt remember the last time I ate something like this, so so good! I‚Äôve included some pics of the store and signs.

#Hiroshima

Caff√® Ponte I had planned to eat dinner here as they have a gluten free menu but we walked past too early for dinner and my feet couldn‚Äôt manage the walk back. Have included a pic of their menu.

MoreThan @ The Knot Hiroshima. They have a gluten free menu and OMG one of the best meals we‚Äôve ever had. I had the duck breast, my husband had the chicken and we shared a plate of vegetables. My husband isn‚Äôt a big veggie eater but tried and liked every vegetable, I wish we‚Äôd got the large plate! We had the cr√®me caramel and cheesecake for dessert. All of the dishes we ordered were gluten free. The service and food were incredible. Regret we only had one night in Hiroshima so couldn‚Äôt go back a second time.

MoreThan @ The Knot Hiroshima have a set menu with four choices. You can‚Äôt have the bread or sausage but it was more than enough for me without. 

#Miyajima

Miyajima Base. With the amount of food I‚Äôd eaten in the previous days I wasn‚Äôt overly hungry so I had three prices of chicken with sparkling lemonade for lunch.  The batter was seasoned and crispy, full of flavour and the chicken was tender and juicy.

Title:
I wanted to share my experience at a Michelin-starred restaurant in Kyoto called Takayama, named after the chef. The chef, who is young and humorous, studied in Italy and has extensive knowledge of gluten-free meals. When I made a reservation, I mentioned that both my son and I have celiac disease. Despite having to prepare 25 dishes, he managed to make all of them gluten-free, and even crafted a special gluten-free bread for us. The food was spectacular! Moreover, the wine pairing was exceptional.

The restaurant only hosts one seating per day, with a single table accommodating up to 12 people. The table is designed like an amphitheater, with the kitchen acting as the stage, where guests can observe the entire food preparation process. Additionally, the entire cooking team actively engages in conversation, taking turns to interact with the diners and share insights, making the experience both intriguing and entertaining.

I should also mention that the chef accommodated vegetarian guests, and both couples were delighted with their food.

I highly recommend this place for its exceptional dining experience, personalized service, and outstanding food quality. 

https://takayama-kyoto.com/en/

ResponsesV2.Message: Ooooooooo I‚Äôm definitely putting this on my list for my next stay in Kyoto! Thank you for sharing!

I have great news for everyone who wants to buy the Doraemon Tokyo Banana cakes: I contacted the manufacturer and was able to confirm that the ingredients are 100% gluten-freeü•≥‚ÄºÔ∏è

- The starch (denpun) used comes from corn.

- The sweetener (mizuame) used is made from corn and potatoes.

Note: These are still made in a factory that also processes items with wheat.

Title:
For those looking for solutions while at Disney, you have options. I tested out the service to have my food packet warmed. After a few misses, I was sent to a quick service restaurant ‚ÄúCape Cod cook-off‚Äù. I had to use a translation app to make the request. There are cultural nuances to living in Japan, but after working through that, it went well. I was presented with an iPad in Japanese verifying a disclaimer/waiver that the kitchen is not certified for specific allergies, etc. They confirmed how long to heat it and scurried off and another cast member seated us. Maybe 4 minutes later, the chef returned with a tray, a clean plate, cutlery, and my packet. 
Easy peasy!! I‚Äôll post the link to the microwave friendly page. It is on the TDR page under ‚Äúaccessibility‚Äù stuff. #tdr #disney #microwave #disneysea #tokyodisney

Title: I wanted to mention that we had no issues bringing in Gluten Free, Dairy Free & Nut Free processed foods to Japan. Read what you're allowed to bring in but definitely bring cereal, museli bars, breads, snacks etc. without meat or fish. It's so much easier to have a supply of familiar foods as, even though I've been organised and tracking this group for a while, you all know how looking for food can be stressful and time consuming. We have managed to find bits & pieces so far but a good supply from home will tide you over until you get additional supplies. We have a duffel style bag full of food which will become our dirty laundry bag at the end. We all have easy access to this bag if we need specific foods. Also, I booked the seats with extra luggage storage months ahead on the SmartEx app at this has been perfect for our suitcases & food stash. Currently on a bullet train & loving it! #customs #tokyo #shinkansen

ResponsesV2.Message: Thanks for the info. Can you take a picture of the SmartEx app?

Info for UK coeliacs: with a letter from your GP confirming diagnosis, you may be able to claim an additional cabin bag for free from your airline to pack gluten-free food. I haven't tried it myself, so I'm not sure what the ins and outs are, or whether only certain airlines offer the service. However, I've heard many stories from fellow UK coeliacs who managed to claim this successfully, so it may be worth investigating.

Title:

They also help with picking food out at grocery stores and convenience stores (combini)

Hi guys. Probably a stupid question, but for those of you who have taken your own gluten free soy sauce. Did you buy it at home and take it on the plane? ResponsesV2.Message: Not a stupid question. Yes, I take it on the plane. Sealed glass containers are not going to burst. Your main concern would be breakage, but just put the sealed container in a large plastic ziploc and gently wrap in clothes. I've never had an issue.

Thank you in advance!

A blogger said that the Ritz Carlton Kyoto was super attentive to dietary restrictions if that‚Äôs with your budget. This is my first post so I apologize in advance if I‚Äôve violated any rules.

I‚Äôve done numerous organised tours in Japan (mostly focussed on art and gardens) through Renaissance Tours in Australia. Not customised in terms of itinerary but they had no issue with arranging GF meals for me in restaurants or even picking out items from a convenience store for lunches on the run. The tour guides on the ground in Japan should have this expertise.
