Title:
Just returned from 2 fantastic weeks in Japan with 2 x GF/DF (dairy free) coeliacs and 2 x eat anything-ers. Very grateful to all those who have posted and mentioned places in this group - it was absolutely invaluable! The DF factor added another level of complication to several places, but we managed pretty well. 

Most of the places we ate at have already been mentioned here, but just thought I'd give a quick wrap up of where we ate and add some DF information for any GF and DF folks out there:

#tokyo
Gluten Free T's Kitchen (https://glutenfree.co.jp/home-en/) - classic spot for GF'ers in Tokyo. Highlights were the okonomiyaki and fried chicken. So good to have a place where all allergens are noted and easily identifiable.

Soranoiro ramen (https://soranoiro-vege.com/shops-en/soranoirotokyoeki.html) - was a bit tricky to find and a bit of a wait, but really good ramen. However, the GF ramen seemed to be much smaller in size than the normal ramen, so our GFers were left a bit hungry...

Shochikuen cafe (https://shochiku-en.jp/cafe/) - stopped for dessert here - the strawberry and lemon cakes here were a real highlight! 

Sushiro (Asakusa) - A sushi train chain restaurant with an allergen menu online, but we noticed that the names of the dishes on the allergen list and what was available on the in-store menu didn't always correlate. Sushi was average quality. No GF soy sauce in sight, so we used our own.

Nabezo (Shibuya) - Chain of sukiyaki/shabu-shabu restaurants. Seemed to be quite knowledgeable about GF and DF and let us know exactly what was safe and unsafe. They offered GF tamari and ponzu as well. Not sure we took full advantage of the all-you-can-eat menu, so go on a very empty stomach! :)

Rizlabo pancakes (https://www.rizlabo.com/) - Our GF/DFers loved these so much we went back twice! Only the strawberry and plain could be made GF and DF (without cream), as there is milk in the sauces for the other pancakes. Nevertheless, the strawberry was still a major hit!

Esoragato udon (https://www.instagram.com/esoragoto_udon/?igshid=NTc4MTlwNjQ2YQ%3D%3D) - we were so lucky to find this really great little place after quickly checking this group while we were away. If you are in the Harajuku/Shinjuku area do yourself a favour, get down here and get either the curry udon (if you like a bit of spice) or wagyu udon with an onsen egg - both were fantastic! Not sure if curry udon was DF, but all the others on the menu seemed to be. Don't be put off by the standing room only - food comes out in a hurry and is made to be gulped down quickly! We thought it was so good we went twice - and honestly, you couldn't tell the udon was made without wheat.

Hinomaru (yakiniku in Shinjuku) (https://www.hotpepper.jp/strJ001283896/) - The waitress seemed a bit perplexed when I explained that soy sauce contains gluten, but nevertheless, they brought out meat and veg to grill without any sauces or other seasonings on the top. We were then left to our own devices to grill away. Used our own GF soy sauce for dipping here.

#hakone
Nukafuku (https://www.instagram.com/nukafuku/?igshid=ZDdkNTZiNTM%3D) - right outside the exit of Gora station, almost missed it! Great little GF donuts that are donut shaped but actually taste more like cake. Noticed they also sell packets of the little GF soy sauce fish, packet GF ramen and GF granola (although this was out of stock when we visited). 

#kyoto

Sushi Naritaya (near Arashiyama)(Japan, „Äí616-8385 Kyoto, Ukyo Ward, ÂµØÂ≥®Â§©ÈæçÂØ∫Ëäí„ÉéÈ¶¨Â†¥25ÂµêÂ±±„Çπ„ÇØ„Ç®„Ç¢„Ç¶„Ç®„Çπ„Éà„Éë‚Äï„ÇØ) - had a long wait, but it was worth it for the very high quality sushi here. Staff were knowledgeable and guided us towards the GF/DF offerings (almost everything on the menu) and provided GF soy sauce as well.

Musubi sweets cafe (https://musubi-cafe.jp/arashiyama) - Stopped in here for cake one afternoon and were very glad that we did. Great little cafe - who would have thought that GF/DF tofu "cheesecake" could be so tasty! If we had been in the area again, would definitely have gone back here!

Choice (https://hs-choice.com/) - GF and vegan restaurant with really great meals and desserts. Also make really good smoothies and home-made cola. Highly recommended and would definitely go here again!

Ikkaukuju Karasuma (https://www.ikkaku10.com/) - GF okonomiyaki, teppanyaki and yakisoba restaurant. Were knowledgeable about GF and DF and gave us okonomiyaki without the mayo (apparently it has dairy in it). Yakisoba was very tasty as well. If you're hungry, make sure you go for the large sized okonomiyaki :)

Yak & Yeti (https://yakyeti.owst.jp/) - great Nepalese food. Were knowledgeable about GF and DF and had 1 set menu that our GF/DF duo could enjoy - substituted with poppadoms for naan bread. Very tasty curries!

Cafe & Bar Maru (https://maru.keika.kyoto/) - had a great dinner here. The owner was very friendly and very knowledgeable about GF and DF. Highly recommend the katsu, hamburger steak and fried chicken here. Took the whole family for dinner, so don't worry about the "bar" vibe in the evenings. Would definitely have gone back if we had more time!

Kyoto Engine Ramen - mentioned heaps of times in this group and was well worth going. Was a little skeptical after reading some google reviews saying "not authentic", "worst ramen" and "tourist trap". Although, maybe there is something wrong with us, because we all thought it was great! Sure, it's different to other ramen places, but it tasted great!

Torori Tenshi no Warabi-mochi ([https://www.torori-tenshi-no-warabimochi.com/](https://www.torori-tenshi-no-warabimochi.com/)) - Half of our crew were not sure about the squidgy texture and flavour combos of warabi mochi from here (green tea or roasted soy bean). Having said that, the other half really enjoyed it and it was GF and DF after all. Eat it over the tray as it has a habit of falling out of your chopsticks on to the ground :(

Waco crepes (https://www.wacocrepes.com/) - Great tasting crepes that are packed with filling. DF (or vegan versions) use coconut-flavoured cream as normal cream substitute (in case you are not a coconut fan). Choc-banana crepes were a highlight!!

#HIROSHIMA

Roopali Honten (www.roopali.jp) - very tasty Indian food. Were knowledgeable about GF and DF - said the curries could be done with a cashew base so that they were DF. Great value lunch sets that were yum!

#nara

Total Therapy cafe - Kururu (http://www.nl-kururu.com/index.html) - Appreciate the idea of this cafe, which is more or less summed up as "healing through food". Most of the menu seemed to be out of stock when we visited so we didn't get to try a wide variety of dishes. Curry and rice was pretty good, though.

#universalstudiosjapan

Had a great day at USJ and spent a lot of time researching where we could eat that would be GF/DF on the day. Got busted at the entry trying to smuggle our snacks in - manager was called over and we explained in Japanese that these were snacks for people with allergies in our group. He said it was fine to take them in, but we were not allowed to eat them out in the open and that they had allergen menus at many restaurants so could we please buy lunch there. We obliged and had lunch at the Parkside grill, where our GF/DFers ate from the allergy menu with a hamburger steak and teriyaki chicken. Honestly, for the price, these lunch sets were pretty good value - you wouldn't be able to get half as much for the same price at any theme park here in Australia. Staff were knowledgeable and came over and asked what the allergies were and then showed what could be ordered. Made the experience a lot less stressful, although there was a booking system for these restaurants in effect when we were there, so reserve your time early or you'll end up waiting around for an hour when you are already hungry!

A few other tips (if you're still reading):
* Took plenty of little GF soy sauce fish with us, but only ended up using about 3 or 4 (hot tip if you are in Australia - just pop down to your local Sushi Sushi and ask them if you can just buy the GF soy sauce fish - they gave us about 20 for a couple of bucks).
* Took 2 loaves of GF bread with us, but probably could have done with 1 extra as we found GF and DF bread pretty hard to come by. Managed to find some small rolls in a pharmacy just outside Nara station (Kinouta Pharmacy Nara train station, 8-1 Aburasaka Jikatacho, Nara, 630-8246, Japan), but didn't have much luck at any Natural Lawson's or other supermarkets in Tokyo or Kyoto.
* We did have some luck with GF cereal in Natural Lawson's - found some plain corn flakes at a few stores.
* If you are DF, soy milk is everywhere and comes in all sorts of flavours not available in Australia - chocolate, banana, strawberry, peach, melon, tea, tropical fruit (!!)
* BUT, we didn't manage to find any truly DF margarine while we were there. Plenty of margarine, but it all had at least some dairy mixed in.
* Our GF/DF crew were a bit over convenience store onigiri and boiled eggs after the first few days, so spread these out across your trip :)

Thanks for reading - happy to answer any questions!

ResponsesV2.Message: Brilliant review and tips (yes I read and took notes the whole way to the end üòâ). Thanks for taking the time! I‚Äôll be travelling with kids so this was especially helpful.
Omg thank you!! My husband is GF and DF abd I've been stressing! We are staying in yokohama, Hokone, Kyoto and Tokyo so this is a great help for us.

Title:
We just returned from my trip to Japan and I want to give a huge heartfelt thanks to the admins of this wonderful group!!

You know you did a good job when your 12 year old daughter with Celiac says, ‚ÄúMom, I thought you said it would be hard to eat gluten-free in Japan?‚Äù üòÇ. If she only knew the months and months of info I‚Äôve been collecting from this group to make it seem seamless.

To pay if forward here are a few of our experiences to help others‚Ä¶

#1 - we did a tour through Trafalgar (Tour name: The Splendors of Japan) and I was weary of their ability to help us with GF since other tours we‚Äôve taken in other countries didn‚Äôt do such a great job. They were fantastic! Every meal we had with them, which included a sushi class and specialty restaurants all prepared GF options without us saying a thing.

I had packed literally half a suitcase of food for her (I‚Äôm an anxious over planner) and she only had to use her emergency supply twice during a 9 day tour. Much of that was due to what I also learned in this group.

#tokyo

#whereisthedog
Near the #Ghibli Museum we ate at Where is a Dog (https://maps.app.goo.gl/Wnei9PLeppGVFxFG9?g_st=ic). What an amazing place of GF food. Home cooked and such friendly owners. We were also able to purchase GF bagels and muffins that turned into a life saver the next day.

There are tons of options in Tokyo. We were on the tour most of our time in Tokyo so didn‚Äôt need to use any of the group suggestions.

#kanazawa

#Aashirwad
I had planned for us to go to Love for All, but had heard mixed experiences in this group and then luckily stumbled on a post that mentioned they won‚Äôt serve kids due to having an alcohol license - that made me scramble, but I went to the highly recommended Aashirwad (https://maps.app.goo.gl/5deoUcBfvBAeNsBa8?g_st=ic) Indian food. They were English speaking and were able to clearly tell me everything that was GF on their menu (which was almost everything)! Also CRAZY good food.

#shiromcrepe
We also went to Sharon Creperie the next day (https://maps.app.goo.gl/Hs368ZvY5PQKHWob8?g_st=ic) for lunch. They had both sweet and savory GF crepes that were so delicious. We watched her make them in front of us and it was so fresh and well made. 

#kyoto

#gionsoymilk
GION Soy Milk Ramen Uno Yokiko (https://maps.app.goo.gl/6hQGJzwS947GGPDw9?g_st=ic) was so delicious and everything is GF, so my daughter got to try her first Goyza!

BONUS‚Ä¶ don‚Äôt miss this üëÄ
there is a Gluten Free vending machine in front of the restaurant that has GF desserts, including the popular cake-in-a-can as well as donuts. It was so fun for my daughter to be part of the vending machine experience üòÇ. They do come out frozen, so open it a bit later. We made the mistake of opening them and walking around with frozen cake while it thawed.

#ikkakuju
I was on the hunt to find gluten free okonomiyaki for my daughter. Luckily we were in the area where I pinned this restaurant: Ikkakuju - Shijo Shimmachi (https://maps.app.goo.gl/RgzpoeaGfAqUL5KN8?g_st=ic). She ironically didn‚Äôt get the okonomiyaki, but picked the risotto instead. It was the best risotto I have ever tasted. I enjoyed the okonomiyaki as well. All gluten free!

Also our hotel, Hotel Higashiyama (https://maps.app.goo.gl/aPYw5kBrNErQCwcHA?g_st=ic ) had a little counter of cookies beautifully packaged for gifts. they actually had a tin of gluten free cookies. Made for a nice gift for some GF friends back home.

#starbucks
Also, if you are in Japan before July 9th, 2024 try the banana br√ªl√©e line only available in Japan that is made from rice flour. I wouldn‚Äôt have known to look for it if it weren‚Äôt for this group (Christie‚Äôs post about it). It was SO good and it was a great snack at the airport where there were less options for my daughter.

I had so many places pinned on my google map because of this group. It made our trip so much less stressful.

Thank you üôè

It is very possible to have an enjoyable GF experience in Japan, especially with the advice and support of this facebook group ‚ù§Ô∏è.

ResponsesV2.Message: Following
Thank you for this generous post!

Title:
Hi all, 

We just came back from Japan after 15 days discovering this wonderful country. My husband is a symptom-free coeliac that follows a strict gluten-free diet, so we did a bit of research (thanks to this group and other blogs) and bookings before our trip to ensure he‚Äôd be able to try Japanese cuisine. Most of the times we base our trips on local food and restaurants, so we wanted to try as many real and local Japanese food as possible. 

Please note that as a symptom-free coeliac he doesn‚Äôt get any reaction in case of cross-contamination, but we did our best explaining how they should cook to avoid the risk. Of course, we were carrying our own gluten-free soy sauce everywhere and we brought madeleines and bread for breakfast. 

TOKYO: 
- Soranoiro Ramen (Tokyo Station): it took us a while to find it but it was worth it. 

- Kura sushi: I suggest to go during the first days of your trip, cause as the days go by and you try better sushi, the experience will be different. But we loved it. Gluten-free soy sauce was not available once.

- Shimbu Sakiya Ramen (Shibuya): we tried the fried chicken and the dumplings. They were really nice, and the ramen looked amazing.

- Tsukiji Market: although a bit touristy and overpriced, we found some places offering options that are naturally gluten-free that were really tasty: Grilled Wagyu Beef (amazing beef skewers) or Maguroya Kurogin (great sashimi and nigiris), or another one offering grilled crab. 

- Comburger (Cooking class in Shinjuku): can‚Äôt recommend enough this experience. We cooked at Sato‚Äôs place, who lived in the USA and moved back to Japan, a full gluten-free home meal (spring tofu salad, a super rich soup, chicken karaage/fried, and rice with seaweed). Super experience!

- Ise Sueyoshi: lovely kaiseki experience based on food from the Mie prefecture. We were only four, and my husband‚Äôs menu was completely adapted. The chef is well aware of the gluten-free diet. Highly recommended. 

- Yakitori alley (Yurakucho): we wanted to spot some salarymen afterwork, so we had a fun experience while eating salted yakitoris which were delicious. 

- Otsuna Sushi (Roppongi): great omakase experience. The chef was well aware of the gluten-free diet and adapted the menu to gluten-free. They also provided gluten-free sauce. Highly recommended. 

- Gluten free Kushiage Su (Ginza): it was a nice experience for only 6 people seated at the counter, everything is gluten free and fried skewers were nice. Personally, coming from Spain where it is easy to find gluten free deep fried food (mainly fish or croquetas using chickpea flour), this was a bit overpriced experience and I would probably not go again. But if you‚Äôre not used to gluten-free deep fried food, then you must go. 

- Hoshinoya hotel (Otemachi): no words to describe this incredible hotel. They were also able to accommodate the western breakfast to gluten-free, and gluten free bread was included! 

KANAZAWA:
- Omicho market: there were different options, mainly seafood. We also ended up having some sushi there. 

- Fuwari: they were aware of the gluten-free diet and provided gluten-free soy sauce. We had some lovely yakitoris. 

SHIRAKAWA-GO: we went for the day and we were trying to find a safe place to eat. Unfortunately some were closed (do not trust google‚Äôs opening and closing times in Japan, as many times it turned out to be misleading). However we found a meat place (yakiniku) out of the touristy area which was really nice. We had very nice Hida beef. 

TAKAYAMA: 
- Heinraku: it was an absolute pleasure. The restaurant is managed by a lovely couple that are well aware of the gluten-free diet and have a specific menu. We had great gyozas, fried chicken, and gluten free beer! Highly recommended. 

- Matsuki Ushi: again the times of some restaurants were wrong in google, so we asked in the lobby of the hotel for a place to have lunch and they recommended this one. Great Hida beef and wagyu nigiris! 

KYOTO: 
- Ikkakuju - Shijo Shimmachi: it turned out to be very close to our hotel and everything was gluten free. We tried the okonomiyaki for the first time and it was really nice. 

- Kyoto engine ramen: super nice ramen with different gluten free options. The soup was super rich and delicious. Highly recommended

- Kobe Beef Steak Mouriya Gion: amazing experience. The chef was well aware of the things that my husband could not eat and the meat was just delicious. Highly recommended 

- MOON and BACK Ramen Bar & Branch Cafe: incredible gluten free ramen. Different from the engine ramen, but also delicious. Highly recommended. 

-Breizh cafe: they had really nice gluten free cr√™pes. 

HIROSHIMA AND MIYAJIMA: 
- Caff√® Ponte: lovely terrace with an additional gluten free menu. Risotto was very nice. Not local food, but due to time constraints we didn‚Äôt have many options. 

- Miyajima Grand Hotel Arimoto: we were staying at this hotel which was well located in the island. For dinner, they offered a kaiseki course which was fully accommodated for a gluten free diet. It also included their local famous Oysters. It was lovely. For breakfast they could only accommodate the western breakfast. 

OSAKA
- Itamae Yakiniku Issho Edobori: we wanted to have dinner close to our hotel and it was amazing. They understood our needs and didn‚Äôt marinate the beef and explain what may contain gluten. The beef was amazing. Highly recommended 

- OKO takoyaki vegan vegetarian glutenfree: we had to try the takoyaki, and these were gluten free and nice. However, as non vegetarian we missed trying glutenfree octopus takoyaki, the famous one in Osaka. 

- Kitashinchi Okurano: no words can describe this kaiseki. We informed about the coeliac disease when we did the reservation and at first we were not sure they had understood it as we got an email in Japanese. The staff at the hotel called to be sure and they confirmed. We were seated at the counter, only the two of us, admiring how they were preparing the meal. So exquisite, so nice.. They fully accommodated my husband‚Äôs menu. They barely spoke English but we were able to communicate with a translation app. Highly recommended

- Sushi S≈çichi: also an unforgettable experience. We had an omakase course in a very local and tiny restaurant where the chef was extremely nice (although we needed to translate most of our conversations). He was able to accommodate all the food to gluten free and was fine with us using our own gluten free soy sauce (he even used it to prepare some courses)! Highly recommended, not cheap but definitely a delicious and unforgettable experience. 

Hope this helps those coeliac friends wondering whether to go to Japan or not. I definitely recommend you to go!! I have not included any reference to combini foods as there‚Äôs a lot of useful information in this group.

ResponsesV2.Message: Ti ringrazio tantissimo per le preziosi informazioni: tra 5 settimane partiremo e con mio figlio celiaci! Ciao
Following

Title: We are headed in September to Tokyo Disneyland, Disney Sea, and Universal Studios. If you have gone to all 3 of these theme parks or any, I would LOVE to see a list of your favorite GF meal (not snack) for each of these parks. Anyone? (Bonus if you have a photo!)

ResponsesV2.Message:
Tokyo Disney.
The kids meals is about all they offer and popcorn üòú
(Just not the soy sauce flavored popcorn)

I went to Tokyo Disney last August. I'm celiac, my partner is not. The park itself is well laid out and the rides are super fun. The food? It was really disappointing sadly. Finding gluten free was really hard. I had ice cream, and we did have lunch and dinner there, but the meals were very...blah. We went to that spaghetti restaurant on main street, and while they did have some gluten free pasta for me and soup and the like, it was bland. Dinner we did at one of the galaxy cafeterias by space mountain and it was... Not good. Sadly I was really disappointed by the the food and the lack of options. I would recommend bringing snacks to really supplement the hunger throughout the day. Pictured is the meal I had at the spaghetti place. I don't have a picture of the other one sadly.

Title:
Considering Ninja Tokyo. Others have posted here about gluten free options there. But when I go to reserve, I get this message: ‚ÄúFor gluten-free request, we omit breads and noodles to serve. Please note that we are unable to provide meals if guests are not allowed to eat soy sauce.‚Äù
Um, is their soy sauce gluten free????
(I have asymptomatic celiac and can tolerate low amounts of cross contamination)

ResponsesV2.Message: I would take them at their word. They can‚Äôt accommodate you.
If you're a celiac, you are damaging your intestines whether you can feel it or not.

Title:
Hello, I have been using this group so much and it has been so helpful in our planning. We are off to Japan in August and my 10 year old son is Ceoliac. I am just working through each day and making sure I have a list of places for where we are going to be. 
My question is for Disneyland/DisneySea - I see there are hot chips available and have noted that these are listed GF on a previous spreadsheet posted on the group. Do they use separate fryers just for the chips? I have searched the website and the allergen for the listed is soy. Will I need to check each restaurant while we are there? Sorry if it is a silly question but I am thinking hot chips will be a handy snack to grab for my son :) Thank you

ResponsesV2.Message:
Keryn, if you search Disney in this group you will see several posts from me with the link to the online Disney allergen tool. You can search in English by ‚Äòallergen‚Äô. In our case, it only lists wheat - there is no listing for gluten or other rye, barley, oats, etc so you have to be comfortable with taking wheat as a proxy for gluten. We do - my daughter is coeliac and also anaphylactic to some nuts and has had a scope soon after eating at Disney with no damage. Also, be careful as not all French fries at all locations are safe but the Disney tool will only list those with a separate fryer.
Here‚Äôs the link to save you the search: https://fsp.tokyodisneyresort.jp/en/s/info
F

Title:

Title:
Now that I have returned from my trip to Tokyo, I wanted to give back to this group some things I ate and found out. 

First off, yakiniku places were a lifesaver for me. All I did was Google places nearby and all of them that I went to either accommodated allergies or provided no sauce and switched out their grills for every new customer, so I felt safe. 
#yakiniku

Another lifesaver on days when I was too tired to venture out, was Frijoles and Guzman y Gomez. I stayed at Hotel Indigo in Shibuya and although they had a restaurant that had gluten free options, Frijoles was on the ground floor and is super quick and cheap. I just ordered a rice bowl at these "Chipotle" type restaurants to avoid any issues and never got sick. As for Guzman y Gomez, I ate there a few times when staying near Tokyo Disneyland as they have an allergy list and it was also quick and less expensive. 
#tokyo #disney

Also in the Ikspiari at Tokyo Disney, they have a Korean yakiniku called Yakiniku Toraji that took gluten free seriously and provided items without sauce and also their online menu mentioned if items had wheat in them. As for food at Disneyland and Disneysea, as others mentioned, the turkey leg, most popcorn, ice pops, and the curry were safe, but to add onto that, doing mobile order for quick service places was the easiest I found in checking allergies and getting food quickly. A lot of the times we beat lines,  and you can check each item for wheat. 
#disney

At Teamlab Borderless, they didn't have food but had a tea cafe, which I warn to be cautious. Their menu said drinks were gluten free but one drink was a barley tea labeled gluten free and that made me skeptical of all drinks. The yuzu green tea seemed okay. 
#teamlabborderless

At the WB Harry Potter Studio Tour, the food didn't seem safe aside from drinks, Butterbear, and popcorn. 
#harrypotter

Lastly, I relied on conbinis a lot for breakfast as most places don't open until 10am and we got up a lot earlier than that. My regular food was salted eggs, yogurt, apple juice, and whatever fruit they had available from strawberries to bananas, cherries and grapes. This was also a go-to if we couldn't find a safe place to eat nearby.
#conbini

Overall, what I found out from this experience is that Japan does take allergies seriously, but many places don't seem to fully understand the difference between wheat and gluten, cross contamination was less of a worry for me due to their cleanliness, and sometimes I just took chances on foods and hoped for the best. For instance at Tokyo Skytree they have a bunch of food places and there was a strawberry soft serve that I risked and it was delicious.  

I hope this is helpful and not too repetitive.

ResponsesV2.Message: Alternatively, my coeliac partner obtained GluteGuard in Australia and it was a game-changer for giving him assurance whenever there was confusion about the gf status.
BTW Guzman is awesome. We eat it in Australia without any issues

Title:
Highlight of our trip so far, Ramen cooking class with At home with Nahoko in Tokyo.

I was the only one in the group needing the gluten free, but she has the class so well organised and structured to ensure my food was prepared safely and away from the ‚Äòmuggle ramen‚Äô. (You can book a private class if you want to be certain of no cross-contamination, for me it‚Äôs not so much of an issue) 

It also meant that I still felt like part of the group throughout and got to learn the different recipes and method for both gf and regular by watching the others.

The ramen was hands down the best I‚Äôve had and I‚Äôm already looking forward to giving it a go back home. 

The best part of the day is Nahoko herself, she invites you into her home (which means you get to visit an off-the-beaten track part of the city) and she makes you feel very welcome. She is so knowledgeable and kind hearted. We learnt so much and left absolutely stuffed! 

Side note: We were there from 10:30-3:15 plus travel time from our hotel was about 1 hour total,  so we made sure we had the full day just for this and one easy activity in the early evening. You do need this much time as it‚Äôs a lot to go through and you want to enjoy it, not clock watch. 

If you have the time in your trip, I cannot recommend this unique experience enough! ü´∂

http://bit.ly/4144rwz

Title: What are people's thoughts on items that contain mizuame but are listed as "wheat free"? Specifically, I'm seeing it as an ingredient in a lot of the low allergen stuff at Disney. My understanding is that it could still be made from barley, but I've also seen posts from people saying that they've had things like the curry, ice pops, and turkey legs, so I'm very confused about whether those are actually safe.

ResponsesV2.Message: My understanding is that mizuame is usually not made from barley but it *could* be and there is no way to know without contacting the manufacturer. Barley is not an allergen in Japan so mizuame with barley could theoretically be used in their low allergen meals.
Hi üëã very sensitive coeliac here! I don't avoid mizuame (life is far too short) and have never had a reaction.

Title:
Hey.
In 23 days I'm going to Japan for the first time. Will stay there for a month in a hotel. I always thought it will be an incredible food journey, but now I'm celiac, lactose and fructose intolerant... I'm really afraid to eat out. To eat anything. Especially when I can't read or understand the language and don't know the products. Most fruits and many vegetables are problematic for me, just as the sugar in convenience products. I'm going to take gf soy sauce, rice cake/crackers and a few other things with me. I've safed places from this group for month now and I'm really thankful for all the info's about the celiac part, but I'm still so scared üôà all the food problematics are stressing me out. And on top of that I got a tendinitis in my left arm. I hope it's gone in 3 weeks üòÖ

Sorry, I just feel like I have to speak on all of that with people who understand.

ResponsesV2.Message:
Hi.  Not sure of your budget but we used Gluten Free Tours Japan for the first week of our trip and it was fantastic.  They asked about other intolerances as well, recommended restaurants, booked tables for us and if a restaurant wasn‚Äôt exclusively GF they would speak to the chef to make sure your food was safe. It was a good way to ease into the country before we were on our own‚Ä¶.

On the tendonitis front, I had tennis elbow before i left so bad that I couldn‚Äôt even lift a cup without pain).  I got a steroid injection the week before I flew out - best decision I ever made, pain gone within a couple of days, and no issues since.  Might be worth considering ü§∑üèª‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è

You will find it difficult, so prepare and take foods with you. I took freeze dried meals, dont take meat ones, not allowed in Japan. I took breakfast ones and dinner ones and carried these where ever I went incase I got stuck, all you need to do is add boiling water. I got them from Anaconda camping store. Would have a been hungry without them. Research places to go, but honestly, bring these meals with you. Have fun, Japan is amazing. Dont be insulted if you get turned away from restauraunts, they dont have the knowledge and dont want to make you sick. I was refused entry many times even when I asked for plain rice and boiled veg.

Title:
Okinawa Gluten Free Recommendations. Please see my notes for each place, not all are 100% gluten free so eat at your own risk. 

- Anjinmoko
This place is 100% gluten free and very safe, they also accommodate other allergies and have vegan options. My favorite here are the pancakes and the chicken sandwich. This is one of my favorites places. The owner is very kind and doesn't speak English, so please be patient and use a translation app if you need, but the menu is easy to understand. She knows me very well and will take good care you.

https://maps.app.goo.gl/9miNLzB2WTEQWkRU8?g_st=ic

- 52Hertz Cafe
This is also 100% Gluten Free and caters to other food allergies. The owner is super kind and loves taking care of people. She's Good friend and always willing to accommodate as much as possible! I love her karage and potato box, Fresh baked breads, as well as the burger plate. She has many other frozen foods you can buy to-go and cook in your hotel microwave or Air BnB.

https://maps.app.goo.gl/PweB1imF3akW5JNP7?g_st=ic

- Mama Lella
This restaurant is 100% Gluten Free and the owner converted this restaurant to be GF after realizing he had an issue. It's fantastic Italian Food and the owner (He's from Italy) is a great guy and runs the restaurant with his wife. Contact them ahead of time to make reservations. Definitely amazing food here and wine!

https://maps.app.goo.gl/yx5r9nNagZNCpJ7e9?g_st=ic

- Osteria La Pesciolin
This is an Italian restaurant specializing in seafood. It's NOT gluten free, however the owner here is my best friend and started preparing gluten free food for me. I go here at least once a week. You MUST let them know you are gluten free, speak to the owner Mr. Nasu and tell him Evan recommended it for GF pasta and ask what else he has available as well or what he can make you that's off the menu. Definitely try his fried mozzarella! He understands how to prepare GF foods and anything boiled or fried is done in non contaminated water/oil. He always has a great choice of fantastic wines and of course the raw oysters are sublime. 

https://maps.app.goo.gl/phyv98WZSQVNSrA57?g_st=ic

- Spice Cury Kofta
This place is also NOT a gluten free restaurant, but many of their foods are made safe to eat. You have to speak with the owner and his wife and let them know your needs. Anything and everything they make is fantastic.

https://maps.app.goo.gl/NZWv1xYcJ2rzUfu56?g_st=ic

- Cafe Halcyon
This is NOT a gluten free spot, but they make a gluten free crepe. It is cooked in the same area as everything else, so since I have celiac I don't eat the crepes here, if you're mildly sensitive you might be alright, I go here for their GF/vegan chocolate chip cookies!!! Go when they open because sometimes the cookies sell out.

https://maps.app.goo.gl/4tjjPp7FyWUQ9nRP8?g_st=ic

These are my main recommendations for safe eating. There are other places that say they have gluten free foods available, I don't try them because the risk is too high. I own a restaurant here called Bacon Bar Japan and I used to offer GF food but stopped marketing as such because we make our own breads/dough and cross contamination is very likely, I get sick often just working in my own restaurant, so be careful and ask questions when eating out. I tend to stay away from Japanese and Okinawan food restaurants because there's just too much of a risk, and many places will tell you their food is safe but they don't understand that Japanese soy sauce and mizuame as well as some vinegar has wheat. There is a fancy market called Rogers that sells a bunch of GF snacks that are imported from around the world, so check that place out if you need snacks. Good luck and be safe!

ResponsesV2.Message: Just ate at Mamma Lella last night! Very good and friendly owners. Cafe 52Hertz was closed when we arrived due to the rain we think so keep that in mind when visiting in the rainy season! Thanks for these recs, we had a wonderful stay in Okinawa.
This is incredible. Thank you so much üôèüèº

We're going back to Hakone this fall with my mom and we looked at several higher end ryokans and hotels but ultimately decided to go back to Yutowa because we had a very good time last year.

Not really an answer to your question as we didn‚Äôt stay in any of those. But if you wanted a recommendation we stayed at Gen Hakone Gora. They catered very well for gluten free, and catered for me not liking raw fish or tofu.

Title:
Sorry for the long post....

After seeing many posts including my own that mention things not being certified gluten free.  I did some googling. 

I wanted to find out if the Japanese 28 allergen system's "wheat" is similar to the certified GF in the US.  

It seems that in the USA, the FDA has a strict threshold of less than 20 parts per million (ppm) of gluten for a product to be labeled gluten-free. This is considered one of the strictest standards globally. While not mandatory, many manufacturers opt for third-party certification from organizations like the Gluten-Free Certification Organization (GFCO) to provide additional assurance. 

In Japan the threshold for gluten in gluten-free labeled products, instead, relies on a "not detectable" standard based on current testing methods. And like in the US, some manufacturers may voluntarily obtain certification from organizations like the Japanese Consumer Co-operative Union (JCCU) to provide additional assurance.

So if this is accurate, then the Japanese system might be even better than that of the US, but I do wonder what "Current testing methods" means, as I couldn't find details of what kind of equipment is used. 

IE If the US equipment is very sensitive, and the Japanese is not very sensitive then none of this means anything....  

If it is the same equipment in both countries, I would certainly prefer not detectable.  

Does anyone else know more about this?

EDIT:  I just found this. 

A landmark study published in the American Journal of Clinical Nutrition in 2007 found that 10 mg of gluten per day was the lowest level at which some individuals with celiac disease experienced intestinal damage (villous atrophy). And that 50 mg of gluten per day was considered harmful for most people with celiac disease.

So the current consensus is that consuming a diet containing less than 20 parts per million (ppm) of gluten is generally considered safe for individuals with celiac disease. This is because a diet at this level should keep most people below the 10 mg threshold when considering the cumulative amount of gluten consumed throughout the day. 

Personally I will try to avoid any at all, as I notice symptoms shortly after consumption, so villous atrophy, isn't my only concern.

ResponsesV2.Message: the usa is extremely bad as far as i've heard, apparently, like Japan, Barley isn't even considered an allergen. This is in contrast to Canada, Europe, Australia,New Zealand etc

In New Zealand and Australia (it‚Äôs a combined regulation authority - Food Standards Australia and New Zealand) they use testing kits that can measure quite low, so have decided that less than 3ppm is the accepted limit here. But like you‚Äôve described for Japan, in NZ legislation it doesn‚Äôt explicitly refer to the 3ppm - only that the product can claim it‚Äôs GF if there is no detectable gluten or oats or cereals containing gluten that may have been malted.

It‚Äôs interesting to think for example we sell Lindt milk chocolate here in NZ which contains barley so us coeliacs in NZ/AU naturally avoid it, but in the UK the same package can be labelled gluten-free because it‚Äôs less than 20ppm so coeliacs there will eat it.

Title:
LONG POST! Thank you to this Facebook Group for making our trip to Japan so wonderful!  We just got back and want to give back to this group for all the help you gave me in planning our trip so I could eat gluten free and delicious food.  Here are my tips and restaurant information to share:

Note that ALL of the restaurants listed here except one took credit cards!!  In my research I learned that most restaurants prefer cash.  That was not my experience, even in some small restaurants.

Not all of the restaurants are easy to find.  I recommend giving yourself enough time to get lost before your reservation time. Show up on time or a few minutes early for reservations in Japan.  It's not unusual for reservations to be cancelled by the restaurant if you show up 10 minutes late.  

Do your best to make reservations in advance for the restaurants below.  Things went much smoother when we had them than trying to find availability at places at the last minute.  

You can have a great time and enjoy delicious gluten free food in Japan.  It just takes a some planning in advance.  I hope this post helps you do that!  

**TOKYO:**

Gluten Free T's Kitchen: 2F, 7-8-5 Roppongi, Minato-Ku, Tokyo 106-0032

This restaurant was probably the most disappointing on our trip.  The food was not really great but, it was a relief to know that anything I ate there would not make me sick because the restaurant is entirely gluten free.  It does give a sense of comfort to those of us who are anxious about being "glutened" while on an international trip which is saying something however there are other restaurants that have been recommended by this group that are likely much better quality.

**Takayama:**

Sakurajaya Restaurant: 3 Chrome-84-13 Sowamachi, Takayama, Gifu 506-0007

This was one of the BEST restaurants we went to on our trip!  Highly recommend.  They happen to be open on Tuesdays which is a day that most restaurants are closed.  Food is AMAZING!  The owner/chef speaks some English and made sure I knew what was gluten free or could be made gluten free on the menu.  We had an awesome Hida beef dish that we are still talking about.  This was the one restaurant that did NOT take credit cards.  Cash is a must.

**Kyoto:**

Sugarhill Kyoto Restaurant: 600-8028 Kyoto, Shimogoyo Ward, Uematsucho 75

This restaurant will accept reservations via Facebook and reservations are highly recommended.  The food was fine, the prices were very reasonable and we had great service.  I got the chicken teriyaki, which most people had recommended in this group.  It was fine but not great.  Again, this is a restaurant that is great if you want to make sure you are not exposed to gluten but don't expect high quality food.  

Gluten Free Cafe and Bar Maru: 600-8012 Kyoto, Shimogyo Ward, Saitocho, 123 RAKAS, 3f

This was the other outstanding restaurant we experienced.  Highly recommend but know that it's difficult to find from the street.  It's located on the 3rd floor of the non-descript building it's in and has a very small sign on the side of the entrance door to the building.  If you come from the North, you may be able to see it.  If coming from the South, it's easy to overlook.  The building is next to a Family Mart which is easy to spot.  I asked the hotel concierge to make a reservation here on our behalf and glad we did.  The food was truly amazing and the entire menu is gluten free.  It's an attractive interior and most of the customers are westerners looking for high quality, gluten free food.  You will definitely get that here. We had a wonderful meal here!!

Waco Crepes: 605-0801 Kyoto, Higashiyama Ward, Miyagawasuji, 6 Chrome, 355-1

This is a fun, tiny restaurant that was also a little hard to find.  It's a small store front on a neighborhood street about 1.5 miles north of the Kyoto train station.  We had a great time and enjoyed the food at this restaurant.  Know that they are closed on Sunday, Monday and Tuesday.  The crepes were delicious and the staff speaks English very well.  Everyone eating there were westerners looking for gluten free food and we all enjoyed chatting about our travel experiences in Japan and sharing tips about gluten free eating in Japan.  It is a small, delightful place with creative crepe options to consider.  

Loco Chicken: „Äí600-8018 Kyoto, Shimogyo Ward, Ichinocho, 253-1 Ê≤≥ÂéüÁî∫‰ºöÈ§® 101

This is a tiny restaurant about .2 miles away from Nishiki Market.  They have gluten free fried chicken that's made with rice flour.  Delicious!  You may have to wait in line outside the restaurant for a seat (they have only 4 or 5 seats total) but it's worth the wait.  Service is fairly quick and the food was really delicious! It's considered fast food and no reservations are taken here.

Ikkakuju Karasuma Restaurant: „Äí600-8092 Kyoto, Shimogyo Ward, Shinmeicho, 248 „Ç∞„É©„É≥„Éª„Ç∏„É•„Éº„É´Á∂æÂ∞èË∑Ø B1F

This was a very fun restaurant that was also hard to find.  Look for the white Unicorn on the outside of the restaurant (it's placed there after 5pm) and take the stairs down to the restaurant which is underground.  We had a very authentic Japanese restaurant experience here that included taking off our shoes and cooking some of the meal on a shared grill in the middle of the table.  Very fun and the food was really good.  Let them know you have a gluten allergy before ordering.

**Kanazawa:**

Omicho Fish Market: 50 Kamiomicho, Kanazawa, Ishikawa 920-0905, 

Inside this market is a stall called Omicho Burgers. They were able to make me gluten free beef skewers that were made with salt (called Shio), not soy sauce.  It was a quick meal and very good.  Highly recommend if you need something quick and gluten free while there.

ResponsesV2.Message: TY for your post. Did you have to make reservations and what app did you use?
Thank you for your post!  So helpful! I'm looking forward to eating at some of these places!

Title:
One more thanks to the group post :-)

We went to CUPS Kamakura and and had very nice lunch. They said everything is gluten free. They have some #dairyfree items. But, I think cheese crackers that came with lunch might have cheese in them. They really tasted like real cheese but I didn't have any reactions. (I usually have delayed reactions to dairy but not all the time, though). My son, who gets immediate reaction to dairy didn't eat them so I'm not sure. 

Nice bonus was you can see the ocean while eating lunch! 

The closest train station is Hase on Enoden.

Thanks to this group, we did a Japanese cooking class at Tsukiji Cooking. We enjoyed it so much! 

We included that my son needs gluten free diet when booking. 
https://tsukiji-cooking.com/tsukiji-outer-market-tour-cooking-class/

When we got there, they already had "gluten free" sticker on the table. He was provided his own sushi rice, cooking utensils, and pans. The instructor said she receives gluten free or vegetarian requests quite often. My son was able to have the same kind of cooked eggs for the sushi that everyone else got. They are usually cooked with soy sauce, but I didn't taste soy sauce or maybe she used tamari. So, please verify if you have Celiac. 

It was fun and delicious!

Title:
Hi, I'm planning my trip - Tokyo to Osaka

Few questions, 
1Ô∏è‚É£ How much data would you, have used, had bought and not needed? 
2Ô∏è‚É£ Suggestions for foods to take into Disneyland, Disneysea, universal studios? 
3Ô∏è‚É£ Travelling around with food and snacks. I noticed it's not etiquette to eat and walk, is it fine to eat your own foods in restaurants or cafes?
4Ô∏è‚É£ The MOST used words that is a MUST for us to learn? 

Thanks!

ResponsesV2.Message:
We have T-Mobile, which has free roaming for text and data so we didn't buy an esim or anything like that. No extra charges on our bill after 2 weeks.

I took Larabars and That's It bars into Tokyo Sea and Universal with no issues last year in March.

Agreed do not take your own food to cafes/restaurants. The culture around those places is quite strict. It's hard to even find places that will allow you to sit without ordering anything, from my experience.

For speaking out loud, the main words for us were "arigatou" (thank you), "sumimasen" (excuse me), and "daijoubu" (that's OK, I'm OK). For written, ‰∫∫Âè£ is exit, as mentioned already. Â∞èÈ∫¶ is wheat if you're reading ingredient labels. È∫¶ by itself is grain and is used for all the stuff to avoid paired with something else before it, so that's usually what I look for.

I downloaded the airalo e sim just have to make sure your phone is e sim compatible. easy to use easy to top up in app .worked great under ground on train. I bought 1 gig for about 6 aussie dollars lasted me a week I used it while out mainly for directions and google translate then used wifi at hotel

Title:
Hi everyone,

We are planning to go to Japan in October. We will have 1 week in Kyoto and 10 days in Tokyo. My husband and son are both Coeliac. I've been keeping a list of all your recommendations of places to eat, so thank you!

Could you recommend accommodation that would be near GF places to eat so we don't have to travel a long way each time we need to find food? We are a family of 4 with 2 young kids.

ResponsesV2.Message: If you have the budget for it, a hotel that has a breakfast buffet or breakfast accommodations would be immensely helpful. Lots of places in Japan don‚Äôt open until after 10. There are some grab and go conbini options, but I found for our family that being able to eat a really large very filling breakfast helps so much with the rest of our day. Lunch we would either pack it to remove the stress of trying to be near a suitable location or plan for conbini. We planned to have the days‚Äô activities end near a pre determined place that had GF options (even if it wasn‚Äôt near our hotel, we planned to end our tourist activities near a place to eat)
If you don‚Äôt mind a small room gluten free T‚Äôs opened up their second location at a APA hotel I think in Akihabara.

Title:
Hi all,
Currently trying to organise a trip to Japan and trying to budget appropriately.

Would anyone be willing to share:
- How much you spent on your trip overall? (Please specify whether it‚Äôs your own currnecy or yen)
- Time of year you went and length of trip
- Any other relevant information (eg tight budget, spending lavishly).

It would be a big help! Thank you! ‚ù§Ô∏è

ResponsesV2.Message:
Where are you coming from? 

My daughter 8, was a newly diagnosed Celiac. 

We went LY, 3 weeks. 2 kids & 2 adults. AUD $20k for everything! 

We didn‚Äôt go lavish - I would say budget to mid range. We did have 3 nights in a Onsen ryokan which increased the price by about $3k.

We went in August - we attended a wedding. I would NOT recommend going in summer. It‚Äôs wayyyy too HOT! Go spring or Autumn.

Went last April. 14 days

Flight (Delta, Premium Selext, $2100 USD).

Gluten Free Tours Japan concierge service (approx 1200 usd)

Hotels for whole trip were only like total $800 usd.

Food I didn‚Äôt keep track of. I only had one really expensive meal.

Overall Japan is cheap in country, it‚Äôs usually the getting there that‚Äôs expensive. Gluten Free Tours Japan could be considered an extra because you can of course fend for yourself but I didn‚Äôt want that stress.

Title:
I just finished a 10 day trip in Japan as a newly diagnosed celiac (January 2024). It was an extraordinary trip and my gut has never been healthier (thanks, vegetables!). I‚Äôm grateful for all the tips I learned on this page and others.  Here is what I did to make it work for me.

1.  I bought the legal nomads card.  It was worth it. When I used it, folks read it very carefully, and were very considerate. https://www.legalnomads.com/gluten-free/

2. I learned about 300 words of Japanese using Duolingo and other sources. This enabled me to have basic conversations about what I could eat.  People really seemed to appreciate my efforts to speak Japanese. They were very very patient.

3. Ôøº I did a 7-day supported, self guided hike on the Nakasendo Trail, booked through Walk Japan.  Www.walkjapan.com.  I booked the trip before I had the celiac diagnosis, while I was still eating wheat and soy sauce. I had to pivot quickly. Walk Japan handled it superbly ‚Äì ‚Äì they got in touch with all the ryokan, and ensured that I had a gf feast at every breakfast and dinner. I still had to have conversations with innkeepers to avoid mistakes. But the result is that I did not feel deprived at all ‚Äì ‚Äì I had an extraordinary variety of local cuisines and specialties, and my gut was actually the happiest it has been since I got this diagnosis.  So I give huge kudos to walk Japan for the success of this trip.  (Originally, I was writing up every day on the trail on this Facebook group, including links to places mentioned in my posts, but not including links in the captions to the individual photographs attached to the posts; my posting privileges were suspended after two of these posts, and some photos deleted, when I did not include tags in the photos attached to the posts.  To avoid a repeat, I‚Äôm not going to attach any photos to this post.)

4.  In Tokyo, along with ‚Äúfind me gluten-free app,‚Äù I learned to love the ‚Äúdepachikas.‚Äù  See link below.  These are huge food halls and grocery stores under the biggest department stores.  Most of the food was not safe for celiac. However, at least in the grocery store portion, virtually all the sashimi, and most of the sushi, along with the produce, was safe.  The sushi and sashimi was beautiful, and well priced.  https://www.timeout.com/tokyo/shopping/best-depachika-food-halls-in-tokyo

5.  I bought snacks from home, and gluten-free soy sauce packets, oatmeal packets, peanut butter, and cheese.  I also brought a thermos for food. When I was on the trail, on days where I wasn‚Äôt sure if I could find something for lunch, I would make a thermos full of oatmeal mixed with cheese and peanut butter.  The food stayed warm in the thermos, and then I only needed to look for supplemental food like gluten-free, mochi, ice cream, things like that.

6.  Like other people, I supplemented with red salmon flake onogiri from 7-Elevens, and soft boiled eggs also from 7-Elevens (and other combini).

#nakasendo #tokyo

ResponsesV2.Message: Wow, I am so glad to hear about Walk Japan and that they will arrange gluten free food with the inns. I had done a walking tour with Oku Japan before my diagnosis and wanted to do one again, but when I contacted them about the food they said they could not help. Sounds like a huge difference! Thank you thank you thank you!

Great work! I don‚Äôt eat oats (Aussie so it doesn‚Äôt meet the PPM standard) but I can‚Äôt quite get over oatmeal, cheese and peanut butter! Very interesting combo! Well done on your success and thanks for the tips üòä

Title: Looking for local recipies! What are your hacks for cooking gluten free in Japan?  Do you make your own bread and pizza? Have alternatives? Live only on rice based dishes?

ResponsesV2.Message: You can eat pretty much anything/type of food you want here and keep it gluten free. Tell me what you're interested in eating  and I can help you with creating a recipe, or if you want I can give you some simple recipes with ingredients found in local supermarkets!

I also cook very simply. I think of it as nutrion
... So protein is my focus and just add rice. But I am having a bread kick and I luckily work near places with gluten free bread. 

If I had an oven I would be making gluten free pizza toast or casseroles. 

My current obsessed recipe is a mix of stuff made up. 
Edamame, pea, kidney beans and tofu mix with tomato sauce. I put garlic and oragano in it. I serve it on top of rice. I'm not a recipe person I just mix some stuff I want nutritionally.

Title:
Hey everyone! so last trip I compiled a few things things that was safe for me to eat. (Super sensitive Celiac) Most drinks should be fine but google translate is always a life saver! (These are Google translated)

1. ***Salted Rice Ball 7-11

Clear Package Onigiri Ingredients***: Non-glutinous rice (domestic), salt, seasoning vinegar, vegetable oil, fat

***Brown Package Onigiri Ingredients***: Non-glutinous rice (domestic) Dashi, seasoned vinegar, sake, kelp tea, salt, vegetable oil/seasoning (amino acids, etc.)

I Prefer the Clear package over the Brown one since it has less ingredients at the chance of cross contamination

2. ***Tropicana Essentials! (Mango, Orange, Peach Blend)

***3. ***Mentos! (Grape, Orange)

Orange Ingredients***: sugar, starch syrup, vegetable oil, concentrated orange juice, starch, dextrin, cocoa butter/acidulant, fragrance, thickener (polysaccharide thickener, CMC), emulsifier, brightener, carotene pigment, (Partly contains orange)

***Grape Ingredients***: Sugar, starch syrup, vegetable oil, concentrated grape juice, starch, dextrin, cocoa butter/acidulant, flavor, thickener (polysaccharide thickener, CMC), emulsifier, brightener, grape skin Pigment***
***
4. ***Kagome Vegetable Life Smoothie! (Rich Banana Smoothie)

***5. ***Calbee Jagariko (Salad Flovor)
 
Ingredients***: Potatoes (domestic), vegetable oil, dried potatoes, powdered skimmed milk, powdered vegetable oil, milk-based food products, salt, dried carrots, parsley, pepper, emulsifiers (including soybeans), seasonings ( Amino acid, etc.), antioxidant (VC), fragrance

6. ***SOYJOY (Chocolate and Almond)

Ingredients***: Soy flour (manufactured in Japan), almonds, margarine, fat sugar, eggs, chocolate (contains milk components), indigestible dextrin, agave syrup, cocoa powder, inulin, salt/fragrance

7. ***Lipton Milk Tea!

Ingredients***: Sugar-mixed fructose-glucose liquid sugar (manufactured in Japan), dairy products, sugar, coconut oil, black tea/fragrance, emulsifier, pH adjuster

Again you dont have to take my word for it but I did do alot of digging into the products before I decided to tested them myself.

Most of these can be found in local supermarkets or conbinis :D
if anyone has anything they can recommend me when I'm there in a few days that would be awesome :D

Title:
Hey all!! 

I currently live in Japan but I‚Äôm leaving for a trip to Thailand on Friday and I have a pretty severe allergy to barley, and then mild reactions to wheat, rye, and oats. Does anyone happen to have an allergen card for gluten in Thai? 

I know it might be a bit of a stretch, I was going to try and get by on antihistimines and being careful but I got gluten-ed last night and reminded of why I shouldn‚Äôt do that üò≠

ResponsesV2.Message: Unfortunately I can't help you with the card, but I will say that having been to Cambodia and Vietnam (both also on the Indo-China peninsula), I found navigating celiac so much easier there.  English is more widely spoken and as barley and wheat can't be grown in those climates, most products are soy and rice based because it's cost prohibitive to import wheat/barley.  Thai food is actually one of the few things that's typically a slam dunk for me!  Good luck and hopefully your experiences are similar to what mine were in Cambodia and Vietnam.

Thailand used to be easy but not so much now that soy sauce is creeping onto a lot of things it didn'tused to. Also the fish sauce brand that's used a lot there contains gluten as part of the colouring. It's totally doable as a country (especially if you're staying in larger cities) but you'll need to ask for no soy sauce, no fish sauce, salt and sugar only. Another tip I got from within a gf group is don't ask 'does this contain soy sauce or gluten', ask 'what ingredients are in this'? I've forgotten the name for the custom, but in a lot of south east Asian countries it's culturally important to please visitors, so you'll often be given the answer the local person thinks you want to hear, which in a coeliacs case can cause issues. There are quite a few gf cards, but you also need to be cautious eg look at the cooking area and implements if you can. I avoided eating at a few places the rest of my travelling companions did,as even though I believed the cook would change ingredients for me I could see how much Seasoning g was locked into cooking implements. I was also fortunate enough to have access to a fluent Thai speaker for several of the meals on my trip. 
If you get exhausted double checking all the time there are some specially places in Bangkok and Chiang Mai that   are either dedicated gf or are low gf for their menu and understand c/c they won't guarantee it, but I'd say excluding flour in the air or a total accident from staff they'd be as safe as you can get out of a dedicated gf venue - though they tend to be more western and often double as a vegan venue.

Title:
ATTENTION for Coeliacs going to  
‰∫¨ÈÉΩ„ÇÇ„Å°Á≤â„ÉÅ„Ç≠„É≥Â∞ÇÈñÄÂ∫ó LOCO CHICKEN in Kyoto.

I had long looked forward to eating here and had read some wonderful reviews.

Today we attempted to go but the very kind and knowledgeable chef who spoke good english explained to us that; 

These last three days, *nothing* that they offer on the menu would be considered safe for a coeliac. 

The reason is that they use 2 types of french fries, one GF and one type that is not GF. 

Today the fries were actually GF, but the oil in which they *(and the chicken)* was fried in was not changed since the ‚Äúnon-GF‚Äù chips were fried in it 3 days prior.

Such a shame, but I am so grateful for the lovely staff‚Äôs awareness and helpful advice.

Just a heads up to anyone coealiac who might pop in assuming most things were GF and not cross contaminated - always confirm on the day!

If you're Tokyo/Shinjuku/Shinagawa/Shibuya-based during your trip, and heading to #kamakura  or #enoshima I suggest you "force" a train change (connecting train) by #Ofuna

Let me count thy ways:
1. BIO-RAL (inside Grandship Mall connected to the train station). Not all Bio-ral branches are created equal. I always go here for gluten-free loaves and gluten-free ready-to-eat Financier and Rucola bars. The microwaveable steamed breads are yummy, too, but since I live  here, I usually opt to make my own mug cake at home using my almond flour stash. Today, I was thrilled to find gluten free shumai and gyoza, gluten free beer, sooooo many gluten free cookie brands (I got Miso flavor from Bio-ral home brand and Maple from Ohsawa brand). They have lots of senbei (salty, spicy, sweet) which are "naturally" gluten-free BUT of course, check the other ingredients (I'm gluten intolerant and I don't react to soy sauce and cross contamination). I usually buy gluten free pasta, there, too, and other condiments. They have rice flour cakes, too (I didn't check cross-contamination).
2. JUPITER (inside Grandship Mall too). They have lots of crisp breads and corn chips, popcorn, and chocolate that are clearly marked gluten free. They have lots of cheese, spreads, and hummus that have no wheat or Â∞èÈ∫¶Á≤â (I don't check other ingredients). I also usually get my olives and saurkreut here. 
3. THAT SUSHI SHOP. I always go here but I don't know the name. I've done 100-yen sushis, Tsukiji sushis, and "it's a date so let's spend sushi" but this shop has really good and fresh stuff. They assemble the negitamago don freshly, as well as the tuna bowls. They have sashimi and rice sold separately, too. I can speak Japanese, but I bet with an allergy card or a Google translate that requests no soy sauce, etc., extra GF sensitivities can be accommodated. It's an unassuming shop beside a pork cutlet shop, in the hallways connecting Bio-ral and Jupiter. 
4. DOURAKU, GYUKAKU, and a few yakiniku shops right outside the Ofuna train station. You grill your own meat here. So with allergy cards, they could serve you raw meat for grilling. 
5. STARBUCKS in Grandship Mall has the Rice flour Matcha Cake and choco muffin.
6. „Çµ„É≠„É≥ „Éâ „ÉÜ „ÇØ„ÉÅ„É¶„Éº„É´ „Éû„Éü„Éº„Éï„É¨„Éº„Ç∫ „Éñ„Éé„ÉØ„Éà„É≥ „Ç∏„É£„Éù„É≥
Salon de The Couture Mommy Fraise Benoitton Japon. Hidden gem. 10 minutes walk from the station. Does not easily come up on Google Search as name is not in English. 
Japanese thick pancakes, galettes, cakes, tea. YUM. 
https://maps.app.goo.gl/JVu1JA7usLqHBM8i6 
7. MILLOW KITCHEN Yokodai. It's 3 train stops from Ofuna (about 15 minutes), but worth it if you want a good meal. Not a dedicated GF facility, but very GF knowledgeable. Fryer and soy sauce are GF. They have good vegan options, too.
https://maps.app.goo.gl/5cV4u5N3Y2Xumrn29
8. SEIYU OFUNA (5 minutes from the Station). I buy gluten free rice flour canelle mix here for cheap (sold with the pancake or cake mixes). They have lots of fresh sashimi, lots of fresh fruits, veggies, nuts, chocolate, ice cream, etc. Very cheap compared to Tokyu Supermarkets and Seijo Ishii. If I'm in the area, I usually get my food for the week ingredients here. I haven't checked lately, but they should usually have Tamari soy sauce. 
9. DON QUIJOTE (across Seiyu). Not necessarily a GF place, but if you're grocery shopping and you have company that needs amusement, THIS.
10. DAIKOKU DRUG STORE OFUNA (corner shop fronting the Kasama Exit side). Not a GF place, but another place for souvenirs and Japanese health and beauty stuff for cheap. Lotions, makeup, serums, creams, shampoo, cheap chocolate and snacks for giveways.I usually buy my collagen and facial moisturizing masks here. 

I have other reasons, but I was supposed to be editing an academic paper todayüôâ not writing one, so I'll stop. üòÖ Let me just say if you're #Yokosuka or #Kamakura bound, Ofuna is worth a stop over. ‚ù§Ô∏è

Title: I just want to add a very surprising, unique and utterly delightful - even if expensive - authentic Japanese but GF experience in case anyone on this forum is heading there and wants to experience this. I had the most amazing GF teppanyaki meal, cooked and served with utmost consideration, care and expert craftsmanship at the 5* Okura Hotel in Huis ten Bosch (among the stunning multiple-island scenery in Sasebo, Kyushu). Not only did I get to enjoy a top-class 9-course meal including several different cuts/styles of wagyu beef, a half a grilled lobster, grilled scallops and vegetables, and two delicious soups (a Dutch-style creamed onion and a Japanese-style cockles with seaweed in broth),   but I also got to watch the colourful night-time illuminations overlooking the huge, Dutch-themed park (this hotel is actually designed to resemble Amsterdam's Centraal Station). Including a glass of superior plum wine on ice, the bill came to just over ¬£100, but it was totally worth it just to watch the very exacting care the chef took to clean the grill surfaces thoroughly and then prepare my GF beef + garlic fried rice seasoned simply with olive oil, salt, pepper and butter. It was awesome and will remain a top memory of Japan! #teppanyaki #teppanyakigrill #huistenbosch #sasebojapan #hotelokura

ResponsesV2.Message: Please add the address + related hashtags~

Huis Ten Bosch is one of the weirdest (yet really wonderful) places in Japan. I had a season pass years ago (pre diagnosis).

 Never stayed at the hotels or dined at one of their upscale restaurants, but now I'd love to try! Thank you for sharing.

Title:
Hey everyone üëãüèª 

I am living at Wako-shi and I am looking for some place close to me to go out.

I tried to order some food from restaurant in Tokyo, but I am a little bit too far. So, I can‚Äôt order. 

I am having a bad day and I just want some good  (safe) food not cook by myself üòÖ 
Otherwise if you know where I can find good gyoza around there ü•ü It will be great 

I checked ‚Äúfind me gluten free‚Äù and made a research in the group but found no one speaking about Wako-shi ü•π

ResponsesV2.Message:
I live even farther down the line in Saitama than you do! 
Since there basically zero gluten free options out here, using UberEats to get kaiten sushi (Like Kappazushi or Sushiro!) is my go-to if I‚Äôm too exhausted to cook. Plain raw nigiri is fine, don‚Äôt get anything grilled or seasoned. Use your own gluten free soy sauce and don‚Äôt eat the pickled ginger!

I lived in Wakoshi for 2 months last year and unfortunately I wasn‚Äôt ever able to find anywhere I could eat out nearby. If I really wanted to eat out, I would take the Fukutoshin line to Shibuya for ramen at Shinbusakiya.

If you are ok with some risks for cross contamination, there‚Äôs a Muji in Wakoshi which has packet curries (I‚Äôm not usually ok with cross contamination but I made an exception for living in Wakoshi because honestly I needed easy meals and it felt like a mental health vs physical health trade off I was willing to make. Also I didn‚Äôt see the cross contamination warning the first few times I ate these lol). There‚Äôs also Seijo Ishii at both Wakoshi and Narimasu stations if you have cooking facilities - they have pasta, bread, etc. The supermarkets in the area don‚Äôt have much that‚Äôs GF except ice cream and some puddings. I also did a lot of shopping in Ikebukuro because I found they had a lot of international foods.

I think there‚Äôs a Coco curry place near the train station, but I didn‚Äôt visit. 

I had a kitchen and basically cooked, ate Muji curry or conbini onigiri, or I took the train into Tokyo. Shinbusakiya can be reached in about 40 mins if you take the fast train, which is why it was my go-to.

Hope this helps!!

PS: if you‚Äôre in Wakoshi for RIKEN please please keep in mind that the rice in the cafeteria contains barley!
