Title:
I went to Tokyo, Hakone, and Kyoto in November of last year and had a great time! I'm celiac and was very worried about traveling safely. My research and this group really helped me. I bookmarked all the restaurants listed in this group that are GF. I saw that at least five were in the Roppongi area, so I booked a hotel in Roppongi (APA Hotel Roppongi Ekimae). I figured if I had to eat at those five places, I could simply rotate. These places were:
* Gluten Free Ts (yummy dumplings)
* Otsuna Sushi (omg so good)
* Lobelisk (upscale and unique)
* NachuRa Gluten Free cafe (love the sweets)
* Cafe Komaya (cute spot)

Things nearby that I wasn't able to try but noted bc of gluten-free options:
* Freeze and Sleep Glue 10 Free 
* Jomon Roppongi 

I had yogurt and fruit in the morning and had the salmon and salt onigiri from 7-11 with my own tamari packets that I brought for lunch. I had almond packs for snacks. 

Not in the Roppongi area, but I loved eating at:
* Gluten-free Kushiage Su (incredible, worth it) 
* Rizlabo (the pancakes are to die for, so unique)
* Gonpachi (very knowledgeable, so tasty) 

In Kyoto, I ate at Engine Ramen and there was a place in the market that had GF Matcha Cake (forget the name). Also got plain sashimi and shio style skewers at the market. 

Hakone was the one place I struggled with food. The onigiri was sold out and most places couldn't accomodate me. I was able to eat Box Burger with lettuce instead of bread. I knew I was risking cross-contamination but they assured me they would clean it as best as possible and I didn't have a reaction. 

Anyway, I had a fantastic time and didn't get sick. Having a translation card, tamari packets, and almonds really helped. I relied heavily on onigiri and yogurt and stayed near places I had researched ahead of time. 

It sucks that we can't be spontaneous anymore but planning like this really helped me enjoy my trip. Sorry if this is redundant with some other posts, but wanted to share my experience. I had the trip of a lifetime in Japan and am so glad I went. #Tokyo #Hakone #Kyoto

ResponsesV2.Message:
Great information, thank you! 
How or where did you find the translation card?
Did you bring the tamari packets from home or find them there?

Title: Hi everyone, I'm a coeliac travelling with a "Muggle" (don't worry, I say it to his face too üòÇ). It's a big birthday for him and he wants some of the experiences that don't offer gluten free/allergy friendly alternatives. Is it considered rude if I was to go along and not eat anything at restaurants? Tokyo if it makes a difference

ResponsesV2.Message: You could just order something to drink. Or usually you can get a salad with no dressing or croutons if you are very specific. Or a bowl of white rice that comes with a tiny dish of chopped fresh green onions. (I take nuts in my purse and sprinkle some on a bowl of white rice.) Boiled edamame are sometimes available as an appetizer.
Some restaurants has the rule that everyone have to eat.

Title:
I wanted to thank everyone on this group for all the help and advice. Just got back from 2 weeks and couldn't have done it without you (GF Tours were booked out already). Thank you especially to the moderators and the regulars who keep it going. 

I'll give my two cents worth for the next traveller...I did get glutened, more below. 

**Air Korea. **Airline meals were decent and clearly labelled (apart from one bread roll which I decided to not risk). 

Tokyo - 

**Kura Sushi.** The flagship branch in Harajuku is not that big and really busy - we got a ticket in person and came back for our time but even then had to wait almost 2 hours for our number to come up. Great fun for the kids though. In Shinjuku we booked on an app and there was much less of a wait. The allergen menu is online and I used my own soy sauce. 

**Soranoiro Nippon** at Tokyo Station. This was really good. Got there around 11.30am and had to queue a bit so careful if you plan to go for lunch and you have a train to catch. The place is small so you have to wait for one in one out tables. 

**Gluten Free Ts** - grateful to have a place where I could eat everything we all ordered but the food was just 'ok'. 

**Genuine Where Is a Dog**. Yes, you have to find the dog! This is a lovely place where the 2 owners work really hard to get all the food out to everyone, be patient. After eating a lot of seafood it was lovely to eat salad and humous and soup. Lovely fresh rice bread and I bought baked goods to have the next day too. 

**Rice Hack. **Yes, very delicious and fresh, as others have said. 

**Riz Labo. **We got there 15 mins before it opened and there was a queue behind us soon after. These were great and light as air - not super filling. 

**Otsuna Sushi.** These guys were really great when we had to leave our course menu half way through (my daughter wasn't feeling well). Thank you Otsuna. 

**The Knot** - this was a hotel and there was salad (own dressing) and fruit I could eat at the breakfast buffet. There are probably better hotels for GF though. 

**JR Kyushu Blossom hotel**. This was great location but really not much to eat for breakfast. 

Kyoto - 

**Waco crepes. **I was nervous about the oats but actually I was fine and the crepes were delicious. Factor in a queue. 

**Gion Soy Milk Ramen**. Also factor in a queue. Hot tip if you are a group of 4 to list yourself as 2x 2 and sit separately. Food presented beautifully and large filling portions. Impressed with the noodles - so bouncy!

**Engine Ramen. **Got there at 4.30 for 5 and already people queuing. But a big restaurant so we all got a table when they opened. Again, good bouncy noodles. 

**Sugarhill. **I got glutened here, possibly my fault as I totally relaxed when the server took our order and asked if there were any allergies up front. I ordered a ginger and lime soda which could have been the culprit. I was also suspicious of the Japanese mustard which came on the plate of my gluten free chicken dish. 

Osaka - 

**Comeconoco**. They had sold out of sandwiches by the time we got there, so we had cake for lunch. The cream puff - possibly best thing I have ever put in my mouth! 

Takayama - 

**Heinraku**. Just a totally delightful experience from start to finish. A cosy and homely place with lovely owners and good home cooked food. Come with an empty belly. 

**Fukyuan. **Another cute and homely place with a lovely courtyard to look out onto. GF fluffy pancakes but what I liked the most was the warabimochi with soybean powder (although maybe not to everyone's taste). 

**Wanosato. **This was a totally amazing ryokan experience. Unfortunately I think I got slightly glutened here but they really tried their best and I can only thank them for that. What really stuffed me up was the 2 x onigiris that I followed up with on the train back. I had been sticking to the 7-11 red salmon and salt but - as seen in posts on here - they appear to have changed their recipe halfway through my trip! Face palm emoji x 100!!

This was my 3rd time in Japan but my first since coeliac and even though I did get sick, I still want to come back again. All the GF places were highly popular so hopefully they will spread as a good business opportunity.

ResponsesV2.Message: Robert Sussman
Summer Gidewall -  GF Ts (certified), Rice Hack, Riz Labo, Gion Soy Milk, Comeconoco, Waco Crepes (gf oats) and Where is a Dog all fully GF.

Title:
My turn to give back to this group that helped me so much! Here it goes:

Osaka:

1. Gengi-soba. They serve GF ramen and GF tempura! Good understanding of celiac.
üìç https://maps.app.goo.gl/PVU8SFH74Ebhiu4Y6?g_st=ic

2. Matsusakagyu Yakiniku M Dotombori Sennichimae Branch. It‚Äôs a hot pot on a grill. The entire family loved it and they have GF soy sauce.
üìç https://maps.app.goo.gl/36gSh9bMjGc9RDfa9?g_st=ic

3. Gluten Free Cafe & Shisha Bar Anosaki Konosaki. It was an ok place. It wasn‚Äôt a very popular place for the family but good if you‚Äôre looking for something in the area. I completely forgot to take any pictures! ü§¶üèª‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è
üìç https://maps.app.goo.gl/8jcgUu1jxXbfxo6S9?g_st=ic

4. Comeconoco Gluten Free Cafe. The cakes here are to die for!!! Amazing desserts and they have lunch boxes that include salad, scones and a sandwich. Loved it all!
üìç https://maps.app.goo.gl/Bd6iS5Yd2om5UagW6?g_st=ic

5. Hard Rock Cafe, Citywalk Universal. It‚Äôs Hard Rock Cafe so they‚Äôre knowledgeable about allergies.
üìç https://maps.app.goo.gl/9cLJRYPPrJu7gnLP9?g_st=ic

6. Otis! This is a tiny little shop in Hiroshima where we went for a day trip. Amazing food and great value for your money! The owner is a sweet old man that understood cross contamination and kept us at ease! We had a reservation for 1pm on a Monday but there was only one more party there when we walked in.
üìç https://maps.app.goo.gl/8aCVEtWLQnRMpfxb9?g_st=ic

7. Throughout all of Osaka, we ate mochis, candied fruit and on occasion, fresh grilled beef and seafood from street vendors after talking via google translate and ensuring it would be safe.

Kyoto:

1. Sugarhill Kyoto. Best chicken teriyaki I‚Äôve had and great knowledge of celiac and cross contact. Resos highly recommended. [@sugarhillkyoto](https://www.instagram.com/sugarhillkyoto/)
üìç https://maps.app.goo.gl/ZbwQibskEGC6HLYC6?g_st=ic

2. Caf√© & bar Maru Gluten Free. 100% GF and best service! Resos highly recommended. [@gluten_free_kyoto8](https://www.instagram.com/gluten_free_kyoto8/)
üìç https://maps.app.goo.gl/ct1Q8AiPNGSM91WP8?g_st=ic

3. Ginsui. If you‚Äôre picking only one place in Kyoto, make it this one! It‚Äôs an experience! Must make reservations. [@ginsui1937](https://www.instagram.com/ginsui1937/)
üìç https://maps.app.goo.gl/uCCeEhTtayXDJDn39?g_st=ic

4. Waco Crepes. I still dream about the ham and cheese crepes. If you‚Äôre not a sweet tooth, skip the whipped cream crepes. Check their IG and go as soon as they open as they run out early. [@wacocrepes](https://www.instagram.com/wacocrepes/)
üìç https://maps.app.goo.gl/ejKA71HskMZ8Psme8?g_st=ic

5. Kikyo Sushi. If you‚Äôre into sushi and raw fish, this is the place for you. They even have GF soy sauce and understand cross contamination. Resos highly recommended.
üìç https://maps.app.goo.gl/MfJjihYCjkghRqaY7?g_st=ic

6. Throughout all of Kyoto, we ate mochis, candied fruit and on occasion, fresh grilled beef and seafood from street vendors after showing my GF card talking via google translate and ensuring it would be safe.

Tokyo:

1. Gluten-free T‚Äôs kitchen (Roppongi location). Amazing amazing amazing! 100% GF. Resos recommended.
üìç https://maps.app.goo.gl/HBfswRcVCbq94PBV9?g_st=ic

2. Gluten-free T‚Äôs kitchen (Ueno location). Amazing again! 100% GF! We walked in and got a table right away.
üìç https://maps.app.goo.gl/NA31M2LqA1xzG1Lo8?g_st=ic

3. Carniceria Meat Shop Grill & Wine. We stumbled across this while walking and used my GF card and google translate. It‚Äôs in the basement of Parco building. Food was great!
üìç https://maps.app.goo.gl/oivhqvmUNXAkBKgGA?g_st=ic

4. Un-Gluten. This is a 100% GF pasta place. The food was absolutely delicious!
üìç https://maps.app.goo.gl/5zsS3hRmrQizrvUY9?g_st=ic

5. Kuroboshi Sweets Asakusa. This place is a gem and they have the most delicious GF churros!!!
üìç https://maps.app.goo.gl/ZZjzUAC8gehK5q3R8?g_st=ic

6. Shark Coffee in Shibuya. Delicious GF pastries. We stocked up for breakfast at the Airbnb.
üìç https://maps.app.goo.gl/9J84AEfSksqr7yBW6?g_st=ic

7. Mo‚Äôs burger is a godsend! They have GF burger and hot dog in their kids menu. They‚Äôre small so we ordered 2-3 each person.

8. Yakiniku restaurants are a safe bet! We walked into quite a few and I showed them my GF card and they‚Äôd just give me plain beef with salt. Delicious!!!

9. Like in Osaka and Kyoto, mochi places are everywhere in all 3 cities. Mochis are naturally gluten-free as they‚Äôre made with rice flour.

10. There were a lot of places I didn‚Äôt get to try for myself, unfortunately. Their locations below:

Rizlabo. 100% GF pancakes:
üìç https://maps.app.goo.gl/XJi4b91WCvuzvo7H9?g_st=ic

Ricehack. 100% GF bakery:
üìç https://maps.app.goo.gl/2bNYZDqDUXwceUvi9?g_st=ic

Gluten Free Kushiage Su. 100% GF skewers. Amazing reviews and reso required:
üìç https://maps.app.goo.gl/HC8EtxUF7quq4QoW7?g_st=ic

And that‚Äôs a wrap! A GF card in Japanese is highly recommended.

For anyone interested, I have an IG page where I post pictures of safe places to eat around the world with pictures. The above places are all marked with pictures there. The handle is @celia.theceliac.

Honestly, I did not find Japan as hard as I thought it would be. It just takes a little patience, a GF card in Japanese and loooooots of planning. Good luck to all of you!

Title:
We just got back from our trip and I‚Äôd like to thank everyone in this group for their recommendations. 

Our 16yrs old was diagnosed with coeliac disease a few months before we went to Japan, and I was so stressed about what she was going to be able to eat, and if we would be able to eat at restaurants and keep her safe. 

Our accommodation wasn‚Äôt self-catering and as we were going in peak Sakura season I couldn‚Äôt find anywhere else suitable, plus we didn‚Äôt really want to have to cook.

So finding this Group was fantastic, plus some websites such as Endless Distances, Legal Nomads, plus many others. 

We had a GF Japanese translation card and used Google Translate to also communicate with staff.

She had great GF meals on ANA flights - booked in advance.

In Tokyo we stayed at Asakusa Tobu hotel which was so convenient for transport as 5mins walk to two subway lines so we could easily get around. 

In Tokyo we ate at the following:
- Gonpachi Asakusa twice (reservation in advance). They had a separate GF menu and my daughter loved the GF tempura, they gave her separate GF soy sauce, she also had wagyu steak, yakitori, sushi. It was all delicious, service was rather slow and not the friendliest of staff, but great for the food. This was the only place we had issues with service and unfriendly staff - everywhere else the staff were great.
- Kuroboshi Churros in Asakusa for GF churros which were wonderful.
- Otaco in Asakusa for chiffon cake - the lightest most amazing cake we have ever had - we tried the chocolate and also the lemon.
- Rizlabo in in Harajuku/Omotesando. GF Souffle (fluffy) pancakes were incredible. They don‚Äôt do them every day, some days are GF crepes so check before you go if you particularly want souffle pancakes. You can‚Äôt book so arrive before they open. We arrived at 11.45am for 12pm opening. 
- RiceHack GF bakery in Harajuku/Omotesando - incredible baguettes, rolls, chocolate muffins - get there when they open to have a good choice as it‚Äôs a very small bakery. They were doing sausage rolls later in the day which I‚Äôve heard are great. We went twice as it was so good, and lovely for us all to be able to eat the same thing.
- Gluten Free T‚Äôs in Roppongi - all GF food. (reserved in advance). We had delicious fried chicken, spring rolls, gyozas. They have now opened another restaurant in the APA hotel Ueno Hirokoji in Akihabara, we didn‚Äôt have time to go there unfortunately.
- Cafe Komoya in Roppongi - all GF food, salads, sandwiches, cake, curry and rice. The lady spoke fluent English and we discovered that they have a sister cafe in Kyoto where we also went (Koma Gallery Cafe). (reserved in advance but wasn‚Äôt busy).
- Soranoiro Nippon Ramen Tokyo Station - fabulous ramen with GF option. Go early otherwise you‚Äôll have a long wait. 
- Teppan Baby in Shinjuku for okonomiyaki - (reserved in advance). We were concerned that on the menu it said they cooked on the same grill, however after speaking to the staff they assured us it was cooked on a separate grill. Great fun restaurant and staff were friendly and helpful. 
- Torikizoku Asakusa - we were the only Westerners here and loved the Japanese atmosphere. (reserved in advance). Yakitori skewers with GF options. We then did karaoke just down the road which was fun. 

In Kyoto we stayed at Hotel Vischio Granvia just south of Kyoto station. Great location as near Shinkansen, subway, trains and buses.

In Kyoto we ate at the following:
- Kyoto Engine Ramen - great ramen with GF option. (reserved in advance).
- Toshoan cafe - completely GF, amazing souffle (fluffy) pancakes. Takes 30mins to make the pancakes but worth the wait.
- Cafe and Bar Maru - (reserved in advance). Quite expensive but very good, and all GF. 
- Kikyo Sushi - (reserved in advance). Amazing sushi with GF options. Family run, and the owner‚Äôs son Mitsuru speaks fluent English and can advise on GF options. Fabulous meal. 
- Sugarhill - (reserved in advance by Messenger). We went twice as it was so good, GF options. The chicken teriyaki was incredible - both the GF and standard versions. Also had Wagyu beef which was great. 
- Koma Gallery Cafe - GF, limited menu but nice food. 
- Breizh Cafe Creperie - GF options, they can change standard crepes for buckwheat galettes - you wouldn‚Äôt know the difference and they were delicious.

In Miyajima we went to Miyajima Base and had GF fries chicken which was delicious. 

At Tokyo Haneda airport Terminal 2 our only option was Healthy Tokyo Cafe for GF vegan lasagne which was fine and served its purpose. Daughter didn‚Äôt realise it was vegan and thought she was eating meat so you wouldn‚Äôt know the difference. 

So having been so worried beforehand, all the advance planning and using this group paid off and made the holiday fabulous and worry-free.

ResponsesV2.Message: Thank you for your post! I‚Äôve been super worried for our trip in July as my family is GF due to Celiacs. Can I ask how far in advance do we need to make reservations?

Can I ask where you found the gonpachi coeliac friendly menu? I can only find the standard one üôà
Thank you for the list, I have screenshot it!

Title:
Hi everyone! We have loads of new members, so I thought I would post about what it's really like to eat a gluten-free diet in Japan, sort of an introductory guide. Many Westerners come here and are shocked by and unprepared for the differences between their home country and Japan. I would like to welcome other residents of Japan to comment any of their advice as well. 
First, labelling laws are different here. For example, there is a product called mizuame that is a sweet syrup that is sometimes made from corn, sometimes from potatoes, and sometimes from barley, and companies do not have to list the source. Google labelling laws and get educated before coming. It is not like many Western countries where if the label says gluten-free, that means it's 100% safe from cross-contamination. At best, that means it has no gluten-containing ingredients. 
Food allergy knowledge can be very limited here. Some Japanese people you talk to for ordering food won't know the word for barley, I know that sounds bizarre, but they sort of group grains into one category in their minds. I have told many people that my daughter is allergic to Ko-mugi and O-mugi (wheat and barley) and gotten asked what O-mugi is. Like Westerners, many Japanese people don't know soy sauce contains wheat. We went to a restaurant that advertised itself as gluten-free once, and they used regular soy sauce. (Yes, I know about the argument of less than 20ppm, let's save that for another day). 
Wealthy travelers who stay in expensive hotels or eat at fine dining restaurants in urban centers will have an easier time eating gluten-free in Japan as those hotels' and restaurants' staff members are trained in catering to foreign guests with food allergies. These members of this group will often comment on posts about what an easy time they had eating gluten-free in Japan. There's nothing wrong with that, but if you're more a budget traveler (or resident, like me), be aware of that discrepancy in the posts on this group. 
Don't plan on walking into any restaurant you find and expect to be able to eat there. Restaurants in Japan are allowed to refuse you service. If you come in with a card, it is possible that you will be turned away. 
Restaurants in Japan usually serve set meals. If you ask to change anything about the set meal (unless you're in a fine-dining establishment that caters to foreigners) you will likely be met with shock and panic, and they often say no. If you explain you have an allergy, I have found that about 1 out of 5 times, some kind soul will help you out, but only in mom-and-pop shops, not chains.  
Sometimes translation apps translate a label badly because it's on a rounded containers. Double and triple check! 
Don't despair, it is possible to eat gluten-free in Japan. I have lived here for 5 years with a Celiac kid and she's thriving. You just need to do loads of research and be prepared. Have a map of safe restaurants in the areas you will be visiting. Save pictures of safe foods from combinis. Find natural grocers. Learn the kanji for gluten-containing ingredients.  Read lots of articles online. Good luck and enjoy Japan!

ResponsesV2.Message: Sorry to ask- what is the 20ppm thing about? Just briefly!
Thank you for your post! Quick question; I thought they used hiragana for labels.. should I be focused on learning/recognizing Kanji?

ResponsesV2.Message: I haven't had this meal, however, there's a difference between celiac and wheat allergy. Many folks with celiac can have wheat flour that has been altered. I would double check with the airline since it says "designed for gluten intolerant" and not "gluten free". I'd specifically ask about cross contamination.

I flew on JAL from DFW to Haneda last month. I did not go hungry! I was served fish, chicken, sweet potatoes, veggies, salad, yogurt, and fruit. They do not have as many snack type options for GF, so just bring yourself some snacks and you should be good! I have celiac and did not get sick.

Title:
Just wanted to give a heads up if staying in Kanazawa... The gf place "Love for All" was the worst gf place we've ever been to. Very overpriced and we were amazed how subpar the taste was :/. And very unnecessarily small portion sizes. I have never had such a bad experience at a gf place or felt so ripped off, and I've been to quite a few gf places in Japan now. You'd be better off just grabbing a steak/veggies at the omicho market ten minutes away and cooking yourself ($20 for an a5 wagyu.. we had about half each so still less than we had spent at Love for All). 

Gonna leave my first bad review for this place, I had read the reviews before going but didn't see all the one star reviews...

ResponsesV2.Message:
Kanazawa resident and I second this. I‚Äôve only been once and was really disappointed with the service (the staff was really unfriendly) along with the high prices and subpar taste. Even the prices for the GF items for sale were way overpriced.

Omicho Market is good option if you‚Äôre staying in a place with a kitchen, but if not, Aarshirwad is a Michelin star rated Indian restaurant that‚Äôs right down the road from Love for All. It‚Äôs not dedicated gluten free, but I‚Äôve had good experiences there. It‚Äôs not cheap, but it‚Äôs not overpriced, some of the staff speak English, and they have some gluten free items on the menu. I‚Äôm gluten intolerant and don‚Äôt have too many issues with cross-contamination, so if that‚Äôs not as much of a problem for you then I recommend it. They also do take out if you‚Äôd rather eat in your accommodations. 

This option is a bit farther away (it‚Äôs right across the street from Curio, near the station), but Midoriya is a cafe with gluten free and vegan options. It‚Äôs a store as well, and they had a decent amount of gluten free items for sale (pasta, etc). I haven‚Äôt eaten the food there myself so I can‚Äôt vouch for it, but it looked promising. 

If you prefer cooking, most AEON supermarkets sell gluten free and allergen-friendly products. Osakaya sells gluten free soy sauce, but that‚Äôs all I‚Äôve seen there. AL Plaza in Kanazawa has great allergen-friendly options. They even sell frozen takoyaki, which are alright. If you go to the supermarket in AL Plaza, there‚Äôs two allergen-friendly sections: one is the health section (it‚Äôll have green labels that say ÂÅ•Â∫∑„Çµ„Éù„Éº„Éà (kenkou sapooto, health support), and the other is in the baby food section. The best part about the AL Plaza supermarket is that they sell GF/allergen-friendly dashi, mentsuyu, and ponzu. I haven‚Äôt been able to find these in any other store, just online. Do be aware that the dashi sells out fast if you go to the store. 

Sorry this is so long, and Charlotte Jessop I‚Äôm really sorry you had such a terrible experience at Love for All üòû You‚Äôre not alone on that front. I hope these recommendations help for anyone else traveling in Kanazawa and Ishikawa! 
(Google pins posted in the replies)

We have managed to visit 3 times (soon to be 4) with an allergy card but also take advantage of allergen menus at restaurants as peanut, cashew (and I think a couple of other nuts) have to be listed by Japanese law - what they call the main 7 but often they list a further 20. Family restaurants, chains, etc have these menus on their websites and sometimes hard copy.
Also:  Be careful of some of the GF curry and ramen recommendations from this group as they use nuts.

Title:
Onigiri Nima test. As promised to some of you, I did a Nima test of the onigiri ball and, unfortunately, it came back positive. Below are pictures of the one I tested, the test screen and the Nima capsule‚Äôs back.  I would just like to indicate that Nima does test for minimal amounts which are safe for celiacs. We can have up to 20ppm and Nima is known to find gluten as low as 5ppm.

Edit: I went on Nima website to find out what the back lines of the capsule mean. Turns out that 2 top lines means ‚Äúno gluten‚Äù. So I tested a second time and got gluten found again, checked the lines again and only the top 2 again, so I‚Äôm not really sure what to do with this information. I think it‚Äôs probably <20ppm, which is safe for celiacs. Also, I‚Äôm very reactive and I had a bite and didn‚Äôt react.

ResponsesV2.Message:
Thank you so much for testing one. I‚Äôm eternally grateful! 
To offer some insight; the camera inside the device is infrared, so it might be picking up on a faint line that the human eye cannot.
The other guy was talking about Lawson and you tested 7-11...not really  what she asked for... :-)

Sharing from another group as it looks like there will be some gluten-free stalls during the event: https://www.facebook.com/groups/kyotoveg/

On Sunday 14th April the annual Kyoto Vegan Gourmet festival will take place at Umekoji park.

This is one of the highlights of the Kyoto vegan calendar as there is always a lot of great food to try and brilliant people to meet. 

Time is 10:30-16:00 but arrive early to avoid disappointment.

The closest station is Umekoji-kyotonishi which is 2 minutes walk away and Kyoto station is 10 minutes walk away.

Directions:

Exit Kyoto Station by Kyoto tower, turn left and follow the road along the train tracks over the bridge until you reach the park. (note that at Times car rental and Daniel‚Äôs mondo Italian the road curves right but just stick to the left and keep following it.)

Exit Kyoto station at the Shinkansen exit, turn right and walk until you get to the first major junction where the train taxis intercept. Turn right until you reach the foot bridge. Walk over it and keep walking straight until you reach the park.

[https://maps.app.goo.gl/fkz48nuimYMZ8z616?g_st=ic](https://maps.app.goo.gl/fkz48nuimYMZ8z616?g_st=ic&fbclid=IwAR3-FfqHPSPHQmHO7S7VNV3T34RA7vpnT4INDhIqR2483bNOiu-kx_J1dwg_aem_ARK3ZELcFzkXWTys2v-mmduhOl0OnsUFIQ8t-pQXnXnTNmyzRDROc_xq95Hb7nHC7SfREq1bQBWyv9ZmmTWusftU)

Title:
I‚Äôm reading a lot about the salmon & now plum ongiri from Lawsons & 7/11.  My super sensitive coeliac daughter & myself are soon to go to Japan BUT she doesn‚Äôt like salmon! Can someone please clarify what a plum ongiri is, & if it‚Äôs safe for her.
Thanks heaps üôèüèª

ResponsesV2.Message:
konbini offers multiple onigiri, most of which are not for us.
in the last 2 years the salmon and salt option, and the plum options have been considered coeliac safe.
i ate them for 3 weeks everyday (one salmon, one plum), with no problem, both from 7/11 and lawson.
today others wrote that felt sick after eating a salmon one in lawson.
However, your daughter hate salmon so... not problem for her.
Plum onigiri is rice wrapped in nori seaweed with a plum heart.
I liked it very much but has a pretty sour taste, the kind i didn't like when i was younger.
As for safety... Japan is mostly by word of mouth, i and others can tell you we ate them multiple times with no problem (i'm usually very sensitive); but nothing is 100% safe, sadly.
7-11 sometimes has a plain salted rice onigiri (no filling, just rice). There are also boiled eggs or some packaged meats that could make a meal in a pinch.

Title:
Hi fellow celiacs and gf people! 

Firstly, I‚Äôm so stoked I found this page and that everyone so actively shares their recommendations and experiences, what a gold mine!

I‚Äôm planning to do my working holiday next year so it‚Äôs great to see what places and foods I could try. 

However, as I‚Äôll be there for 6+ months, I‚Äôm wondering if anyone has recommendations for the following, as I will need to do some of my own cooking:

- cooking gadgets (and where to buy them)

I‚Äôm looking for something I could potentially use by plug in and transport in my suitcase, so not too bulky. I‚Äôm thinking of getting a small rice cooker and potentially some camp ware cooking style stuff, but wanted to see if anyone had any recommendations üôÇ thank you!

ResponsesV2.Message: Japan has a different plug and voltage so it's best to buy it here (one-day delivery) by Amazon. Or Bic Camera and IKEA here should have them. Should have a lot of small and portable stuff because most of Japan urban areas have small spaces. Upon arrival, just enjoy takeouts and dine-ins at GF restos/cafes most abundant in Shibuya/Harajuku area. Microwavable rice packets and raw sashimi/some chicken from convenience stores would help while waiting for your delivery. With cooking gadgets, cheap raw meat/chicken/fish/veggies from Gyomu, Hanamasa, or OK supermarket would do. A few of us have posted GF finds from these supermarkets, too. For sweets and other GF supplies, Bio-ral and Bio c'Bon should have them. üòä
I saw a lot of mini appliances at Kmart yesterday, including a rice cooker. (I‚Äôm in Australia, btw)

I went for 2 weeks with 2 non-GF people and every sit-down restaurant we went to was mentioned here on this group with positive experiences. Less stress trying to find food, Find Me Gluten Free app is the best, 7-11 and family Marts are great, there are a few places you will find you can eat at just need to research, have fun you will love it

Title:
I have nothing but admiration for so many of you and your ability to find places to eat, and work your holiday around it!! 
Been here since last Wednesday and I have found the whole process of trying to find safe places to eat without it consuming every day an absolute ballache.  Not helped by my wife being vegan and having two kids as well.  Thankfully, my short term symptoms are mild so I have just given up and decided to just not let the search for food consume me or our holiday.  I haven‚Äôt gone overboard (no pizzas, noodles or bread) but I have let the regime slide.  Plenty of green tea will help my gut, and the knowledge that in just over a week I will go back to my new normal.  I figure I managed nearly 45 years before being diagnosed.  A couple of weeks is hardly going to be the be all and end all.

ResponsesV2.Message: It is really hard I'm struggling big time .found 1 places in tokyo that was open 2 nights of our 5 but a train ride away. then in kyoto our 4 nights i lived on muffins from home and the candied strawberries then in osaka i found a place but it was a train ride way and only did dumplings so ate there for 4 nights. We are now back in kyoto and staying in a different part to the first time lucky for me we are a 7 minute walk from Waco crepes looks like I'm eating there for next 4 nights till we fly home I've been so tempted to  just eat anything to get by but unfortunately gluten effects my joints so bad that i can't walk üò¢ i have been travelling quite a bit this last year and japan has been the worst for finding gf üò¢

Hi Mike Spall I‚Äôm here in Japan too and I‚Äôm extremely sensitive. Even a crumb will make me go to ER as I puke violently so I‚Äôm extra careful. Having said that, let me give you some tips to make your life easier:
- breakfast is onigiri rice balls from family mart or pancakes at home. I brought a package of GF pancake mix and we have it every other day. My son and myself are the celiacs in the family. 
- I plan my itinerary around places to eat that I found in this group or on ‚Äúfind me GF‚Äù. Yes, I know it takes away spontaneity but unfortunately spontaneity went out the window as soon as we got our diagnosis.
- your wife being vegan works in your favour as most places that cater to GF also caters to vegan so do a quick google search in the area you‚Äôre in and you might be surprised.
- I have an IG page (@celia.theceliac) where I am making stories and putting them as highlights for every city I‚Äôm going to. I went to Osaka and now we‚Äôre in Kyoto. You might find something there but I do suggest you message them ahead of time and explain the gluten-free situation. All places ive been to this far already understood what I was talking about when I mentioned gluten-free or celiac because they have received several similar requests. 
- don‚Äôt hesitate to educate people. Just this afternoon near the bamboo grove, my husband found a fresh seafood grill place and showed them the GF card. Initially, they were going to turn us away but I saw that they were not putting any sauces on the grill and it was just meat and other seafood so I explained to them that if they were that afraid, they could just put a fresh sheet of aluminum over the grill and use a new utensil for cooking it and after much back and forth, they obliged. This was the second time at a street stand that I‚Äôve been able to get delicious Kobe beef on a stick. My first time was by Osaka Castle. I know it‚Äôs a pain but use google translator and ask specific questions like: ‚Äúcan you please tell me what ingredients are in this (blank)?‚Äù, ‚Äúdoes it have any soy sauce?‚Äù ‚ÄúDo you cook anything else with soy sauce on the same surface?‚Äù ‚ÄúCan I please kindly ask you to use a clean utensil as I have a severe allergy? It won‚Äôt give me an anaphylactic reaction but I‚Äôll be throwing my guts up later.‚Äù  9 times out of 10 that I tried that, people understood and obliged.

I‚Äôm so sorry you‚Äôre going through this and I hope your trip gets better!

Title:
I was delighted to find a gluten free pastry shop "Soak" in Kagoshima in the basement floor of the „Ç¢„Éü„É•„Éó„É©„Ç∂ÈπøÂÖêÂ≥∂Â∫ó connected to the kagoshima-chuo train/shinkansen station. They appear to have a main bakery too but I only went to their small take out facility. They use dairy and almonds, with rice flour  and almond as the base for their treats. 

They were having a strawberry fair and I started by ordering the two parfaits they offered- one pudding flavored and the other strawberry. (We shared between four people.) They were good but reaction was mixed in our group. I liked the pudding flavored one but was the only one... it had interesting texture in the ice cream/pudding blocks that was somehow icy and chewy at the same time. However I was a bit disappointed the sauce tasted a bit underwhelming and there were no fresh fruit that would have elevated it. 

I also tried their take-away omiyage donut. It tasted reassuringly of rice flour but I wouldn't buy it again.

My daughter and I decided to have a cake party on the shinkansen because I wanted to try the strawberry tart. It was nice with a custard filling and real strawberries. We also tried a multi-layered strawberry dome that had a softer shell than we expected but had an amazing lychee strawberry filling. Last we tried their cake with strawberry jam and accents of strawberry. Their fancy desserts were not only the most beautiful but the most delicious. 

This is a really good fancy gf bakery, and once you know where it is you can grab an order and take it easily on the shinkansen. They are all sweet items, no savory, but very well done. 

#kyushuu #dedicatedglutenfree #glutenfreecake #kagoshimachuostation

 https://maps.app.goo.gl/sWEC3tcTzm74TVmu8

Title:
Ciao a tutti, here is my little contribution to this group that has been of great great help during my 2 week holidays in Japan!

I  had wonderful ramens in Tokyo Station and at Engine Ramen in Kyoto,  churros in Asakusa, tempura at T's Kitchen, okonomiyaki at Chibo  Dotonbori Osaka, crepes at Wacos Crepes, pancakes at Rizlabo, fried  chicken at Miyajima Base, hotdog at Mos Burger and a lot of onigiris for lunch and GF Kirin beer for aperitivo. I was so happy to be  able to try all these new tastes, so here are my few discoveries:

1) [https://www.yakatabune-tsurishin.com/en/index.html](https://www.yakatabune-tsurishin.com/en/index.html)

l  managed to have a very nice typical dinner while cruising Sumida river in #Tokyo on a traditional boat. A Japanese friend called in advance to ask for  gluten free options and l had miso soup, tempura, sashimi, fruits and  drinks. A little pricey (abt 70 Euros) but worth it. 

2) [https://miyajima-kikunoya.com/en/](https://miyajima-kikunoya.com/en/)

I  stayed one night in #Miyajima (totally recommended to avoid the crowds)  and l had a full japanese GF breakfast. They seem to understand  perfectly what gluten is and the cook came also to double check  everything with me. l gave her my restaurant card, hoping it will help  others. 

3) http://www.lifecorp.jp/store/bio-ral/
At Namba Station in #Osaka there's a Bio Ral shop, for the first time l found GF bread, pasta and cakes.

Hope you will have a wonderful trip, if you need any help, don't hesitate to ask. 

Thanks again for all the useful tips l read in this group, you literally made my journey much easier than l could ever hope. 

Silvia

Title:
For admin: I have done a group search and have had trouble finding *vegetarian*, *kid-friendly* (non GF) and GF options for *all* of the places I listed. Thank you!

I need all the recommendations for GF *and* #vegetarian *and* kid-friendly restaurants/food/treats/hotels in Tokyo, Nagoya, Kyoto, Nara, Osaka, and Wakayama! I have asymptomatic celiac , the rest of my family is vegetarian but not GF. Kids ages 9-12. We love ramen, soba noodles, tofu, gyoza, tempura, rice, mochi. Also looking for amazing desserts. Bonus points for accommodating special cafes/experiences (cat cafe, Pok√©mon, pikachu, kawaii, robots, etc and tea ceremony). Also will take tips for DisneySea, Universal Studios, Sanrio Puroland, and Yomiuriland

ResponsesV2.Message:
You‚Äôre playing in ultra hard mode. When you say vegetarian what exactly do you mean? Will you eat dashi? Anything flavored with fish? Etc? If not you‚Äôre going to have an extremely hard time. Japan is not friendly to celiacs, and also is not that friendly to vegetarians.

You will not find safe g/f options in any of the special cafes, and may not find vegetarian food there either.

Ramen is almost always in dashi. Soba is almost always not 100% buckwheat and not gluten free. There may be one restaurant that can do g/f gyoza but I don‚Äôt think it‚Äôs vegetarian (gluten free t‚Äôs). Plain rice will be fine. Mochi for the most part will not be safe for celiacs; will be fine for vegetarians.

I can‚Äôt speak to the parks you listed.
Please share what‚Äôs wrong with all the places already shared that are labeled as vegan?

I'm feeling a little better but still very sore and bloated and i have a lot of joint inflammation.  They gave me little sachets of powder to take after eating... truth be told I'm afraid to eat üò¨ but I'm sure these sachets are giving me liquid diarrhoea (sorry to be graphic).

Title:
#KUROBOSHI #zeroichi 100% gluten free. If you head up to nasu please make sure you‚Äôre going to the correct place. There is another location inside an amusement park. 
KUROBOSHI headquarters/flagship store in #Nasu #Tochigi 
üìç 3-46, Terakohei
Nasu, Nasu-Gun, Tochigi
Japan 329-3222

#disneyland #disneytokyo 
*Please remember to manage your expectations when you visit and plan accordingly for long wait times* I didn‚Äôt have a problem finding food or GF snacks. 

We spent Saturday at Tokyo disney and had a blast! There was surprisingly a lot of allergy information on their website. I‚Äôve included screen shots of restaurants with low allergen meals, GF popcorn and GF turkey leg. 

First picture is matcha white chocolate popcorn (stand located outside of cafe ollins) with the rum coffee from cafe ollins. It was a hot day and the rum coffee drink is served hot. I asked for ice on the side and they gave it to me. 
Next are Mickey ice pops. They are tropical flavored and hit the spot! Not all wagon locations have both Mickey and Minnie ice pops so if you‚Äôre looking for a specific flavor definitely check the menu before getting in line. 
For lunch we went to hungry bear cafe and I got the low allergen vegetable curry with tandoori chicken. At the register I said I have an allergy and the lady got on a Walkie-Talkie and a dude with an iPad came out so I could pick my allergy and then my meal. Super quick! Once chosen I paid and received food in like 10 minutes. Before we left the park we got a turkey leg at cowboy cook house! 

Lastly there is an area connected to Disneyland by the Disney monorail called #IKSPIARI. This place is like downtown disney and there are a lot of American restaurants here including TGIF, red lobster, Outback Steakhouse, and rainforest cafe. There is also the Australian restaurant Guzman y Gomez where everything if GF expect for the wheat wraps and churros. Their French fries are fried separately than their churros.

Title: I just returned from Japan today had an absolutely amazing time. That being said finding gluten-free food was a struggle and there was a couple of days where I was very frustrated and hungry. Thanks for this site I had a lot of information about convenience stores and what to buy there and so that was my go to when I was really hungry. I‚Äôd look at the post you all made and go to a 7-Eleven or a Lawson or a family Mart and buy some food and save the day. Thank you so much an amazing beautiful country . Ôøº

Long post.
I returned from a 16 days trip to Japan between February and March and I would like to thank this group so much, and share some information with you.
The celiac and lactose free person was a friend of mine, but I well know the problem having a celiac nephew and having various food intolerances (I did have a GF bar some years ago).
I planned every part of the trip (flights, hotels, itinerary) trying to include GF places to eat whenever possible, and I must say that, for me, the best tricks for enjoying a GF Japan are two: planning and booking.
Speaking of planning: this group is a unique and unparalleled source of informations, so take advantage of it before you leave by using the lens of research, because it will allow you to have fantastic experiences.  The GF part was the last thing I had planned and even if I found her almost one place a day to have a decent meal, I could have done better with a few more days to spare.
I used a lot 2 of the GF maps found on this group by Spenser Babb Biernacki  and @Katarinakokic showing the GF spots.
Whenever we knew where to eat it was easy, and we found good food and nice people with knowledge of the problem.
When there were no places marked on the map, or when the places were too far away from the area we were in the time we want to eat (considering that we were a group of 6, so we have also to mix the needs of different people) we had 2 choices: get food from combini or ask restaurants if there was any chance of having anything GF.
Combini: I highly recommend to use the magnificient work done by a member of the group I‚Äôm not able to find the post anymore (so please excuse me if I cannot write your name, but I‚Äôm sure other members will help me find him/her again): it was a list called ‚ÄúJapan_Food products list‚Äù and there were hundreds of articles in the combini that in this group were identified as GF. If you can, print the list (even if there are many sheets), choose the food you might like, highlight it and try looking for it in the combini, or simply show the photo to the clerk. This will save you a lot of time in the combini store. Some combini have a special ‚ÄúHappy bakery‚Äù line which is gluten free and some lactose and egg free, so you can have bread to make sandwiches or for breakfast with jam.
I also recommend visiting some big supermarket, although this doesn‚Äôt mean there are more options of GF because it depends on the brand of the market, but there are more options for vegetables, fresh fruit, dried fruit, ham, eggs, sashimi, mochi.
The main problem with food bought in combini is where to eat it: in Japan you cannot eat on the street or on the train, except Shinkansen. We were, as said, in the company of other people, so we tried going to the restaurants where the others would eat, asking if it was possible for the celiac person to eat her own food. I must say that for the most of the trip we found several places where this has been accepted without problems, but, especially in the last part of the trip, we found some places, especially small or crowded ones, that hasn‚Äôt allowed this to happen. We had respected that, because they are not obliged to do that and even in Italy (where I‚Äôm from) the most of the places do no accept people eating their own food in a restaurant.
Language: English is not always well spoken, so sometimes it can be difficult to make yourself understood, but the translator helps a lot.
GF Card: I didn‚Äôt use the GF cards I found on this group because, as someone else has already written, this will scare Japanese restaurateurs and you get a ‚Äúno‚Äù as answer, because they prefer not to offer you a food that can make you sick. This has not to been taken as a bad thing, but, on the contrary, it‚Äôs a big form of respect, and once you will be in Japan you will understand that Japanese people love to help others in any way they can, so, please, do not get angry if someone will not accept to cook for you because it‚Äôs a form of respect towards you.
When you enter a place not marked on the maps, you can ask if they have GF options, if they do not understand you can ask if they have anything cooked without flours and additional seasonings such as grilled meat or fish. If they don‚Äôt understand what you are asking for, it‚Äôs probably it‚Äôs best to change place because they do not know what contamination is. We tried to do this at one place, asking for plan cooked eggs with nothing else, but than my friend has contamination issues, so we never tried again.
Kindness: Japanese people are absolutely kind and respectful and this is also the way to relate to them. And if sometimes it could be difficult, it‚Äôs not their fault: celiac disease is something relatively new to them. In Italy we were like them about 15 years ago, so they will learn in the next few years and it will be better.
Breakfast: almost no hotels offers GF breakfast and, especially for those who are used to eating sweet food (like Italians), consider to bring it from home. Even for non-celiacs the choice of sweet food (croissant, jam, etc.) is very limited, but we are in Japan, Asia, so we have to adapt to their way of having breakfast. They have vegetables (sometimes raw) and fruit, but most of the food is cooked, so not ok for contaminations even tough basically it is GF.
About booking: we were in Japan at the end of the low season, we didn‚Äôt book any restaurants except one. We were lucky in most places, in GF places we wait sometimes up to 30 minutes, in Fuji area (after waiting 30 minutes to enter) we sit down and order, but after 2 other customers besides us, they put the ‚Äúsold out‚Äù signal out! In Miyajima the place it was supposed to do GF, it doesn‚Äôt do it for lunch but only in the evening. In Shinjuku it was Sunday evening and without a reservation there was no place. In Takayama we have to book online, because they only accept reservations, as they cook for 2-4 customers every 30 minutes. If you go in high season you must book.
In summary: Japan is wonderful, not yet well prepared on GF it‚Äôs true, but if you plan, book, and have a great spirit of adaptation, if you bring some essential food from home and use all the tools that this group will give you, you will probably love it.
In the pictures there are name of the GF places we went in.

ResponsesV2.Message: Really glad my map was able to help you! Cheers!

Title:
Please be wary even when at major chains that have GF options.

I live here, I speak Japanese, and I still got caught.

I was at Starbucks Shijo Kawaramachi in Kyoto, and my celiac friend in front of me got the last rice flour muffin assuming they had more out the back. I asked if they had other gluten free options and the staff said the sugar donut, which I purchased. She said „Ç∞„É´„ÉÜ„É≥„Éï„É™„Éº„Å™„Çâ„Ç∑„É•„Ç¨„Éº„Éâ„Éº„Éä„ÉÑ„Åå„ÅÇ„Çä„Åæ„Åô„ÄÇ‚Äôif you want something GF we have the sugar donuts‚Äô

Once I sat down my friend was pretty sure they are not, so I went back to the counter and she said ‚Äúwell, it‚Äôs plant based‚Äù „Éó„É©„É≥„Éà„Éô„Éº„Çπ„Å†„Åã„Çâso I explained in Japanese that plant-based is vegan but gluten free is an allergy to wheat etc but she didn‚Äôt seem interested/understanding. It was very busy though and I‚Äôm guessing she was new ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è 

(This was partially my fault as I rushed due to the long line behind me, and didn‚Äôt have my glasses on to be able to check for the wheat mark on the sign.)

Pics for tax and to offset the current rainy weather in blossom season

ResponsesV2.Message: I tell them I have mugirui arerugi and say all the mugis, starting with komugi. Often then they look very serious and tell me it could be contaminated, even at major chains. So you are right, be wary
I found it more useful to talk about "wheat allergy" rather than "gluten free"

Title:
Takayama - Just had the most amazing meal at Heianraku Â§©Ê∫ÄÁî∫Ôºñ‰∏ÅÁõÆÔºóÔºçÔºí, Takayama-shi, Gifu, Japan, 506-0025
My daughter is fairly newly diagnosed and has struggled a bit to find food she likes and can eat in Japan. She has eaten a lot of Salmon Onigiri from Family Mart but today we could eat good, wholesome food as a family. Not only was the food superb but the husband and wife team behind Heianraku are so nice and welcoming. You must make a reservation but I would hands down recommend that it‚Äôs totally worth it.

Anyone travel around Japan who is coeliac and also Type1 Diabetic? Any tips would be amazing! 

Am worried that I will be eating cakes, curry and rice for the trip. All of these high carb foods add another level of complexity. I want to enjoy my holiday and not be focused on battling high sugars. 

Am also dairy and egg intolerant (can have some). 

It takes next level planning! This group has been great to gather info and start making lists. 

Will be visiting Tokyo (staying in Shiomi), Hakone (hotel does GF so okay there), Takayama, and Kyoto with a day trip to Hiroshima.

ResponsesV2.Message: We have additional dietary requirements too, so I'm bringing pre packaged items from home just in case we get stuck. The advantage is when you eat your food from home, you have space for souvenirs at the end of the trip! Good luck and I hope you find plenty to eat while you're there

I‚Äôm T1D and celiac, recently was in Tokyo and Kyoto. With all the walking, I was fine with some of the higher carb foods and didn‚Äôt have highs. (The candied strawberries were worth bolusing for!) One of the challenges I ran into that I didn‚Äôt expect was finding zero or low carb drinks. For example, Tokyo Disneyland did not have Diet Coke or Coke Zero. So, lots of water for me üòä I did find Coke Zero at 7-11, Family Marts, and some restaurants.

Title:

My daughter is a huge fan and I saw a note on this page to just get the coffee‚Ä¶ so we took our chances, waited 100 minutes (took a long walk and checked out the incredible fashion) and got in this afternoon.

We told the server about our allergies (two celiacs) and specified wheat. Looking at the menu we saw three potential options- the curry/rice meal, the mango sundae and the mango lassie. Title:
Hello everyone!

We‚Äôre getting ready for our Japan trip in a few days and I have a few questions I hope you can help me with:

1. Locco Chicken: is a reservation required or can we just walk in? I don‚Äôt want to call due to language barrier and I can‚Äôt seem to find an online way to get in touch with them.

2. I‚Äôm bringing some breakfast things from home (pancake mix, oatmeal) but will need to use milk in Japan. Do they manage to put gluten in milk too or can I be confident that any milk is safe?

3. Any other suggestions for an anxious celiac mom with a picky celiac teenager in Japan?

Thank you all so much!

ResponsesV2.Message: Loco Chicken Kyoto: They respond online on their instagram page. They are from the Marianas, so they do speak English. I just messaged them and they got back very quickly to confirm that their fries are NOT gluten free, though. The chicken is, sort of, as it is cooked in the same oil as the fries.

Bring protein bars! Anything you can fit. I have nuts,bars and chips and have been living on these most days with a meal here and there when I find somewhere safe. The restaurants are lovely and read my card I printed that says I‚Äôm coeliac and highly allergic etc. They go out of their way to research ingredients from Starbucks to Restaurants, but often say no to being safe. Grateful but back to the protein bar too often.  Good news is, haven‚Äôt been glutened. üíú

Title:

Title:
I have been living in #Kumamoto for a year and can say it is challenging to find GF food.  I am finally posting my list so far.  

„ÉªThe most convenient restaurant is at the Kumamoto train station in the Blossom Kumamoto hotel: #Senzanbansui (‰πùÂ∑ûÂâµ‰Ωú ÂçÉÂ±±‰∏áÊ∞¥) inside Forest Terrace Kumamoto. It is a new fancy place that has never been busy when we have been there. Great food, and they have been happy to make accommodations for my gluten intolerance and my wife‚Äôs dairy intolerance.

[https://forestterrace-km.jp/restaurant/](https://forestterrace-km.jp/restaurant/)

[https://maps.app.goo.gl/8ZQurU8BzybXT1Ui6](https://maps.app.goo.gl/8ZQurU8BzybXT1Ui6)

„ÉªNear the #KumamotoZoo is #Pho Time, a tiny Vietnamese Pho place we just discovered today. They are entirely gluten free, make tasty Pho, house-made sodas Ume, cola, ginger ale, etc. Pho Ga is ¬•1000.

[https://www.instagram.com/pho___time?igshid=OGQ5ZDc2ODk2ZA%3D%3D](https://www.instagram.com/pho___time?igshid=OGQ5ZDc2ODk2ZA%3D%3D)

[https://g.co/kgs/2DKgJMy](https://g.co/kgs/2DKgJMy)

„ÉªThere is a great GF bakery that makes great #Chiffon cake: Amam Komeko, a bit out of the way between Kumamoto city and the Kumamoto Aso Airport. Great GF chiffon cake. She uses mostly rice flour, olive oil, beet sugar, and soy milk. 

[https://www.instagram.com/amam.komeko?utm_source=ig_web_button_share_sheet&igsh=ZDNlZDc0MzIxNw==](https://www.instagram.com/amam.komeko?utm_source=ig_web_button_share_sheet&igsh=ZDNlZDc0MzIxNw%3D%3D)

[maps.app.goo.gl/7yVZKPA7yYnVRy4r9](http://maps.app.goo.gl/7yVZKPA7yYnVRy4r9)

„ÉªThere is also a small GF #donut shop pandatoneco also a bit out of the way and they close as soon as they run out of donuts, and they have limited hours. 

[https://www.instagram.com/pandatoneco?utm_source=ig_web_button_share_sheet&igsh=ZDNlZDc0MzIxNw==](https://www.instagram.com/pandatoneco?utm_source=ig_web_button_share_sheet&igsh=ZDNlZDc0MzIxNw%3D%3D)

[https://maps.app.goo.gl/tywnxuP4HhifqzU16](https://maps.app.goo.gl/tywnxuP4HhifqzU16)

„ÉªThere are also #yakiniku restaurants around where you can order plain meat and veggies to grill and salad bars. Avoid most dipping sauces, but some places may offer ‚ÄúShio-dare‚Äù, salt based sauces.

„ÉªThere is #Aeon Mall where you can buy GF bread and rolls.

[https://maps.app.goo.gl/FYxcp9hDnFovx8kW7](https://maps.app.goo.gl/FYxcp9hDnFovx8kW7)

„ÉªThe #Starbucks currently have GF vegan chocolate muffins, and GF vegan matcha roll cake.

„ÉªMost (not all) MOS burgers in Kumamoto sell the simple but edible non-allergen hot dogs and burgers made of pork with simple rice flour steam buns that they microwave to order. This has been one of our safe options when all else fails.

Hope that helps. Would love to hear from anyone else in Kumamoto who is avoiding gluten, though I feel like I know all 5 of us ;-)

Title:
Hello! I‚Äôve used the search engine to look for peanut and nut allergies to coincide with gluten allergy but didn‚Äôt find results that pertained to my specific question. So here goes‚Ä¶

The restaurants and bakeries recommended here that are gluten free friendly, are they using nut ingredients in place of gluten ingredients?  Example: instead of wheat flour they‚Äôre using almond flour. Example of dairy free, they‚Äôre using cashew cream.

Anyone here who has peanut, tree nut, gluten, and dairy allergies? I‚Äôll be traveling in the end of March and my 8yo has these allergies and I‚Äôm having anxiety trying to figure out which restaurants could accommodate these allergies beyond just gluten free. TIA

ResponsesV2.Message:
Each place will be different. Bring your allergy cards and try to speak to an English server where you can. Learn the important words ‚Ä¶like excuse me ..sumimasen.and the kanji symbols for packaging. 
I also can‚Äôt eat almonds in place of wheat. 
I had good luck at itzakaya , and Thai, Indian‚Ä¶.we found a French crepe place. And the larger hotels like Hilton , have great restaurants, and English speakers, and gf bread , so you can always pop in there! We also found GF ramen in Tokyo station. 
Lawsons, Family mart and 7-11 are great for yogurt , snacks, easy meals, and rice balls, too . 
Search in GF Japan for a list of restaurants
You‚Äôll need to check but a lot of places use rice flour, potato starch and soy milk. But definitely ask to clarify üòÖ

Wanting advice on where to go in Japan as a coeliac, outside of Kyoto/Tokyo. We are spending anywhere between 11-14 days in Japan depending on how easy we can find safe food. Already thinking 4 days in Tokyo and 4 days in Kyoto. Hoping to not jump around the country as such, but to make a cohesive travel plan that won't just eat up all our time in transit. Looking specifically for picturesque places - potentially on the Hokuriku pass line? - that are still able to accommodate dietary requirements whilst still giving an authentic Japanese experience. If anyone is able to give suggestions/advice/previous experiences we'd greatly appreciate it!!!

ResponsesV2.Message: In Kyoto. Look for soy milk ramen.  Probably the best gluten free ramen I‚Äôve ever had.

My advice? With that length of time split your time evenly between Tokyo and the combo of Kyoto/Osaka. Take day trips out of both regions if you feel like it. That‚Äôs just enough time to get the feel for both places.

Tokyo is the easiest for food, then Kyoto, and Osaka is probably the hardest. Do a bunch of research and plan your days around food or you‚Äôll be miserable.

Getting outside the Golden Route will present much harder food challenges.

You can take picturesque day trips to Nikko, Hakone, Kamakura, Nara, Koyasan, etc. you‚Äôll just have to pick. Food will be less available in most day trip locations too.

Title:
Reviews of #NISEKO #HIRAFU #SKIING

Breakfast

The hotel didn‚Äôt really have anything I could eat and due to cross contamination I asked if the chef could make me an omelette each morning. 
I also brought cereal from home, bought some bananas from the supermarket and used the milk from the hotel and some bread rolls from home to give some calories!

Lunch

This was hard‚Ä¶ no where on the mountain offers gluten free. I did find on the last day steak potato and vegetable and the Hirafu gondola restaurant which was delicious - they reassured me only salt and pepper on the steak and nothing else. 
Three days I ate pot noodle from home I had brought with me and a brioche bun I also brought with me alongside some snacks like nuts and crisps from the supermarket. 
We did CAT skiing one day and our tour company made me a delicious gluten free takeaway lunch with rice, mince tomatoes cheese etc. 

Dinner 

We ate at the following;

#renkitchen gluten free menu - amazing izukaya experience, they told me everything is prepared in a separate area, I even checked the edamame beans were cooked in separate water. 
#tajmahal Indian restaurant - we ate here twice - the owner told me Japanese curries use flour to thicken but they used almond flour. It was delicious and cheap. The only thing is I think i saw them bbq‚Äôing some of the chicken in the same oven and same preparation area as the nans so I would stick to curry‚Äôs that are prepared in the kitchen. 
The #vale - (chips not GF) - gluten free burger - the bread was so delicious and staff were on it - they grilled the bread in a separate area to the other bread. 
#rpizza - GF pasta - they asked if I wanted the pasta cooked in separate water or not - which I said yes as I‚Äôm a coeliac. Pasta was absolutely delicious.  

Let me know if any questions I‚Äôd be happy to help/answer!

Title: I read something about gluten enzymes in a post. I‚Äôve messaged my doc. I‚Äôm not Celiac. Has anyone used enzymes and eaten soy sauce? Not looking to eat bread, pastries, but maybe just enjoy a couple of meals with my group without so much trouble.

ResponsesV2.Message: Mina I‚Äôm in Australia and we have two products we can use for a sneaky gluten cheat. Gluteguard and  Glutenzyme. I‚Äôm only gluten intolerant so these are great if you are not sure about all ingredients and want to avoid a reaction. Maybe order some online before you go? Or you may have an equivalent where you are. Good luck.

I'm also really sensitive to soy so I don't really get relief there, but I use enzymes when I want to "cheat" and have some gluten. It helps mitigate the effects and it tends to reduce the severity and spread it out over a longer period of time. So instead of three hours of immediate feeling completely messed up, the next couple of days I will feel kind of off. I recommend giving it a try for special occasions if your glutening symptoms are manageable, just in case it doesn't work for you. I like dynamic enzymes brand and I usually take two but I also am usually about to eat a whole piece of cake üòÖüòÖ

Title: I‚Äôm curious what the consensus is on why there seems to be little known about gluten free eating in Japan. Do they not have all the food sensitivity issues that the rest of us have due to their diets? Or do they just live with it, and their country hasn‚Äôt gotten up to speed with gluten free eating? Just been wondering about this ‚ò∫Ô∏è

ResponsesV2.Message:
Celiac is very rare in ethnically Japan people. Its about 1 in 100 in the general world population but more like 1 in 10,000 in Japanese people.

The reason is because one of the two main genes thst causes celiac is very rare in Japan. This is probably due to the hundreds of years of isolation (ÈéñÂõΩ). 

The other gene that causes celiac is common in Japanese people but gets activated less often than the main one.

There is probably a large amount of undiagnosed people in Japan. Even with an incidence of 1 in 10,000, thwt eoukd be about 13,000 in Japan. Its probably betweeen 50-100,000 to be honest (probably more common thsn 1 in 10,000). and of course there are non ethnically Japanese people in Japan  too.

but maybe all those people just eat rice... soy sauce is probably damaging but might not cause symptoms in most. so it's not noticed. some might get misdiagnosed with a wheat allergy.

If doctors in Japan even hear about celiac it would be as a 'foreigner disease' and they would not pay any attention to it.

I saw a study that said there had been something like 27 reported cases in Japanese people. Ever. those people were extremely sick/dying.

I‚Äôm going to Mito in August and I‚Äôm super scared. Find Me Gluten Free didn‚Äôt have anything within like an hour labeled as safe and I can‚Äôt find any resources on how to find food outside Tokyo while I‚Äôm there. üò´

Title: Hi. So after having my previous post removed I have extensively used the search engine. I made a list of places that would be coeliac safe for my daughter who is in Shinjuku atm to eat. She has called us tonight upset and anxious as she is finding the language barrier difficult. The places we found have either not understood (she has a translation card for coeliac) or have said no. Is there anyone who can help us out a bit please? Even some pictures of gf snacks that are pre-packaged that she could buy perhaps? Any help would be greatly appreciated. Thanks so much.

ResponsesV2.Message:
There‚Äôs a place in Shinjuku called AIN SOPH. Journey that has gf options and will likely understand the translation card. 

Also Mos Burger chains have an allergen hot dog and hamburger that are a rice bun and meat with ketchup. I really liked them and found them fairly easily on my travels. They‚Äôre sealed and confirmed gluten free.

7/11 and lawsons also have soft boiled eggs, plain rice onigiri, and salmon salt onigiri which are safe. 

Konbini also have potato salad sachet, salad mix, cups of fresh fruit and puddings which are safe. My breakfast most days were an egg, plain rice onigiri and fruit.

I did a quick search in Shinjuku area. There‚Äôs a shabu shabu chain called Onyasai (or On-Yasai). If she orders the kombu broth, brings her own soy sauce, and sticks to just the meat and veggies, it‚Äôll be gluten free. I eat at this chain often. 

Also check for Indian restaurants. Indian curry is almost always GF and just eat it with rice vice naan. I find the staff at Indian restaurants typically speaks decent English too and I‚Äôm well understood.

Title:
Tomato and Onion (Tomaoni) is an American-themed  family restaurant chain that is not in Tokyo, but they have a couple dozen locations in smaller cities like Kagoshima, Naha, Tottori, Wakayama, etc. and is often on the highway. 

According to their allergen menu, the 100% beef Hamburg steak, hire saikoro steak, "American" grilled chicken steak, kids low-allergy hamburg, kids low-allergy curry, rice, pickles, spinach and bacon sautee, and a few other things are wheat free. Fries also listed, but I'm sure it's a shared fryer. 

When you're not in a big city, I recommend to look for national chains (Bikkuri Donki, Denny's, Gusto, Jonathan's, Cocoichi, Coco's, Kura sushi, Mos Burger, etc) as they often have an actual allergy menu and should theoretically have an allergy policy and can serve you when other restaurants may turn you away for asking about gluten free. It's lovely to support local businesses, but chain restaurants are our safe backup plan when traveling around spontaneously for sure. It helps that my family likes curry and hamburg steak üòÖ

There is a risk because it is "wheat free" and not "gluten free" and it is a shared kitchen, though you will have to assess the risk yourself. 

Here is the part of the website with a link to the allergy menu: 

https://www.tomato-a.co.jp/tomatoonion/tomaoni/index.html

And here is a blog post (not mine) of gf menu items at other chain family restaurants: 

https://glutenfree.empacede.co.jp/familyrestaurant/

.

ResponsesV2.Message: Thank you for sharing!ü´∂

Title:
#Kyoto - **January Japan trip notes**

We stayed at #MIMARUSuitesKyotoShijo in a 2 bedroom suite for 5. It had a large luggage room, dining table plus couches. Great location and offered free coffee and juice all day plus free beer and sake during happy hour. There was also a calligraphy activity on several days.

[https://mimaruhotels.com/en/hotel/suites-kyoto-shijo/](https://mimaruhotels.com/en/hotel/suites-kyoto-shijo/)

For restaurants - we stuck to the ones recommended in this group. We had dinner at:

#IkkakujuKarasuma - Mimaru called and booked on our behalf as the website reservation didn‚Äôt work. My son had GF okonimyaki. The staff seemed to understand about gluten and it is described on website. It is in a basement and a little hard to find.

Since then they have announced all dishes will be gluten free.

[https://www.ikkaku10.com/news/%E3%81%8A%E6%96%99%E7%90%86%E5%85%A8%E5%93%81%E3%82%B0%E3%83%AB%E3%83%86%E3%83%B3%E3%83%95%E3%83%AA%E3%83%BC%E3%81%AB%E3%81%AA%E3%82%8A%E3%81%BE%E3%81%97%E3%81%9F%EF%BC%81](https://www.ikkaku10.com/news/%E3%81%8A%E6%96%99%E7%90%86%E5%85%A8%E5%93%81%E3%82%B0%E3%83%AB%E3%83%86%E3%83%B3%E3%83%95%E3%83%AA%E3%83%BC%E3%81%AB%E3%81%AA%E3%82%8A%E3%81%BE%E3%81%97%E3%81%9F%EF%BC%81)

photo

#Sugarhill - we made a reservation a few weeks beforehand using Facebook Messenger. However, it wasn‚Äôt busy. There are only a few GF items on menu but they are very diligent and understanding about allergies etc.

#EngineRamen -  got there about 5:30 and got table straight away. When you order a GF dish, they give you a coaster when you order GF.

photo

We bought some cinnamon and macha yatsuhashi from #HonkeNishio atsuhashi in Arashiyama. Note they don't stock the GF chiffon cake at that store. I showed the staff the translation card and he confirmed it was made from rice.

[https://www.8284.co.jp/shop/arashiyama.html](https://www.8284.co.jp/shop/arashiyama.html)

As for groceries, Mimaru gave us a pamphlet showing the local grocery stores.

#SeijoIshii on the lower basement of Shijo Subway Station had a reasonable selection of standard groceries and western food (taco kits and sauce, pasta, pasta sauce etc.). It even had GF pasta. It was pretty small otherwise with very limited fruit and no vegetables.

photos

[https://www.seijoishii.co.jp/shop/details/135](https://www.seijoishii.co.jp/shop/details/135)

#MoritayaQualityFoodMarket - SUINA Muromachi (walk through the bookstore) had a reasonable selection of groceries plus meat, fruit and vegetables. I got some popcorn and saw some GF pasta.

[http://moritaya-qfm.com/shop/](http://moritaya-qfm.com/shop/)

I went to #Tavelt in Fujii Daimaru but didn't buy anything as I couldn‚Äôt find anything marked GF. It had a good selection of products, lots confectionary and gluten biscuits including Tim Tams at a similar price to Australia.

#Hakuba - **January Japan trip notes**

We stayed at #WadanoForestApartments. We had a 2 bedroom for 4 nights then a 3 bedroom for 4 nights. They will drop/pick up at supermarket, ski lift, rental, restaurant - very handy as Hakuba is quite large and spread out. And the in house onsen was great.

[https://www.wadanoforestapartments.com/](https://www.wadanoforestapartments.com/)

Our accommodation dropped us at the #ACoop supermarket several times during our stay. They pick you up 30 minutes later so it was a mad rush to buy ingredients for a few meals plus snacks and breakfast items. There‚Äôs only one coeliac in our family of 5 so we also needed lots of standard food. 

A-Coop is a big Japanese supermarket with not much international food. I couldn‚Äôt find tacos or corn chips. Following another post, I did find the gluten free section on the last trip but this section mainly had pancake mix, okonomiyaki mix and curries - nothing we needed. It's Aisle 17.

On mountain GF options are limited.

#BearsCafeSakka in the Snow Plaza Sakka (Happo One) did chips in separate fryer and a vegan curry with rice. The staff were Australian so easy to confirm. My son did take a GluteGuard when eating the chips.[https://www.bearscafehakuba.com/sakka](https://www.bearscafehakuba.com/sakka)

At Iwatake, inside the mountaintop cafe restaurant ‚ÄúSky Ark‚Äù we found #SoupStockTokyo. It was to the right with Hakuba Deli to the left as you enter the food service area. It had lobster bisque labelled as GF and Tokyo chicken curry gluten free by ingredient. The menu had a link to a website with the gluten free options. The staff didn't have the best English so we took a chance on cross contamination and had the soup/curry combo.

[https://s3-ap-northeast-1.amazonaws.com/sst-web-master/uploads/sst_gluten-free.pdf](https://s3-ap-northeast-1.amazonaws.com/sst-web-master/uploads/sst_gluten-free.pdf)[https://iwatake-mountain-resort.com/winter/ss](https://iwatake-mountain-resort.com/winter/ss)

This place is a chain that I hadn't seen mentioned during my research.

All the on mountain eating places have free water but sometimes you need to ask.

We ate out 3 times for dinner. Prior to travel, I emailed Hakuba Hotel Group to ask about gluten free options.

#RabbitHole in Wadano - did their El Chapo burger with lettuce instead of a bun and coleslaw instead of chips. Booked prior via Hakuba Hotel Group. 

[https://www.therabbitholex.com/locations/hakuba-japan](https://www.therabbitholex.com/locations/hakuba-japan)

[https://hakubahotelgroup.com/winter/restaurants/tori-co/](https://hakubahotelgroup.com/winter/restaurants/tori-co/)

#ToriCo. in Wadano - various yakitori were GF but not everything. You need to ask and they had to make some modifications and handled my sons order separately. There was no GF soy sauce so take some - I forgot. The wait staff were Australian so easy to discuss. Booked prior via Hakuba Hotel Group.

[https://hakubahotelgroup.com/winter/restaurants/tori-co/](https://hakubahotelgroup.com/winter/restaurants/tori-co/)

#MrMiyagi at Whitehorse Hotel in Echoland - majority of menu is GF. Run by Australians. Booked via appointment request on Facebook. 

[https://www.facebook.com/mrmiyagis/](https://www.facebook.com/mrmiyagis/)

#Tokyo  - **January Japan trip notes**

We stayed at #MIMARU Tokyo #Ikebukuro in a 2 bedroom family suite. It was comfortable and had what we needed. The only annoyance was the lowish table with couches.

[https://mimaruhotels.com/en/hotel/ikebukuro/](https://mimaruhotels.com/en/hotel/ikebukuro/)

We found 2 supermarkets within a few minutes walk - #Akafudado and #AeonMyBasket. Akafudado was larger and had all the typical things for a Japanese supermarket.

[https://www.ababakafudado.co.jp/afd/shop/ikebukuro/](https://www.ababakafudado.co.jp/afd/shop/ikebukuro/)

#Yamaya has a good selection of western food. However, Google did send us to back alley.

[https://maps.app.goo.gl/EhxnTxFqaaF2ByvF7](https://maps.app.goo.gl/EhxnTxFqaaF2ByvF7)

The pantry area of #ISP (Ikebukuro Shopping park) has a good selection of fresh fruit and vegetables and meat plus some western food. Bought tinned tomatoes, olive oil, salt, sugar, cheese, taco kit (note this had a may contain statement but we choice to use in Australia) and teabags there.

[http://www.web-isp.co.jp.e.qf.hp.transer.com/](http://www.web-isp.co.jp.e.qf.hp.transer.com/)

Managed to find #Marlowe in Seibu basement and purchased a GF chocolate cake.

[https://www.marlowe.co.jp/shop/ikebukuro/](https://www.marlowe.co.jp/shop/ikebukuro/)

Also checked out #NaturalLawson but didn‚Äôt find any GF food. Don Quijote north of station had quite a bit of food but didn't find anything specifically GF.

Special thanks to all the posts from Christie Osawa.

As for restaurants - we stuck to the common ones recommended in this group.

#GlutenFreeTs for lunch

[https://glutenfree.co.jp/](https://glutenfree.co.jp/)

#GonpachiAsakusaAzumabashi for dinner between visiting Sensoji and Sky Tree. Note that there are inappropriate explicit pictures on the wall upstairs. They had attempted to cover them up the offensive bit but it wasn't very effective. Also, the food serves are small and expensive compared to a kombini. My husband ate my sons beef dish thinking it was one of the appetisers.

[https://gonpachi.jp/asakusa/](https://gonpachi.jp/asakusa/)

#SoranoiroNipponRamen on Ramen Street in Tokyo Station for lunch - we were helped by the staff with ordering and warned about cross contamination. My son took a GluteGuard.

This map would have been handy as the street then the restaurant were a little tricky to find.

[https://www.tokyoeki-1bangai.co.jp/assets/pdf/floorMap_en.pdf](https://www.tokyoeki-1bangai.co.jp/assets/pdf/floorMap_en.pdf)

We ate a giant fairy floss from #DecoraCreamery at Odaiba DiverCity. They had an allergen menu and confirmed the fairy floss was GF.

[https://mitsui-shopping-park.com.e.act.hp.transer.com/gourmet/divercity-tokyo/g0019000000023121/](https://mitsui-shopping-park.com.e.act.hp.transer.com/gourmet/divercity-tokyo/g0019000000023121/)
