Title:
**January Japan trip notes**

Thanks to this group for all your tips and information. 

Our family of 5 - husband, myself and our 3 boys (18, 16 and 13) - from Australia spent 18 days in Japan in January. Our 13 year old is coeliac and also allergic to peanuts. He wasn't ever unwell and found enough food - although was sick of salmon onigiri by the end of the trip. He did use a GluteGuard when we thought cross contamination might be an issue.

We stayed in apartments in Toyko, Hakuba and Kyoto and I will follow up with separate posts for each location.

We took the following food with us:
* 3 loaves frozen GF bread - this was placed back into the freezer at each apartment
* Toaster bags
* 2 packets GF pasta
* 2 boxes GF muesli bars, 2 packets Coles GF cake bars
* GF cereal - Weetbix, GF Sultana Bran, Maple Crunch - this ran out on 2nd last day
* Mighty mite, Laughing Cow cream cheese
* 40 GF soy sauce fish purchased from Sushi Sushi, few Ketchup sachets from McDonalds
* Chicken spice mix jar, taco spice mix sachets
* Corn thins, rice crackers
* Drinking chocolate
* Rice flakes for porridge (didn‚Äôt use)
* Tunas, Tuna and beans. Tuna rice crackers snack pack (small enough for plane)
* 3 Noodle cups
* Dried cranberries

We also took:
* Normal muesli, muesli bars
* Vegemite squeezy pack

My overarching advice is that don‚Äôt do Japan (or any trip) without self catering. It is so much easier and healthier to make your own breakfast, some dinners, some lunches and snacks. In some ways it was harder to feed the 16 year old who only eats quite plain food and nothing with a sauce. Therefore, the ability for him to fry some eggs or chicken was invaluable. It was easy to find bread, oatmeal and cornflakes for the non-coeliacs.

Note that the kitchen sink won't have a plug (a Japanese thing according to the concierge!). Where we didn't have a dishwasher, we used an old bread bag to plug the drain.

I found the following websites provided some invaluable gluten free advice:

[https://www.tokyoweekender.com/food-and-drink/parents-guide-gluten-free-tokyo/](https://www.tokyoweekender.com/food-and-drink/parents-guide-gluten-free-tokyo/)

[https://gfguidejapan.com/](https://gfguidejapan.com/)

[https://fukuokaeats.com/eats/gluten-free-japan](https://fukuokaeats.com/eats/gluten-free-japan)

[https://www.legalnomads.com/gluten-free/japan/?fbclid=IwAR27eOPC8XFDC_mz2qIc5XdeZC8rpyylWZ_UX0asIg6vHottp3nBSMJttZ0](https://www.legalnomads.com/gluten-free/japan/?fbclid=IwAR27eOPC8XFDC_mz2qIc5XdeZC8rpyylWZ_UX0asIg6vHottp3nBSMJttZ0)

And this gave an overview of supermarket products:

[https://www.simplyoishii.com/grocery-guide.html](https://www.simplyoishii.com/grocery-guide.html)

In addition, I followed this group for 6 months saving particular posts then used the search for specific locations, products, restaurants etc.

I would also note that I printed cards from Coeliac Australia and made a list of words and kanji to look for on packaging but I didn‚Äôt really use either. We relied on Google Translate, English menus and English speaking staff - we were in very touristy areas.

Some general advice - I couldn't have done without mobile data to access Google Maps, Google Translate and general searching. 4 of us had eSIMs (airalo) and one had a physical SIM (older phone). It was cheaper than a pocket wifi and allowed us to separate then contact each other via WhatsApp.

We purchased Pasmo Passports in Ikebukuro Station on our second day. Using an IC card was very convenient and I would definitely recommend this over tickets. We did have to ask 3 times where to go for the correct office within the station but everyone had a map to show us.

After you plan your itinerary, double check the places will be open on the days you are planning to go and the closing time - we went to Tokyo Imperial Palace on a Friday when East Garden wasn't open and got to Tofukiji too late to entry the gardens.

I was worried about not having enough food on the trip as we had to transit via Hong Kong (where there are no GF options) so took frozen cooked chicken and 10 x 100g yoghurts in our carry on. However, the plane food was enough and ended up throwing away the chicken and some yoghurts as we entered Japan. We hung onto the Tuna rice crackers snack pack in case of delay on the home trip but wasn't required.

Have at least 20 minutes to transfer between trains a. We only had 10 min between express train and skinkansen  at Nagoya. Bit tight!

For sightseeing and other general advice, I borrowed guide books from the library and listened to most episodes of [https://www.facebook.com/SightseeingJapanPodcast](https://www.facebook.com/SightseeingJapanPodcast)

ResponsesV2.Message: Great post. We'll be travelling from Australia as well and plan on taking our Weetbix and other pre-packaged items. With the tuna, did you bring cans or tuna in other types of containers? With the GF soy fish, I've never heard of sushi sushi. I'm in Sydney. Is there a link, by any chance? I can't find them anywhere (I've got a few satchets from Big Crunch Sushi meals but not enough to take). Was customs funny about anything? I'm worried they'll dispose of my daughter's food.
Thank you so much for your advice üôèü´Ç

Title:
Hi All! I went to Japan back in October and never posted about my favorite restaurants.  I am posting here about TOKYO specifically, and and a lot of these places came from suggestions on this group (thank you!) or were ones I found.  Lots of notes as I was writing this all up into an email for a friend. 

Also a side note- I do NOT actually recommend using the Gluten Free Translation card.  I used it my first few days, and it generally sent the workers into a frenzy and they would be so worried they would make me sick and ended up just saying "dont eat here"- so I got better at explaining I cannot have wheat, soy sauce, etc, and asked if they could cook my food on a clean surface.  I stayed away from fried foods unless it was a totally GF place.  Japanese people are *SO NICE* and *POLITE*, that sometimes the GF card made the situation more dramatic than it needed to be.  Just my 2 cents, you do you.  

**Convenience Store foods**- the convenience stores were generally my go to.  The common brands are 7/11, Family Mart, and Lawsons.  Lawsons and 7/11 were the best, FamilyMart was fine but not quite as much selection usually.  Here is a good blog post about GF foods you can find at most of those places. I am also attaching a picture of Onigiri- there are only certain ones that are GF tho (mentioned in the blog), so you just need to check.  I lived on these and the soft/hard-boiled eggs and presliced fruit. Also, if you happen to see the "green tea cheesecake" (its in like a little cup you eat with a spoon) from Lawson's, don't sleep on it. its real good! https://healthytokyo.com/blog/gluten-free-food-in-japanese-convenience-stores/

**Restaurants**- These were some in particular in Tokyo I had a good meal/success at.  Sushi is kind of hard, they sometimes brush the soy sauce onto the sushi in advance, so you just have to explain to them no sauce when you arrive, and I brought my own tamari and showed them I had my own sauce.  I still took gluten-ease pills at places I was not entirely sure about in case there was some gluten in the rice vinegar or they had possibly marinated the sushi. 
# Shimbu Sakiya Ramen- Shibuya. Several GF options, even GF fried chicken and gf/vegan pot stickers.  I went here twice, it was really good.

Gluten Free T's- Roppongi, this was definitely mostly "western" people dining, but the food was good.  I went here twice as well. 
# NO MEAT, NO LIFE. 5go.- Shinjuku, Yakiniku restaurant (you grill the meat yourself, and it is really good) This was another place I just brought my own tamari and it was totally fine. I just had meat and salad, but could have also gotten some rice. I think any Yakiniku restaurant could accommodate GF since its mainly just meat.  Just need to make sure it is not pre-marinated.  The beef in Japan is incredible quality, I really highly recommend at least trying one meal like this.
# Mimasu- Shinjuku. Sushi, was good, they were out of a lot of fish when I was there but it was overall good.  (you have to try Toro- fatty tuna!). the owners were very old but were fine with me showing them my questions on my phone. This was the one place I felt like GF was not fully understood so I just watched a little more carefully when they were preparing my food. This came up on a GF google maps search and others said they "were great and totally understood GF and accommodated" but I did not feel that was the case personally.
# Soranoiro NIPPON- Ramen in Tokyo Station (Ginza), you have to exit the actual train part of the station (but stay in the station...) and put your bag in a locker, the restaurant is very small, and it was a bit hard to find. I looked at the google photos of what the outside of the restaurant looked like.  I wish I could tell you exactly how to get there, but it was sort of under a staircase... there are a ton ton ton of restaurants in Tokyo station, but this was my first meal after flying into Japan and it was good. It was not anything fancy but again, good.
# Gluten Free Kushiage Su- Ginza- this place was really special.  It was a 10 or 13 course meal and it was all small bites on skewers.  It was honestly so good and unique, and only 8 seats in the whole place.  You need to make a reservation, and it was the most expensive meal I had there, but it was honestly worth it.  Highly recommend if you are a foodie and want a unique experience.  Everything on the menu is GF!

We also went to a "teppanyaki" restaurant, but I do not remember the name.  you could *try* for this style of cuisine (it is "hibachi", which is not the correct term for it but what we call it in the US), they just cooked my portion first without any sauces etc. It was a little more complicated to explain GF, but if you end up at a place like that with your friends I think you will manage.

For breakfast, I usually just had 7/11 stuff.  I am weird tho and can eat savory for breakfast.

Did not make it to, but wanted to (they were either closed or it was not convenient for me)
# Cafe Komaya Roppngi- someone at Gluten free t's suggested this place

There were honestly quite a few places I tagged on google maps that had GF in the reviews or came up for some reason, so I am sure you will find something where you are, there are a lot more I could list here but were just ones I found on a search, so not sure how legit they were.

**Bars (just for fun!)**
# Aoyama Tunnel- if you go here make sure you check out both floors, It is really small but a really cool spot. Maybe my favorite bar I have ever been to.
# DJ BAR Bridge SHINJUKU- another fun bar. you have to take the outside elevator to it. you will see what I mean if you go there.

#tokyo #conveniencestore #ramen #yakiniku #Sushi #glutenfree #Shinjuku #ginza #shibuya #roppongi

ResponsesV2.Message: I had the same problem with the gluten free card. I did better without it.

Thank you for such a positive post. I am travelling with my parents and two kids in April, 3 of the 5 of us are coeliac and the posts on this group have been stressing me out. We are not looking for "foodie" experiences and just want to eat to survive. I lived in Japan for a year when I was 16 so can speak Japanese so am now confident we can just work it out. Time to now relax about it even if it means we are eating the same 7/11 meal every day for 2  weeks üòÇ

Title:
ü´•**LONG POST**ü´•

Hi everyone!
 
First of all, want to give a **big thanks** to everyone in this group, you have all been an immense help in planning my upcoming trip.

I am travelling to Japan in March and I am a lifelong (diagnosed at 9 m.o.) sensitive celiac with really bad reactions to gluten. These reactions have even required hospitalization the last two times I made a mistake (üôÉ‚úåÔ∏è), so I am feeling really anxious regarding this trip, but Japan has been on my bucket list for the longest time.

I have made for myself **a GF map**, **a list of (possibly?) GF products in stores **and **a list of keywords regarding GF diet**. I want to share these with you in hopes it will be of help to someone else in planning their own trip, as I know that so much random information can be really overwhelming. I also apologize for not giving credit to original specific posts, but as I was in the beginning preparing this only for myself and as I have gone through (literally ü•≤) hundreds of posts in this group, I really don‚Äôt know whose posts I have used to compile this.

These might be useful especially to **people who are traveling as a part of a group** - my issue is that I am travelling as a part of a travel agency organized group trip and I need to be able to find something (whatever) to eat near me at times when we have free time or breaks for food, so it was really important for me to prepare myself in a way that I do not need to search a lot for the nearest place where I can get something to eat. With that in mind, I have prepared the following:

**1. GF MAP**

I‚Äôve created a GF map showing GF offer in restaurants, bakeries, confectioneries and similar in **Tokyo**, **Kyoto**, **Osaka**, **Hiroshima**, **Nara**, **Nagano** and **Matsumoto**. I have also included some specific stores (like those offering organic produce) and stores that are not as widespread as 7/11, Lawson and Family Mart (as, of course, there is no sense in pinning all of those üòÅ).

The way I have compiled the map is that I was searching through this group and the Find me GF app/website for recommendations, and then checking out menus on the official websites of those restaurants, bakeries, etc. I have included only those that specifically mention on their websites keywords like **gluten**, **gluten free **and **celiac disease**.

Each city is marked with its color-specific pins. For each location, I have listed a couple of dishes they offer, just so that I have some general sense of what their offer is. At the end of each description is a code ‚Äì **N/D (not GF dedicated)** or **D (GF dedicated)**. I have additionally highlighted GF-dedicated objects with **black pins**. I have tried to list all locations alphabetically for each city ‚Äì there might be some errors, as I was mostly trying not to change the names as they show on Google Maps.

**You can access the map via the following link: https://www.google.com/maps/d/edit?mid=1QuiUYYbNtotsmNcrjRdXIZ4icOqsmjg&usp=sharing**

‚ùóÔ∏èDISCLAIMERS‚ùóÔ∏è

- Although I previously said that I have only included locations that mention gluten, gluten free and celiac disease on their websites, there are a couple of exceptions - such as chain restaurants that have previously been rated safe by members of this group (Coco Ichiban and its allergen free curry, for example).

- In some cases, I was not able to find official menus ‚Äì when they are not posted on the official website or when there is no official website. In these cases, I would look at the latest version of the menu posted on Google reviews or I would look at menus posted on Find me GF. With that in mind ‚Äì please use the dishes listed only as **general guidelines** and look for a complete menu/the most updated version of the menu available.

- For the majority of locations, **I haven‚Äôt listed cross-contamination information**. There are a couple of exceptions where I added a special note (*) ‚Äì in these cases, there were either many positive or negative reviews regarding cross-contamination.

- As I am not really a fan of sushi, I haven‚Äôt really mentioned sushi places, sorry. üòÖ

**2) LIST OF (POSSIBLY?) GF PRODUCE IN STORES**

I have gone through hundreds of posts in which people have posted products they have found in **konbinis**, **supermarkets **or **specialized stores**. I have screenshotted those products, put them in a single document and organized them according to the store they were bought at. At the end of the document, there is a large category ‚ÄòUnspecified store‚Äô ‚Äì that is for the products for which the post owner has not listed the store or where I simply missed that info.

I wanted to have this list just to have **SOME starting point **when looking for GF products.

**You can access this list both in Word (in case you want to additionally edit it yourself) and PDF (in case you just want to save it to your phone) via the following link: https://drive.google.com/drive/folders/1zWMGlxQj1xJLk_9fDhsXkKcaamKMmmOL?usp=sharing **

‚ùóÔ∏èDISCLAIMERS‚ùóÔ∏è

BIG BIG disclaimer ‚Äì **a LOT of these might not actually be GF** for several reasons:

1. A lot of people have different levels of tolerance to gluten.

2. A lot of people have different opinions on eating mizuame, unidentified starch, unidentified yeast, etc.

3. A lot of products listed are from several-years-old posts, there is a large chance that the ingredient list has changed.

**PLEASE CHECK EACH PRODUCT FOR YOURSELF BEFORE YOU BUY IT ‚Äì make sure it is GF, and specifically, that it is GF in a sense that is acceptable for your own experience with celiac disease.**

**3) LIST OF KEYWORDS**

I have compiled a list of **keywords related to the GF diet **just to have a **visual reminder** when checking any suspicious ingredients on a label, or in case a restaurant employee asks for **additional clarification** on my restaurant allergy card.

I have marked ingredients that are explicitly harmful to a person with celiac disease with **red and ‚ÄòX‚Äô**. The exemption is oats, which are, of course, individual to every person with celiac disease, but as I avoid oats myself, I have marked them with an ‚ÄòX‚Äô.

I have marked ingredients that are questionable with **yellow and a ‚Äò?‚Äô**. These are the ingredients that can be acceptable to celiacs, depending on **what are they derived from** (i.e., mizuame from barley is bad, mizuame from corn is good).

**You can access this list both in Word (in case you want to additionally edit it yourself) and PDF (in case you just want to save it to your phone) via the following link: https://drive.google.com/drive/folders/1Mt3H6RuukCGmfV18ROi4K6JRNvUv9HfR?usp=sharing**

‚ùóÔ∏èDISCLAIMERS‚ùóÔ∏è

I do not speak Japanese, so these are my best guesses based on a Google search of translations and pronunciations.

I am aware that this may seem like ‚Äòtoo much‚Äô but I am fully determined not to end up in a hospital in Japan. ü´†ü§û

Sorry for the long post and I hope these will be helpful to at least one of you out there! üòä

P.S. I also have some questions if you can help me:

1. I have bought my allergy card from Legal Nomads, and I‚Äôve noticed that it does not, for example, mention mizuame. That seems like something I would also like to check when wanting to try some dish that has a sweet element to it, but I am afraid of overwhelming the staff with the allergy card and my additional monologue.

My question is - how do you usually approach staff without overwhelming them with information and what are some things that you ALWAYS highlight when trying to explain GF and contamination?

2. Which apps for food delivery have you used in Japan?

Thanks everyone!

#gfmap #restaurants #bakeries #stores #supermarkets #konbini #list #Tokyo #Osaka #Kyoto #Hiroshima #Nagano #Nara #Mastumoto

ResponsesV2.Message: This is incredible!! I am so grateful. I'm also a sensitive celiac! I really appreciate your thoroughness in researching each restaurant to make sure it's truly celiac-safe!
Wow! Thank you so much, we are planning our trip in July and this has really helped relieve fear of finding gf food ‚ù§Ô∏è

Title:
Huge thank you to this group, backing up some recommendations I found on our recent trip! I am Coeliac  so I try my best but I also have moments of letting my guard down and then I know it. But def found some gems! Here‚Äôs my experience. 

Onigiri (or as we call Sushi Triangles) - salted salmon best snack around- grab from convenience stores and supermarkets.  
Miso paste- check ingredients you can get GF ones without barley 

Shibuya
Gonpachi - Great with GF I had the Yakitori with salt and the GF version of the Prawn Tempura bowl. Even came with a GF miso and staff helpful. It‚Äôs loud but a great atmosphere, you can book private rooms here also. 
Food show - I love Japanese food halls!! I found you can buy yakitori cooked with salt, and a range of salads and sushi gluten free

Hakuba
Hakuba Pizza and some of the other pizza restaurants do GF and home deliver. 
Unjuane (Happo One)- amazing burgers, they will do lettuce versions of burger, I had the beef and the staff were helpful with GF
Calico (Ecoland) - Will do lettuce version of their burger.
Campfire Sushi (Ecoland) - these guys have an English menu that is really helpful, I was not able to determine if the sushi rice was safe but i took the risk and ordered the salmon and tuna nigiri, I was ok. Took my own soy. They also do an amazing sashimi bowl that comes with warm rice on the side - prob safer option if worried about sushi rice. 
Base of Tsugaike (next to the foot Onsen) There is a yakitori stand they will cook you chicken yakitori with salt. The other side of foot Onsen is a place that does a vegan and gf curry. 

Haneda Airport: Terminal 3 under Villa Fontaine Grand Hotel there are a stack of restaurants, this is what I found. 
Hot Pot - I didn‚Äôt eat at hot pot but had a great chat with a very helpful restauranteur we worked out I could have the kelp broth but no dipping sauces - so take your own soy or dipping sauce
Sushi restauant- They have a menu with allergens the cooked miso cod was GF
Indian -The Indian curries are GF (I spoke with the chef) we had butter chicken and chicken tikka was delicious

#hakuba #HanedaAirport #shibuya #tsugaike #calico #gonpachi #foodshow

Title:
Sharing recent trip experience as we went to rural part of Hokkaido and did not have access to GF friendly restaurants (only had one restaurant at the hotel and no other stores within walking distance).

I found Amazon Japan had a number of gluten free (and also dairy free options), and they delivered to our hotel location in Hokkaido within 2-3 days. It was easy to search in English I just typed Gluten free and tons of results came out. 

We ordered before we travelled so by the time we arrived the hotel the items were already delivered. 

So instead of carrying all the items in your suitcase from home, you can easily order GF soy sauce, snacks, ramen, and even ready made GF curry to your location.

Title:
Hi! I‚Äôm going back to Japan and will be doing one night in Kusatsu in Gunma. We would like to stay at a ryokan that can serve me gluten free food. I am gluten intolerant. I thought we had found Urakusatsu TOU which said they can accommodate. But then they just came back saying there is wheat in many seasonings so it is difficult to serve dishes without seasoning. 

I am not sure if I could try to clarify that cross contamination is not an issue for me, in the case that‚Äôs why they‚Äôre saying now they cannot feed me?

Or find another ryokan in Kusatsu but I‚Äôm having no luck. 

Any suggestions?
Thank you so much.

ResponsesV2.Message: I frequently encounter this seasoning issue. It's because soy sauce and many other seasonings used in Japan contain wheat, and it seems like many Japanese chefs can't imagine cooking without them. It's not an issue of cross-contamination, it's one of the ingredients, albeit in small quantities. Often at ryokan I just end up asking them to broil me fish with just salt on it, and give me a bowl of rice and a raw egg. But of course that is not so much fun when everyone else is getting some elaborate meal.
Gluten Free Tours Japan is this something we‚Äôd be able to hire you to help with?

Title:
Just back from a week in Furano with a coeliac 16yo. We took a half suitcase of gf noodles and microwave meals, plus Carman's bars for snacks on the slopes. This stash proved invaluable as the on-slope dining options were difficult for our coeliac because:
* The restaurants (next to the Furano Ropeway and the Kitanomine gondola) were fairly busy from about 11.30am-1.30pm. There were few other -- perhaps no other -- dining options on the slopes due to a recent fire in the mountain-top restaurant. 
* Self-ordering, so limited customer-facing staff to discuss gf options.
* However, steamed rice was available and consumed without a problem.

Some ski and gf tips following our experience:
* We stayed at the Prince Hotel on the Furano side of the resort. It was ski-in, ski-out, which meant we could come back to the hotel room for lunch -- a big plus. However, dining in the hotel was very expensive, which ruled it out for us as a regular option. The least expensive dinner was the buffet at 6500 yen per person. Three of us were eating for that sum in town. The other restaurants were 8000 yen to 12000 yen pp for dinner. Our room did not have a microwave and the only common microwave was in the hotel souvenir/convenience store. We took a small electric rice cooker we bought from K-Mart and it did the job on the microwave meals (although over 30 mins v 3 mins).
* Salmon flake onigari from the Lawson and 7-11 convenience stores is good trustworthy snack. Others in this group have mentioned the spicy pollack roe onigari as safe but we avoided due to wheat being mentioned in ingredients when we translated using Google lens.
* Google lens is very handy for translating ingredients in convenience stores on the fly.
* A gf card in Japanese helped. Japanese staff happy to read -- and understood the content. We bought ours here and it worked (you also get an English translation): https://www.legalnomads.com/gluten-free/japan/
* Travel with gf soy or terriyaki sauce
* We were fairly conservative. When in doubt, we left out. 
* A skiing tip: if you want group ski lessons in English, book a long way out. I would suggest perhaps four weeks in advance ... but I don't know for sure as we missed out (was seeking group lessons for 14yo and 16yo intermediate skiers). There was not an abundance of English-language ski instructors. 

All-in-all a great week of snow and skiing without a glutening. Can recommend the following restaurants in Furano for coeliacs (the first is a new one I hadn't read about in this group before): 
* Ezo Dining: https://www.instagram.com/koko_ezo_dining_?igshid=MzRlODBiNWFlZA%3D%3D Book them by messaging Instagram link above. They are a very welcoming shabu-shabu (Japanese hot pot) restaurant which, once we explained we had a gf diner, prepared a coeliac-safe seaweed broth for cooking. We brought our own gf sauce. 8000 yen for three.
* Masaya: http://furanomasaya.com Famous teppan restaurant whose owner-chef is well-versed in gf for coeliacs, points out gf dishes and cooks them separately to avoid contamination; also provides gf soy sauce. The food is sensational. 6500 yen for three.
* Bistro Le Chemin: https://www.tripadvisor.com.au/Restaurant_Review-g674811-d4555582-Reviews-Bistro_Le_Chemin-Furano_Hokkaido.html High-quality and more expensive French bistro. I had read here that some coeliacs had visited in the past and had communicated directly with an Aussie chef. This year, it was a Japanese chef and maitre'd. The maitre'd read our gf card carefully and chatted with the chef and me to make some great recommendations. When our taxi was taking too long, he drove us back in his car to the hotel! The deserts were superb, including creme br√ªl√©e accompanied by black tea ice-cream. 15,000 yen for three.

Title:
If you‚Äôre looking for an easy ‚Äúteishoku‚Äù or Japanese set meal restaurant and don‚Äôt mind cross contamination, I highly recommend the Otoya teishoku chain.

None of their premade sets are gluten free, but many of their side items are wheat free, so I just choose several of them and make my own meal.üòä
They have menus in Japanese and English.

The 28 major allergens are marked in their menu for reference as well. I typically get one of the fish options + miso soup + a couple of other items. In the photo, I got bonito flakes + mentaiko + free diced radish.

Another bonus: They have unlimited free hot green tea!

Title:
Just got back from two weeks in Japan. Huge thanks to this group, we ate well at many of the recommended places in Osaka (Genji Soba), Kyoto (Engine Ramen so good we ate it twice), and Tokyo. It was a little more difficult up in Hokkaido so I thought I'd add the following:
#Otaru
We stayed at the Grand Park Otaru which is in the same building as a nice Eon supermarket and close to a 7-11. The brunch buffet had allergen labels on each dish, not many options for the price but that's Otaru. As with all buffets, there is a risk of cc but the kitchen looked tidy.
On an old rec from this group we went to „Åæ„Çã„ÅÑ„Å°ÂæåËó§ÂïÜÂ∫ó for dinner. I showed the staff my gf card and the chef came out to point out which items were safe. Their ramen is 100% buckwheat noodles but the broth is no longer gf as they use soy sauce in it. I went with a great plate of tempura veggies and their Otaru chicken which was very good.
https://maps.app.goo.gl/nbmrkMY6xvz4LXpb7
#Kiroro
We snowboarded two days at Kiroro. I brought lots of safe snacks but noticed that the cafe on the first floor had not only good coffee but also a German-style sausage as well as a potato dish that looked safe but I did not investigate.
#Yoichi
We went for the Nikka distillery tour during a massive snowstorm, when we got off the train we gambled and walked about 15 minutes to Unino Yoichiya for a bowl of sea urchin and rice. I showed my gf card to the staff who told me that the rice + urchin and tuna was safe but the miso soup was not. It was really good and very fresh. My non-gf partner loved the half-crab in miso.

We‚Äôre from New Zealand and purchase these capsules from our pharmacy or health shops. My daughter is finding them invaluable whilst travelling, enables her to eat fries that are cooked with other foods if that‚Äôs all there is on the menu for her. Some places have said no to a simple bowl of rice.

ResponsesV2.Message: These supplements are not beneficial for people with celiac disease. Most of them are broken down in the stomach before they get a chance to work on the gluten, others leave peptides from gluten that are even better at attacking the intestinal lining. Scientists are working to find a way to break down gluten in such a way that it won‚Äôt cause the immune reaction that causes the damage of celiac disease but so far there is no such treatment. If you would like to see scientific evidence here‚Äôs a good article: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC7400306/

We use this product from the US.  Comes in a large bottle or in individual packets great for a purse.  I originally bought them from the manufacturer but are now carried on Amazon US.  I travel a great deal for work and are great for me dealing with cross contamination.  When I‚Äôve been ‚Äúglutened‚Äù they help ease the symptoms.  We are leaving for Japan in March and have a fresh supply on the packing pile!

Title:
#niseko
Just back from a week in Niseko and happy to share our experiences.
For breakfasts we took our own gf cereals with us and bought eggs, bacon & baked beans as well at the pharmacy in Hirafu188.
Lunches were hard on the mountain. She had snacks from home in her pockets and we took mostly gf 2 min noodles and asked for hot water. The place at the base of Hanazono happily filled these for ¬•200, the restaurant at the Hirafu Gondola fussed as not allowed to bring in own food but I showed them our GF card and then they agreed to (plus we were a group of 11 and the other 10 were ordering from the menu). Boyo mountain hut at Hirafu happily filled it but the water was luke warm and the noodles remained raw so she ended up with a bowl of their rice and we had taken our own gf soy sauce which came in handy plus a sprinkling of noodle flavouring. We also took a thermos and prepared gf Mac & cheese (from home) in our apartment before heading out a couple of days.
Dinners - we tried to make our own one night but honestly it was so hard to find ingredients and took so long using translator app that I actually think eating out was easier.
The Vale - could do a gf burger, no chips/wedges were safe but the burger was fine. We ended up going here twice.
Wild Bills were easily able to accommodate (tex mex)
R Niseko pizza we were told did gf pasta - which they did but it took an extra 20 mins for them to prepare (ü§∑üèº‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è) . The pasta looked and tasted suspiciously like regular pasta but she had no reaction so maybe it was just very good gf pasta?? She said it was delicious but the long wait had her almost in tears from hunger as we were only able to get an 8.30pm booking
Kumo Restaurant at Skye Niseko was amazing and a favourite. She was able to eat the rice, the skewers without the glaze, a cold tofu dish and salmon hand roll. All very good. They couldn‚Äôt guarantes the miso ‚Äùmay contain‚Äù but she risked it and was fine.
The Alpinist she was able to eat the raclette and also the fondue (minus the bread). Delicious.
Hope this helps!

ResponsesV2.Message: Did you bring the 2 min noodles from home or buy them in Japan?
We loved Kumo!

Title:
Otoshi („ÅäÈÄö„Åó),

For visitors unaware Otoshi is a Japanese appetizer that is served sometimes without you ordering it. You can look at it like a table charge. It will be served without you requesting it and you will be charged for it even if you don‚Äôt eat it. It‚Äôs customary in places like bars and Izakayas. It can be confusing when food turns up that you didn‚Äôt order and you might  expect not to pay for it that it might be complimentary. In some cases you may be able to request before you sit down not to be served it but given this contributes to the financial operations of a business it‚Äôs best just to accept it graciously. Unfortunately it‚Äôs very rare that it would be gluten free. Edamame can be an Otoshi dish which is gluten free but you need to check the water used for boiling them was not contaminated by boiling wheat noodles.

Sho-Chiku-en‚Ä¶ Vegan and gluten free cafe with online store

I haven‚Äôt been to the cafe but ordered on their website (using chrome to translate). I was able to use my American credit card to order on the website and have it delivered to my house. 

The tiramisu (in the jars) is amazing! The rainbow cake is also really good. I haven‚Äôt tried the muffins yet.

https://sho-chiku-en.com/

https://maps.app.goo.gl/h6ZXPcBaTB9FRGb79?g_st=ic

Title:
There‚Äôs an interesting steak place near my real estate office that I‚Äôve eaten at around four times now. 
It‚Äôs called Steak Lodge and it has this whole country-western vibe. You can also get lamb and kangaroo meat (I‚Äôve only ever had beef!)
Showing the staff my allergy card, they‚Äôve been very accommodating. Just be advised that we can‚Äôt have the mugi-rice nor the soup (because the vinagar is sus!). 
I usually get 200g of steak with broccoli and mashed potatoes on the side with a coke. 
They have a few locations around Tokyo. 

https://maps.app.goo.gl/RMN7SrJdimpd789M7?g_st=ic

https://vt.tiktok.com/ZSF1u94ac/

Please advised that I have tested the mashed potatoes with my NIMA sensor, so this meal may not be appropriate for Australians. 

üö®(PLEASE NOTE: I understand that the NIMA Sensor is very controversial within the celiac community. I‚Äôm using the NIMA sensor as just another tool in my arsenal to keep myself safe from sickness and harm. I‚Äôm well aware of its limitations with detecting gluten in fermented foods such as soy sauce. But since it is expensive BUT could be helpful to others, I‚Äôm sharing results here so that other people can have access to the information. You don‚Äôt have to trust the results I post. What food one chooses to eat, what risks to take, are deeply personal decisions. Always do what‚Äôs best for you. 

NIMA Sensors can only test a pea-sized portion of food, not an entire dish, so cross contamination is still possible. Use of a NIMA Sensor is not a replacement for reading food labels, asking questions, or being cautious and diligent. 

With all that said, please understand that because I‚Äôm very sensitive to gluten, I research every single thing that I eat. I only post ‚ú®safe‚ú®test results on foods that I have consumed myself with zero reaction. Thank you for your time and have a great day!)üö®

If you‚Äôre in Tokyo this month, be sure to drop by the Baumkuchen Expo in Ikebukuro!
Bakeries from around Japan are selling baumkuchen cakes, and many are wheat/gluten freeüòç‚ÄºÔ∏è

Dates: January 24-29, 2024
Station: Ikebukuro
Location: Tobu Department Store, 8th floor
Hours: 10:00-19:00

This event is held each year and I typically buy 5-10 whole cakesüòä See my previous posts on past events.

As always, check each individual bakery/item to see what the ingredients and specific allergens are.

‚û°Ô∏èEvent instagram: https://www.instagram.com/baumkuchenexpo

We now wish that Meghan and Hiroshi covered other countries too!!

Title: I‚Äôve been looking at food that I can bring into Japan. ResponsesV2.Message:
Pack food is a great idea. I brought gluten free pasta, tuna, protein bars, nuts (I think customs has an issue with cashews) package gf oatmeal and 7-11 has rice balls and many other snacks (check this site)
I did not eat out but I stayed with son and daughter in law so I had a kitchen to cook in and plenty fish rice and eggs from the local market.

You cannot take animal products (meats and cheeses) or produce. Learned the hard way at customs and was almost fined thousands of dollars.

Title:
Hi All,
I went to Japan in November 2023 and posted my review of places shortly after. But I‚Äôve finally updated our plan, which I thought I would share here should it help anyone.
I can‚Äôt stress the importance of planning. Basically I worked out places to visit and then found food options near by. I booked as many places as possible. Booking places meant i could confirm gluten free options. The majority of places I booked I found from this group. I showed my translation card to a few places but all said no. 
We visited a friend who lives in Tokyo so he also helped me. Having the plan made the situation so much easier. Yes sometimes things didn‚Äôt work out and I had a seven eleven lunch but this only happened once. Yes I was a little sad that I couldn‚Äôt just wing it but Atleast this way I knew I would be getting safe food.
Happy to answer any questions.
Just can‚Äôt stress how important it is to plan your Japan trip.

https://www.facebook.com/groups/glutenfreeexpatsjapan/permalink/2529132273963982/?mibextid=W9rl1R

ResponsesV2.Message: Did you confirm udatsu sushi uses gluten free vinegar?

Title: Honestly, I would not recommend travelling to Japan with a gluten intolerant child. It has ruined our trip trying to find food for him to eat. Many restaurants won‚Äôt serve you they want nothing to do with it. There are a few gems but they can be hard to find. Or they might be closed the day you go, or they may have changed their menu to what is online or the line is too big for your child to wait patiently in a blizzard. If you do it, get airbnbs so you can prepare as much food as possible yourself. I‚Äôve been in tears at least five times trying to sort out something for him to eat.

ResponsesV2.Message: Are you still there? If you are I‚Äôd contact Gluten Free Tours Japan and see if they can squeeze you in as a client for the rest of your trip, I hate to see people struggle so hard and not enjoy their vacation.

I‚Äôm so sorry. I have celiac and was just there for almost 3 weeks and found it pretty easy. Granted, I‚Äôm an adult and perhaps your child is a pickier eater. For me if worse came to worse‚Ä¶.and I couldn‚Äôt figure something out‚Ä¶I went to yakiniku ‚Ä¶so easy to eat grilled meat and rice.

7-11 has onigiri and perhaps they don‚Äôt want salmon, but they also have plain rice and string cheese‚Ä¶.yogurt, even make your own smoothies. I ate a lot of string cheese for snacks.

Coco Curry has a veggie GF option. Cheap and easy and fast.

Starbucks has a GF banana rice flour muffin.

All the mochi treats at street vendors made me feel like I could for once eat street foods like everyone else.

I hope it gets easier for you all.

Title:
Update/reminder: went to #Afuri tonight (in #tokyo) and there are no gluten free ramen options. While the konjac noodles are gluten free all the soups have soy sauce in them. The vegan ramen was suggested as the ramen with the least soy sauce in it. Another post a while ago also suggested they cook all noodles in the same water - I didn‚Äôt watch them cooking so I have no idea. 

I ate it anyway and feel fine. I‚Äôm not a hugely reactive coeliac and so am just rolling with cross contamination and the occasional thing with a little bit of soy sauce in it for 3.5 weeks to help retain a dash of sanity!

The hubby wanted me to add in how fabulous the service was - it really was, they went above and beyond to figure out what I could and couldn‚Äôt eat and were honestly really great! Could not fault the service. 

Especially after lunch when we went to a different place that had no gluten free mains. I asked to order rice and an egg and they said no you have to eat a main to get a seat. So I went window shopping while the hubby got seated at a 2 person table and had a lunch date with an empty chair üôÑüôáüèº‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è

ResponsesV2.Message: This has been known about Afuri for awhile, unfortunately. Not trustworthy for very sensitive celiacs.

Title:
Our 3-week trip has been absolutely incredible! üáØüáµ Feeling grateful for this group and keen to pay it forward for future travellers.

So not only am I gluten free, I am also dairy free, red meat free (only occasions), steer clear from sugar, processed foods and having oil-heavy meals. I have a few gut issues and work really hard to avoid putting junk into my body. And to top it off, my partner is vegan too. It‚Äôs safe to say that food was certainly an obstacle for us, however we managed to stay well fed. Here are my tips!

**Tokyo**

üç¥Gluten free Ts  
They need no intro to this group. I ordered the chicken noodle dish twice in a row. Available on Uber eats.

üç¥ Crisp salad works shibuya square - 
Custom made salad bowls! You have complete control over everything they put in it. Available on Uber eats too. 

**Fujikawaguchiko**

This place was a highlight in terms of sightseeing and the sheer beauty of the lake/mt Fuji. HIGHLY recommend. However, many of the Japanese here don‚Äôt even know what gluten free or vegan is. We luckily had our own kitchen and cooked every dinner (it did take a good 1.5 hours in the supermarket using google translate). We did find one lunch spot that we loved:

üç¥ Shaw‚Äôs 

Absolutely delicious! We had lunch here twice in a row. They have a gluten free, vegan menu and all they are receptive to making things gluten free to suit. The hostess speaks excellent English and is extremely helpful. 

**Kyoto**

We lucked out a little here as we arrived on the 2nd of jan which is a string of public holidays. This meant most places were closed. We relied on Uber eats for the first few days as we biked around the city for hours trying to find open restaurants when we first arrived. Here were the food highlights:

üç¥ Waco crepes

They were actually closed when we arrived and re-opened just for us! The lovely lady there wrote out a whole list of vegan restaurants for my partner too. Lovely people and delicious filing crepes that didn‚Äôt make me feel awful after eating.

üç¥ Zero waste

I‚Äôm not kidding when I say we came here for lunch and snacks on four occasions. Mutsumi was so accomodating and takes pride in every meal. They offer gluten free cupcakes (try the matcha muffin you won‚Äôt regret it!), chicken salad, pork pate (I didn‚Äôt try but looked good) and other meals. Great for vegans too. I got the chicken salad every time because the vegetables and condiments changed daily. They also serve vegan curry, quiche and cheese cake.

üç¥ÁéÑ gen

This is a hole-in-the-wall take away only vegan and gluten free restaurant. Lots of curry‚Äôs and vegetable style dishes and tofu. Also lots of sweets. He doesn‚Äôt use heavy oils or refined sugar. I had the chai scone - which was good however if you don‚Äôt like the taste of sweets without sugar it‚Äôs probably not for you.

üç¥ Root2lab (Uber eats)

This place was my jam. Make-your-own salad bowls. The only kicker is you‚Äôll need to use google translate while using the Uber eats app. I put in the instructions ‚ÄòGLUTEN FREE - WHEAT ALLERGY‚Äô and felt perfect after the two times I ordered from them. I recommend writing ‚Äòmore toppings then lettuce please‚Äô

üç¥ Sugarhill

Lovely hosts, good English, great understanding of food allergies. The first thing they ask is what food allergies you have. My partner got the vegan pasta and I got the terriyuki salmon. Delicious! Make a booking. 
 
**Nara**

We stayed in Nara for one night and I HIGHLY recommend doing so. We spent the first day riding around Nara and exploring. The next day got up at 6am which meant zero tourists. You can literally walk around the park surrounded by deer - it‚Äôs magical. The forest is underrated and worth checking out too. 

üç¥ We stayed at a Ryoken called Tabist which includes half board (breakfast and dinner)

Whilst the staff don‚Äôt speak fluent English, they understand food allergies. We were served what I would say was my favourite meal in Japan! Gluten free for me, vegan for partner. We were so so full afterwards. Amazing value for this stay. 

üç¥ Total Therapy cafe salon school studio KURURU

This organic cafe is a hidden gem - they believe food is medicine. Most of their dishes are gluten free - you actually get to pick which rice noodle flavour you want (tomato, kelp, brown rice etc). My partner got the curry and said it was his fave dish of the trip.  Their English isn‚Äôt great however the menu is extremely informative and they understand dietary requirements.

üç¥ Big Mountain CafeÔºÜFarm

Wow, where do I start with this place? Incredible food, hosts and atmosphere. They have a chicken dish with rice, salad and condiments. I asked if they could make the chicken grilled instead of fried and do extra salad instead of chips which they were happy to do. They have a full gluten free menu which is easy to navigate. I recently quit coffee and have been drinking cacao - it was so good to see it on their menu‚Ä¶ and it was the best cacao I‚Äôve had in my life!! Unfortunately she doesn‚Äôt sell it otherwise I would have bought 10 packs to take back to Australia. Do not miss this place!

**Takayama**

üç¥ Sushi dining nob

Huge list of western style sushi. If you‚Äôre looking for basic no surprise lunch, perfect spot. 

üç¥ Heianruku

This was an absolute highlight in terms of restaurant experience!! We were lucky to be the only ones in the restaurant. The couple who run the restaurant are engaging, friendly and go the extra mile. We had a chat to them throughout our whole dining experience, showing them photos from Australia which they were so grateful for. They have an allergy sheet they provide so that you can point to everything you can‚Äôt eat. The chef made me a personalised meal with less oil (chicken rice and veggies) and my partner had a vegan gluten free ramen. We both got gluten free dumplings which were the best we have ever had! They give you a cute little starter dish and a snack at the end. I also couldn‚Äôt believe how much the whole experience cost us! $5300yen for two meals, dessert and a small bottle of sake (plus the complimentary starters) Extremely grateful for the experience. They are also very responsive over email (they changed our reservation from dinner to lunch within a hours notice). 

**Hakuba**

üç¥ Penke Bar

Western style menu. Staff mostly Aussie. Dietary requirements clearly marked on menu. I had the pork cutlet with cabbage and chips which was good (not something I‚Äôd usually order). 

üç¥ HybridÔøº

If you‚Äôre feeling fancy, this place is for you. Everything on the menu other than 2 dishes are gluten free. The owner Leo is extremely friendly, speaks excellent English (From canada) and has a great understanding of dietary restrictions. They made a custom vegan dish for my partner and I had the pickles, hybrid salad and roast chicken. Best chicken I‚Äôve ever had! Excellent service. They do walk-ins however I‚Äôd book as I saw a few people get turned away. Really nice wine too if you enjoy a glass. 

üç¥ Gravityworx 

Italian restaurant serving pasta and pizza. Quirky place with an eccentric owner who loves a chat. GF rice penne. I got the tuna, tomato and mushroom pasta and it was honestly the best pasta I‚Äôve had In a long time‚Ä¶. Basic but done right. They also ferment and farm most of their ingredients which is cool! 

üç¥ Mr Myagi 

Japanese (western vibe) casual dining part of a hotel. Very basic   - lots of gluten free options (and they can do a few of the dishes vegan). I got teriyaki chicken and a side salad. Chicken was good. Side salad was literally two pieces of lettuce thrown together with no dressing‚Ä¶ not a lot of veggies with the chicken dish too. Was still OK. Nice friendly staff.

üç¥ Sol organics (at the base of the Goryu ski resort)

They have gluten free and vegan snacks - we literally got their snacks every 3rd day. Matcha cakes, cookies, brownies, scones‚Ä¶. GF/DF heaven. Was nice to know we were eating organic produce too. I got the hot ginger drink which was delicious. 

üç¥ Roots Cafe

Vegetarian place with lots of GF options - gyozas, falafels etc. my partner got the falafel curry and said it was pretty good. I tried the gyozas which were delicious. 

üç¥ A-coop supermarket

Has a GF section with pancake mixes, muffin mixes, curry‚Äôs etc. would need a kitchen to utilise this section. 

üç¥ Hakuba pizza

Good selection, they do gluten free, vegan cheese. We got delivery - took 30 mins. Pizza itself was a little soggy but still really yum. Good comfort food. 

üç¥ Lion cafe

Lots of gluten free snacks/muffins/treats - all clearly marked. I had the rice chicken bowl. Very light lunch. Healthy and fresh.

Random other tips - 
üí° When in doubt, 7/11 three items. Grilled chicken, rice and a packet of salad. I always had apple cider vinegar with me as a go-to dressing. Don‚Äôt make the mistake of accidentally buying chicken giblets ü§¢ 
üí° 7/11 plum sushi is gluten free and vegan
üí° Allergy cards work so well. Sometimes we would try to explain what our dietary requirements were and only when we pulled out the allergy cards did it click. 
üí° If you are doing a longer trip like us - we did 3 weeks - book places with kitchens where you can. You will be forever grateful you did that once you realise how tricky navigating GF is.
üí° A lot of the rice cakes are gluten free in the supermarkets and there is literally an entire isle of them. If you have the time, get your google translate app and start scanning. It‚Äôs worth it because they are all delicious!

Hopefully this helps with your planning üáØüáµ‚ú®

ResponsesV2.Message: oh THANK YOU!!! we are DF and GF too!! i'm dreading the food part of the trip and your notes have given me hope. I've saved this so I can go to the places you've recommended.
Thank you so very much for taking to time to write out these notes. We‚Äôre heading there in April with my GF daughter and this has been so helpful.

Title:
3 nights in Tokyo before we head to the snow. Thank you to this wonderful group for making it much more stress free than I was anticipating for our 15 year old coeliac. 

Stayed at „Éí„É´„Éà„É≥Êù±‰∫¨„ÄÄHilton Tokyo 
We booked club floor rooms so we had access to the lounge. Everything is clearly labelled with allergens & the staff can provide gf bread. The lounge is definitely worth it for the ease of breakfast & evening canapes that became dinner on our last night. 
We had dinner on our first night at the grill. It was quite expensive but very convenient to stay in the hotel after an overnight flight the night before. There were enough choices to stop the noodle cup being required. 

Our first full day was a booked private tour via Trip Advisor. The guide sent me the itinerary & then I searched this group for recommendations in the area he had assigned, Asakusa, for lunch. All 6 of us, guide included, loved Ê®©ÂÖ´ ÊµÖËçâÂêæÂ¶ªÊ©ã Gonpachi Asakusa Azumabashi Highly recommended. 

Booked Teppan Baby ÈâÑÊùø„Éô„Ç§„Éì„ÉºÊñ∞ÂÆøÊù±Âè£Â∫ó  via instagram about a month ago. Bookings definitely required. It was the best night. We sat at the tappanyaki grill & watched the action. All the staff communicated well & our girl was well looked after. 

On day 2 we hit a hurdle. I had been planning our day around lunch at Shimbu Sakiya Ramen in Shibuya however when we got there, they claimed they did not have room for 5 of us & that was the end of the discussion. The lady closed the door in our face. We could see that they had room for at least our coeliac however we had no choice but to accept & move on. The 4 non gluten free ate elsewhere , then I googled, used the Find Me Gluten Free app & this page. We jumped on a train & made our way to Harajuku. Thankfully My Bahn Mi by Gluten Free saved the day. They fed the hungry teenager & all was well. 

Overall, it was great trip, made better by this page.

ResponsesV2.Message: Such a shame you didn‚Äôt get to enjoy Shimbu Sakiya Ramen. My (celiac) husband hadn‚Äôt had fried chicken in nearly 20 years and thought it was absolutely amazing. Ramen was delicious too.

Title:
Leaving #Hakuba (staying in #Echoland) and found a bunch of good gluten free spots. #Hakuba is well catered to westerners and the alike. All the restaurants understood coeliac disease. If you can reserve in advance or show up early (before 6pm) so you‚Äôre not disappointed.

#Mr Miyagis - Run by an Aussie. They seemed to know about gluten free but as someone else mentioned I would be careful about cross contamination. Had #Okonomiyaki, it was delicious! 

#Japanese Dining Kyoto - had the wagyu #Shabu shabu. The stock was only water, so had to add a bit of salt for taste. They had gluten free soy sauce out the back. A few other item on the menu were obviously GF like grilled prawns. 

#uncle stevens great #Tex Mex. The kitchen serves food fast, so could be some CC. Had beef tacos and Nachos. 

#Taco Taco - loved this place. Gf fajitas were tasty and filling when asked for more corn fajitas. The #margaritas were dangerous. 

#Bears cafe - understood about coeliac, said they couldn‚Äôt guarantee no CC. Dish was delicious, just a bit on the small side.

#The campfire sushi and cafe - sushi rice had soy sauce in it so opted for tuna rice bowl and edamame. Fish was really fresh but on the smaller side if you‚Äôre a big eater.

#Hakuba kebab - Had beef with rice. Definitely the most affordable dish I had in #Hakuba. I didn‚Äôt get any CC but they don‚Äôt change the gloves after handling the flour kebabs. 

On the hills -
 Every place had at least a rice bowl with some veggies when asked.

#Happo1 couldn‚Äôt find much on the hill, but #uncle Steven‚Äôs tex mex is a few minutes from happo gondola base. 
#Goryu - veggie curry with rice.
#IWATAKE - chicken curry with rice

Title:
Hi guys, the hubby wants a traditional Japanese breakfast while we‚Äôre here ideally a place where I, the coeliac, can eat too. We are in Kyoto for a few days then Osaka and Tokyo. Does anyone have any recommendations? Thanks! 

(Yes I have tried #breakfast in the group already and I‚Äôve just attached an image of what I‚Äôm talking about. I haven‚Äôt yet and likely won‚Äôt do buffet breakfast on this trip.)

ResponsesV2.Message: The eggs are always suspiciously cut with flour to keep it's fluffy yet rigid consistency. Does anyone know? How about your run of the mill sushi at the train stations? Do they normally use a (safe) generic vinegar or mirin?

Most restaurants in Japan are not open for breakfast. If you are at a hotel that offers breakfast, often they will have both western and Japanese breakfast items. The issue then becomes verifying what Japanese items do or do not contain gluten. Search in this group for hotel recommendations.

Title:
Thank you for the incredible recommendations in this group.  Just back from a three week holiday.  Family of 5 travelling with 2 Coeliac teenagers. 

A couple of tips and recommendations. 

Hakuba
Hakuba Pizza - excellent - they also deliver.  Can take a while to deliver, order early and very worth the wait.  They can run out of gluten free bases though. 

Mr Miyagi - so good, so accommodating. Great good, great atmosphere, great owner, book ahead. 

Tokyo
Toranomon Hills Station - T Market
La Boucherie - great meat and other gluten free sides and very obliging and helpful with gluten free 

T‚Äôs Kitchen very good as mentioned. Very small and best to book. 

Kyoto 
Nohga Hotel - Cicon restaurant.  Good dinner options. Helpful staff. 

Breakfast is good here too, upon request they can arrange great gluten free bread

We found Kyoto the hardest part to find places to eat. 

Osaka
Taqueria La Fonda
As mentioned it was excellent! Must book, we went three times and everyone loved it. Very small but great fun and great food. 

Kobebeef Teppanyaki RIO Osaka
Located in the ground level of The Royal Park Hotel Iconic. 
They said they couldn‚Äôt do gluten free, but with some careful google translating work, we managed it.  We had lunch here twice which ranges from 22 - 28 yen for tepoanyaki beef, salad, cooked veggies and unlimited rice. We omitted the Miso soup for the Coeliacs.  It was excellent.  

Another thing I did before I left was vacuum sealed small portions of gf cereal for my kids to take down to breakfast each morning in case things got tricky. We also took some on the planes and just ask for some milk in a bowl. 

Hope this helps, as I was very grateful for all the recommendations I found in here. 
Thank you

ResponsesV2.Message: Thank you! With teppenyaki.. was it ‚Äòfun‚Äô? With tricks and fire?

Thanks for sharing. Which airline did you fly with and did you have to pre-book the request for milk in a bowl. We just travelled to Singapore with Scoot and there was only 1 item (dahl with rice) that was gf.

Title:
## **#Kyushu Region**

***Post 2 of 5***

I started the bulk of my travels in one of the harder areas to find GF food, BUT so beautiful and well worth it despite the more limited options. If I had limited time, I'd definitely suggest either reaching out to https://www.facebook.com/kyushujourneys/ or https://glutenfreetoursjapan.com.au/ to help you, as it just isn't as populated as other areas, and english was also even more limited than in the major places.

**#Takachiho**

First up, one of the popular instagram places, Takachiho Gorge üòâ For those who need the alternative milks, #Nobeoka station does have a Starbucks!

We stayed at Solest Takachiho, a newer property in Takachiho. I couldn‚Äôt find any options that catered to GF in town, and so we just went with this. It couldn‚Äôt accommodate for dinner, and breakfast was plain rice. Hotel itself was fine.

Nagomi
* This is a butcher shop and restaurant that specializes in Takachiho beef, one of the main areas for wagyu beef. I did show my allergy text to the waiter, but as there was such limited gluten on the menu, I didn't push cross contamination protocol in the kitchen. He indicated I could eat the rice and the beef, and the veggies that came with the beef, and I avoided the sauces and the little dishes that came on the side (the salad, the seaweed salad, miso soup). It was excellent meat.
https://maps.app.goo.gl/BJj2NV5ry1Yxecn76
https://takachiho.ja-miyazaki.jp/pages/44/

Takachihogamadase Market
* This is a market that sells products local to the area (both packaged and fresh), right next door to Nagomi. I was able to find a few gluten free products, including these really yummy little cookies made from rice bran.
https://maps.app.goo.gl/j3qcqZdy2qB4Jxww6

Caf√© Terrace Tachachihoya -
* This caf√© has the sweetest owner! She was very responsive on instagram messages and though her caf√© isn't 100% GF, I felt completely safe eating here. I was able to eat the majority of her menu (see image for what is GF) and she also has soy milk for lattes for those with lactose intolerance. Definitely suggest if you're in the area!
https://www.instagram.com/takachihoya/
https://maps.app.goo.gl/KuJPfr5yVemLqy1k9

**#Beppu, **an onsen town on the coast. I couldn't find any options via google (other than Coco Ichibanya and Kura Sushi) but as we were there for 24 hours, just to see the 7 Hells, I was prepared to just deal. The hotel find was great though, so I got to eat after all. There was one onsen that we did want to try, and the steam cooking seemed like it should be gluten free (just without the sauces they give to add after) but they were closed the days that we were for cleaning. For reference though, this was it: https://www.hyotan-onsen.com/english/

Galleria Midobaru hotel was such a beautiful property AND they were able to accommodate gluten free for both dinner and breakfast AND it was super tasting! The mushrooms and veggies were absolutely delicious, and breakfast was so big that I couldn‚Äôt finish half of it! It is pricier though, but it was really nice to have a great meal AND such a nice property.
* https://beppu-galleria-midobaru.jp/en/

Myoban Yunosato Onsen - this is a little complex with one big souvenir shop and one smaller more boutique one, a little open air museum of sorts to see the huts they use to collect the salt in, and then a very cute open air onsen at the top of the complex with a sweet man who runs it. He serves these onsen water boiled eggs (they do taste like sulphur üòâ ) and down by the bigger souvenir shop they also sell onsen water boiled corn. Both are good snacks, and from everything I googled, gluten free. I didn't ask, and didn't have any side effects.
* https://maps.app.goo.gl/E5FXg49Jv1Veomuh8
* http://yuno-hana.jp/

**#Yufuin, or #Yufu, **another onsen town, inland from Beppu, about 1 hour by bus, and another place that had very limited options when I googled, but the description of the Edo style town made me want to stop in for a quick visit. Don't laugh, but we found an Indian here, that was incredible - and wound up eating both dinner and lunch at, as it was so good and gluten safe!
* Avatar Indian - I asked about the curries and if they were safe, and the waitress quickly assured me they were fine. We had one of the dal's, a veggie curry and the aubergine curry - which was our favourite. Hands down though, some of the best Indian food I've ever had. But note there is a chance of cross contam as it's not 100% GF. 

https://maps.app.goo.gl/sB322DAHuoYisSDS8

The other option that came up, was this one, just for reference as there's not a lot around!
* Caf√© Siesta
ABOUT | cafesiesta
Siesta Organic Cafe („Ç∑„Ç®„Çπ„Çø„Ç™„Éº„Ç¨„Éã„ÉÉ„ÇØ„Ç´„Éï„Çß) (@siesta_organic) ‚Ä¢ Instagram photos and videos

The ryokan that we stayed at couldn't accommodate me for dinner or breakfast - Besso Shiksai http://www.shikisai-hotel.jp/ -  I couldn't find any through googling that would, but I didn't reach out to any to ask any others specifically either, as the majority were already full for the days we needed.

**#Kurokawa Onsen -** an incredibly beautiful onsen town in the mountains, and my favourite place on my whole trip! There are pretty much no options for dining outside your ryokan - let alone gluten free - and this was my only place that I wound up eating my rice crackers and individual peanut butter packets! However, it turns out that my ryokan would have been able to accommodate me, but it was lost in translation before my arrival. They couldn't manage dinner on the short notice, but breakfast was a win - and my first true ryokan breakfast experience!

Wafu Ryokan Misato
* I couldn't find any email for them, and communicated via Booking.com - I would suggest calling and getting the meal sorted in advance, as they are able! At check in - which they do with you in your room, so it's very relaxed - the girl took my questions on gluten very seriously, and took screen shots of my allergy text. She went to speak to the kitchen and then came back, checked my notes again, took another screen shot, went back to the kitchen and then came back and said that breakfast was 100% no issue, and she was very very apologetic and said that dinner would have been possible, but it was too late in the day by then to sort for that day. Very sweet staff, big Japanese style rooms, and a smaller family run ryokan.
* https://maps.app.goo.gl/qUjDGEpAHsd1rNf29
* http://www.kurokawa-misato.jp/

Goto Liquor Store
* I scoured the shelves at this local konbini and there are snack options like chips and fruit - and liquor üòâ No onigiri (none left at that time of night anyways)
* https://maps.app.goo.gl/bibhUfDASnsZHW5NA

I did find one place by chance, and I highly recommend - particularly as there are not a lot of restaurant options, at any time of the day - outside of your ryokan meals!

ÈªíÂ∑ùÊ∏©Ê≥â ‰∫àÁ•ù „Çà„Åó„ÇÖ„Åè and in english Yosei - Check out their website - it's a very neat concept of connecting earth/ people/ food. I only ate lunch at Yosei, but there is a sister restaurant and a ryokan as well, that would be worth checking out for gluten friendly. At Yosei, they have a small plates menu, with a few options that looked gluten friendly. The Kumamoto beef was possible GF, and it was excellent.
* https://www.okyakuya.jp/en/
* https://maps.app.goo.gl/CAWiziuRWwfMBkRh7

**#Ureshino - **a tea town, in Saga, the other side of Kyushu. I stopped here as I wanted to check out the regional tea center - which was manned by these super sweet ladies, and I highly recommend if you're in the area - but was aware that again, there weren't a lot of options that I could find via googling anyways.

Ureshino Tea Exchange Museum: Chaoshiru- I did the tea pouring class and the tie dying class, and confirmed that the teas that I was trying were not the barley tea/ mugi cha. None of the sweets they have in the caf√© were possible though - at least not the one's that were there when I was there.
* https://maps.app.goo.gl/goMsWEtGTLRH7s9r7
* https://www.city.ureshino.lg.jp/.../ureshi.../_23805.html...

Hamilton Hotel - They were not able to accommodate me for dinner, but, breakfast was possible - I have to say that I wasn't 100% positive it was all gluten free, so I just ate the rice, fruit and hard boiled egg as I just couldn't be bothered to triple check! No alternative milks for coffee.
* https://www.hamilton-ureshino.jp/

If you do find yourself here, I'd suggest checking out Wataya Besso property - they didn't have space for my dates, but have a few different restaurants, that looked like they'd be open to dealing with dietary restrictions
* https://wataya.co.jp/

Monte Stella - an Italian restaurant that was able to accommodate me with gluten free and I felt safe eating at. I explained to the hotel staff and they called to check and it was deemed possible. I then showed my allergy text to the service staff at the restaurant, and indicated the items that I had thought would be fine, and they visibly thought for a moment, and then nodded their heads. It was simple food - grilled chicken and vegetable antipasta - but I felt comfortable with it and didn't get sick.
* https://www.montestella.jp/
* https://maps.app.goo.gl/fMaYREcD6HBQtfst9

ResponsesV2.Message: Planning a repeat trip to Kyushu and these are fantastic, thanks! So glad you found Avatar in Yufuin too :)
Thank you so much!!

Title:
Rice Hack -Tokyo. This is currently my favorite savory bakery in Tokyo. I waited until our last day but it was well worth the wait. I ordered pizza and we were still able to eat it at the cafe next door. This time we ordered  Pepperoni and the margarita pizza. Previously I tried the pesto with anchovies but it was a little fishy for me personally. I was able to get their curry bread rolls with the pizza and all three flavors are delicious (pork, plain, and cheesy). They are also great for a shinkansen ride!!!

*The cafe next door is now a beet themed restaurant without gluten free options but if you order a drink (one per guest) they don't mind if you eat the pizza there. They do ask that you return the pizza box to the bakery rather than leaving it for them to dispose of, which makes sense. I ordered coffee and kids had Maccha lattes (they don't have to be gluten free, so I didn't check the gluten free status. The latter can often contain wheat.) They cafe owner and helper were extremely pleasant and made our visit even better. :) 

A cute thing happened while we were eating our pizza. A couple had come in to order one of the sets and saw us enjoying their pizza. The man darted out to order one too (miso with white fish) and he and his partner seemed to thoroughly enjoy it. So the pizza is tasty even for non gf people. 

#Tokyo #Ricehack #Omotesando

ResponsesV2.Message: I ate there yesterday and since I could speak Japanese, I could ask the ingredients. They do not label the beet-based soup meals as GF because these come with non-GF bread. But the soups (2 of 3 or all 3) are GF (they said „Åì„ÇÄ„Åé) at 1000 yen and drink is cheaper at +300 as a set. üòâ The warm soup is perfect with the pizza ü§ó I totally agree that it's a good savory place ü§ó (nearby Gluten Free Banh Mi and Neal's Yard, also good üòâ)
Where was this?

Title:
#Kobe post - it was a bit hard to find info on here so while I don‚Äôt have much I‚Äôll share what I do have. I went to Kanauta which does use barley in some of their products but the guy can tell you exactly which ones. I had their chocolate cake. For a proper meal we went to steakland for a lunch set menu. We got the tender steak one and they said they don‚Äôt use wheat, mostly is was simple fresh ingredients so I felt safe but there was some sauce on the side I decided to pass on, but my husband didn‚Äôt use that either since the steak was great by itself. You can make a reservation or show up and wait in line, we went at 10am and got first place which meant we came back just before 11 and went straight in. I also spent a proportionately ridiculous amount on those candied apples cut up and sprinkled with cinnamon and sugar which I have no idea if it was safe or not but I figured hopefully it‚Äôs just sugar and water with some food colouring. Either way it was divine and I didn‚Äôt feel sick afterwards soooo ü§ûüèª I‚Äôd do it again. We tried to make a booking for Hanasato but they didn‚Äôt reply to our message I think as they were just opening back up after the holiday period. At Nishimura coffee and I managed to order the gratin without toast which hopefully works well - update: I felt a little off afterwards but I‚Äôm also lactose intolerant which I did take my pills for. I wouldn‚Äôt do it again as I‚Äôm not fully convinced but that could be my error in not taking enough lactaid. The ice creams look ridiculously good though üòÇ 

Side notes of things I‚Äôve learned - the sweet potatoes at 7/11, kombini‚Äôs, roadside places are amazing. I‚Äôve eaten soo much rice - those are an incredible alternative and so easy to miss. 
I have been struggling with proteins - mostly eating eggs and the salmon in an onigiri or sashimi/sushimi.
I have no idea why but I‚Äôm struggling to find mochi without wheat. It seems like everyone I come across has wheat in it! I‚Äôve had one since I‚Äôve arrived and I love them so it‚Äôs driving me insane a little! Rant over! 
Any suggestions welcome!

ResponsesV2.Message: Mochi is usually covered with soy sauce which is the problem. The ones that aren't can have unidentified starch which is also a problem, or sweetener which uses barley malt, etc. Just plain mochi is something you have to find in a grocery and toast it or microwave it yourself, and it's usually not the cheapest version!

Title:
Hi everyone, my name is Adi and have Celiac (i know i came to the right place ;)) 
Am a foodie and would like to try these store bought Buldak/Ramen bowls.
Is there anything/product/label that is safe for us?

ResponsesV2.Message: Those look Korean. Any ramen is going to have wheat unless specifically labeled gluten-free Ôøº

If you want just generic "noodles" without being Japanese specifically, the best and most numerous are Vietnamese, as they have historically never planted or grown wheat. Although the majority of their products are rice/tapioca-based, increasing globalisation and greed is making some manufacturers add wheat to cheapen the production of the product.
"Mien", "Bun", "Hu Tieu" are what comes to mind. So far, all instant packaged foods containing those words are 100% gluten free.

Title:
Hi! Traveling with a teenager who is allergic to gluten, fish, dairy and eggs, and 3 people who don't have allergies. We will eat in as many GF friendly places as possible.

Knowing that GF items can be more expensive and generally just happy to order whatever fits that allergy profile in a restaurant. Aiming to eat in the hotel for breakfast and then lunch and dinner in restaurants most days, how much would you budget per day for food per person? Planning to visit Tokyo, Kyoto and Osaka. 

For comparison, on the west coast in the US, I would budget $50-$75 USD per person.

ResponsesV2.Message:
I'm vegan and celiac living in Tokyo! You have:
Shibuya/Harajuku: Falafel brothers, Chao Thai, Bio Cafe, Nataraj Indian Restaurant, Vegan bistro Jangara (ramen) 
Shinjuku: Ain Soph, Mamahuhu 
Meguro: Cabe Meguro 

Kyoto: 
Bassanova Kyoto (ramen), S Vietnamese Cuisine, Bali Bali Indonesia, Ain Soph, Gion Soy milk Ramen Uno Yukiko. 

There is more than you'd first think as long as you plan where to go üòä Modifying menus here in Japan is very difficult so it's always better to go to places that already have options on the menu.

Uh, with that combo of allergies your teenager will not be able to eat anything in Japan. Plain rice and fruit. Everything will either have those elements or be contaminated by them.

For your situation I would really really recommend you contact Gluten Free Tours Japan to make your life a lot easier unless someone in your group can speak Japanese fluently,

Title:
