Title:
**#Tokyo & surrounding area (#MtFuji and #Kamakura)**

***Post 5 of 5***

**#Tokyo**

I wish I could have tried Kushiage Su and Otsuna sushi - people's reviews sound amazing, and particularly the story behind Kushiage Su makes this top of my list for my (hopefully) next visit to Tokyo!
* Otsuna Sushi - Otsuna Sushi ‚Äì Founded in Meiji      8, this is the official website of Roppongi Otsuna Sushi.      (otsuna-sushi.com)
* Kushiage      Su - [https://www.tablecheck.com/shops/glutenfree-kushiage-su/reserve](https://www.tablecheck.com/shops/glutenfree-kushiage-su/reserve)

For the rest, in Tokyo is where I ate the most at places that weren't 100% dedicated GF - and I definitely cannot vouch that they were all great with cross contamination. That is definitely partially down to me. I was with friends for the most part while eating out in Tokyo and I found it tough to do more than ask for things to be without sauce, not wanting to make a bigger fuss by pushing the service staff on cross contamination in the kitchen. I did "guide" our restaurant selections in advance for options that I figured were the safest, searching them in the group and on google to see other people's experiences etc‚Ä¶ and then just hoped for the best. Anyways, my comments below, so others can make their own decisions!

**#Ginza and surrounding area**

FANCL Brown Rice meals - this is 100% GF and I tried to walk in on a Sunday and they had no space. They have two seatings, so do make a booking I'd say, to avoid not getting a seat. It's in the basement of the FANCL building, so not obvious from the street.
* https://maps.app.goo.gl/L31gQkrQDbsXLBQo7
* [https://fanclbrownricemeals.foodre.jp/](https://fanclbrownricemeals.foodre.jp/)

Bill's - I ate at both the Ginza and Odaiba locations, and had the same dish: the buckwheat and quinoa salad. I asked the server, and they brought me a print out with all their dishes and the different allergens. I found what I could have, and then asked her to tell the kitchen I needed it gluten free. I cannot vouch for their cross contamination protocols, but felt fairly comfortable eating here. I wouldn't choose to go on my own, but given the rest of the group wasn't gluten free, I felt comfortable enough.
* [https://billsjapan.com/en/ginza](https://billsjapan.com/en/ginza)
* [https://maps.app.goo.gl/XWTSJ3DzgyWTZiDT7](https://maps.app.goo.gl/XWTSJ3DzgyWTZiDT7)

Tsukiji Sushi Say Honten - in the fish market block, this was a great experience. They don‚Äôt take reservations, and lines up start 30 min before they open. There are 2 locations it seems; we were at the one closest to the road. We got seats at the bar upstairs, and had our own sushi master that prepared the food for us. I did show him my allergy text for sushi, and he couldn't answer on the vinegar, so we decided together that I would stick to sashimi. It was really yummy sashimi, but the experience was what made it great - the 4 sushi masters behind the bar were super relaxed and joking (in Japanese, so no idea what they said ha ha) and laughing with each other. He was also able to indicate which sake was 100% rice, so all in all, I was able to eat and drink safely, and we all enjoyed our meal immensely.
* [https://maps.app.goo.gl/rCAyBb54AgEAbn8r8](https://maps.app.goo.gl/rCAyBb54AgEAbn8r8)
* [http://www.tsukijisushisay.co.jp/store/honten.html](http://www.tsukijisushisay.co.jp/store/honten.html)

Soranoiro Nippon Ramen - I did try this place, and appreciated having a warm meal that I could eat while out for the day. As others have said, the Ramen street is like a hidden row that runs parallel to the main row - it took us a while to find it! You have to like go around a corner to get to that row. At the shop, you order on the machine outside the shop, and there is a gluten free button you choose first. I asked for help, just as a double check that she was flagging it as gluten free. I also asked if it was in different boiling water, and she said yes. The gyozas were also gluten free it seems. It was warm and filling, and gluten free, but other than that, I wouldn't go back. I also didn't feel fabulous after, but again, it's hard to know if this was due to any cross contam.
* [https://maps.app.goo.gl/gnaHYWp8aYT48Lqr5](https://maps.app.goo.gl/gnaHYWp8aYT48Lqr5)
* [https://soranoiro-vege.com/](https://soranoiro-vege.com/)

**#Hiroo area**

La Jolla - a little Mexican place just past the Starbucks. Generally Mexican is a fairly safe bet for getting a gluten free meal, with limited cross contamination, and again, I was in a mixed group so this was the safest compromise when we were out and about and just needed lunch one day. I asked the owner about gluten, and he pointed out what I could have. I can't vouch for cross contamination in the kitchen, and I'm not sure that I would try this one again.

Eat Play Work building - this a neat concept right by the Hiroo metro station, with a few floors of different restaurants that each have a counter area you can sit at, or, you can take your food to sit in one of the common areas. Definitely not all gluten free, but if you're in mixed company, it could be a good location as you can all order what you want.
* I ate at     Salam, the Middle      Eastern place, and the owner was able to clearly tell me what did/ did not      have gluten, but, cross contamination is definitely an issue here for      those very sensitive (and did bite me in the butt) and she clearly stated      that she's not a gluten free venue. I wouldn't suggest it, if you are at      all sensitive.
   * „ÄêÂÖ¨Âºè„ÄëSalam(„Çµ„É©„Éº„É†) | EAT PLAY WORKS-THE       RESTAURANT Â∫ÉÂ∞æ (salt-group.jp)
* Oxomoco is a mexican inspired      venue, and from the menu it looked like it might be easier to make gluten      free and free of cross contam, but I didn‚Äôt have a chance to try      unfortunately.
   * [Official] OXOMOCO | EAT PLAY       WORKS-THE RESTAURANT Hiroo (salt-group.jp)

**#Asakusa Area**

Marugoto **-** 100% gluten free and vegan caf√© on the river. It's small, just a few tables, and quite healthy :-) But, it's filling and safe to eat at, which is a win!
* [https://maps.app.goo.gl/ztFCzCsLq2Ayy2QK8](https://maps.app.goo.gl/ztFCzCsLq2Ayy2QK8)
* [https://dining.marugotovegan.com/](https://dining.marugotovegan.com/)

Sho Chiku En** -** 100% GF and vegan caf√©, with a sweet story of why they opened. We stopped in for a cake and coffee/ matcha latte. I had the tiramisu and my friend had the Mont Blanc. Match was good, the cakes were also good. I didn't try any of the savoury dishes, but there definitely a handful of uber eats or similar bikers coming in to get orders! It's nice to have a completely safe option if you're around Senso-Ji Temple.
* [https://maps.app.goo.gl/mmgaYLYbLeDmbVMo7](https://maps.app.goo.gl/mmgaYLYbLeDmbVMo7)
* [https://sho-chiku-en.com/](https://sho-chiku-en.com/)

**#Shinjuku area**

Marbre Caf√©** -** this is a vegan cake and coffee shop right by Shinjuku Gyoen Park, and the Shinjuku entrance. The staff was very sweet with explaining what options were GF (not all are) and I thoroughly enjoyed the caramel dessert I chose for takeaway, on the grass in the park next door. I didn‚Äôt ask about their cross contamination protocols in the kitchen, but based on previous comments, I was comfortable eating the dessert and didn‚Äôt get sick!
* [https://maps.app.goo.gl/MuAVtRSQo3G9JQmV6](https://maps.app.goo.gl/MuAVtRSQo3G9JQmV6)
* [https://www.facebook.com/marbrevegn/](https://www.facebook.com/marbrevegn/)

**#Roppongi area**

Gluten Free T‚Äôs Kitchen** - **I went a few different times, and only once had to wait a few minutes, but it's quite small inside, that I can see it's better to make a reservation if you really want to eat here. It's great that it's 100% GF so just no worries at all on cross contamination, and I definitely appreciated being able to pop in for lunch, but I found the food *just ok* personally. Gyoza's were good, and the cajun fried chicken (though it's a HUGE portion of ONLY the chicken) but I didn't love the miso corn ramen, the tempura, nor the takoyaki balls.
* [https://glutenfree.co.jp/](https://glutenfree.co.jp/)

Gonpachi**- **I ate at the Nishi-Azabu location, and as some others have mentioned, there isn't a specific gluten free menu here. Our waitress didn't understand what I was asking, her colleague did, and then rattled off a list of the items I could have to her in Japanese. The waitress then turned around and pointed them out to me on the menu, but there was a lot of uncertainty from her if she had remembered it all. She did confirm the tempura would be made in a separate fryer, and that it would take longer, and it did come out later than the rest of the table's dishes. I was not overly confident with both her recollection of what I could/ couldn't have, and, what was happening in the kitchen, so I just stuck to chicken skewers with salt and the tempura. I didn't feel the best after, but I can't say if this was due to cross contam, or just something else.
* [https://maps.app.goo.gl/UxnFumtuhw4XUerbA](https://maps.app.goo.gl/UxnFumtuhw4XUerbA)
* [https://gonpachi.jp/nishi-azabu/](https://gonpachi.jp/nishi-azabu/)

Meatman - again, not a dedicated GF restaurant, and it's at your own risk for cross contamination. I didn't even bother telling them I had a gluten allergy here - it was so busy and pretty much 100% Japanese - so I just picked the skewers that were salt only, checked with the waitress that they had no sauce, and hoped for the best. This was also based on what I had read that generally in izakaya's they don‚Äôt use the same part of the grill for salt only and with sauce skewers as it affects the taste. All in all, it went well, and I didn't feel ill. It's an interesting concept - they are known for wrapping their skewers in bacon - and I wound up having a variety of vegetables with salt only (some wrapped in bacon, some plain), and a chicken wrapped in bacon.

**#Harajuku area**

Las Dos** **Caras **- **I wound up eating here three times just due to ease/ me being able to eat here! Again, Mexican is often a safer bet, and I didn't feel ill any of the times I ate here. However, I didn't check cross contamination protocols in the kitchen. I checked which of the dishes were with corn tortillas (the majority are) and know they are usually heated up differently than flour tortillas, so figured the level of cross contamination was low. The guacamole is made at your table, and delicious, as are the margaritas.
* [https://www.huge.co.jp/restaurant/modern-mexicano/lasdoscaras](https://www.huge.co.jp/restaurant/modern-mexicano/lasdoscaras)

**#Shibuya/ Omoetasando area**

Rice Hack** - **I didn't make it here until my very last day in Tokyo, and trekked here for some plane food. I had the plain tomato sauce and basil pizza (I can't do cow's cheese) and the baguette, both of which were really great texture, and, were also perfect for plane food! There were plain buns and curry buns, at 10am, which is when they opened, but you could see they were putting out more product as it came out of the oven, so it is hit or miss what you will find. It is a take away counter only (you can buy a drink at the caf√© next door and eat your food there) but definitely work a stop if you are craving some good, fresh baked goods or pizza on the go.
* Home | RICE HACK Gluten-Free      Bakery (jimdosite.com)

Rubia - this is a newish Japanese-Mexican restaurant in the heart of Shibuya, with a mezcal bar upstairs (that I sadly didn't try). They clearly note on their website that they can easily accommodate dietary restrictions and on the night of it was no issue. The food was well presented, they clearly had made accommodations for my courses, and the interior is calm and modern in style, with an open kitchen. I definitely felt comfortable eating here. Food wise, it was a bit hit or miss taste wise, but, apparently lunch has a really good set menu choice that is very tasty.
* [https://rubia.co.jp/menu/](https://rubia.co.jp/menu/)

**#Kamakura**

I spent just a day here, and stumbled across Luna Burger - it's vegan, and must be fairly new. The chef looked at my allergy text, and confirmed that the curry was gluten free. He then took care to check if barley was ok as the rice he serves with it has barley. When I said no, he said no problem and went and got plain white rice. Overall I was comfortable with his preparation in the open kitchen, and didn't get sick. The back up option was Cups, as others have mentioned, but I didn't wind up going - [https://maps.app.goo.gl/AxPj2o1NaJoWfpJQ8](https://maps.app.goo.gl/AxPj2o1NaJoWfpJQ8)

Luna Burger
* [https://www.instagram.com/lunaburger_j/](https://www.instagram.com/lunaburger_j/)
* [https://maps.app.goo.gl/UEjw6MhoTMoqtoHX7](https://maps.app.goo.gl/UEjw6MhoTMoqtoHX7)

Kannon Coffee - We also stopped by this very cute place for a coffee - they do have alternative milks as well, and seem to have multiple locations.
* [https://maps.app.goo.gl/n9jrFjbdENcyiAxG9](https://maps.app.goo.gl/n9jrFjbdENcyiAxG9)
* [https://www.kannoncoffee.com/](https://www.kannoncoffee.com/)

**#MtFuji area**

We also just did a day trip here, and wound up eating onigiri, but that was because the one option was too far, and the other one was closed that day! I'll mention both here as both seemed very good options.

Taqueria 3 Hermanos
* [https://maps.app.goo.gl/xQCsQDmCKXpT7Uzj8](https://maps.app.goo.gl/xQCsQDmCKXpT7Uzj8)
* [https://www.instagram.com/tacos_3hermanos_df/](https://www.instagram.com/tacos_3hermanos_df/)

Shaw's Sushi Bar and Dining
* [https://maps.app.goo.gl/xPMoMPgb3qYYnQkx6](https://maps.app.goo.gl/xPMoMPgb3qYYnQkx6)
* [https://www.instagram.com/shaws_sushi_bar_n_dining/?utm_source=ig_profile](https://www.instagram.com/shaws_sushi_bar_n_dining/?utm_source=ig_profile)

ResponsesV2.Message: Wow, what a great wrap up of your dining experiences! Thanks so much for all this info, I‚Äôll visit some of these places on my next trip. I can vouch for Meatman in Roppongi, I‚Äôve been there several times and they generally understand when I explain plus I give the waitress my GF explanation card in Japanese. I eat the skewers with salt only and ask for the fries without the flavoured salt. They also have nice starters like burrata with tomatoes. I also highly recommend Kushiage-su, it was a highlight of my many meals in Japan in 2023 and my husband (not GF) still raves about it.
This is amazing thankyou

Title:
**#Gifu Prefecture**

***Post 4 of 5***

This was the second hardest area to find food during my travels - other than in Takayama! But like Kyushu, very beautiful, more nature, and neat to see another side of Japan.

**#Magome**

I have to say this is a super cute little town (a juku town on the #Nakasendo trail) and was worth the very long trek to get there! It didn't have anywhere that I felt comfortable trying, but, I also just didn't try, given the timing of my day. I did try the following:

Hill Billy Coffee
* Cute little place closer to the      start or bottom of the hill. I had a really lovely matcha latte - and they      had soy milk!!
   * @hillbilly_coffee_roasters (on       instagram
   * [https://maps.app.goo.gl/r7H6w72HCA2awcAAA](https://maps.app.goo.gl/r7H6w72HCA2awcAAA)

Kamiogiya Shoten
* I also bought some (confirmed      100% GF) sake from the lovely owner of a store at the top of the hill of      Magome juku. I had time to kill and he shared some info about the      different types of sake, and clearly pointed out which one's were not GF/      had barley.
   * Kamiogiya Shoten - [https://maps.app.goo.gl/aVYxR9PwTUdZmYCx5](https://maps.app.goo.gl/aVYxR9PwTUdZmYCx5)

**#Nakatsugawa**

I didn‚Äôt spend much time here - I just grabbed onigiri from a konbini for a quick snack. I did check out the historic area of the town (it is also a juku town, on the #Nakasendo trail) and found a beautifully housed sake brewery for a quick tasting (again, used my allergy text to confirm 100% GF)
* Hazama      Sake Brewery
* [https://maps.app.goo.gl/BtWPLEJpsjKuEKBV6](https://maps.app.goo.gl/BtWPLEJpsjKuEKBV6)

**#Gero** is an onsen town, and I wound up here as I couldn‚Äôt manage to get to Takayama in the same day. I wouldn't have spent the night otherwise.

I stayed at Hotel Sumeikan, which is quite a big property on the river. It's a bit faded glory :-) but it has 3 separate onsen areas, which were nice to relax in. The hotel did have their European restaurant that could do GF dinner but it was pricey at 10,000 Yen. Breakfast was buffet and well labelled, but other than the plain rice and fruit, there was no GF options that I felt were safe from cross contamination.

Om Ganesh - dinner in Gero was limited. I googled and found an Indian, debating between that and one of the izakayas that served Hida beef bbq. Very friendly staff (owners?) who seemed confident there was no gluten in their curry, and I just left it at that and didn't ask further. I didn‚Äôt have a reaction, but I am not 100% certain that there was no cross contamination risk.
* Om Ganesh - [https://maps.app.goo.gl/vx8G3A3F53GZ9jUk9](https://maps.app.goo.gl/vx8G3A3F53GZ9jUk9)

**#Takayama.** How on earth are there so many good options in a such a small town! In my two nights I didn't get to try them all. Do be aware that most of the places do close between lunch and dinner.

Heianraku -
* As others have said, it was      amazing. Go here. Such a great experience, lovely lovely husband and wife      hosts, super tasty food, really reasonably priced! Everything but one item      on the menu is gluten free, and they take absolute care to provide a safe      gluten free environment. I cannot recommend this place enough! Do book      ahead (via email) as they only take a few tables per night.
   * [https://heianraku.com/](https://heianraku.com/)

Sakura-jaja
* this one didn't pop up except      for in older posts (until a recent one the other day) but I also really      enjoyed this experience and am so glad I decided to try this one out. It      is a bit further out of town, but worth the walk if you can get a table -      you can only do this by calling direct (I had my hotel call) - as it also      has limited seating. The owner (and chef) is definitely a personality :-)      He entertains his guests while he cooks behind the bar, while his super      lovely, super tiny mother clears and serves the delicious and beautifully      plated dishes he creates.
   * [https://maps.app.goo.gl/ECtcAX2SzkDWXgX78](https://maps.app.goo.gl/ECtcAX2SzkDWXgX78)

Royal Nan House Takayama
* I wound up here as I needed      lunch and none of the other options were open. It was a filling and tasted      good, and I didn't get sick. Same      as in Gero though, there is definitely possible cross contamination here.
   * [https://maps.app.goo.gl/YWFA5Vja2taieaqj8](https://maps.app.goo.gl/YWFA5Vja2taieaqj8)

Falo Coffee brewers -
* this is a little coffee shop at      the top of town (away from the river) that has really good coffee. They      also have soy milk (and Bon Soy as well!) which was a win for me! They do      also have some baked goods and small breakfast items that are made with      oats, so if you can tolerate oats, you'll be good - unfortunately I'm not      so I couldn't try.
   * On instagram:       falo_coffee_brewers
   * [https://maps.app.goo.gl/B5Vb2rAoUGqw8QqEA](https://maps.app.goo.gl/B5Vb2rAoUGqw8QqEA)

This place was mentioned and I tried it out - they are yummy :-) It's this little dessert shop that is open during the morning market on the river. They are somewhat like a roasted marshmallow, and they say on the sign gluten free.
* „Åä„Çè„ÇâÁéâÂ§© is      the name of the shop but check the google link and you can see what the      front of the shop looks like and save to your maps! - [https://maps.app.goo.gl/y6uKXs9z18VVKebT8](https://maps.app.goo.gl/y6uKXs9z18VVKebT8)

Sake tasting - Harada Sake Brewery -
* I did the (self paced) tasting at this sake house, after having confirmed if all the sake was 100% GF ( I      used my allergy card here as well) with the ladies who sell you your own      sake cup for the tasting.
   * [https://maps.app.goo.gl/euBiYmPhzrGCEhPn6](https://maps.app.goo.gl/euBiYmPhzrGCEhPn6)

If you're walking to the Hida Folk Village
* Starbucks is on that side of the train tracks      and of course has all the alternative milks, which I took advantage of to      combat a mid afternoon energy dip!
* I did pass this place while walking up, that I didn‚Äôt get to try and hadn't seen mentioned before
   * Fudo - has soy milk (though were sold out the day I was there!) and gluten free treats (though I didn‚Äôt investigate up       close) and their menu looks very adaptable
      * [https://maps.app.goo.gl/nhX2TXPv2YWddNTD7](https://maps.app.goo.gl/nhX2TXPv2YWddNTD7)
      * [https://www.fudo-restaurant.com/](https://www.fudo-restaurant.com/)

Title:
Finally booked our trip‚Ä¶.!!

April 5-28.

13 y/o son is coeliac, the rest of us don‚Äôt have any allergies or intolerances.

First 7 days are in Tokyo, then flying to Nagasaki and spending a few days there.
Bullet train back towards Tokyo with a couple of days in Hiroshima, Osaka, Kyoto, Nagoya, Yokohama, then another couple of days in Tokyo before flying home.

I have read up so much on the do‚Äôs and dont‚Äôs but I am at a complete loss when it comes to GF options for my son.

I did read somewhere that there‚Äôs a company that you can pay to help you navigate the menu process.

If anyone has any ideas, recommendations (tried and tested), please let me know!

ResponsesV2.Message:
Hi Stacey, we just got back from a trip to Tokyo and Osaka. My biggest suggestion is take enough premade snacks and breakfast cereal sachets for your coeliac...just to help with the transition. 
There are lots of gf cafes in Tokyo and Osaka...do a search on the page and pin them on maps...some can be a distance away from tourist areas. If you are planning to go to usj or Disney they do have an allergy friendly meal..a lot of people have posted about...but you can do a search and see lots more info. If you get stuck you can buy salted onigiri at 711 or Lawson's... allergy friendly meals are available at moss burger(see the recent post) and ichibanya curry house all kept separate and coeliac safe. 

Finally if you get time in Osaka I highly recommend Comeconoco Gluten-free Laboratory & Cafe -Á±≥Á≤âÂ∞ÇÈñÄ„Ç´„Éï„Çß Â§©Ê∫ÄÊ©ã Yukiko and the team are amazing. They conduct fabulous cooking classes and have a cafe with some delicious treats..I highly recommend the choux pastryü§§...

We are here now, currently on the Bullet train.  It has been difficult over the busy NY period as lots has been closed. We walked around Kyoto for 2 hours yesterday morning just to find breakfast as everything was closed. TheFind me GF app is very handy.  We‚Äôve found that most people are not familiar with Gluten Free even with the allergy card. There are some places who are very good but not many.  Bring snacks from home. I would have planned more in hindsight and plot more options on Google maps from this group.  If you nail your planning as much as possible and make reservations it should be easier outside of peak season. Bring breakfast as much as possible. We brought muesli from Aus.

Title:
#takayama Johanna Beim

Sakurajaya
A few negative reviews on this site for this place as they only serve locals at lunchtime but after talking to the owner we understand he is trying to keep a balance and support the locals who helped him get started. He only allows a few bookings in the evenings so that he can provide an amazing experience. Get a seat at the bar and you will enjoy more than just food. He explained everything he was doing and all the ingredients. Very happy to accomodate to Gluten Free but may not suit Celiac as he fries all the food in same place so could be some cross-contamination. Just amazing experience though!
Reservation needed.

Heianraku
This is owned by a Chinese couple who cook Japanese food. They clearly state what is gluten free and are so friendly and enthusiastic. Gluten Free Goysa and Ramen! Home cooking with an excellent atmosphere.
Reservation needed.

Suzuya
Not strictly gluten free but very helpful once we showed the gluten free card and explained options. Amazing smells of cooking, cozy vibe and excellent food. Local cuisine - hot pot or grilled food.
We went for lunch and didn‚Äôt need a reservation.

Title: Spent two nights at Yudanaka Seifuso in Nagano Prefecture. This is a lovely little hot springs inn that can prepare gluten free meals by request. They have a very good understanding of the requirements for gluten free/ celiac safe food and can also accommodate allergies if you let them know (soy, shellfish, nuts, etc). Staff consistently put us at ease with their clear explanations of how the food was prepared. I am very reactive to gluten and had no issues. Also, the brand of hot corn soup and bean sweet in the vending machine next to the bath are gluten free, which is a fun after bath treat! In town is a lovely little shop that sells onsen pudding in lots of flavors and that‚Äôs gluten free as well, I didn‚Äôt try them but that shop also has gluten free cookies. There‚Äôs a well stocked Lawson‚Äôs right across the street from the station for snacks and drinks (the Lawson‚Äôs stocks Nodogoshi-Nama by Kirin which is a gluten free beer - I have enjoyed a few!). And Yudanaka is close to the Snow Monkey Park!

ResponsesV2.Message: This is in the city of Nagano?

Title: Hi all! My wife with Celiacs and I are travelling to Japan soon for 2 months and planning to travel for one month and stay somewhere for one month (we work remotely and also love travelling this way). After doing some location scouting I've narrowed it down to Fukuoka, Hiroshima, and Osaka. I'm leaning towards the first 2 but concerned there wont be enough gf options there for her for a month. Do we need to stick with a bigger city like Osaka so she can eat in peace? Anywhere I may have missed that would be suited for this kind of stay?

ResponsesV2.Message:
I would recommend Kyoto over any of the others, but I don‚Äôt have experience with with Kyushu.

Kyoto has a lot of options for restaurants if the postings on here are anything to go by, Osaka is believe it or not, a lot harder. And it obviously gets harder the further you get away from main tourist destinations.

I didn‚Äôt try to find any when I was there but I‚Äôm sure they have to have some grocery stores with options there too. Situating yourself in Kyoto would be great for day trips and stuff too and it‚Äôs only 2 hours to Tokyo.

Also‚Ä¶ Japanese immigration doesn‚Äôt play around so if you‚Äôre doing work on a 90 day tourist visa that may be a problem,
Fukuoka and Hiroshima are both nice size cities. I‚Äôd recommend to stay in an apartment with kitchen so you can cook your own meals, so much easier than to search for a restaurant all the time.

I think the best ones are found in the supermarket produce areas. Convenience stores sometimes have them but those are usually little scrappy pieces from China. You can usually tell where they are produced based on price (if you  can‚Äôt read labels). The more expensive ones will be from Japan. This bag was ¬•680 at Aeon. Title: This is a really late post but better late than never. This past October my husband (not gluten free) and I honeymooned in Tokyo and it was amazing! The food was outstanding and most of the time my husband was saying how it was the best he has ever tasted. Not just for gluten free food but overall. We went to a bunch of gluten free places or places that offered gluten free but our over all favorites were Avan, RICEHACK, Waco cr√™pes(Kyoto), and Rizlabo Kitchen. The Find Me GF app was super helpful! I know RICEHACK, Waco, and Rizlabo have been talked about a lot and for good reason the food is amazing! Not only that but the owner of RICEHACK is super kind and thoughtful. We went on our last full day there to get curry buns but unfortunately they had sold out right before we arrived. The owner was kind and felt bad that we would get one more before leaving for home that he offered to sell us one that was set aside for a regular. He insisted that this regular was very understanding and would have no issues with him selling us the bun. I was so unbelievably thankful for that. Now if you made it this far in reading I have a treat for you. If you‚Äôre going to be in Shibuya go the Avan! Avan is a dedicated gluten free cafe. It was the best food we came across hands down! The fried chicken almost brought me the tears it was so good. The eggplant spaghetti was also gobbled up so quick lol. And the desserts, they have a variety of churros! This was the first time I was able to try one and I‚Äôm so happy I did!Please please please go to Avan and keep them in business. I want to go back and have some more!Ôøº

Title: Hey! I‚Äôm staying in a ryokan in Nagano in February, and they are providing breakfast and dinner. I was thinking of calling ahead to see if they can possibly make gluten free meals. Has anyone had any success with gluten free meals at Ryokan? If so, how would I go about asking if this is possible? Thanks in advance :)

ResponsesV2.Message:
We had an amazing experience at Wafu No Yado Masuya in Nagano near the snow monkeys. Delicious food, beautiful stay and service. They have two public onsens to all guests and a private one you can rent that is really special. Highly recommend!
Hi! Sorry I didn't see this until now. Yeah I emailed them to make sure they could accommodate and told them I would put the notes in my booking to be sure. I booked through hotels.com (https://www.hotels.com/affiliate/zD91Q3W) and put celiac requiring gluten free food due to allergies to make sure they knew. We had no issues and it was an amazing experience! So yummy there. I would definitely reach out to your Ryokan and ask if they can accommodate, it's likely and would make the experience so much better for you! Good luck, excited to hear how it goes.

I would definitely email in advance (and I would email rather than phone unless you have fluent Japanese) and check whether they can accommodate gluten free meals. Based on my experience, if you do not it is highly unlikely that they will be able to do so at short notice. Certainly I have had ryokans refuse my booking when I have enquired as to whether they can make changes! That said, when a ryokan has agreed to make adaptions it has always been spectacular - part of the joy of staying at a ryokan is the amazing food so definitely worth finding one that will feed you!

Title:
I've returned to say that I tried the tofu +rice flour pizza crust that people spoke about and I've made it 5 times better by adding psyllium  husk powder.

I personally never measure anything out but I've gotten fantastic pizza crust with this very unscientific method. I throw everything in a plastic bag and squish to mix so I don't have exact measurements for this. 

I take average size of firm tofu, add spices (salt pepper, oregano, basil and garlic)

Then If I had to guesstimate it I'd do 3tbs corn starch, 1tbs potato starch, 1tbs of baking power and 2-3tbs of psyllium husk powder. 1 tsp neutral oil or olive oil and 1tbs sugar. Add enough rice flour to form a solid dough (almost cookie dough like) .

I take this and flatten in in the pan and will prebake to make it crunchy around 190C at 15-20mins. Add your sauce and topping and bake again till everything is toasted and melted.

ResponsesV2.Message: Do you drain and press the tofu first?
Thanks!! I'm definitely trying this

Title:
***This is not a sponsored post, just wanted to share my incredible experience in Japan this last week with a company I actually found here: Gluten Free Tours Japan. This FB group is by itself a godsend with all of our posts and discussion! But if you are specifically looking for someone to help directly during your trip, I definitely recommend them!
To say that this company was amazing is an absolute understatement.
My husband and I did Japan back in 2014 when I was only a few years into being officially a diagnosed Celiac. Even though it was one of the best trips of my life, travelling in Japan with a gluten allergy was super difficult as you all have experienced ‚Äì I survived mostly on plain meat and plain white rice as it was very difficult to properly communicate my allergy so it was a very frustrating experience, even with the allergy cards. I wanted to experience the incredible food I was seeing and smelling ‚Äì its one of the things we know Japan is famous for!
Fast forward to this year when we decided we wanted to go back. I was hesitant from a food perspective, but wondered if with Google Translate now I might be able to get by but would have to spend tons of time trying to figure out if it was safe, if every time I try something should I take the risk etc.
Enter ‚Äì Gluten Free Tours Japan. Meaghan and Hiroshi were a GOD SEND. Before the trip they answered every single question I had, learned what I wanted to taste and try (much were fried food that normal people can eat so I was hopeful!), and gathered all of our plans.
Once we got there, everything was so simple. They booked tons of delicious experiences for us from Teppanyaki, Omakase, Keiseki, Japanese BBQ, Shabu Shabu and Kushiage. I got to eat SO MUCH ‚Äì they found me tempura, souffle pancakes, ramen, bread, yatsuhashi, teriyaki, sushi ‚Äì you name it! My husband is not gluten free and he was able to eat everything he wanted to as well. Anything I came across they were able to help me decipher by checking out any ingredients from the konbini snacks and talk with the chefs and staff directly at any place I had questions ‚Äì I felt so safe and so taken care of. It was so nice to be able to actually enjoy all the wonderful flavors of Japan without worry and also enjoy the country in a new way!

ResponsesV2.Message: That‚Äôs great! I‚Äôve been looking at them as well. Did you book one of their tours or just their assistance with finding gluten free food?
That is amazing to hear! I have booked in with them for a Xmas new year trip ‚ù§Ô∏è‚ù§Ô∏è‚ù§Ô∏è

Title:
I've been living in Japan for almost a decade, and half of which, I've managed to live as a gluten intolerant. I have a sweet tooth, so five years ago, I would always have to bake when I crave or wait for my I-Herb shipping. I moved near the beach side from Tokyo by now, but if you are visiting Enoshima Sea Candle and nearby attractions, Greenstamps Coffee in Tsujido is soooo worth the side trip.

There are many gluten-free options where I live now in Chigasaki (I guess people associate beach life with healthy life so many cafes have gluten free desserts and options) but it's probably not accessible to those touring Tokyo.
So my HUNGER STRIKE plan is below.

I came to Japan with no knowledge of gluten issues, so I ate ALL THE GLUTEN I CAN, so if there are two things only that I miss: IT'S CHOU CREAM (for non-Japan residents, it's basically cream puff on steroids!) and RAMEN/TSUKEMEN (dipping noodles).

Out of the way but if near your itinerary:
Greenstamps Coffee. The pistachio nama chou cream almost made me cry cause I never thought I could ever eat one again (like cream puffs from Beard Papa which I used to love!)

I know it's not easy to stop by places but here are my you-can-find-anywhere hacks if you have no cross-contamination issues.

1. DOUTOR COFFEE is everywhere. The optimistic in me, always hopes, so I ask and check the ingredient list. For years, everytime I need a quick dessert, I get their BROWN MONT BLANC. (Never the seasonal flavors of murasaki and pumpkin because base is made of tart). The Brown Mont Blanc is made of meringue base and fresh cream. I pair it with black coffee and it instantly makes me happy!
2. AFURI. Surprise! You can find gluten-free from a chain resto! I've been praying soooo hard for tsukemen that I dreamed it to life. I am not a coeliac and I have low to no reaction to soy sauce. I've eaten the spicy yuzu tsukemen with cold (can be warm) tsukemen konjac noodles many times after a tiring day, and I always feel satisfied and have no reactions. 
3. MARLOWE. Their main branch is in Hayama, where I usually hang out after beach tennis, but they have many stalls across Tokyo. The hopeful in me always asks, so I receive. Haha. Seriously, whenever I tour visiting friends, wherever we are, I always try to discover if maybe something is for me. Marlowe's pudding is cut above the rest. And they have other desserts (financier/cookies/small cakes) that are gluten-free. If I'm not mistaken, made of almond flour. 
4. IKEA. They're accessible in most parts of Japan. Say your family is shopping in Shinjuku, Harajuku or Shibuya, do a stopover. Go to the frozen section. The Daim Almond Cake which is like Ferrero in cake form (with some nougatty, flaky layers) is easy, cheap, and delicious. 

Shameless plug. More on coffee and beach life than gluten free, but if you want that, too, follow me @coffeee.jp and @beachvintagejapan on Instagram. 
Happy Gluten-free Eating!

ResponsesV2.Message: Home party life saver from Ikea üòä
the problem with afuri is that they boiling konnyaku noodles in the same water of flour noodles so it‚Äôs very unsafe.

Title:
GF in Japan. Oct 2023

A big thanks to this group for all of the advice. 

You‚Äôll need a bottle of GF soy sauce. To find it in a supermarket I needed the picture of the bottle that is on this site (use ‚Äòsearch‚Äô on this site).

Here are my wins:

**Tokyo**

Shimbu Sakiya Ramen. GF &/or vegetarian ramen. Near Shibuya station

**Kawaguchiko**

Alladin Indian restaurant, near the Ogini supermarket. No actual GF menu, but could easily accommodate.

**Magome**

Magome Chaya guest house (G/H). They didn‚Äôt get back to me with my email queries re being able to provide a GF meal, so I booked ‚Äúroom only‚Äù. On arrival at 3pm the 2 lovely sisters who run the place said ‚ÄúYes, we can do that‚Äù, and OMG! It was divine. I now know that they are so busy providing a top notch service to their guests that my email might have dropped off the bottom of their ‚Äòto do‚Äô list. I would go back there tomorrow!

**Tsumago**

Koshinzuka Minshuku G/H. They assured me in advance that they could do GF meals, and yes! Fabulous. And it‚Äôs an old traditional house, with a host who ‚Äòhosts‚Äô. Great experience. This place is a little out of town, but we were there for the walking, so it wasn‚Äôt a problem. My luggage was transported from Magome to a G/H near to this one.

**Kyoto**

Engine Ramen. fab GF &/or vegetarian ramen.

Waco crepes. SOOOO worth the journey there.

Okonomiyaki Katsu. A tiny ‚Äòcook your own savoury pancake‚Äô place near Ryoanji Goryonoshitacho (historic temple with fabulous rock/sand garden). The proprietor here groaned (nicely) when he read my GF card, then suggested a pork with worchestershire sauce dish. It was amazing! Sorry, I don‚Äôt know its name.

Mimikou. Udon noodles. Near Chion-in Temple. I mention this as a ‚Äúnot a good experience‚Äù. It was mentioned on this site as a safe/good place. I found the staff had no understanding, and struggled to accommodate me. I wasn‚Äôt glutened, but my meal was not very nice.

**Hongu**

Engawa Cafe and Guesthouse. No cafe now, just 1 room for guests. This is a very modest/rustic family home. The family have a ‚Äòtread lightly on the earth‚Äô philosophy. There is a great outdoor bath, and a host (the father) who understands GF. He picks you up / drops you off in Hongu. Be warned: composting toilet here.

**Zao Onsen**

Kasheru. Owned and ran by a young Sobanoodle chef. No GF menu but a good understanding of what I could not eat. Grilled veges and lamb, lovely sake, and GF miso soup (so good I had seconds of this). They are cash only.

**Takayama**

Heianraku. Needs no introduction to this site. Totally wow! It is worth the effort to secure a booking, through their website [https://heianraku.com/](https://heianraku.com/)

**Yamagata**

Theatre side cafe Slow Jam. Bit of a hit and miss with the staff (like everywhere). I went here twice. The waitress on the first visit was all over the GF thing, and said everything on the menu could be GF. She showed me their bottle of GF soy sauce. I had the Khao man gai.      Next day, different waitress. She was unsure, so I had the Khao man gai again.

**Sendai**

Healthy hut. A wonderful GF enclave in Sendai. Great owner and staff. You feel safe here (re gluten).

**Hiraizumi**

Yakiniku restaurant/ pub. No GF menu, but a great waitress/ barmaid who took the time to understand and ‚Äòprotect‚Äô me from gluten. Great experience here, no other westerners here, the locals took us under their wings and were gorgeous.

ResponsesV2.Message: #ramen #shibuya #kawaguchiko #magome #tsugamo #kyoto #vegetarian #hongu #takayama #heianraku #yamagata #cafe #sendai #yakiniku #hiraizumi

Title:
Hi All,

Just wanted to thank this group. Just got back from 11 days in Tokyo and Kyoto. Gluten free travel in Japan is possible with lots of research and planning. 

I started planning about 3 months out. And booked as many restaurants as I could 4-6 weeks out. I diarised restaurants that could be booked closer to the date. I recommend booking as many restaurants as possible. If a restaurant is too busy they won‚Äôt seat you. Also we tried showing the translation card to
a few restaurants and it was a no. 

I found restaurants by searching this group. Then I short listed restaurants and matched them to attractions. Tokyo is a huge city. Makes it so much easier to eat in areas you already plan to be. 

My husband and I stayed with a friend in Tokyo. Our friend could speak a little Japanese which helped. 

I didn‚Äôt have any reactions and I took Gluteguard before every meal. I am not a sensitive coeliac. I don‚Äôt have reactions from shared fryers or shared hot plates. I will have reactions from same chopping board, utensils or dirty hands. 

Snacks
Onigiri- convenience stores with red salmon and salt. Used my own soy sauce. Definitely for when lunch hasn‚Äôt gone to plan. 
Brought my own soy sauce and snacks (rice crackers, museli bars, GF Tim tams, GF Kit Kats, GF tiny teddies, GF Pringles, GF lollies, GF noodles). Good to be able to have snacks as needed. Most snacks in Japan contained gluten. Also I often didn‚Äôt have time to google translate snacks.
We were walking about 19-24kms per day so I was definitely hungrier than normal. 

Laduree Kyoto- GF macarons. Lady in the shop was super helpful and showed me the ingredients list for the macrons. 

Breakfast- I brought GF Muesli bars, which was an easy breakfast. Got a little sick of them after a few days. Wish I had brought some GF cereal or muesli. I did find some haloumi towards the end, so was able to make eggs, haloumi and avocado. If you go to Rice Hack (GF bakery) stock up on GF bread. 

I managed to have GF churros from Kuroboshi (Asakusa Riki Street) near Senso-Ji temple, definitely recommend. Was delicious and a long time since I have had churros. 

Totti Candy Factory, Fairy Floss (Harajuku). Also delicious. 

Tokyo 
Udatsu sushi- very memorable lunch. Not cheap but worth the $. Lunch is half the price of dinner. Book in advance and request gluten free. Adapted the meal for me. Chef makes the nigiri in front of you he was good a preventing cross contamination and washed his hands regularly. He would make mine first. You can bring your own soy sauce. 
Hakkido Sapporo/
Shimbu Sakiya Ramen- Delicious GF ramen and fried chicken. They also had goza but I didn‚Äôt try these. Cheap, quick and easy. No bookings. You order on a vending machine and need to pay in cash. Was an absolute treat, I have not had ramen in a very long time. The noodles were so good, was a little worried but my noodles were different from my husbands. The signs inside the restaurant indicated that there could be cross contamination with the fried chicken. I ate the fried chicken and did not have any reaction. Just something to consider for sensitive celiacs. The gluten eaters also enjoyed this place. 
Soranoiro nippon- a little hard to find. But eventually found it. You need to purchase your meal at the vending machine and then join the waiting line. You need cash. GF ramen option is on the vending machine. We waited about 25 mins. Was delicious, poached chicken, egg, brown rice noodles and broth full of flavour. 
Otsuna- sushi- delicious dinner. On the pricey side, but worth it for the high quality. Restaurant even had GF soy sauce, the chef told me it‚Äôs hard to find in Japan. Meal was adapted for me, the eel course was substituted. I booked this restaurant in advance. 
Ricehack-delicious GF curry puffs. They also have bread and pizza. Close to Harajuku and kaleidoscope escalator. 
Gonpachi Nishi-Azabu- I had some chicken and mushrooms skewers and a tempura prawn and rice bowl. They served the tempura rice bowl with matcha salt. I brought my own GF soy sauce to use. A little confusion to start but after I showed the translation card and GF menu from the Asakusa restaurant the waiter talked me through what I could have. All delicious. Fun vibes, 90s music and we were treated to a drum show. Felt my requirements were taken seriously. My food come out separately to the rest of the group. I booked this restaurant in advance. 
Kazu (Oshiage)-Japanese bbq place. So much fun. Explained gluten free when we arrived. We just ordered meat with salt ( no soy sauce). I brought my own soy sauce. You cook everything yourself. The hot plate had been cleaned. We also ordered vegetables and rice. I booked this restaurant in advance. 
Gluten free T‚Äôs- okay. Food is pretty average. Was nice not to have to worry about how the food is cooked and having to explain what wheat is. Definitely good for sensitive celiacs. I booked this restaurant in advance. 
Teppan Baby- delicious, I had an GF Okonomiyaki and cheese teppanyaki. The menu labels items GF. There was a cross contamination risk on the teppan, so I wouldn‚Äôt recommend for a sensitive coeliac. I booked this restaurant in advance. 
Torikizoku- chain skewer place in Japan. My friend was able to look up the menu online which specified which items contained wheat. We ordered skewers that were wheat free. I brought my own soy sauce. Good value for money. Was a fun evening. I booked this restaurant in advance. 
Vege Herb Saga- vegetarian Indian restaurant, I had a masala dosa. Indian food is a go to takeaway at home as lots of GF options. So was good to find one in Japan. 

Kyoto 
Fish market- beef skewers with salt. 
Kikyo sushi- well worth the train ride. Delicious sushi and sashimi. They have gluten free soy sauce. Good English and seemed knowledgeable. Family run. Good price for the quality. 
Loco chicken- chicken is coated in rice flour. Chips are not GF. But chicken is GF and juicy. GF sauces are labelled. You can also get a meal with sides. We just got fried chicken and sauces. Small restaurant with only 4 seats. We didn‚Äôt have a booking, just walked in on a Tuesday lunchtime. 
Park Hyatt Kyoto- celebrated our first wedding anniversary at Yasaka. Amazing. Food was delicious and the views. The only course that was different to my husbands was dessert. Restaurant couldn‚Äôt guarantee cross contamination. But I wasn‚Äôt worried when I got there as only my dessert was different. And my dessert wasn‚Äôt cooked on the teppan plate. They were cleaning the teppan plate throughout dinner service. The teppan plate was very clean and ordered. We also had a drink at the bar next door, called Kohaku. Was an expensive experience but worth it to us. 
Yosiya - I had the GF/ Vegan bento. I enjoyed the tempera and the tofu and rice. My husband had eel on rice which he enjoyed. Service was bad I waited 35 mins for my lunch and my husband waited 45 mins. Our first drinks also took 30 mins to come. I wouldn‚Äôt go out of my way to come here but if you‚Äôre going to be in the bamboo forest it‚Äôs not too far away. Not sure about cross contamination. I didn‚Äôt have a reaction but when I booked they did say they couldn‚Äôt guarantee cross contamination so I wouldn‚Äôt recommend for sensitive coeliac. 
Sugar Hill- I had the chicken teriyaki and it was delicious. They had a few GF options on the menu. I would definitely go back. Wait staff and chef were all very friendly. Also have GF soy sauce. 

Teuchi Toru Soba- wanted to go here, but it was closed on a day a few weeks ago it said it was open. 

Hope this helps. Really enjoyed our trip. Did get a little sad as I couldn‚Äôt eat whatever I wanted. But focused on all the delicious food I could have. 

For more photos you can check out my Instagram- travel_and_eating_as_a_celiac

Title:
Hello! I‚Äôm a newer member here and I am SO grateful for this group! I‚Äôve been heavily relying on this FB community as we‚Äôve been traveling through Japan.

I‚Äôve tried a lot of the recommendations mentioned in this group (delicious!) and wanted to add an amazing experience I just had tonight at Oh! Teppanyaki Restaurant in Osaka.

A little about me: I have celiac disease and have about medium-high sensitivity to cross-contamination.

Back story: My daughter and I went to Genji-Soba last night for the second time because we loved it so much. My husband and son were craving meat and stumbled upon Oh! as they were wandering around. They had a fantastic dinner there, consuming the best wagyu and Kobe beef teppanyaki they‚Äôve ever had in their lives. They had such a great experience that they made a reservation for our family for the following evening. 

At first, I was a bit weary of the idea because teppanyaki back where we live usually involves marinated meats and lots of sauces. And I was worried about cross-contamination. But my husband felt confident that the chef would be able to accommodate to my dietary needs. And because it was going to be the same chef serving us tonight, he wanted me to try it.

I showed the chef and the server my translation card and we communicated back and forth via Google Translate. They wrote, ‚ÄúWe will make sure we will accommodate to your dietary needs and be extra careful as we prepare your meal!‚Äù I legit wanted to cry because I felt so seen. üò≠

We ordered from the set menu and they served me the following:
- salad without dressing, but with olive oil and salt on the side 
- cooked teppanyaki beef without adding sauces, just salt and pepper. DELICIOUS!!
- cooked veggies with salt and pepper
- saut√©ed bean sprouts with oil and salt for me, and the chef added the ponzu sauce into the individual serving bowls for my fam so that the cooking surface didn‚Äôt have sauce on it 
- lastly, fried rice without sauce for me (I added some tamari to it and it was amazing). He then cooked fried rice with soy sauce for the fam on the cooking surface since it was the last item in our set menu.

While all this was happening, the other chef came by to observe and see how our chef was accommodating to my GF diet so that he could also learn more about it. ü•∞

I know this post turned out to be awfully long, but I just wanted to give a special shoutout to the chef, Keshiro, and the staff at Oh! for going above and beyond tonight. Here‚Äôs the location if you‚Äôre ever craving kobe beef tepppanyaki! Cheers! 

https://maps.app.goo.gl/MtKUgGfNAGSaRpMaA?g_st=ic

Title:
Everyone should go to Love for All in Kanazawa for lunch and dinner. They serve seafood as well as plant-based foods, so it's not just for vegans. Everything is gluten free except some buns they cook separately. They also mark the allergens on the menu and take care to prepare things separately and I believe everything is home made. A lot of the food was nut free as well, which is great because I have a tree nut allergy. Unfortunately I think I am an asymptomatic coeliac, so can't advise if you will react, but I was confident in their precautions.

The staff were knowledgeable and really nice and even gave us recommendations for Kyoto and Takayama and some cookies for free. At night it has a cozy, fancy yet not too formal vibe - would be a great date night if you get the set menu like we did. It also wasn't busy at all when we went - for a while it was just us in the restaurant. Will note it is not cheap by Japan standards, but the food is very high quality and delicious - best we have had so far. Non-coeliac partner was very impressed, including with the vegan items we got.

So we ordered the set menu. We got lotus chips, spicy edamame, snow crab and avocado on little rice cakes, sweet potato potash soup, eggplant yakiniku with rice and vegetables, mushroom tempura with yuzu dipping sauce and rice and vegetables, hot yuzu and ginger drink, kanazawa parfait with yuzu and berry ice cream and fruit and coconut cream. Also got some takeaway matcha and apple and cinnamon muffins. We were very full afterwards...

#kanazawa #loveforall #coeliac #nutallergy

Title:
Hi All
Ok, as I write this I think I know what you'll say! I'm only mentioning it because it came up within a day of my reading an old but similar post somewhere else. 

Obviously this is not advice and everyone decides their own risk. Yesterday I ate lunch at Healthy Hut in Sendai and enjoyed it, all good (gf marked meals, search this forum for more details). 

My Japanese friend asked about soy sauce during a long conversation and was told that Japanese doctor/s tell their coeliac patients that they can eat soy sauce. It was noted that foreigners may have different sensitivities and it was not any sort of recommendation. I had just heard previously that some people normally sensitive to any gluten had been able to take soy sauce in Korea and possibly Japan without a reaction. A smaller number couldn't. 

I guess I'd like to know more about the source of wheat used by various manufacturers, the processes undertaken in production and whether they are different for any products available in western countries. Is soy sauce the same everywhere is the question....... The next 'pie in the sky' wish is for various types of soy sauce to be actually extensively tested for gluten so we'd know. Any likely PhD candidates out there? :-)

ResponsesV2.Message: Who is this mystery doctor that has celiac patients? I actually had to give my doctor printouts explaining celiac disease since he‚Äôd never heard of it.

From the other comments I've read here, it seems similar to how some people say light beers in the US don't bother them because the wheat is so "broken down" by the brewing process. It's all based on how sensitive you are and what kinds of reactions you have. Plus, your body can be damaged without showing the obvious symptoms. So it's a personal choice - risk silent damage or go without.

Title:
I was panicking I couldn‚Äôt find a lunch for my Shinkansen trip Tokyo to Nara, but found e-cute food hall. I can‚Äôt give precise directions as  the station is massive and you can enter ecute from multiple sides. But found a concession that sold pickled snack packs - only allergy is apple. And nearby was a seller of different dessert. The chestnut, walnut, red bean mochi pudding was listed as GF. Not until I was on the train I Google Translated the ingredients. Wheat starch is listed - PANICK - but I googled the fermented wheat starch and coeliac disease. it is highly fermented and several studies show the gluten levels drop to near nil. 24hrs later I don‚Äôt have symptoms and I am very sensitive even to cross-contamination. And importantly, both were delicious.

PS thanks to this community, I survived Tokyo without incident.

Title:
Here‚Äôs my Kyoto experience.

Slightly more difficult than Tokyo for gluten free just because of logistics. There aren‚Äôt as many options and things are more spread out. Also the train service doesn‚Äôt run as many places like in Tokyo. Kyoto requires more planning and I would definitely have a back up plan. 

Oku-no-Niwa: They have one gluten free option which is a traditional Japanese plate. We came here on a Sunday around 12:30 and it was sold out. Have a plan B because there really aren‚Äôt any other options in the area for gluten free food (Arashiyama area). There is a cafe at the base of monkey park that‚Äôs 100% gluten free and vegan but has only sweets. However, I saw a post somewhere that they also have a cafe in a separate location nearby that has gluten free options, but I did not confirm this. Ended up walking to 7-Eleven for the usual rice ball, egg and fruit. 

Cafe Maru- The bar menu is all that is available now. It‚Äôs 100% gluten free but there are limited options. Very good food! 

Sugarhill: I would recommend a reservation. While sitting there we saw a few groups get seated and a few were turned away so it depends on luck if you don‚Äôt reserve. I reserved about a week in advance using Instagram messenger. The staff all speak good English and they are good with all allergens. 

Waco Crepes: DO NOT miss this place! So so good! Everything is gluten free and also everything can be made dairy free. They speak English and are lovely people! 

Kyoto Engine Ramen: The broth here is a creamy broth which is really good, but heavy. Staff speaks good English. They can do any ramen with gluten free noodles. 

Here Cafe: At the base of Kiyomizu-dera. Has a gluten free matcha omelette. It‚Äôs not dairy free so I didn‚Äôt try it. 

The city bakery: Has a gluten free muffin made with rice flour. I didn‚Äôt try it. They do have soy milk and oat milk for their coffees.

ResponsesV2.Message: Omg I live here, thank you so much
Thank you!

Title: Hello, we just wanted to go out for sushi and they give us this after asking for gluten free soy sauce. So sushi rice contains wheat??? I‚Äôm now a bit confused. We ate a lot of sushi and had no problems.

ResponsesV2.Message:
The vinegar used to make sushi rice could contain wheat or barley depending on which vinegar they use. 

That restaurant seems to be very knowledgeable about their food! In my experience, most places don't really seem to know much about possible allergens.

Rice Vinegar is sometimes but not always flavoured with a something like soy sauce (made from wheat). 

So its like 'our sushi rice contains wheat'.

Unfortunately you alwayshsve to check.

Just had a look and this place seems nice if you‚Äôre close by. I haven‚Äôt been there though, so double check about ingredients and allergies with the staff if you pop in.

https://www.himitsukichi-cafe.com/

Looks like they make really nice rice bread and cakes üç∞üëçüèª

Came to pier Bandai there‚Äôs a cute sushi place - #5 on the map Sado Benkei (not sure on safety but given I‚Äôm working from not much I‚Äôm willing to risk it - I‚Äôm a coeliac, no judgement please) but the wait was 1h 40 so we had to pass but there looked like there was lots of options. Next door is #6 on the map. My husband got the set menu sashimi with miso etc. it has tempura in it but it is served on the side. If I was to order again, I would order that and just eat what‚Äôs in the bowl and nothing else! Will keep updating this incase anyone else ends up in Niigata!

Title: My child is allergic to wheat along with seafood. Has anyone with a fish allergy also been able to eat gluten free ramen? He can eat meat so it doesn't need to be vegan. We are hoping to check out Shimbu Sakiya and some others. Thanks!

ResponsesV2.Message:
Soranoiro Nippon has two vegan ramens which should be fine, I highly recommend the tantanmen which uses GF soy sauce and is GF if you sub brown rice noodles (source: literally the owner who has commented on this page).  

I don‚Äôt know about fish in chicken or pork based ramen, honestly.
If he has a fish allergy you probably won‚Äôt be able to eat much‚Ä¶ daishi is in everything

Title: Also at Costco today: this is the same brand of the sliced bananas that were being sold at 7-Eleven. I didn‚Äôt buy them yet because I have no space in my freezer right now! Ôøº

**LONG POST** - Gluten free restaurants review in #Osaka, #Kyoto, #Nara, #Takayama, #Kanazawa, #Tokyo.

First of all, appreciation message to this amazing community that allowed me to prepare our Japan trip with lots of pre-saved places which was a massive help in day planning during our 2 week stay in Japan. Also very appreciated all people mentioning #gluten in Google reviews.

FYI, we are a couple on a honeymoon and I can eat gluten but my wife was diagnosed with coeliac desease 3 years ago. We used to be super picky with restaurants and meals before diagnosis (we still are) so I will be very honest with all reviews below. Even though it is highly appreciated to have a restaurant with GF options, it doesn't mean it is automatically a good restaurant.

A few thoughts before jumping into reviews:

**1.** What we found more frustrating is not being able to step in all these lovely small izakayas that you constantly pass by when walking around the cities. Actually 80% of restaurants reviewed had a clear western attendance, so it kinds of water down the purely Japanese experience.

**2. **Breakfast are impossible to manage for a GF individual, actually difficult to manage for a gluten one since most bakeries open around 10.00 so practically all breakfast were from konbini's or fresh fruits from bigger supermarkets. Take advantage to buy bread and similar stuff for next days if you step by a GF bakery (several ones mentioned below).

**3. **Eating GF requires planning, you cannot avoid that and you better have a look at what needs to be reserved or not. Most of reservations can be done with 3-4 days in advance so do not get crazy reserving with months in advance. However, cancellations are frequent so show up to a place that seems fully booked as we were successful in a few places doing that.

**4.** Final thought, GF experience in Japan is not completely the same in culinary terms (bear that in mind) but we still managed to eat a lot of different tasty foods so do not be afraid to go Japan if you are coeliac, you will have an amazing time and 100% sure you will not be hungry. Btw, God bless Google Lens and Google translate.

**RESTAURANT REVIEW **(I had a longer list but only mentioning the ones we actually ate at)

**#Osaka**:

**- Genji soba**:

First meal in Japan so quite excited for it but an average experience since main chef was out for 1-week travel and gluten free noodles were not available, only rice + meat bowls. I guess we had bad luck but still very valid option as it is near Dotonbori/Namba and seems quite safe for a coeliac.

**Reservation**: I don't think it is needed (only another couple having dinner on a Wednesday) but place is quite small.
https://maps.app.goo.gl/pjavzS6mHNbFEGbn7

**- OKO Okonomiyaki:**

Super well known place in gluten free /vegan community, a must go for location and menu options. However, long lines are a bit frustrating (go early or go late) and you will go out with a strong food smell in your clothes. Food quality is pretty good so I would repeat for an informal dinner.

**Reservation**: not allowed.

https://maps.app.goo.gl/mxrUfPqm37mQ37dN8

**- Matsusakagyu Yakiniku**

We wanted to try some beef in Kainiku style so we went to this place (branch with several restaurants in Japan) as I read some gluten mentions in Google reviews. Beef was delicious but super expensive in my opinion (19k yen only beef menu, drinks and sides on top), so it may be better to go with a cheaper menu. Also note most of appetizers and sides are not gluten free. Decent option to eat some beef as they were aware of gluten and spoke some English.

**Reservation**: can be done through website but we walk in without it and was half empty. They have private dining booths which make experience quite cozy.

https://maps.app.goo.gl/VCdUadsqvjhPPCRe6

**#Kyoto**:

- **Gion** **Soy Milk Ramen**

Vegan ramen place in old Gion district. Their ramen tastes VERY different to a regular ramen that you may have in another place. We didn't like it at all, I would not repeat it since Engine Ramen has also gluten free ramen and is muuuch better flavor-wise.

**Reservation**: not sure if can be done, we went for a lunch in a weekday and no waiting at all.

https://maps.app.goo.gl/AtdLvWypfi8YNFrR8

**- „Ç∏„Éì„Ç®„ÉªÊ¥ªÂ∑ùÈ≠öÊñôÁêÜ**

This was one of the most Japanese experiences that we had. It is run by a man that only speaks Japanese but has a device translating English or other languages to Japanese and vice versa so easy to manage. He had several gluten free options and all quite tasty to be honest. Soba's were very good and some charcoal fishes were available too.

**Reservation**: not needed for dinner, maybe needed for lunch. However as place is small, I may recommend stepping in if you are around the area and make a reservation for later on or following day just to make sure.

https://maps.app.goo.gl/R4vBZ8TPnEh5ztB28

- **Kikyo sushi**

Still dreaming about this sushi. Fresh generous fish cuts for a memorable omakase experience. It is run by a family in a traditional way but their son speaks English which makes it easy to understand each other. We thought it was actually cheap for the high quality of food delivered. Gluten free soy sauce available too.

**Reservation**: make a reservation in advanced to not miss out this place - their website has instructions on how to book. We were not in time for reservations so we went early to have lunch on a weekday and it seems it is common for them to have late cancellations so we just had to wait 15 min and had our place at the counter. Can't recommend it enough.

https://maps.app.goo.gl/4s7jx6iZGNBWzpCQ8

**- Engine Ramen**

Another gem in Kyoto for coeliacs as ramen is very tasty, mentioned several times here so not going to repeat myself. Only downside is it looks like you are in a London/NY spot since everyone there is western, even staff running the restaurant.

**Reservation**: I don't think it is allowed, we went quite early for dinner and we didn't have to wait but there was a waiting line when we went out. However, I think line shouldn't be too long since it is a fast meal.

https://maps.app.goo.gl/woN2N5KZJ5N83h5Y7

**- Ikkakuju Karasuma**

Best Okonomiyaki we had in a 2-week Japan travel. Oyster and special beef Okonomiyakis were to die for and tofu appetizer was tasty as well. They publicly state that Okonomiyakis are gluten free but we are afraid that some cross contamination may exist since they only have 1 big griddle to make them and there are normal/gluten free options. My wife didn't feel bad after the meal and it looked like a clean kitchen but you may want to ask if you are very sensitive to gluten contamination.

**Reservation**: it didn't look like a packed place but it can be easily done though their website so it may be better to assure your seats.

https://maps.app.goo.gl/9Ewbh3XHcp3bWLPH9

- **Toshoan** (bakery)

Fancy sweet place near Nijo Castle, all gluten free with multiple options to eat in the place or to take out. A bit pricey but options like pancakes are very tasty.

https://maps.app.goo.gl/GWgZZVGN6x5D6ZSG6

**#Nara**:

**- Big Mountain Cafe & Farm**

Nara was a hard spot to find decent gluten free restaurants. After failing with Nino (Italian restaurant offering gluten free pasta but fully booked when waking by and no GF pasta available on that day :/) we had to do a quick research and ended up at a Hawaiian restaurant a bit far away from Nara park and surroundings. Good food, nice desserts and cozy atmosphere. Other options in Nara seemed to be indians or curries so this one looked healthier.

**Reservation**: not needed, place at half capacity on a Sunday lunch.

https://maps.app.goo.gl/MSocF7VXTTmeuJ2k6

- **Nakatanidou** (mochis)

Super famous place near Nara park were original old recipe mochis are made. You will easily spot it as there are always queues to get a mochi and they do a mochi demonstration at some hours during the day (even more crowded). However don't feel intimidated as they deliver super fast and these mochis are incredibly good, not specially sweet since it is the original bean recipe but we absolutely loved it. And gluten free!

https://maps.app.goo.gl/iPhdPLpWAi7zyeMA6

**#Takayama**:

- **Suzuya**

Beef restaurants are usually a safe place for a celiac so we went to Suzuya and quite satisfied with quality and price of the food. Not a surprise what you will find there but they are knowledgeable of gluten and have several options for it so highly recommended to go.

**Reservation**: I would say not needed since we didn't have any problem on a lunch weekday. However, it may be recommended to step in if you are already in Takayama to book for a later hour/day.

https://maps.app.goo.gl/Bvvd9H4N4uMF9B2c6

**- Heianraku**

This place has highly rated reviews in Google and has been mentioned here as a superb place many times, I thought people were exaggerating but NOT AT ALL. What a wonderful place to eat! One of the best meals of our trip. It is run by an old couple that makes you feel very welcome since you step into their place. Food was outstanding, all was very good but mabo tofu... I never thought a tofu dish could have such flavour. On top of that, price is actually cheap which it felt like we were stealing them. GO.

**Reservation**: absolutely needed, I actually think they only work through reservation as they take a very few people on each dinner slot. I got some email from their website so I interacted with them through email with no problems at all.

https://maps.app.goo.gl/Bvvd9H4N4uMF9B2c6

- **Sakurajaya**

It must be a nice place looking at their reviews but it was a huge disappointment in our trip. No website or booking place is provided to ask for a reservation (other than a phone number) so we walked there to book seats to have lunch on the next day. Once at the restaurant, we found out they recently changed their policy and now lunch time is only accepting local Japanese customers.. which is quite funny since I guess he will ask for the ID or only accept you if you speak Japanese and look Asian. We found this policy utterly discriminatory so I cannot recommend it.

https://maps.app.goo.gl/Aw9QuH6xdB6HXZi86

**- Sushi-Dining Nob**

Decent sushi at a reasonable price in Takayama center where we ended up after Sakurajaya refusal. Not the best quality since they have lots of rolls with avocados and some sauces (like western sushi delivery style) but it tastes quite good and the guy knows about gluten. Gluten free soy sauce available too.

**Reservation**: I don't even think it is allowed. We went at a peak hour for a lunch (12.45h) and we were accepted after waiting 15 min.

https://maps.app.goo.gl/iT7YChbhdVfGoduy8

**- Hidatei Hanaougi **(lodge)

Not actually a restaurant but a Ryokan lodge that we stayed in. Quite expensive but absolutely worth it to have a private onsen in a traditional Japanese room. They include a private dinner and breakfast. Dinner can be highly adapted to gluten free requirements and it is presented in a Kaiseki way with many small dishes. Breakfast as gluten free options differed widely to a regular option since it is directly a western style (pancakes, coffee, etc.), still worth it IMO.

**Reservation**: needed and very much in advanced to secure a nice room with a private onsen in a small garden.

https://maps.app.goo.gl/KAUBrB68J2qv6s4v7

**#Kanazawa**:

**- Omicho Market**

Touristic place in Kanazawa where they sell fresh fish and all types of seafood. You can either take it directly from the stands (safe option asking for no dressings) or go to some of the restaurants in it to have a full plate of sashimi with rice. This second option is better to have a full meal but more difficult to manage since most of the places don't speak English and we only managed to get a meal after talking through Google translate to request no soy or vinegar rice in the bowls. My wife didn't have any issue after eating there but it didn't feel 100% safe - try showing the GF card to several place to assure that.

https://maps.app.goo.gl/TKkmQi4iJ42do9Tb9

**- Fuwari**

Another highlight of the trip. They actually have a specific gluten free menu which makes it quite easy to order. Sashimi, eel and fish of the day were incredibly good. A bit pricey but food quality makes it absolutely worth it. They also speak decent English.

**Reservation**: recommended or actually needed since dinner time looked with all tables full. Easy to do through their website.

https://maps.app.goo.gl/c7XM35QUkNVDQ7Zn8

**#Tokyo**:

**- Soranoiro Nippon Ramen**

Convenient place in Tokyo Station serving a good GF ramen and outstanding normal ramen. Quite hard to find for the first time, it is located in B1 near Yaesu Central Exit (out of turnstile) in a hallway called Ramen Street.

**Reservation**: not allowed, it has a ticket self service machine but it is usually a short waiting time even if line looks long.

https://maps.app.goo.gl/kqWxZEikdA9D3N7n8

**- Gluten Free Kushiage Su**

Another highlight meal in our trip. This one is quite an expensive experience since it is a 2-hour private dinner (or lunch in weekends) with the chef in a counter with space for 8 people max. Chef barely speaks English but enough to explain dishes and he will use a translator if there is any additional explanation. Food quality is outstanding and not heavy, even though is it mainly deep fried skewers. Absolutely worth it if you are used to fine dining in your country, not recommended if you are on a budget in Tokyo.

**Reservation**: needed. Easy to do through their website/Instagram.

https://maps.app.goo.gl/bToxSPLSoWMZ2Fms6

- **My Banh Mi **

Nice option for a quick meal in Harajuku neighborhood, near Takeshita street. They serve typical Vietnamese banh sandwich with several fillings. It is a bit expensive looking at how small are the portions but still a nice/tasty option in the area. I may recommend to complete it with a pancake in Rizlabo as we did :).

**Reservation**: not needed, it looks more like a take away place.
https://maps.app.goo.gl/nYyuDJ6d1CVdQoF46

**- Rizlabo **(bakery)

Pancakes and sweet place in Harajuku as well. Pancakes are huge and super good so highly recommend it.

https://maps.app.goo.gl/uXQJyr9fokCV3Jdo9

**- Shimbu Sakiya Ramen **

Place very similar to Soranoiro in Tokyo Station but with more ramen options and even GF gyozas and chicken karagee! Must go if you are in Shibuya since it is not allowed to reserve (ticket machine at the entrance) and it is open until very late in the night. Again, not 100% sure about cross contamination since they disclaim kitchen and utensils used are not different for GF options. However, we went twice with no symptoms.

**Reservation**: not allowed.

https://maps.app.goo.gl/oPQxfK61D3V3Pang9

**- Gonpachi Asakusa**

Nice option in Asakusa near Senso-ji temple with views to the river. They have a gluten free menu making it easy to order. Lots of options to choose and quality is ok (not the best) so I would repeat if I am around the area again. Downside is service being super slow as we stayed more than 1h30... They had a big travel group at the same time so this may be the reason.

**Reservation**: people was showing up without reservation but it is easy to do through their website so better do it if you can.

https://maps.app.goo.gl/59F9v1CUPkNoV6t4A

-** Shou Toyosu market**

This restaurant is next to super famous Sushi Dai which is fully booked for the day before 7.00 am, we didn't even try although we were in the market for the tuna auction at 5.30am. Instead of Dai, we tried out Shou after reading some reviews and it was a marvelous experience. We showed our classical gluten questions to the chef using Google translate and they adapted the omakase menu to GF by not using soy sauce and avoiding a few nigiris like tamagoyaki (kind of egg omelette). Not 100% sure if they were using a rice with a GF rice vinegar but again, my wife didn't feel bad after that. Amazing fish quality.

**Reservation:** not allowed. Check the opening hours as all these market restaurants close quite early (most with last order at 13.30). You may have to wait in a queue for your spot at the counter but nothing crazy.

https://maps.app.goo.gl/h6AUFQCEAmiJvfSL8

**- Breizh Cafe Creperie Shinjuku**

There are several Breizh crepes restaurants in Japan specialized in french crepes (galettes) offering nice set menus with a wide GF range of salt and sweet crepes. Nice quality of crepes and fillings so it is a safe choice around Shinjuku. Note it is on the 12th floor of a shopping center which may be a bit difficult to find it at the first time.

**Reservation**: not needed, it is quite a big place with indoors and terrace.

https://maps.app.goo.gl/SVqDUoiuHnkvMb1j6

-** FANCL Brown Rice meals**

This restaurant was an outlier in our trip. Su from Kushiage deep fried recommended us this restaurant in Ginza that I never read about it before. We went there with low expectations and what a surprise! They had a gluten free menu and food quality was outstanding. It is a bit western type of food (pasta, chicken, etc) but lovely cooked and even the other tables were mainly japanese people. They even had GF tiramisu and a small store of staples to buy like bread, cookies, etc. Highly recommend it.

**Reservation**: I would say it is not needed, it doesn't seem a very well known place.

https://maps.app.goo.gl/L31gQkrQDbsXLBQo7

**- Otsuna Sushi**

Another amazing sushi restaurant very knowledgeable of gluten. They have a weekday lunch menu that is a joke, 1.880 yens for a 10pc nigiri set with miso soup but it is limited to 20 meals per day so you better go early when they open or other menus will be far more expensive. We went later in the day and nigiri menu was considerably more expensive but fish quality was outstanding so we didn't mind to pay for it.

**Reservation**: not needed for lunch, maybe for dinner. 20 meals limitation is first come, first served. As lunch then gets more expensive it was almost empty when we were there. Not sure how packed will be for dinner.

https://maps.app.goo.gl/PgxdaNCrk5r7bycE8

**- NachuRa **(bakery)

Best bakery in our Japan trip, all gluten free. Quite pricey but absolutely worth it.. cheese cake, pistacho cream puff and Mont Blanc were to die for. They also have cookies and similar stuff to be sold for take away. Take a few things with you since it is all super good.

Location is not the best since it is in Ropppongi but not close to a major touristic spot - around 30 min walk from Ropppongi Hills or Mori Tower.

https://maps.app.goo.gl/jLmFizwhTpKEzqyM8

**- Kuroboshi Churros **(bakery)

New tiny bakery selling churros close to Asakusa temple. Average quality so unless you are very hungry or desperate for a sweet treat, you may skip that since taste is not great.

https://maps.app.goo.gl/9c93aR7SZ6iE4hJ59

Hope you find this large review useful and don't hesitate to ask me questions when preparing your trip to Japan üòä

Hope you enjoy as much as we did!!

ResponsesV2.Message: Wow thank you Marc Oliver! Awesome post. I‚Äôm following parts of your food trail üôèüíÉ
