Title: Hello, does anyone know of mint candies or gum that are suitable for celiacs, I'm in Japan

One tip I want to mention for people traveling - learn some Japanese. My husband did the Pimsleur course for 6 weeks and did 6 private lessons in the lead up to our trip. He says about 4 weeks of Pimsleur and a single private lesson would have done the trick for the purpose of allergen eating. It has helped us be more confident in what we eat out because he's able to have full conversations about allergens with the staff. It has also significantly helped because during the lesson the teacher was able to say exactly what to expect with what people say and things to say to help them understand. 

Of course Google translate can work but the translations are not great once you know Japanese even a bit ü´£ so more chances of miscommunication. 

Hope this helps someone!

ResponsesV2.Message: Even learning the hiragana and katakana can be extremely useful.
I have a trip coming in January. I‚Äôm using Duolingo, but I‚Äôm finding it difficult to learn Japanese.

ResponsesV2.Message: I go there a lot but I‚Äôve never eaten out in Iiyama. The Tsuruya supermarket in front of the station has GF bread (loaf, needs to be toasted) and some roll cake slices that are GF.

Title: Tried searching the group and google with no luck so hoping someone would be able to help üôè does anyone have any recommended cold&flu medicine that‚Äôs safe for coeliacs?

ResponsesV2.Message:
Have you been to a pharmacy here yet?? It‚Äôs quite the experience.
Maybe 
Try Amazon.co.jp for your favorite and you may get lucky with next day shipping. 
Otherwise I have only gotten a coughing ‚Äúpowder‚Äù and have no idea if it was GF. I was so miserable and can‚Äôt attest that it was a reaction or symptoms üò©

Title: If you‚Äôre in Osaka and looking for a great place for lunch then find your way to Comeconoco Gluten Free Laboratory and Cafe! I found it on ‚ÄòFind me Gluten Free‚Äô App. Yes EVERYTHING is gluten free! It‚Äôs only small and you can eat in or take away. Run by a delightful young woman who speaks excellent English. It was so lovely to sit down and with no need to communicate my dietary needs. Heaven ‚ù§Ô∏è

ResponsesV2.Message: It is indeed heaven. Probably one of my favorite gluten free cafes in the world and that includes really good ones in the US.
Yeah an absolutely wonderful place. Their cooking classes are also fantastic

Title:
Am I right in thinking this is the GF meal in Matsuya? 
#matsuya

ResponsesV2.Message:
Currently having this discussionü§£
From the searches I‚Äôve done in this group it seems to be safe, but I haven‚Äôt tried it yet.

If you are not coeliac and have no fear with cross-contamination (just main ingredient reactive like me as a gluten intolerant), this is okay. I'm Japan-based and I've eaten this many times with no problem. This and their Negitoro (mashed raw tuna) bowl are my go-to's in chains like Matsuya and Sukiya.

Title: Myself and many others have recommend the "Find Me Gluten Free" app. Does anyone use the paid version? I know you can look for dedicated GF places with the full version, but have noticed that a lot of dedicated GF places also come up in the free version (certainly here in Madrid).. Would appreciate some feedback. Many thanks in advance.

ResponsesV2.Message:
I use the paid version, and have done for about six months. I mostly paid for it because I felt I was getting so much from the service that I wanted to pay as almost a ‚Äúthank you‚Äù to the people behind it.

I have coeliac and I now use the ‚Äúmost coeliac friendly‚Äù filter which has been helpful. I don‚Äôt know about in Japan, but in my country it fundamentally shifts the order of recommendations and saves me a bit of time in filtering through them to find a safe option.

I pay for apps that are useful to me. It help support their development. One paid-only feature of FMGF that I use a lot is filtering by time. That is ‚Äúopen now‚Äù or ‚Äúopen at X:00‚Äù if I want a place that‚Äôs open late.

Title: We are on our way to Kyoto, staying in the Gion area. Has anyone found g/f bakeries making loaves of bread in Kyoto? Thank you!

ResponsesV2.Message: I have found Boulangerie L'oiseau bleu online but can‚Äôt vouch for it.

Title: Has anyone from Australia purchased any GF soy sauce/tamari sachets? Having trouble finding any that ship to Australia that aren't very expensive, and trying to prep for our upcoming trip. Thanks!

ResponsesV2.Message: I take a full bottle and fill some travel shampoo bottles from the chemist
I take a small bottle travelling with me... Like a 100 ml bottle

Title:
Universal Studios Japan (USJ) Kinopio Cafe Warning!

We are literally here, right now.  They changed their menu (I last checked in June).  They no longer have an allergy option at Kinopio Cafe, nor the Yoshi drinks (which were safe). üò≠

Presently, these are the only two options that do not include wheat, rye, barley, mizuame, or sesame. (I held up my card, but it does not mention cross contamination.) 

Since I added sesame, please ask them to verify if there are any other options you can eat.

(I'm asymptomatic celiac, so am being quite bad, and not mentioning cross contamination to anyone if it's not a dedicated GF establishment.)

ResponsesV2.Message: When I was there they were able to give me an allergen curry, did they offer this? It‚Äôs not themed but it hit the spot a bit better than a salad at the end of a long day
I am going there tomorrow. Thanks for the heads up!

Title:
Hi there! Just returned from a great 2 weeks in Japan,  and wanted to share some insights. I'm a severely reactive celiac that was diagnosed 32 years ago at the age of 2. Safe to say I'm pretty well versed in gluten freedom, so here's how I managed Japan! 

Notes up front:
- Eating gluten free in Japan isn't easy, but it's very possible. Use Google translate on EVERYTHING, do your research beforehand (what words to look out for, what people have already found out is safe, etc), and do not trust anyone without checking yourself or giving them a translated card about celiac. Celiac and gluten allergies are still pretty uncommon in Japan, and the understanding around gluten just doesn't really exist. Have patience and grace, and take care of yourself first and foremost. 
-The hardest part was the social aspect- I couldn't just walk around and find food with my friends. I had to plan my meals for the day, and sometimes just eat what I could. "Fed is best" was my mantra, and it helped a lot. 
- I used the Legal Nomads Celiac card (https://legalnomads.gumroad.com/l/GFJapan?layout=profile) and it was essential! It contains a researched translation of what Celiac and gluten are, what ingredients are not safe, and cross contamination details, and everyone responded to it with respect and care. 
- Find Me GF was really helpful, though I generally cross checked with this group to see what was actually good and went to the celiac-reccommended places. 
- Have a glutened-regimine! Accidents happen, and it's important that you have a plan if they do. I got glutened once, and only lost a day to the effects. I brought several things to help me: a probiotic, the gluten ease enzyme pill, turmeric, and fish oil. It helped me bounce back MUCH quicker than normal with manageable side effects that did not completely derail my trip.
- This group is SO HELPFUL. Search posts for what you need, someone has already shared it!

WHAT I ATE:
I'm someone that doesn't eat heavy breakfasts, so here's what I did-

BREAKFAST- 
I brought with me 2 weeks worth of Larabars, a jar of peanut butter, a loaf of GF bread, some crackers, soy sauce packets, and Bob's Red Mill instant GF oatmeal (no one bothered me about any of these at customs). I ate a larabar for breakfast, or grabbed Chobani yogurt from the 7-11 for breakfast (sometimes both). Having food on hand for breakfast saved me from having to find food first thing in the day. I usually went out for coffee, and had no problems as long as I stuck to milk and espresso (no flavorings). 

SNACKS/LUNCH-
I would generally plan 1 restaurant meal per day, either for lunch or dinner. That meant finding alternatives for the other meal. I generally preferred dinner out, bc it gave me more time to make other plans. 
I had a host of things I'd eat at the 7-11:
- salted rice balls
- pickled plum onigiri
- edamame
- deli meat (usually just the packaged ham) 
- cheese slices or triangles 
- Calbee potato sticks (blue package)
- Chip Star (red package only)
- microwavable rice meals, including rice and red beans or just plain rice packs. (Sometimes I'd add the meat and cheese to the heated rice packs, good calorie packed meal). 

I would also eat leftovers or takeout from the restaurant I went to the day before.

RESTAURANTS -
As mentioned, I'd usually try for 1 restaurant or eat out once per day. I rarely made reservations - I just didn't find that most of the places I was going needed it. Honestly, I couldn't really find places that even had reservations! Here's the places I tried:
#kyoto
-Gion Soy Milk Ramen (absolutely delicious) https://www.findmeglutenfree.com/biz/uno-yukiko/5561510661849088
-Sugarhill Kyoto (good hearty meal) https://www.findmeglutenfree.com/biz/sugarhill/6625188896702464
-Nishiki market- not a specific place, but I handed my Celiac card to a couple vendors and got amazing wafyu beef sticks, just salted. Couldn't find the mochi place some people in the group talked about. 
- Toshoan (really good, but not really a meal- bakery with small pancakes and baked goods, and all sweet, not savory). 
https://www.findmeglutenfree.com/biz/toshoan/4862767015264256
#hiroshima
- Cafe Ponte (great Italian food, had the risotto and gelato) https://www.findmeglutenfree.com/biz/cafe-ponte/4676846459944960
#Osaka
- OKO Fun Okonomiyaki (hilarious experience, really tasty food. Not everything is GF but most is. Takes a lot of time- run by ONE person who takes orders, cooks, etc)
https://www.findmeglutenfree.com/biz/oko-fun-okonomiyaki-bar/6416950664757248
#Tokyo
- Gluten Free T's (definitely worth the hype, absolutely delicious) https://www.findmeglutenfree.com/biz/gluten-free-ts-kitchen/5152886006480896
- Moyan Curry (literally next to our hotel, and some of the best and filling food I had) https://www.findmeglutenfree.com/biz/moyan-curry/5882937810223104
-RICEHACK bakery (delish pizza, wonderful baked goods, and absolutely worth it) https://www.findmeglutenfree.com/biz/ricehack-onden-house/5242488937906176
- Plus One - the cafe next to RICE HACK, had a blueberry banana smoothie that was delicious. they don't really have food anymore or GF food.
- GF Soba Noodle class- this was a private cooking class that my husband and I took that was completely GF and amazing! Ended up eating a lot! https://soba.specialist.co.jp/sobaclass.html#sobaclass 

WHERE I STAYED:
Kyoto- Airbnb- it was nice to have a kitchen, but not essential. More essential to have a microwave honestly - we were out so much, that cooking meals wasn't something I had energy for. 

Nikko- Honke Bankyu Ryokan- this was a pleasant surprise! I didn't think I'd get to experience the kaiseki meals here, because despite their allergen notice in their website, they responded to our emails saying they couldn't change their food or seasonings. On the first night, I gave the server my Celiac card, and they prepared special meals for me every meal after! They were hearty and delicious. https://www.bankyu.co.jp/

Tokyo - Hotel Gracery Shinjuku- I didn't bother with the breakfast at the hotel, but the accommodations were lovely and I had a fridge and kettle in my room. http://gracery.com/shinjuku/

I've included some pics for reference, but feel free to comment any questions! Cheers!

Tonight, I had a great dinner at My B√°nh M√¨ by Gluten Free TOKYO. „Éû„Ç§„Éê„Ç§„É≥„Éü„Éºby„Ç∞„É´„ÉÜ„É≥„Éï„É™„Éº„Éà„Éº„Ç≠„Éß„Éº
While I was worried based on the webpage that it wouldn‚Äôt be celiac-safe and only ‚Äòwheat-free‚Äô, the owner is extremely knowledge about gluten intolerance and celiac. 

(Just be cautious if you have a nut allergy!)

ResponsesV2.Message: John looks quite astonished by his drink.
Looks delicious and love your drinking partner.  üòâ

Title: For those of you who have enjoyed a visit to Rice Hack, Tokyo would you be so kind to answer some questions. What types of bread can you find there? Would we be able to eat lunch there? What types of lunch food do they have? Do you think if we arrived shortly after they open at 11 am we could get a seat (if seating is available?) Thank you so much!

ResponsesV2.Message:
We were there a few days ago, around 1:30pm and it was definitely worth it!! We had the sausage roll, cinnamon scrolls and made to order pizza! It was all absolutely delish! 

The little cafe next door has a partnership with Rice Hack, you can eat there if you order drinks. The cafe menu also has gluten free items marked. The banana and blueberry smoothie and the coffee was delish!!

To the other comments: I was just there a couple of weeks ago and they have an agreement with the cafe next door and you can sit there, you might need to buy a drink though I can‚Äôt remember (only 3/4 of us bought a drink so I don‚Äôt think it‚Äôs mandatory for everyone, they have really nice coffee though and are very friendly). Definitely more options earlier in the day but they have pizza to order, baguettes (buy more than one, you won‚Äôt regret it), pork buns (more like a pork filled bread bun?), sometimes sausage roll type things (which are delicious), cube bread, and muffins. They‚Äôre super nice there too üôÇ

Title: On my way to Tokyo in December I have a stopover in Beijing T3. Would anyone happen to know of any places to eat in T3? I'll have food brought from Spain on the outward trip and I intend to try to stock up at Ricehack and Konbini before flying back, but just in case... Thanks in advance.

I‚Äôm planning to visit Japan for 2 weeks in December.

I‚Äôm a sensitive celiac who gets very sick within 30 minutes of having gluten, so I am very careful and rarely take risks, but I do eat out and try to order as safely as possible. I‚Äôve had celiac for 15 years and am sooooo careful.

That being said‚Ä¶I spent a month in Korea last year and I realized that on several occasions I accidentally ate soy sauce (which is almost impossible to avoid 100%). The strange thing is‚Ä¶.I never got sick once in my month there! The first time I realized I accidentally had it, I had a panic attack for hours waiting to be super sick.

I spoke with a friend I met there, who is also celiac and Korean and a researcher in the medical field (this is not her field and she is not claiming fact), and her opinion is that the fermentation process reduces the gluten making it gluten-free, but because testing is only done before the fermentation process (unlike on distilled liquors), soy sauce will never be listed as GF. She said she is also sensitive and has never been sick from soy sauce. 

**Please not that this is not fact, just what I was told. Please don‚Äôt take this as advice**

Foolishly, I tested this one meal, and dumped this ginger soy sauce side (probably about a 1/4 cup full) into a soup I was eating. This was extremely risky, but I ate it all without issue and never got sick.

Since I‚Äôve been back in the States, I am very careful with soy sauce, eating gluten-free soy sauce, but once in a while‚Ä¶if I‚Äôm out at Korean BBQ, I‚Äôm pretty sure it‚Äôs in some of the sides and again I‚Äôve eaten and not gotten sick.

***So my question is‚Ä¶..has anyone with celiac eaten the soy sauce (and not asked for GF) in Japan without issue? ***

Please know that I don‚Äôt take risks‚Ä¶.in Europe, I don‚Äôt eat the bread because people say ‚Äúwheat in Europe is safer‚Äù. I don‚Äôt believe that at all, and I am super careful. I don‚Äôt even let others bake for me because I don‚Äôt trust anyone else with cross-contamination.

However, I will definitely be bringing GF soy sauce packets with me.

ResponsesV2.Message: I have found peer reviewed experiments on this because like you my son ate real soy sauce and didn't get ill. As a scientist I had to deep dive on why since he is usually very sensitive. This paper explains that some soy sauces with wheat test gluten free due to the fermentation process. https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0362028X22100803

Hi there, if you are interested you can find clinical studies that relate to testing of soy sauce for gluten.  The one I found showed that gluten was undetectable in many soy sauces but always make your own choices https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0362028X22100803

Title:
Going to contribute info over the next few weeks! This group has been so important in my planning ‚ù§Ô∏è

I've been living on lots of convenience store food, especially for breakfast since not much is open. I'll picture stuff I got. I am not diagnosed celiac, but eat GF for autoimmunity and generally have symptoms of bloating and brain fog when consuming gluten - but have not experienced it here thus far. Also DF generally. Almost all things listed are df. 

I'll add in pics of my various breakfast and one dinner haul so far of what I believe has all been GF. I focus a lot on protein. The chicken sausage looking things and salted soft boiled eggs have been surprisingly satisfying. The miso soup was actually pretty yummy too. 

Tokyo - Matsuya - had their allergen beef bowl (only one gf). Def not impressed but the beef was good. I didn't have sauce with it and it just wasn't very exciting. We got it for the quick convenience. No pic.

Asakusa shopping district, found 2 yummy desserts. Second one was better (the tiny balls from pink paper bakery on the corner on the main street with matcha)

Tokyo - Otaco Bakery - AMAZING gf dessert bread. I have tried a lot all over in USA and have never had one this fluffy. Not all are DF, so ask. 

Tokyo - Kura sushi - we eat here back home in USA and wow the Japan one is so much better! Very unique dishes and they have an allergen guide on their site and in general most nigiri is GF. Def a must go even if you have one where you live. Honestly we might go again. 

Tokyo - Kirby Cafe - they clearly mark GF, just the caprese and curry. I don't usually like curry but I thought it was delicious. There's also a yummy drink with jelly balls I got. 

Tokyo - Gonpachi in Asakusa - GF dedicated menu. Everything we had was super delicious. Beautiful view on the 2nd floor. We had a 5:30 reservation and got 2nd floor no problem. 

Shinjuku Station had these little fish sausage like things. Actually way better than I expected, would buy again. It was across from Becks Coffee. 

Kawaguchiko - Shaw's Sushi - ate here twice and lived on convenience store food the rest of the time. Delicious sushi with local salmon. You have to get there at opening or a little before to get in line as they sell out quick. I did a tunal bowl for lunch (only thing not sold out, and it was actually pretty good even though I don't usually like tuna) and a salmon bowl for dinner (the one I wanted for lunch!). It comes with salad (lunch had 2 salads), a little dessert (yuzu warabimochi I think), and miso soup. The chicken teriyaki is not GF. I also had gf tempura and GF fried octopus. The tempura was super yummy. 

There are a lot more convenience store options I think but milk protein is added to a lot so I avoid.

ResponsesV2.Message: Thank you for all this detail and pics. Makes it all feel achievable. I‚Äôve got a fussy, Coelaic 7 year old to feed. Thankfully she loves salmon sashimi and rice so assume we will live on that. I‚Äôm Coelaic too and can‚Äôt wait to try some of your recommendations.
KaTua Sihanatkathakul, please

Title:
Hello everyone!

I just got back from an incredible trip to Japan and South Korea. My boyfriend and I spent a total of 8 days in Japan (Tokyo, Kyoto, and Osaka) and loved every minute of it. 

I was very nervous since this was my first time traveling abroad after being diagnosed w/ celiac ~5 years ago and I had heard that Japan was not gf friendly. However, I ended up having some of the best food of my life on this trip! I am a symptomatic celiac and would 100% know if I had been glutened...and I didn't get sick! This  group, as well as the Find me Gluten Free app (my holy bible), absolutely saved me. I also brought an allergy card for celiac translated into Japanese that I purchased from the Equal Eats website (https://equaleats.com/). This is the #1 thing I recommend doing (...if you don't speak Japanese). Seriously SO helpful to show at restaurants/street food vendors. I bought the downloadable version and had them printed at fedex (much cheaper then ordering the shipping version). 

I did LOTS of research before the trip and made an extensive google map w/ pins marking everywhere that I could eat, which was very helpful. I was traveling with my boyfriend who is not gluten free, and he loved all the restaurants we visited!! Also something to note is that we are young travelers and were definitely on the budget tour. I feel that all the spots listed below are budget-friendly, besides Kushiage Su. 

Here's where we went in Japan... hope this is helpful! :) 

**TOKYO** 

**Shimbu Sakiya Ramen (Shibuya) **

2 Chome-10-3 Dogenzaka, Shibuya City, Tokyo 150-0043, Japan
* Easy to order outside on the machine, gf options are marked
* Got the pork & fried chicken spicy miso ramen. Delicious. 

**Gluten Free Kushiage Su (Ginza)**

Japan, „Äí104-0061 Tokyo, Chuo City, Ginza, 8 Chome‚àí15‚àí2 „Éë„Éº„ÇØ„Éì„É´ 2Èöé
* Such an incredible experience. I made a reservation through the link on their instagram and dinner ended up  being just me and my boyfriend! 
* 13 course set menu with appetizers, deep fried skewers, and a dessert. Food was insane. This would probably be a $300+ per person set menu in the US, so we felt the price was amazing for the food & service you get. This was definitely the fanciest meal we had on our trip.  
* The chef speaks very minimal english so we used google translate to communicate 

**Rizlabo Kitchen (Shibuya)**

4 Chome-15-2 Jingumae, Shibuya City, Tokyo 150-0001, Japan
* Great spot for GF fluffy pancakes. Got the strawberry ones and they were amazing.
* We got there ~15 mins after it opened and there was a pretty long wait 
* Also in a very chic neighborhood. We had fun exploring the area! 

**Nabezo Shinjuku Sanchome Store (Shinjuku)**

Japan, „Äí160-0022 Tokyo, Shinjuku City, Shinjuku, 3 Chome‚àí30‚àí11, Takano2, 8F
* Shabu shabu restaurant w/ one gf broth option
* Our waitress was absolutely amazing and brought over tamari and physically walked me through the entire buffet pointing out what I could & couldn't eat! 

**Tsukiji Outer Market**
* Street food was generally hard throughout the trip, as expected. Painful watching my boyfriend eat everything but Tsukiji market is definitely worth the visit. It was awesome. 
* What I did eat: lotsss of sashimi (brought my own tamari packets) and fresh fruit as well as the sugar-coated fruit!

**Gluten Free T's Kitchen (Roppongi) **

7 Chome-8-5-2F Roppongi, Minato City, Tokyo 106-0032, Japan 
* Everything is gluten free. We got the fried chicken, pork gyoza, french fries, and chicken yakisoba. Yum!

**Moyankare (Moyan Curry) (Shinjuku)**

Japan, „Äí160-0021 Tokyo, Shinjuku City, Kabukicho, 1 Chome‚àí12‚àí5, Cherry Bld., 1F
* Showed the employee my celiac card and he pointed on which curries I could have. Got the ratatouille curry (which was just a veggie curry) and added a soft boiled egg. Super delicious
* I LOVE spicy food and got a 5 on the spice scale (1-10) and it was superrrr spicy. Fair warning!

**Otsuna Sushi (Roppongi)**

Japan, „Äí106-0032 Tokyo, Minato City, Roppongi, 7 Chome‚àí14‚àí4 „É¨„É†ÂÖ≠Êú¨Êú®„Éì„É´ ÔºëF
* We went for the lunch special (amazing deal) at around 1pm but it was sold out so we went back the next day at 11am and boy was it worth it
* Seriously insane sushi. Couldn't recommend enough. They brought over gf soy sauce and substituted a few non-gf nigiri in the 10-piece lunch special for gf options 

**Gonpachi (Asakusa) **

Japan, „Äí111-0034 Tokyo, Taito City, Kaminarimon, 2 Chome‚àí1‚àí15 ÔºëÔº¶ÔºíÔº¶ ‰∏≠Â∑ù„Éì„É´
* Super cool restaurant w/ a separate gf menu. Got a variety of grilled skewers & shrimp tempura. They asked me if they needed to change the frying oil! 
* A bit on the pricier side for us but very worth it

Other Tokyo spots I had marked but didn't get to visit:
* Soranoiro Nippon (ramen)
* Breizh Caf√© & Cr√™perie (crepes)
* Ricehack (bakery)
* Teppan Baby (okonomiyaki)

**KYOTO** 

**Kyoto Engine Ramen **

580-2 Nakanocho, Nakagyo Ward, Kyoto, 604-8042, Japan
* Got the spicy miso chicken ramen w/ gf noodles and it was incredible. Best ramen I had on the trip 
* VERY busy & very touristy so expect a wait. Also it was on the pricer side for ramen 

**Loco Chicken **

Japan, „Äí600-8018 Kyoto, Shimogyo Ward, Ichinocho, 253-1 Ê≤≥ÂéüÁî∫‰ºöÈ§® 101
* Recommended to us by a fellow celiac traveler who we met at engine ramen. Very small fried chicken restaurant that uses rice flour
* So good! Everything is gf besides the buns used for the chicken sandwiches and some of the sauces. Menu is labeled w/ gf options 

**Kikyo Sushi **

Japan, „Äí604-0071 Kyoto, Nakagyo Ward, Daimonjicho, Ê≤πÂ∞èË∑ØÈÄö‰∏∏Â§™Áî∫‰∏ã„Çã43-2 Â§ßÊñáÂ≠óÁî∫43
* We made a reservation here and were super glad we did bc it was very busy 
* Best sushi we had on the trip hands down. Probably the best sushi I've ever had in my life
* They have gf soy sauce & a menu page explaining whats gf. I got one of their nigiri & roll sets and they substituted non-gf nigiri for whatever I wanted!

Other Kyoto spots I had marked but didn't get to visit:
* 10 Soba (soba)
* Gion Soy Milk Ramen (ramen)
* Waco Crepes (crepes) 
* Sugarhill Kyoto (Japanese fusion)

**OSAKA** 

**Genji Soba **

4 Chome-5-8 Nanba, Chuo Ward, Osaka, 542-0076, Japan
* Super cute small soba restaurant with an option for 100% buckwheat noodles 
* Got the set w/ cold soba & tempura which they boil/fry separately. My part of the meal was pretty expensive (...but definitely worth it)

**Oko - Fun Okonomiyaki Bar **

1 Chome-15-24 Higashishinsaibashi, Chuo Ward, Osaka, 542-0083, Japan
* We got there at 5:40pm (it opens at 6) and were glad we did bc there was a long wait after us 
* So many gf options and the food was amazing! We also loved the DIY bar set-up. Very fun spot. 

Osaka spots I didn't make it to:
* Comeconoco (cafe w/ gf rice bread)
* Caf√© Morning Box (cafe)

SNACKS/OTHER STUFF
* What I would get from 7/11/Lawson/Family Mart - salted salmon onigiri, packaged fruit (grapes, bananas, oranges), soyjoy bars, juice, plain pudding 
* Mos Burger - got the hot dog from the allergen menu once. Good safe option if nothing else is around but wouldn't go out of my way for it 
* Alcohol - I drank rice sake & lots of kinds of soju 
* GF soy sauce - I brought individual packets of tamari and was very happy I did! Here are the ones I got on amazon: https://www.amazon.com/dp/B06XS2P1XG?psc=1&ref=ppx_yo2ov_dt_b_product_details
* Sushi conveyer belts - we really wanted to try one of these and we ended up going to a Sushiro while in Tokyo. I showed an employee my celiac card and she brought it to the kitchen, then a chef came out and told me what I could/couldn't eat. There was a bit of a language barrier, but he told me the vinegar was gluten free, even though I'm not sure he 100% understood what I was asking. We ended up eating at Sushiro twice and I had no reaction at all and it was super fun! I just did not include it above bc I can't guarantee that sushiro in general is safe since it's such a big chain.

ResponsesV2.Message: Are you able to tell me what you ate in Korea and where? My bf has celiac and we were supposed to go to Japan with others but ended up deciding to go to Korea instead with the group. I also joined a gf Korea group as well but would love your insight of eating in Korea as someone who has celiac!
This is SO helpful! Thank you so much for sharing! I feel so much more confident about traveling to Japan because of people like you! The food looks INCREDIBLE!

Title:
Just a heads-up/caution for planning and certain restaurants that were recommended on this group.  I contacted them for reservations during the time period each restaurant specified.  Here is my experience. For obvious reasons, we will not be eating at 2 of them. üò≠ 

 
#kyoto Teppan Tavern Tenamonya [GF ONLY at 5pm; states do NOT contact them for reservations before 12:01am, 15 days before your intended date]:  I emailed them for a reservation at 6am Japan time.  They were already booked solid.  If you want to eat here, you MUST email them at 12:01am Japan time exactly 15 days before you want to eat there.

#takayama Sakurajaya [I called to make reservations, asked in Japanese, "Do you speak English?" and he did!]  Sakurajaya does NOT serve lunch to foreigners, and would not take a reservation for 1pm.  ONLY dinner reservations (6pm-10pm).  I do not know if you were to physically walk up to his restaurant for lunch (11:30am-2pm) if he would turn you away or serve you.

#takayama Heianraku: I emailed for these reservations. The one and only time I decided to ask any Japanese restaurant [prior to arriving in Japan] if they could avoid my other allergens (Sesame and Soy Protein [tofu, mizo]), and they turned me down with, "It is so difficult for us to provide food. Please look for another restaurant."  You're telling me, buddy! ü§£ So, I'm just going to have to bear it all throughout Japan because my Celiac Disease takes precedence over the other (minor) allergies.  I had our travelling companion (successfully) make the reservation since I share the same last name as my husband, and finding GF restaurants in Takayama is difficult...

ResponsesV2.Message:
Stacy Pena for Teppan Tavern, how long did it take them to reply back to your reservation submission? 
It‚Äôs been a few days since I submitted and still haven‚Äôt heard back from them. I followed all the instructions on the website and submitted two weeks in advance at 12:01 midnight Japan time.

We just went to heianraku tonight and they are incredibly knowledgable. I would be confident that they would try their best to avoid what they can for you (the GF will be no issue at all esp given this is your main allergy). Their local snack appetisers include tofu and mushroom with sesame on but I don‚Äôt see why individual main dishes should be an issue. 
The owners are a dietician and chemist and really up to date on allergens - they‚Äôve been doing it for 20 years! Would highly recommend ‚≠êÔ∏è

Title:
I'm about to end my 16-day Japan trip and wanted to pass along some advice to the group while my thoughts are fresh! 

First, this blog was my absolute godsend for planning places to eat: https://www.legalnomads.com/gluten-free/japan/

I would suggest looking up each place and adding it to your Google maps with a special color coded pin so when you're out and about you can pull up your map and see what's close by that you already know to be safe. 

Second, I searched "gluten free food near me" in Google maps countless times when there wasn't anything close by that I knew about and it worked really well! Found several gems that way. 

Third, using the info in the articles above, make a few reservations at GF restaurants so you know even on a rough day that you'll have a for sure good and safe meal coming up. This really helped preserve my sanity when I was frustrated by a lack of options.

Fourth, if you're traveling with people who aren't GF, it's ok to part ways for meals and go on your own lil GF adventure for an hour or two while they enjoy a meal at a place that you may not be able to safely eat. This was way better for me than awkwardly sitting at a place I couldn't eat and I kind of liked the opportunity to just roam on my own a bit, knowing I wasn't holding my husband back from enjoying places he wanted to try too. 

Fifth, bring some protein bars with you just in case. I got GF nut and chocolate bars from Costco that helped me when I was hungry to not make rash decisions. 

Lastly, and this may be obvious, but even if you think a food is safe, if the ingredients aren't listed, just ask. I got glutened once from vanilla soft serve of all things and it was awful. From then on, I asked about everything using a GF card in Japanese and everyone was super kind and thorough in making sure they gave me accurate information. 

I can honestly say I was able to try every type of traditional Japanese food I am aware of in a gluten free form and had some of the best meals I've ever had in Japan. It is totally doable, it just takes a little planning, so don't let being GF hold you back from some great foodie adventures! Enjoy!

ResponsesV2.Message: Ice cream is usually not safe here!
Thank-you makes me feel so much more positive about my upcoming trip !

I am travelling with 3 families and no one else is gluten and dairy free so will not have the luxury of travelling to all these suggested places mentioned. It is making me rather sad that I will not be able to enjoy all the food my friends will be eating . I will have to just really go where the group goes and hope for the best.
So my question is can someone direct me to some cue card or questions to ask in Japanese if they have any gluten or dairy free options . I am planning to take snacks and gluten free soy sauce with me from Australia.  I am staying near the sky tree so any supermarkets near by that offer GF products or restaurants that anyone knows about please let me know . Thankyou !

ResponsesV2.Message:
From what others have said I would not recommend this approach. Many have found it extremely difficult to find gluten free food from any ole place. 

I‚Äôm going next week and our whole itinerary is based around the restaurants where I can eat. We are going with another couple and I‚Äôve informed them about the difficult food situation. They are welcome to join me at the places where I can eat or go off on their own to eat what they would like. Thankfully my husband is very supportive of my dietary restrictions.

Highly recommend you contact Gluten Free Tours Japan to ask whether they can provide culinary support to you. Their services include talking in advance and in-the-moment with restaurants to explain your situation, understand the menu, and advise on what you can/cannot eat including what contains wheat/barley/rye (lactose and other allergens if needed) and when you are at risk of cross-contamination. They are very committed to their work and extremely competent and helpful.

Title:
Had some of the most delicious okonomiyaki last night at OKO Fun Okonomiyaki in #osaka! They can do gluten free, vegan, vegetarian, and dairy free! Better yet, I was able to have gluten free with meat! Most places I've found to be gluten free in Japan are also vegan, which is fine but can get a little old as a non-vegan looking for some solid protein, so this was huge! 

They're only open from 6pm-2am and there was a significant line, but it was so so worth it. You can grab a gluten free beer inside to sip while you wait, and there are stools to sit on outside so you don't have to stand waiting after walking all day. Super fun vibe and one of the more satisfying meals I've had in Japan so far! 

Note: They have gluten free mayo but not gluten free soy sauce, so you can get an oko with mayo, but not teriyaki for instance. Also, the vegan/gf gyoza are amazing.

ResponsesV2.Message: This was great when I visited early this year, and it looks like Oko has moved and upgraded the space from the old one. I can confirm it was worth the wait and she‚Äôs so friendly and accomodating

Title:
Hi all! I just spent 2 weeks in Japan (Tokyo & Osaka). I‚Äôm gluten free and dairy free and underestimated how hard it would be for me to eat in Japan! Very grateful for this group. Here‚Äôs my recommendations in hope they help someone else!

Tokyo:
- RICEHACK GLUTEN FREE BAKERY - Shibuya City - I got the baguette which I ate for the next couple of mornings with a 711 boiled egg. It‚Äôs delicious!
- MY BANH MI BY GLUTEN FREE - Harajuku - so good and fresh. I had the lemongrass Bahn mi. Highly recommend it!
- BREW PARLOUR 3615 - Chuo City - We had breakfast here 3 days in a row. The best gluten free and vegan pancakes! They also do gluten free and vegan lunch boxes which come with corn bread and rice. I bought the lunch box 3 times, so good! And they also have vending machine! So you can purchase when they‚Äôre not open.
- GLUTEN FREE T‚ÄôS - recommend booking in advance. Such a good menu for gluten free / vegan / vegetarians. I got the Okonomiyaki, the fried mustard chicken (fav dish!), cherry kombucha and cherry blossom cake. More pricey but really good! They‚Äôre also on Uber eats!
- MEU NOTA - Suginami City - really delicious vegan cafe. The staff don‚Äôt speak much English but they read my gluten free card and recommend the spicy coconut curry which was so yummy.
- CHAYA MACROBIOTICS - Monaro City - lots of vegan options and the staff were able to recommend a gluten free dish which was amazing! Also had a vegan / gluten free cheesecake. 

Osaka:
- FALAFEL SABARA - delicious! The falafel plate without the pita is gluten free. The owner speaks good English and is very kind and helpful. Vegan options too.
- TAQUERIA LA FONDA - best food I ate in all of Japan. Insanely good! Most of their tacos and their nachos are gluten free. Tacos come without dairy and I just asked for dairy to be left of the nachos. No vegan/vegetarian options though.
- OKO TAKIYAKI - Delicious okonomiyaki and lots of gluten free and vegan options. It‚Äôs a very popular place and we waited in line for maybe 45 minutes so I would recommend arriving as soon as they open and be willing to wait. The food is worth it! Also a note on location: they‚Äôve recently moved google maps will take you to the old location but there is a sign with the new address and it‚Äôs only a 3 min walk. 
- CAFE MORNING BOX - expensive but worth it, the best cakes I ate in Japan! Their gluten free banana bread with vegan butter is insane! And the Madeline and choc chip donut 

Other:
- Starbucks - we went to Starbucks almost everyday! They have a gluten free vegan banana muffin and their soy milk is delicious. I got soy milk tea lattes or soy matcha lattes.
- McDonald‚Äôs - when desperate I would get McDonalds fries and a side salad (no dressing)

Convenience Stores/Supermarkets go to‚Äôs:
- #1 favourite was the banana soy milk poppers! I also had the strawberry, matcha, and fig flavours (all good)
- Pomegranate juice
- Bananas
- Onigari (salmon, picked plum or salted rice) - always check the ingredients with google translate though as not all brands are gf
- Salted boiled eggs 

Other tips:
- If possible book accommodation with a small kitchen. Having a microwave/stovetop is so helpful. We boiled veges and cooked omelettes a lot too.
- if you search ‚Äúgluten free‚Äù on google maps you will be able to view places that other people have left reviews for mentioning gluten free options
- google translate and a gluten free travel card we‚Äôre saviours!

ResponsesV2.Message: Amazing, thank you so much for the detailed post. I‚Äôm headed there next month!!!
Thank you for your post, April! Do you know if in Starbucks they also have almond milk?

Title:
I was at my doctor today to get my usual prescription famotidine. The pharmacist told me they were having trouble sourcing it so the package was a little different because it was a different maker, but "it's exactly the same product." I said, "What about the inactive ingredients? I can't have gluten or PEG. They will make me sick." He found the ingredients and was looking at them. I asked for a printout. He said he can't print but he could take a picture on his phone and show it to me. First thing I see is È∫¶ËäΩÁ≥ñ (bakugato, barley malt) and I said "No, I can't have that." Oh, he says, gluten is È∫¶È°ûÔºü Just a moment.
So he went back and found that they had some unpackaged loose medicine from the former company (the one I take all the time). He asked if that was ok. I said yes and he said "I'll package them for you." I assumed I was getting a bottle or bag. No. He put each pill in a sealed bag like they use for powders.
And the moral is, educate your pharmacist and insist on checking everything yourself on anything new!

ResponsesV2.Message: Yeah they always baggie loose pills individually! I get my medication that way because they cut the pills in half - each ‚Äúhalf‚Äù is in its own vacuum sealed baggie üòÇ
I have to deal with that in the US too. I‚Äôm glad you caught that!!

Title:
Thought this information might be helpful. As I've seen someone commented that no food allowed to be brought in, which is incorrect. 

If you'd like to bring food through customs during your visit to Japan, you can contact the Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries and check with them if a particular food item is allowed to be brought in.
This is their reply to my enquiry
"Thank you for your inquiry.

(1) cheddar cheese
(2) ghee butter 

If these milk products are NOT used for commercial or business, AND are less than 10kg (other than those used for feed), these are NOT subject to animal quarantine.
For detail, please refer to following website and ask for animal quarantine service.
https://www.maff.go.jp/aqs/topix/dairy_products_en.html
http://www.maff.go.jp/aqs/english/attach/pdf/aqs_contact_list_en_ap.pdf

(ÔºìÔºâOlive oil is NOT subject to plant and animal quarantine.

(ÔºîÔºâbuckwheat
(ÔºïÔºâmillet

Regarding the Buckwheat and Millet, please obtain a Phytosanitary Certificate (PC) issued by the National Plant Protection Organization (NPPO) of New Zealand.
If you bring them as hand luggage, you need to present the PC and to have them inspected at the Plant Quarantine Counter at airports prior to customs clearance.
Please check the following website for further information.
http://www.pps.go.jp/english/trip/oversea/keitaihin.html"

So as you can see from their answer dairy is allowed. Raw buckwheat and millet require phytosanitary certificate that I won't bother obtaining. Instead I'm planning to bring toasted buckwheat groats. Also considering buckwheat and millet flakes to cook porridge.

Title:
Currently on my third visit to Japan. Not coeliac but highly reactive to gluten. Staying in Airbnb apartments or hostels with kitchens. I love the Japanese style of having small serves of fresh delicious foods at supermarkets, suitable for cooking/assembly in apartments with small fridges etc. Trying to make the most of that as we travel. 

For people in a similar situation, here are some examples of my GF experience in my first few days, just in case it helps:

- First day visit to a supermarket with my Google image translate app for a scoping of fresh foods in season and general GF options (early morning so I didn‚Äôt get in the way of other customers). Really enjoyed the process. Bought some GF soy sauce, coffee (with filter gadgets), milk, oil, honey, fruit and veg.
- A breakfast: Greek yoghurt, honey, banana, egg, cucumber.
- A lunch while roaming fish market and gardens in Kanazawa: sushi, inari, veggie sticks, coffee, yuzu drink, matcha icecream in a cup.
- A dinner cooked at our accomm using supermarket goodies: grilled ready-made unseasoned chicken and leek skewers, various delicious pickles from the fresh produce section (ginger, turnip, mushroom), microwavable rice, cucumber, ready made omelette, wine, chocolate.
- A dinner out at a local yakitori restaurant: various meat and vegetable yakitori with sides of daikon salad, pickles, okra with kimchi, and sake. Family Mart cr√®me caramel for dessert.

I hope that helps someone with similar allergies and tastes. I am lucky enough to be able to tolerate cross contamination, albeit with some symptoms. Can definitely recommend finding large supermarkets rather than relying on convenience stores.

Edit: Please note that some foods above have included soy sauce in their preparation, and are therefore not suitable for those with coeliac disease or other complete intolerance to soy sauce. I am fortunate enough to be able to tolerate small amounts, although a wheat cracker will send me to bed for a couple of days so I need to be hyper-vigilant in my own way.

ResponsesV2.Message: Thank you!
Thank you so much, the information was very helpfulüòäüòÅ

Hi All! 

Have a bit of a loaded question for anyone who has been a pregnant coeliac in Japan. 

For background, I was diagnosed 12 weeks ago and am still learning the ropes and overwhelmed üòÇ we had booked a trip to Japan in January prior to this and I am now beginning my research into where to eat‚Ä¶..To throw a spanner in the works, my husband and I have discussed expanding our family however I am nervous to be not only a new coeliac, in a foreign country unable to speak the language and also pregnant‚Ä¶.I feel it adds an enormous layer of difficulty to then not be able to eat rice that‚Äôs not fresh or undercooked eggs/meat. 

I guess I‚Äôm just looking for reassurance that if that were the case I would survive, or are we best to wait until the trip is done üòÇ

ResponsesV2.Message:
Hi, First of all, congrats ! :)

GF in Japan is double, but hard; needs preparation and organization to avoid starving and contamination, most of all in your situation.
On top of this i would avoid raw food.

I came back from a Japan trip in August, made a lot of preparing and safe choices, and a map of places to eat too.
If was a great experience, and a lot of work.

I link my post, feel free to check and/or ask.
https://m.facebook.com/groups/glutenfreeexpatsjapan/permalink/2467113590165851/

Japan has probably the highest food safety standards in the entire world, so there is very little chance of you being served rice or any other food which is not extremely fresh. This comes from a culture that has relied on raw fish for a long time, so all food has to be super fresh! Raw egg is usually only used as a dipping sauce for one or two specific dishes and you‚Äôll know that when you see it. And apparently their eggs don‚Äôt have the bacteria that we worry about in the West, which is why they can eat it raw. Meat will also be obvious if it‚Äôs raw. As long as you can show any waitress/waiter the word for ‚Äúpregnant‚Äù on your phone (using google translate), then they will take very good care of you. 

The gluten part may be harder, but they will also do their utmost to accommodate you there. I‚Äôd probably just stick to the places recommended on this page, or even use the Gluten Free Tours Japan company if you are pregnant by then and don‚Äôt want to take any risks with gluten at all.

Overall, people in the food industry in Japan have exceptionally high standards of food hygiene ‚Äî quite the opposite of the rest of Asia!! 

I hope you enjoy your trip. 
Cheers from a currently pregnant fellow Coeliac!  

PS My obstetrician said that the only risk if I got glutened during pregnancy would be if I let myself get dehydrated. Other than that, it wouldn‚Äôt harm the baby.

Title:
I went to Appi Kogen in Iwate Prefecture recently and stayed at the ANA Crowne Plaza Resort Appi Kogen. It‚Äôs a ski resort but it‚Äôs year round. I messaged the hotel using the contact form on their website before I traveled and explained my restrictions (celiac). 

They were amazing! They have several restaurants and although two of them have very little options, they told me the chef could prepare something special if I book in advance. I didn‚Äôt go with this option but it is available. 

I did the breakfast and dinner buffet. Everything is clearly marked with allergen info and chefs are on hand and can give more info. They are knowledgeable on cross contamination and even gave me a set of utensils (tongs etc.). 

At one point the chef walked round with me and pointed out all the food I could safely eat, and offered to make extra if I didn‚Äôt see enough of what I liked. He even made me my own fruit platter for dessert which was delicious.

I didn‚Äôt get sick and because the food was buffet I didn‚Äôt go hungry either! 

Location: 
https://maps.app.goo.gl/fxKT3xinsDcuiZRo9?g_st=ic

Website (has other language options):
https://www.appi.co.jp

#iwate #appikogen #resorthotel #hotel #skiresort #ruraljapan #buffet

Title:
Cook your own food in a restaurant!!!

Found this great little restaurant called ‚ÄúKAZU‚Äù in Skytree Oshiage Tokyo. It‚Äôs 5 mins walk from the train station exit A1. I showed them my translation card and they bought out plain meat/chicken and vegetables with no sauce just salt, pepper and shallots (I added my own gluten free soy sauce). There are hibachi‚Äôs on every table and you cook it yourself. They wash the grill after each use so cross contamination is prevented. I‚Äôm Coeliac asymptomatic but I think it‚Äôs very safe and yummy. 
You should try it but it‚Äôs a small restaurant and people are often lined up outside so enjoy

I thought I‚Äôd just let people know that in Tokushima, Shikoku,  the two Chu Chu Churros Cafes (which sell gluten free churros) were closed near Tokushima station when I was there (changed to more manufacturing/wholesale). There was a sign saying that the aeon mall Chu Chu Churros shop was open. So we walked the 10km round trip to fortunately discover they were indeed still open  üôÇ thank you so much to this group and all the information. It has been so useful for my trip planning. I am in Shikoku for two months and although I am not coeliac I can only eat very low gluten. I will do a summary post at the end of my trip of the restaurants/ konbini I went to in Shikoku üíï

Edit: one of the chu chu churros shop (the one right near the Tokushima station)  was actually open when we passed through Tokushima again the following week. I think the sign said opening hours 2pm - 6pm. Lucky for me as I got to try the chocolate flavoured churros this time it was delicious!

I scraped the 7-Eleven and Lawson websites to compile a list of every wheat- and dairy-free onigiri they have (Japan doesn't seem to have gluten listed as an official allergen, so barley, rye, etc. aren't flagged here). The point of this was to see which onigiri I can (FIRST CONFIRM IN PERSON THAT IT‚ÄôS GF and then) eat. I'm sad to report that pretty much any onigiri involving mayonnaise seems to have wheat (for some reason...). Unfortunate, because tuna mayo is life!

I'm not able to get information about Family Mart or Mini Stop onigiri online. Let me know if you can!

NOTE: THESE ARE LISTED AS WHEAT-FREE ON THE WEB, BUT SOME LOOK-A-LIKES MIGHT NOT BE (E.G. DIFFERENT PREPARATIONS OF ROE [711 SALMON ROE LISTED IS WITH SALT, NOT SOY SAUCE / KOJI]). ALWAYS BE SURE TO DOUBLE-CHECK INGREDIENTS IN-PERSON!

ResponsesV2.Message: My son is allergic to wheat and I was hoping he could have the tuna mayo one. It‚Äôs strange it contains wheat as many Japanese mayo brands don‚Äôt contain wheat. When I look at the tuna mayo onigiri, the outside packages is labeled with ‚Äúseasoned seaweed‚Äù sign, but the salmon one is not. Typically seasoned seaweed means they use soy sauce so I wonder if that‚Äôs where the wheat is‚Ä¶

At least some of the chains put soy sauce in the tuna mayo, but also only some kinds of Japanese mayo are gluten free. (unsure how to tell, just know at my local Japanese market some are marked gf and some aren't)

Title: At Milk Thistle Ramen in Gion Kyoto. You can google it easily to find. Food Gf and fab but watch this beer marked GF that has barley in it. It‚Äôs from Spain so I plan to contact them and ask about it.

ResponsesV2.Message: It's called Gion Soy Milk Ramen Uno Yokiko (rather than Milk Thistle Ramen in Gion Kyoto) and here's the details https://soymilkramen.com/ and map https://maps.app.goo.gl/oT7JSXGYFvuRKPyEA

Pin.Label: Gion Soy Milk Ramen Uno Yokiko
Pin.Address: Gion Soy Milk Ramen Uno Yokiko

ResponsesV2.Message:
The gluten in the barley is cleaved enzymatically and therefore broken down to a level of under 3 ppm which is considered gluten-free by most celiac societies.
However, if I remember correctly, there were some recent studies which showed that even the broken down gluten can still cause some reactions in some people with Celiac disease (I should check the original publication again, I'm not sure if I remember it correctly).
So basically I think there needs to be more research about this and until then you have to judge for yourself.

Japan doesn't have a huge eating-out breakfast culture in general, so there isn't much out there besides family restaurants where they don't list barley as an allergen on their nutrition info so you'd have to use your discretion. 

If you use the search function, I just searched "breakfast" and I just saw a bunch of suggestions for general breakfast ideas in Japan. That will be of help. Convenience stores might be the easiest, or buying something at supermarkets.

Title:
Hello! I just got back from Tokyo and wow, 4 fulls days isn‚Äôt not even close enough to dip your foot in to see the sights let alone the food options. I had several bad nights of food finding issues because of timing issues (the transportation takes forever!). I can confirm that the Ramen Museum does not have GF options. I learned this hard way and felt so silly because I had read the updated post on it wrong. Also, Soranoiro NIPPON does have GF ramen BUT they were out by the time we got there! üò≠ Thankfully at 9:30pm on both failed nights we found options (salad the one night and to go sushi the next). üò© I was so tired and hungry I failed to get the names of the restaurants. However, Gluten Free T‚Äôs and Umaimon Azuma were delicious! I bought the packaged GF ramen Gluten Free T‚Äôs sells too! I used the GF card app that another person posted about to eat at other locations and it worked so well. There are so many things I would do differently but being new to not only Tokyo but also being so rusty and green with public transportation made things a bit rocky at times. Also, the 1 day tour trip to Mt. Fuji was very challenging for food and I am glad I brought my own. I did eat the corn on the cob at the 5th station though and it was delicious! 

I went to Sankei Gardens and there are several little restaurants in it. I was able to find GF savory mochi at one of them. It wasn‚Äôt my favorite but I was able to eat. 

A couple of travel tips:
-don‚Äôt stay too far away from the things you want to see or you spend hours on the train/subway/buses (I didn‚Äôt have a choice as I was joining my husband ona work trip)
-buy the Welcome Suica card at the airport. You cannot get them anywhere else is my understanding and it was a game changer. My husband didn‚Äôt get one and he had to buy tickets ever time he used transportation. 
-have a plan B and C available. I looked for plan b and c but there were not options. I should have this through better. 
-if you can afford it, use Gluten Free Tours Japan. I wish I would have just spent the money and used them but I thought I could do it on my own. Rookie mistake. Things would have gone a lot smoother if I had. 

Disclaimer: I only have an intolerance due to IBS, not celiac. 

I hope this helps someone. Thank you for all the posts and assistance here!

ResponsesV2.Message: The Welcome Suica card is for transportation and yes, I think it is true you can't buy it anywhere but the airport (or possibly major stations.) They are trying to move residents from using physical cards and moving to phone apps for transportation cards. (Those of us who already have them can still use them.)
Thanks for sharing! What is the GF card app? I‚Äôm only hearing about this and feel like I will need this on my trip to Japan in November!

Title: My GF daughter & I are visiting Japan in 3 weeks to see my son who lives in Okinawa. We are also going to Kyoto for 3 days. I have just downloaded the ‚ÄòFind me Gluten Free‚Äô App. Is it worth getting the paid version? For those of you who have it are there many GF options in Okinawa? Thank you

ResponsesV2.Message: Find me GF app is really great in my opinion. Especially if you travel a lot.

Another great app (paid only) is Gluten Free Dude. It lists fewer places, because it is curated rather than crowdsourced. IOW the developer personally vets each listing, by calling and talking to owners to suss out their kitchen practices. So you can have higher confidence in the places that are listed. It‚Äôs especially great for traveling, because it has extensive listings for a huge number of airports. So, you can find the best option in the terminal of the airport you‚Äôre in.

Title: I am connecting through Narita airport. What is my best chance of GF food in the airport? I‚Äôll have about 2.5 hours to claim luggage, go thru customs, and check-in for a domestic flight.

ResponsesV2.Message:
Are you celiac or intolerant? 
I‚Äôm celiac and I could only eat from 7-11 (big long lines, though) 
If you‚Äôre intolerant and can tolerant cross contamination, the sushi restaurants label what allergens are in what pieces. They are way too small and will definitely cross contaminate so I wouldn‚Äôt recommend if you‚Äôre sensitive. But you can also bring in your own food (lawson before and 7-11 after security are there too) in carry on bags as long as it‚Äôs not big liquids. üôÇ 
Just got back home now from terminal 1

I just returned back through Narita on my way home yesterday. I can only speak for terminal 2, so if you are in terminal 1, I have no idea what‚Äôs over there.

After leaving terminal 2 customs, you can go up to the 4th floor where the ‚Äúmall‚Äù is, and there is a 7-11 at the very far right end (go all the way until you see the Pok√©mon Store at the dead end, then turn left). You can find safe onigiri, snacks, and drinks. There really aren‚Äôt any GF restaurants, but there are plenty of posts in the group about all the stuff you can get at 7-11 if you don‚Äôt already know what‚Äôs there.

If your domestic flight is with JAL, the JAL desk for rechecking bags and such is at the other end of the same floor you exit customs on, so if you have a bunch of bags, it‚Äôs best to check those first before going up to the 4th floor so your bags don‚Äôt slow you down. Again, I‚Äôm not sure about the other domestic airlines or terminals since I was traveling with AA and JAL which are both in terminal 2.

Title:
We just returned from our 4 day trip up to Hokkaido, September 9-12 with my (asymptomatic) Celiac kiddo. We stayed at Niseko Hilton based on some posts about Hilton's general GF knowledge compared to most here in Japan and expecting some of the restaurants in the Find Me Gluten Free app to be sufficient.

In the summer/off season, a lot of places aren't open, like Pirateman and Sanbarco (Sanbaraco? One spelling is in Niseko, though we never found it, the other, which has an IG account, is in Northern Honshu! Don't get confused as we did. lol). We were also turned away from an advised yakiniku restaurant saying they were fully booked, though we had the feeling that was not the reason they turned us away, 5 minutes after opening in a small-ish town in off season..... (unless they only half book in the summer? We drove by later and it was still quite open.).

We ate at the Taj Mahal Indian restaurant several times. There are several in the area, one is closed in off season. We ended up at the Kutchan location both times. My family loved it. My celiac had the briyani the first time with papad and butter chicken the second time. He is very sensitive to spices and both were very mild and worked well for him. Portions are quite large, though minimal chunks of chicken, far too much for my tiny 9 year old. My younger girls have no dietary restrictions and had the one option of a kids meal which is must smaller portions (my 5 yr old couldn't finish, but my 7 yr old did) but they DO have gluten (it's like a small amount of butter chicken chopped up, side of yellow rice, giant gluten buttered naan, fruit cup, OJ, and elephant toy - so you know in advance if you have a celiac kiddo and non celiac kiddo, be prepared to order a regular OJ and ask them ahead of time not to bring the toy. My son was ok, but we went twice so he ended up with the toy the second time since my daughters didn't need 2 elephants). 

We had breakfast every day at the Hilton and dinner 2 or 3 times. During the off season, only the buffet restaurant is open. At breakfast, there is an omelet station that is safe, plain yogurt with cut fruit, and a cheese and cut meat area, big rice maker of plain rice, steamed, plain potatoes and veggies, salad station, and then of course a random assortment of many other (mostly unsafe) things. I had included in our reservation that my son had celiacs and we would appreciate if any allergies could be noted. They had little allergy signs beside all the food and included gluten. I checked on several items (like cocoa rice krispies) and they seemed to all be accurately marked. Some items, while not gluten free, we could not chance as they were too closely beside gluten items (like the yogurt dry toppings had barley beside the pumpkin seeds and dried fruit, or the GF "sausage" was in the same container as the gluten "bacon", the tater tots were supposedly safe, though they were probably cooked in the same hot oil as the karaage). 

We did the buffet for him the first day, but that evening for dinner we asked the staff a question about gluten and our server brought over the restaurant manager. We had driven for almost 2 hours trying to find dinner out, before returning to attempt dinner at the hotel. Two hours wasted, we should have gone straight back! Yahata-san was amazing, I almost cried! She seemed very knowledgeable and asked if she could prepare his meal special. She brought so much food, I was astounded! They have gluten free soy sauce for such occasions, you can choose western or traditional Japanese style. I should have specified he has a small appetite and doesn't eat much vegetables, but I was so grateful, I didn't want to make any requests. They just keep sending more food. They did not bring sauce out for the rice, so we brought our own soy sauce packet (I am sure she would have brought some out for him had we asked, but I was nervous to request anything else), and my son has a deep love for white rice with soy sauce. lol There was salad, roasted vegetables, soup, a tasty steak sliced looking pork, fruit, and a dessert. It all looked good, but I think he would have been just fine with the rice and pork and dessert. Oh and gluten free buns that he LOVED! He loved coming to the restaurant every day so he could eat their buns. 

Yahata-san asked us when we expected to have breakfast the next day, and if she could prepare something for him. It was a hearty meal, again! More reminiscent of dinner, but quite tasty. There was some sauteed breakfast potatoes with veggies, tender salmon, and - gosh - I can't remember. A plate of fruit, and rice, and I think 2 bread rolls, because he was so excited about the bread. Maybe more. When we returned for dinner, the staff new us in advance. This time I kindly explained he eats only a little, and told them he loves the bread, rice, and meat. He had yakitori, rice, bread, and fruit. It was perfect! 

The staff was so kind, so friendly! It was such a relief. We tried using the little Japanese we have learned, and I think that helps, too (not for explaining purposes, they had great grasp of English, but for showing we appreciate them and their culture). There are also many conbini in the area. I had picked up bananas and onigiri, but they weren't needed. 

Side note on what we did as a family with a 9 yr old, 7 yr old, and 5 yr old. Hananazono river rafting (very tame - safe for 3 and up, you get a dry suit, though my girls were a bit small for them so they leaked and were quite wet by the end, my 7 yr old was quite cold by the end as the water is about 17 degrees this time of year, but still super enjoyable), Hanazono evening gondola up to the midway point to walk down the jellyfish looking mountain lights (it's short, but neat. Gondola is completely enclosed!), and drove up to North Safari Sapporo to feed a bunch of animals for a quick half day trip. We didn't eat up there, just snacks in the car and drove back for a late (3pm!) lunch back at Indian that day. If my kids were a little bigger, we would have loved the tree trekking!

ResponsesV2.Message: Thanks for your time writing this, much appreciated
#hokkaido #niseko

Title:
Dear all, any chance to (safely) eat yakiori in Omoide Yokocho (Tokyo)? Family with celiac daughter 14 yo 
Thanks üôèüèº

ResponsesV2.Message:
it's a hard bet. 
You can ask yakitori with only salt (yakitori shio dake), but you have to verify that the chicken has not already been seasoned in soy sauce (it will be darker even if raw, not seasoned is almost white).
I've eaten a few in markets but... it's hit or miss, and omoide yokocho is pretty... rough.
Torikizoku many locations all round Tokyo. No problem for me , non celiac but 100% gluten free.

Title:
THANK YOU so much to everyone for contributing to this page! My husband and I just got back from 2 weeks in Japan and got to enjoy some amazing food because of y‚Äôall. 

I‚Äôm celiac and nut free (I do eat coconut and can tolerate a little almond flour). Posting my favorite spots in each place we went.

Not pictured:
Gluten Free T‚Äôs
It‚Äôs an absolute must ‚Äî get the takoyaki and yakisoba! The takoyaki is incredible and was the only version I was able to find in Japan that was gluten free. The only reason I don‚Äôt have a pic is because we wolfed it down. 

Breakfast is not really a thing‚Äî most places don‚Äôt open before 11am. Recommend picking up some rice balls and coffee from 7/11! 

We also did the omakase dinner with Kushiage Su in Tokyo and it was nice but I can‚Äôt say I‚Äôd go out of my way to go again. The spot is hard to find and is basically a studio apartment that‚Äôs been converted into an intimate counter-service style restaurant. 

Lastly, have to give huge kudos to Ben Sojka for suggesting we take a day trip to Kinosaki. It‚Äôs a town with 7 onsens (hot springs) and is so beautiful and has the best gluten free dessert I had on the whole trip. We took the JR train using our rail pass. 

PS In terms of hotel/accommodation recommendations 10/10 would suggest Groove Hotel in Shinjuku, Tokyo. The location is perfect, comfiest bed I think I‚Äôve ever slept in, and lots of gf options nearby (including the restaurant and gelato spot in the hotel itself). Also the ryokan (Ryokan Watanabe) we stayed at in Miyajima was unbelievably amazing. Such a cool experience and the meals were incredible and all gluten free.

Title:
Hi guys! Are oats used frequently in Japan? Maybe not write in ingredients? Does anyone know about it?
I didn‚Äôt find any specific information about that .

ResponsesV2.Message:
I grow oats so feel pretty qualified to answer the question. üôÇ

Oats are sometimes used, granola had a moment awhile back; they will generally be listed as „Ç™„Éº„ÉÑÈ∫¶. I don‚Äôt know of any other ingredients they would be hidden in (the hidden gluten is generally barley - watch out for Ê∞¥„ÅÇ„ÇÅÔºåÈÖµÊØç„Ç®„Ç≠„ÇπÔºåand vinegar and mayonnaise).

We use oats in some of our products at my bakery, which are in shops nationwide, our homegrown oats (in some varieties of brownies) are not contaminated - we don‚Äôt grow barley, which is what generally cross contaminates non-GF oats in North America, and our rolled oats are certified GF oats from Canada.

Japan does not have GF labeling standards, only wheat allergen labels, so always, always, always check the ingredients for yourself.
I don‚Äôt think I‚Äôve ever seen oats used in anything here in four years.

Title:
#recipe #cheesecake

Really easy, sorta-kinda-cheesecake! I read this years ago in a Winnie-the-Pooh cookbook.

Combine equal parts of condensed milk and lemon juice, mix thoroughly and refrigerate! (or just eat it because it thickens pretty fast)

You probably will need to experiment with how much lemon tartness you want. I like mine really lemony.

You can sorinkle with nuts or seeds, or scoop onto a GF cookie or senbei if you want crunch. The original had you put the cheese (lemon and condensed milk mixture) on top of a Marie biscuit or digestive biscuit. I like mine just plain.

Not sure if this is helpful for anyone.

Title:
Hi everyone! I wanted to see whether anyone has had any negative experiences with this soy sauce?
Long story short: I've lived in Japan for a long time and have celiac disease. A friend of mine who also lives with celiac disease in Japan asked whether I've experienced any negative reactions from this soy sauce. I hadn't noticed before despite having it countless times, but after having some yesterday, I felt distinctly "glutened." Absolutely nothing else in my diet was different yesterday and I hadn't had this soy sauce in weeks. I hadn't put two and two together, but having heard a similar story from my friend, I am wondering whether this is in fact gluten free.
I've trusted this brand for a long time, but I'm wondering whether it's been contributing to my frequently not feeling well. Thanks in advance for your comments!

ResponsesV2.Message: I had no issue with it while there and I cooked often with it. I used it for bowls and sushi as well with no difficulty.
I‚Äôve used this brand for many years and never had a reaction.

Title:
Hi everyone!
Thanks to this group I was able to fully enjoy 15 beautiful days in Japan, so I want to share with you all the restaurants where I ate and how I was.
I am celiac and in all places I have always shown the Gluten Free Card.

KYOTO

OSAKA

Title: Hi, what are people‚Äôs thoughts on travel to Japan from the uk? I‚Äôm planning a trip next year and can‚Äôt decide who to book with and if it‚Äôs worth paying extra for a guide/organised tour or to just book everything myself. ResponsesV2.Message: Arrange your travel yourself. Group tours are not conducive to a good time food wise. Use the resources here to find good places to eat, or you have the option of hiring a service like Gluten Free Tours Japan to handle all the food arrangements for you while you‚Äôre in country. (That‚Äôs what I did). I had a great stress free time and got to have a bunch of food I never thought I‚Äôd be able to try.
I was thinking of booking a cruise so at least we could eat some of the time without too much hassle.

Title: How did everyone go with bringing over snacks from Australia or any experience with bringing packaged goods (rice cakes, gf muesli bars, gf soy sauce) to Japan? ResponsesV2.Message: I brought bread, snack bars, GF instant noodles, packed nuts, can food.... no issues

I just came back from my yearly trip back to the US. I always have multiple checked bags of (gf) food and have never been stopped in 14 years. I think the main things to avoid are pretty obvious like fresh produce or poorly packaged food. Products containing meat are also not allowed. I bring back bread, baking mixes, condiments, and snacks. I've also brought back plenty of packaged snacks in my carry-on for my daughter and haven't had issues.

Title:
Info on Kitade Tacos, Tokyo Station:

I ate there for lunch today and the staff told me that the full menu is not gluten free. I‚Äôm pretty sure every post I‚Äôve seen about Kitade Tacos at Tokyo Station has said that they are 100% GF so I thought I‚Äôd clarify.

When I spoke to the staff, they spoke perfect English and explained that certain items are pickled in a vinegar that contains malt. They were able to adapt items for me to be safe. They absolutely understood what gluten free means, and how to serve gluten free food safely, but if you‚Äôre sensitive to malt you need to specify that you‚Äôre ordering gluten free, rather than just assuming everything is safe.

Title:
TLDR: does speaking Japanese make it easier to eat at non-GF places?

Hi everyone! My partner, daughter (3 years old) and I will be visiting Japan for 2 weeks in early November. I lived in Japan for 2 years and have visited several times. It's like my second home, and I speak Japanese (I'm not bilingual, but know enough to get by easily). However, since I was last in Japan I've been diagnosed with a wheat allergy (not coeliac), so I have never experienced Japan with an allergy.  

I'm wondering, given I'm confident to communicate my allergy, will that make it easier? Or is the issue that Japanese restaurants just don't "get it" when it comes to wheat/gluten allergies? I've asked my Japanese friends, but as they don't have allergies themselves, they aren't sure what it will be like for me. Ideally I want to eat at "normal" places so that my partner and daughter don't miss out on all the usual food experiences (they have no allergies), rather than having to track down specific GF places.  Am I dreaming?

Are there any people in this group in a similar situation (i.e able to communicate their allergies /requirements in Japanese) who could share their experience with eating wheat free/GF? We'll be mostly in Osaka and Tokyo, and we want to eat Japanese food rather than western food, if that makes any difference. I hope my question makes sense!

ResponsesV2.Message: Hi Sarah! I‚Äôm sensitive wheat intolerant (and I suspect also gluten in general) and speak Japanese at a conversational level. My experience is that while wheat is an allergen (making it easy to decipher labels), wheat allergy here is uncommon and usually (at least sometimes) something thought of as children‚Äôs allergies you grow out of. So some Japanese do not know what condiments there are wheat in. I have tried at different occasions that I‚Äôve asked whether they used Â∞èÈ∫¶„ÄÅand they say no, but still serve something with soy sauce, ponzu or the like, or with a pre-made dressing thickened w wheat. So just be careful and use common sense if they say ‚Äòno wheat‚Äô but still use sauces.

Other folks with specifically wheat allergies will hopefully chime in, but for what it‚Äôs worth, in my experience a lot of the difficulty in explaining lies in the issue of hidden gluten, which is usually barley. Wheat is nearly always labeled, so you will find it easy to be accurately told whether or not a dish contains wheat. A lot of dishes though do contain wheat, whether as a thickener or in soy sauce. You‚Äôll definitely have more options than someone needing GF. 

That said - outside of specifically prepared allergy friendly meals, there will always be the risk of cross contamination. I am able to communicate just fine, but have been glutened in restaraunts by a stray breadcrumb, and by friends and family who just aren‚Äôt in the habit. Each person really does have to decide on their comfort with risk, and weigh the consequences for themselves - I get quite sick so I very rarely feel like it‚Äôs the worth the risk myself, but if it were a matter of just being uncomfortable for a day maybe I‚Äôd choose differently. Being able to communicate will help you reduce the risk and assess the risk but unless you stick to entirely wheat free places or places with allergy protocols you won‚Äôt be able to eliminate it.

Title: Hi guys! Are these safe? Thank you!

Hi guys 

I‚Äôve heard some tea isn‚Äôt GF in Japan. 

Are coeliacs safe doing a tea ceremony experience?

Can anyone recommend on in Osaka?

ResponsesV2.Message: Mugi-cha, barley tea is obviously not safe. True matcha should be fine. That is what a tea ceremony place should use. But always ask! Today I saw a matcha truck at a shopping center. They had various matcha snacks and drinks. I only wanted a straight match ice drink (bascially, matcha/water.) So I asked if it was just matcha and water and she said yes, oh and sugar. Sugar? Why? But I could not get it without sugar so I realized it was some sort of blended powder. Not the real deal. Anyway, I walked away disappointed....

Piggybacking on this post [thank you, Mark!], in restaurants, how do we ask for safe tea?  What is the name of the safe tea?

Learning Japanese, I was taught to order, "ocha wo kudasai," and that it meant "green tea."  But, in a previous post, someone commented barley tea might be the default served. I'm just trying to figure out what to specifically ask for so that there is no confusion with the wait staff.

I usually make German curry carrot soup hot in the winter, but today I made it in the morning so we could have it cold tonight. It was delicious! I'll put the #recipe link in the comments. 

We had it with Rose brand sausages from Costco, salad, and a Nipponham brand frozen GF bread roll (from Aeon) that I made into garlic toast.

ResponsesV2.Message: I thought I had the soup recipe on my blog but unfortunately I don't. You chop carrots, saute in butter or margarine, add a bit of sugar, flour, curry powder, chicken or beef bouillon, then simmer, then add salt, and I add a bit of soy yogurt and cooking sake then blend after the carrots are soft.

Title: Hi all. I stayed in Kamikochi at Nishi Ito ya for the night and they created an absolute feast of gluten free food (I'm also lactose and dairy free and they accommodated that too). #Osaka #Miyajima #Hiroshima

https://goo.gl/maps/4rT1vGpHLVDoCUea7

Soba noodle shop, a few step from Namba.

Cheap.

-

No reservation, cheap

Many GF options, loved the enchiladas

Okonomiyaki, hiroshima style
