Also Caesar salad (we use once upon a chef recipe online for dressing), with air fryer chicken or salmon. 

Beef stir fry with broccoli and a sort of slap dash yakiniku sauce with mirin, sesame, soy etc. 

Crustless quiche I used to make a lot in the uk, but think it‚Äôs harder to find quark here so think I‚Äôm going to make like a Spanish frittata with sweet potato instead. 

Jacket potato in the air fryer with tuna mayo 

This week we‚Äôre also going to try making gf sweetcorn fritters

Nibuta- simmered pork and eggs- my very simple/careless version is roughly equal parts soy sauce, mirin, water, enough to cover a chunk of unsliced pork and as many hard boiled eggs as fit in a single layer in your pan. Cover, and simmer until the prom is cooked through. I‚Äôm pretty sure onions and ginger improve things, but I have a picky kid so we make the simple version. 

Also on the menu this week, tomato chicken rice (no recipe, saut√© onions and chicken, add a can tomato, some salt, the water you‚Äôd need for the rice and cook in the rice cooker or instant pot). 

Chicken cream stew, onions and whatever veggies and chicken saut√©ed, cook in enough water to cover, add some salt, when it‚Äôs cooked through add roughly the same amount of milk/soy milk as you did water, and a few tablespoons of rice flour mixed with the milk, simmer gently until thickened. You can get fancy and do a proper white sauce roux and add that, but the cheaters version works too. Leftovers mix into either cooked rice or pasta and are topped with cheese for an easy microwaveable gratin the next day. 

Sanshokudon - rice topped with scrambled eggs, greens, and mince meat cooked up with mirin and soy sauce (saut√© the meat first, add the mirin if it starts to stick, save the soy sauce ‚Äòtil it‚Äôs nearly cooked so as not to scorch it)

Also on the menu is Thai curry - coconut milk and curry paste are at import and pro kitchen shops in my area

Title:
#recipe
Summer vegetable soup (cold ok)

Boil chopped carrots and frozen broccoli in enough water to make a soup. Salt, pepper, turmeric or other seasonings to taste. When the vegetables become soft, use a blender and make them into a paste. Add a block of silken tofu and blend in. This can be eaten cold or hot and you can add other vegetables. I like to add kabocha, but I didn't have any, and the carrots and broccoli were fine on their own.

I don't put potato in my cooking because I'm sensitive to it too, but adding a potato would make a good texture.

#recipe

I have recently discovered that baby senbei make good replacement for crushed crackers in meatball or meatloaf things. If you didn‚Äôt put enough in and it‚Äôs still goopy, you can add a bit of cornstarch.

Title:
#Kuroboshi #churros has a new location in #Asakusa near #Sensoji. They make their sweets from rice flour. As I was suspicious of the strawberry frosting, I used my NIMA Sensor to test mine and it came up gluten-free!  
Sorry for the photos. In the bright sun, my phone would photograph either my #nimasensor screen or the churros, not both at once! 

Note: There is no seating, it‚Äôs just a food stand in front of a separate restaurant that isn‚Äôt listed on Google Maps, it seems. 
PQ7V+7H4 Taito City, Tokyo

Check the website for their other locations. 
https://www.kuroboshi-nasu.com

üö®(PLEASE NOTE: I understand that the NIMA Sensor is very controversial within the celiac community. I‚Äôm using the NIMA sensor as just another tool in my arsenal to keep myself safe from sickness and harm. I‚Äôm well aware of its limitations with detecting gluten in fermented foods such as soy sauce. But since it is expensive BUT could be helpful to others, I‚Äôm sharing results here so that other people can have access to the information. You don‚Äôt have to trust the results I post. What food one chooses to eat, what risks to take, are deeply personal decisions. Always do what‚Äôs best for you. 

NIMA Sensors can only test a pea-sized portion of food, not an entire dish, so cross contamination is still possible. Use of a NIMA Sensor is not a replacement for reading food labels, asking questions, or being cautious and diligent. 

With all that said, please understand that because I‚Äôm very sensitive to gluten, I research every single thing that I eat. I only post ‚ú®safe‚ú®test results on foods that I have consumed myself with zero reaction. Thank you for your time and have a great day!)üö®

ResponsesV2.Message: The place was a little hard to find but it was super tasty! The matcha one was really good üòç
Thank you for sharing ü•∞

Title:
Time to play the "Labelled as Gluten Free but actually not" game!

So I grabbed these, the Bio-Ral Gluten Free Cookies, in chocolate, plain, and houjicha versions recently - foolishly without looking at the back of the packet.

Sure enough, an hour after eating and I feel decidedly Not Good - closer inspection of the packaging shows that this is a case of 'all ingredients are technically GF, but everything is produced and packaged in a factory containing gluten/wheat' ü§¶‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è

So yep, everyone should avoid these. And now it's time for me to drink a bunch of water and lie down!

ResponsesV2.Message: Usually we don't have any problem with shared facilities... Good to know that this company maybe isn't so careful.
On the packaging there is written ‚Äúgluten free‚Äù, it is very alarming if it is not true (even in risk of contamination)
